column2: FEW plants are so completely fascinating and easy to grow indoors as are the cactus and cactuslike succulents. For, unlike many foliage plants, cactus hrive in the dry, heated atmosphere of homes and apartments.
Since they were first opened in 1843, Tivoli Gardens in Copenhagen have intrigued millions of natives and travelers, including Robert Moses.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Aug. 20 -- The United States-dominated space congress ended here today in an atmosphere tinged with disappointment.
RALEIGH, N.C., Aug. 20 -- The success of Vice President Nixon's first campaign appearance in the South has raised a cloud of doubt over Democratic hopes in the region.

WENDOVER, Utah -- A dozen miles east of this Utah-Nevada border town on the crusted rim of the Great Salt Lake Desert, drivers of a fantastic collection of super-powered motor vehicles are engaged in an assault on the world's land speed record.

To the Travel Editor: I HAVE read with interest, and some alarm, John B. Oakes' article about Yellowstone, motorboats and the continuing pollution and disruption of other "natural" areas by the incursions of people with powerboats [issue of Aug. 7].

AFTER tearing a piece of adhesive - backed tape from its roll the end often gets pressed back down on the surface so that the roll is hard to start next time a piece is needed. To prevent this from happening try this simple trick.

A summer setback in rate for tramp vessels has been accepted as a "seasonal recession" by owners, who have brought their ships out of idleness in expectation of an autumn revival. This is the verdict of the current Westinform quarterly dry cargo market survey.

THE American vacationist looking for something that is difficult to find in this country -- national seashore recreation sites -- is in some pleasant surprises at point not too far from Maine's eastern border.
HOUSTON, Aug. 20 -- Plans for a dome-covered sports stadium seating more than 45,000 persons were announced here today by the Harris County Board of Park Commissioners.

SPEARMINT is an herb that means many things to many men. It was once believed to have a cheering effect on the brain and it is this attribute that is jocularly said to have led to its association in England with cold mutton.
THE New York Public Library, still firm on its foundations at the easy drop-in location at Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street, has a steady art-exhibition program throughout the year.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Aug. 20 -- Aerovias Sud Americana, Inc., the only scheduled, all-cargo, United States-flag carrier to Latin America, will move to Miami on Sept. 1.

THAT Annie Besant was one of the most remarkable able women of her time (1847-1933) is a proposition that even the most hostile critic of Theosophy would find it difficult to deny. Today she is remembered chiefly as the successor of Mme. H.P. Blavatsky, that mysterious, gross, hypnotic woman who was one of the chief founders of the Theosophical Society.

CHIMNEY ROCK, N.C. -- Each year, more and more visitors are discovering the spectacular natural beauty, the summer-long coolness, the moderately priced accommodations and the varied recreation facilities of Hickory Nut Gorge.

ANOTHER United States stamp was announced yesterday by Postmaster General Arthur E. Summerfield. This is a blue 4-cent adhesive paying tribute to the American automotive industry.
STRATFORD, ONT. SIXTY composers from twenty nations met in this Canadian festival city last week to talk over problems of their profession and hear five concerts of contemporary music.

PHOTOGRAPHS of flower and garden themes, with some human interest, are on display in the exhibit, "Gardens: Adventures in Seeing," at the Kodak-Photographic Information Center and Exhibit in Grand Central Terminal.
WASHINGTON. The first of three consecutive international congresses concerned with rehabilitation opens here today.
CHICAGO, Aug. 20 (AP) -- George Altman drove in five runs with a double and a three-run homer today, leading the Chicago Cubs to a 9-5 victory which smashed a four-game San Francisco winning streak.
FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla. -- Port Everglades, lying just south of Fort Lauderdale and partly in Hollywood, is fast becoming one of the ranking ports of call for cruise ships in the United States.

MOUNT McKINLEY NATIONAL PARK, Alaska -- The traveler who is about to join that fast growing fraternity of motorists driving across Alaska is bound to get a lot of unsolicited advice from well-intentioned but badly informed friends.
SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 20 -- C.V. Whitney's Tompion had nothing to fear from the weight or the opposition today in the ninety-first running of the Travers Stakes.

An account of how Roy M. Cohn and William Fugazy, the boxing promoters, lost a fight with Fortune Pope to control the supply of Dominican rock salt for this city is scattered through the files of the State Investigation Commission.
RENO, Nev. A HOLLYWOOD movie troupe is here to bet at least $3,500,000 on what they hope is a sure thing.

IT is unlikely that one will find an asado trail outlined in the average travel folder on Argentina, but it is something for a gourmet to keep in mind when visiting that country. Last spring when I was in Argentina on business, I managed to work out an informal asado tour of my own that delightfully combined the pleasures of sight-seeing and eating.
The latest Soviet space exploit strongly reinforced the long-held expectation of the American scientific community that the first human to orbit the earth would be a Russian.

CUSTOMERS who relished that pert, British-made, comic fantasy, "The Mouse That Roared," should be pleased to hear that still another spoof from the pen of author Leonard Wibberley is headed toward the screen.

The stock market followed quiet seasonal pattern of trading last week in the lack of any new moves by the Federal Reserve Board to ease credit. Prices held within a narrow range, except for some strength in electronic and special issues.

VISITORS to Mexico City in September will reap special dividends of local gaiety and traditional color if they time their visit to include Sept. 16, when Mexicans will launch a special celebration marking the 150th anniversary of their independence.

ENGLEWOOD, N.J., Sunday, Aug. 21 -- Like Tom Sawyer and Huckleberry Finn, two Englewood boys who were presumed to have drowned in the river last week have turned up very much alive.

Last week 20,900 closely set numbers appeared in full-page advertisements over the logotype of the Consolidated Edison Company. Readers who troubled themselves to seek out the accompanying explanation learned that these were the bonds called in the utility's partial redemption of its 4 per cent convertible debentures of 1973.

JOHN BARTH'S "The Sot-Weed Factor" is a brilliantly specialized performance, so monstrously long that reading it seemed nearly as laborious as writing it. Obviously Barth (author previously of "The End of the Road" and "The Floating Opera") believed he needed these approximately 500,000 words to achieve his effects.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 20 -- Following are the texts of a statement, in unofficial translation, by Vasily V. Kuznetsov, a Soviet First Deputy Foreign Minister, on the situation in the Congo; of a statement by Dag Hammar skjold on questions raised by Mr. Kusnetsov, and of messages exchanged between Mr. Hammarskjold and officials of the Government of Ghana:

When a tightly knit, foreign-language-speaking neighborhood is affected by an urban-renewal project, there is often great resentment on the part of the residents. Sometimes, however, they are eventually grateful to the authorities responsible.

BOSTON, Aug. 20 -- skinny Brown of Baltimore shut out Boston on eight singles tonight, 6 -- 0, after the Red Sox had scored an 8-6 victory in the afternoon part of a doubleheader. Ted Williams led the Red Sox in the first game with two three-run homers.
Two major biographical projects -- one on aviation, the other on Negro leaders -- have been started by Columbia University's Oral History Research Office.
PARIS, Aug. 20 -- The Mali Federation in West Africa broke up suddenly today. A civil war between its component states, Senegal and Sudan, was threatened.

For Ages 12 to 16. THE archipelago that runs from New Guinea to Australia is the setting for this many faceted, wholly engaging story. The characters include Kerri, an island youth (and the narrator); Miss Buchanan, the village schoolteacher from the outside world; and "all the proud tribesmen" of the title.
Oh, No! TITLE of a book to be published in October, by which time the outdoor chef will have had it -- "365 Ways to Cook Hamburger," by Doyne Nickerson.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 20 -- The Pittsburgh Pirates scored six runs in the second inning today and led, 8 -- 0, in the fourth, but still had to stave off a rally to beat the Cincinnati Reds, 10-7. Elroy Face went in in relief again and stifled the Reds after the Cincinnatians had cut the Pittsburgh lead to three runs.

PARIS, Aug. 20 -- Unless present appearances prove mis- leading, the problem of "Eu- rope at sixes and sevens" may soon provide a perfect illustra- tion of how rapidly the inter- national climate can change.

PICTON, Ont., Aug. 20 -- For the second year in succession Bob Hayward, a 32-year-old bachelor of London, Ont., formerly a chicken farmer but now a sensational speed-boat driver, today made Canada supremely happy by winning the Harms-worth Trophy.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: It is impossible to know, at this writing, exactly how much of and how some $621 million in funds voted by Congress additional to the President's 1961 budget requests will be spent. But one thing is certain -- the Eisenhower Administration has been buying money with time.
Construction of the $22,000,000 Newburgh - Beacon bridge over the Hudson is scheduled to be Started in late September.

BEDFORD, Mass., Aug. 20 (AP) -- The number of manmade objects in orbit about the earth reached thirty-seven with the Soviet Union's "space menagerie" satellite, the National Space Surveillance Control said today.
VERY broadly speaking, the theme of this crisp and slightly savage farce is that he who approaches love with preconceptions is bound to get lost in the confusion.

MINNEAPOLIS, Aug. 20 -- The Democratic ticket of John F. Kennedy and Lyndon B. Johnson has a lead over Richard M. Nixon and Henry Cabot Lodge, the Republic slate, in the first Minnesota poll since the national political conventions.

Mayor Wagner voiced regret yesterday at Governor Rockefeller's rejection of his plea for a special session of the Legislature to revise voter registration dates. He reaffirmed his intention to provide additional registration time.
ATLANTA, Aug. 20 -- The deep South faces new steps toward desegregation of its public schools this fall under the complex pressures of a Presidential election year.

Because of the large number of families that are still to be displaced by construction projects here, the city's Housing and Redevelopment Board will attempt to augment the supply of relocation housing with Federal assistance.

DETROIT, Aug. 20 -- A property owners association and a real estate brokers group in the exclusive Grosse Pointe suburbs east of Detroit have agreed to abandon their point rating system for screening prospective home buyers.

THE popularity of nursery schools, it seems, grows every year. In a few short weeks thousands of youngsters across the country will be starting their academic careers in privately run nursery schools, cooperatives run by parents and teachers, nurseries in day-care centers, in liberal-arts colleges and universities, hospitals and child-guidance clinics, as well as those sponsored by religious groups and those run especially for handicapped children.

THE seventh issue of the quarterly, Dance Perspectives, has just made its appearance, and adds a Conspicuous laurel to the young publication's brow. It is called "The Duport Mystery" and is by Lillian Moore.
BONN, Germany, Aug. 20 -- The box-office hit in West German theatres this month is a picture with a sure-fire title -- "Main Kampf."

NOROTON, Conn., Aug. 20 -- Fred Hibberd Jr., of the American Y.C., Rye, N.Y., sailed his Flash to a 7-point lead for the Long Island Sound Lightning Class championship in the first two-races of the series off the Noroton Y.C. today.
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Aug. 20 -- Arkansas will decide Nov. 8 whether to repeal its constitutional guarantee of a free education to all persons between 6 and 21 years of age.

Richmond Estates, a com- munity of twenty-five dwellings with split-level and ranch features on North Jerusalem Road, a fourth of a mile east of Merrick Avenue, East Meadow, L.I., will be built by Robert and Arthur Pullman.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 -- The outnumbered Republicans have clearly grasped the political offensive in the two-week-old short session of Congress and the Democrats are yet to devise an effective counterattack.
LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Aug. 20 (AP) -- United States tennis players continued their domination of the Gordon Trophy competition for seniors by whipping the Canadian team today, 11 to 1.
ROME, Aug. 20 -- Rome's new intercontinental airport at Fiumicino was formally handed over today by the Minister of Public Works to the Civil Avia- tion Department of the Defense Ministry.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 20 -- Southern California won the United States girls' grass court tennis team championship today for the sixth straight year and the eighth time since 1952 by defeating Florida, 6 -- 1, in the final round at the Germantown Cricket Club.

THE big national tournament of the American Contract Bridge League, now being played in Los Angeles, is drawing to a close, It began on Aug. 13 and will end on Tuesday. Another national tournament that began on Aug. 13 ended yesterday with much less fanfare.
SUNNYVALE, Calif., Aug. 20 (AP) -- The capsule of Discoverer XIV, snatched out the skies near Hawaii yesterday, will be studied at the Lockheed laboratories here and not be flown to Washington.
AS expected and as indicated by the column of letters on the Screen Page last week, reader response to our suggestion of Aug. 7 that "subtitles must go" was immense.
An example of the kind of rehabilitation the city presumably has in mind for brownstones on the Upper West Side is being done independently by a woman owner.

INDIAN LAKE, N.Y. -- In the heart of the Adirondacks, only forty-two miles west of the busy Lake George area, is this quiet, uncrowded vacationland, with 120 miles of shoreline dotted with massive glacial rocks and excellent sand beaches.

BY spoofing the ignorance and "infinite capacity for self-deception" of his fellow Hindus, Bhabani Bhattacharya has brought about, almost casually, one of the most effervescent literary reputations among current Indian writers.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Aug. 20 -- Eight weeks of poking around musty record rooms in Britain and Ireland by a Rutgers University professor has brought New Jersey several thousand documents dealing with the state's early history.

HONOLULU, Aug. 20 -- Hawaii's music lovers will take their blankets and tatamis (rice mats) to Honolulu's outdoor amphitheatre, the Waikiki Shell, tomorrow night and Tuesday night to hear the New York Philharmonic in its first appearance in the Islands.

FOR THIS WEEK: Webs on the ends of twigs and branches are caused by fall webworm; spray caterpillars with DDT, lead arsenate or malathion. . . . Start lawn renovation. . . . Spary roses weekly for black- spot control; pick and burn auspicious-looking foliage. . . . Continue drying herbs and annuals. . . . Plant oxalis indoors.

TO THE EDITOR: I liked Gilbert Millstein's article about comedian Bob Newhart ("New Sick and/or Well Comic," Aug. 7). The part I liked beat is where Mr. Millstein tells us that Bob is still a Democrat and how Bob says that no Republican can ever be a good comedian, because Republicans are either too old or have too-old ideas.
To the Travel Editor: Mr. Oakes' summary of the Yellowstone motorboat controversy was excellent.
VIENTIANE, Laos, Aug. 20 -- The prospects of civil war in Laos increased today although efforts continued to settle internal differences peacefully.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Aug. 20 -- Howard G. Seymour's Mutiny beat C.F. Richards' Dido by a healthy margin today to capture Resolute class honors in the interclub racing on Manhasset Bay. James B. Moore's Lure finished third.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Aug. 20 -- More Harvard College students than ever before are graduating with honors and continuing their studies, ac- cording to a survey by the college's Office of Student Placement.
MARBLEHEAD, Mass., Aug. 20 -- Scoring a fifth place in the final race, Albert Frost, a 47-year-old lumberman from San Diego, won the International 110 Class sailing championship today.
PARAMUS, N.J., Aug 20 -- An Englewood man admitted this morning after a night of questioning that he had killed his wife in 1957 and had buried her in a grave four feet deep.

The export of a million barrels of oil a day by the end of next year seems to be the goal of the companies operating in Algeria and Libya. Practically all of this oil would be moving to West European markets, and a question with which the industry generally is much concerned is: What would be the impact on free world petroleum activities?

Harassed by lawsuits and stockholder criticisms, Chrysler Corporation called on a leading New York law firm last week to check on the auto company's own investigation of conflicts-of-interest between Chrysler officers and suppliers.

DURING its eighteen-day television coverage of the Olympic games in Rome beginning Friday night, the Columbia Broadcasting System's sports department will have thirty-two shots at the 4,311-mile airplane relay record between that city and New York.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 20 -- Widespread complaints of voting irregularities here in the statewide primary election Aug. 2 will be investigated by a grand jury, St. Louis Circuit Attorney Thomas F. Eagleton said this week.
TARRYTOWN, N.Y., Aug. 20 -- The Tarrytown Boat Club's predicted log contest for the Bear Mountain Trophy was won today by Edward J. Dennis in Madeline IV. His accuracy score was 98.80 per cent.
ANCHORAGE, Aug. 4 -- Chief Justice Buell A. Nesbett of the Alaska Supreme Court played truant two days last week, the first time since he was sworn in a year ago.

TO THE EDITOR : "Swimming -- Country Style" captures much of the excitement and intrigue which children find in exploring the watery environment, which is foreign to man after birth. The picture showing boys trying to stay under water the longeat cannot and should not be viewed in a mood of gay abandon.

A PROGRAM OF CATHOLIC HYMNS; Male Choir of the Church of St. Dominic of Shaker Heights, Ohio, Cal Stepan, choirmaster (Columbia). Fourteen congregational hymns of the Roman Catholic Church sung with rather cloying placidity and sweetness by an efficient choir of amateurs.

WOODS HOLE, Mass., Aug. 20 -- Steep gradient or V/STOL (vertical and short take-off and landing) aircraft offer a flexible solution to the nation's jammed highway systems, James T. Pyle, deputy Federal Aviation Administrator, said this week.

Conant issued his reform plan for the American high school last year, some academic eyebrows were raised at such demands as a seven or eight hour school day, insistence on a minimum of four years of continuing study of one foreign language and other measures to take up the learning slack.
ITHACA, N.Y., Aug. 20 -- An airedale terrier, Ch. Bengal Sabu, took best in show at the Finger Lakes Kennel Club dog show in Barton Hall today.

Relations between the White House and the Democratic-controlled Eighty-sixth Congress, which yesterday completed the twelfth day of its bobtail session, last week were reminiscent of the 1948 campaign year. It was in that year that Harry S. Truman pinned the "do-nothing" label on the Republican-controlled Eightieth Congress, called Congress back into what proved to be an unproductive session and went on to win a surprising vic- tory over Thomas E. Dewey.
Tranquilizers containing the drug meprobanmte can greatly increase the effects of alcoholic beverages, a report in The Journal of the American Mddical Association said yesterday.
LENOX, Mass., Aug. 20 -- The largest national rally field of the year -- 111 cars -- competed today in the first stages of the Sports Car Club of America's annual Berkshire Mountain event.

For the second consecutive Saturday, the crew of the Furness-Bermuda Line's Queen of Bermuda walked off the vessel at 11:30 A.M. yesterday to stage a one-day strike in sympathy with a wildcat walkout by British seamen.

ON a steep, almost perpendicular cliffside facing the Mediterranean can be seen one of Europe's most fabulous gardens -- the tropical hanging Exotic Garden (Jardin Exotique) of Prince Rainier III of Monaco. The cacti and succulents grow in natural surroundings, planted on a rocky slope that drops to the sea from a height of about 500 feet. From the entrance to the lowest area, the garden drops 130 feet.

ANCHORAGE, Aug. 13 -- This ebullient metropolis on Cook Inlet continues to reflect the spirit of a venturesome Alaska with a great destiny, despite complaints along Fourth Avenue that "business is slow."

CHAUTAUQUA, N.Y. -- This venerable institution begins the final week of its eighty-seventh summer season today, anticipating visitors who will push the attendance total for the eight-week season to about 60,000.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 20 -- The Soviet Union told Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold today it opposed the week-old United Nations technical assistance program in the Congo. Vasily V. "armed groups from Canada" from the African republic "because they are allies of Belgium, which is guilty of aggression in the Congo."
A trailership operator and a Florida railroad inaugurated yesterday the first scheduled ship-rail piggyback system for hauling containers between Florida and the Northeast.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 20 -- A little more than a week remains of the Saratoga meeting of the New York Racing Association. That week finds more members of society from many parts of the East and South in their boxes than at any recent August season.

OLD DEERFIELD, Mass. -- Construction work this summer on a new Federal interstate highway up the Connecticut River valley will come within a few miles of this historic village, but authorities say that neither the present construction nor that planned for the future will be close enough to disturb the 290-year-old village.

MILWAUKEE, Aug. 20 (UPI) -- Bob Buhl and the Milwaukee Braves won a 1-0 duel with Robin Roberts of the Philadelphia Phillies tonight when his team-mates got three of their five hits in the fourth inning to score.

ST. PAUL, Aug. 20 (UPI) -- Lionel Hebert, the 1957 Profes- sional Golfer's Association cham- pion, and Don Fairfield, who has won only one tournament as a professional, shared the 54-hole lead in the St. Paul open today with 17-under-par 199's.
TORONTO, Aug. 20 (Canadian Press) -- Carl J. Printz, Norwegian consul here for thirty-four years, died while visiting Norway, it was learned here. He was 100 years old.

It is a common practice at radar installations for personnel who must work outdoors in very cold weather to warm themselves by standing in the beam of the radar. Although no accidents are known to have resulted from this, it is nevertheless against regulations.

Committee members have been announced for the Nov. 17 performance of "Irma la Douce," which will benefit the New York Arthritis and Rheumatism Foundation. The adaptation of the French musical is scheduled to open at the Plymouth Theatre on Sept. 29.
MOSCOW, Aug. 20 -- Living creatures have returned safely to earth from an orbit in space for the first time in history, the Soviet Union announced today.

PARIS, Aug. 20 -- Senegal and Sudan, former French territories, united in January, 1959, to revive in modern form the old Mali empire that flourished six centuries ago.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 20 -- Three outs away from their second straight 1-0 defeat, the Los Angeles Dodgers got a two-run double from Gil Hodges in the ninth inning today and downed the St. Louis Cardinals, 2 -- 1. The victory put the Dodgers into third place in the National League, 2 percentage points ahead of St. Louis.

The widespread practice of giving a fanciful name to a housing development is more than a means of identification -- it is often part of the builder's sales strategy. Choosing an image-evoking name is so important that some builders have been known to devote great mental effort to it, according to B.J. Bergton, a New Jersey real estate man who has had a score of years of experience as sales agent for home developments.

A 57-year-old Californian,the victim of a crippling spinal ailment, has invented a device that permits the writing of letters in a language one does not understand.

CASSVILLE, Wis. -- Union carpenters, employing skills and methods of bygone days, are helping to create a pioneer village here and are foregoing union rates to do it. They are building a typical nineteenth-century carpenter shop that will form part of the reconstructed frontier village rising in this southwestern corner of Wisconsin and they are using almost-for-gotten methods of timber framing to do the Job.
DETROIT, Aug. 20 (UPI) -- The Detroit Tigers posted their fourth straight victory today by beating the Cleveland Indians, 4 -- 2, behind the pitching of Bob Bruce.

LONDON, Aug. 20 (Reuters) -- Giving their soundest batting display of the series, South Africa scored 419 runs to gain a commanding lead of 264 over England in the third day of the fifth and last cricket test at the Oval today.
Twelve teen-agers from the East Bronx went to East Harlem on Friday to paint a neighborhood community center red, green, blue and yellow.

Long regarded as a trademark of American enterprise and business acumen, the building of dramatic large-scale office, commercial and residential developments by private investment is now being practiced by a British real estate company.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Aug. 20 -- President Sukarno's latest political moves to concentrate power in his National Front are being interpreted here as an effort turn Indonesia into monolithic-type state based on a single ideology advanced by him.

LONDON. JOHN BUCHAN, later Lord Tweedsmuir, had many readers and friends on our side of the Atlantic, both in the United States and Canada, where, while serving as Governor General, he died in 1940. His fine autobiography, "Memory Hold-theDoor," known to American readers as "Pilgrim's Way," is admirably supplemented by a book I have just come upon -- "John Buchan by His Wife and Friends."

WASHINGTON. FOR three decades, since the Supreme Court first dealt with the problem, wiretapping has been the subject of recurrent controversy in this country. Waves of public outrage at notorious uses of the dismal art have alternated with campaigns by law-enforcement officials to eliminate restraints on tapping.

To the Travel Editor: Mr. Oakes' very lucid depiction of a problem in the field of recreation that affects longrun conservation certainly struck a responsive chord. In the summer of 1956, I was shocked to see what was being done on the shore of Jackson Lake in the Tetons in the name of "progress" and "improvement."

For the first time, the battle against academic diploma mills is being carried across the sea. The Federal Trade Commission last week charged that an American agent has been misrepresenting four foreign socalled universities by recommending them to American "customers" as accredited institutions.
Levittown, Pa., won the Eastem Regionals Little League baseball crown yesterday by beating Newton, Mass., 3-1, at Hy Turkin Field on Staten Island.

A NEW and glossy term, no more nauseating than the one from which it springs, is certainly about to be born in the slick magazines: Gracious Outdoor Living. It cannot be avoided; they are as sure to pick it up, and frazzle it tediously, and wear it out, and keep on using it, as they are sure to keep on using Another Hard Look and The American Outdoor Heritage.
The new seventeen-day air excursions to Europe, which begin Oct. 1, have aroused comment in the travel industry ranging from unbridled enthusiasm to a pessimistic view of the whole idea.

SAN JUAN, P.R., Aug. 20 -- The Bull Insular Lines, which has been in the maritime business in Puerto Rico for the last sixty years, has sold three of its four downtown docks in San Juan. It will sell a fourth dock but lease it back from the Puerto Rico Port Authority.

The agenda before the Foreign Ministers of the twenty-one nations now meeting in the Organization of American States sessions in Costa Rica consists of two items that are radically different in origin, but are nonetheless closely linked.
ROME, Aug. 20 (UPI) -- Nikolai Semashko, the Soviet Union's basketball coach, promised "real competition" today to the United States Olmpians his team expected to battle for a gold medal.

NEW York is going to have a normal music season after all. That is, Carnegie Hall, having been saved at the last moment, will be in business as usual. Every other auditorium will be presenting its customary attractions.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 -- In the Congo crisis the United States is caught in the familiar dilemma between the forces of an old, and in this case dying, colonialism and a most difficult young state -- complicated to an exceptional degree by the intrusion of the Soviet Union, which seeks to exploit the difficulties to its own advantage.
BRUSSELS, Belgium, Aug. 20 -- Belgium will ask the United Nations to send civil and military observers to Ruanda-Urundi. The United Nations trusteeship territories are administered by Belgium.

ROME, Aug. 20 -- Against a backdrop of the ancient ruins of the Eternal City and in the splendor of modern architectural masterpieces of marble, concrete and glass, the Games of the XVII Olympiad will open Thursday.

WINTHROP, Mass., Aug. 20 -- Stan Ogilvy of Larchmont, N.Y., finished third in the final race of the series today but easily won the Atlantic Coast championship of the Star Class. He had three firsts, one second and one third in the five-race sailing series.
OCEANPORT, N.J., Aug. 20 -- Sandpiper, owned by Brooke Miller of Lahaska, Pa., won the open jumper crown of the Monmouth County Horse Show today.

SOUTHPORT, Conn., Aug. 20 -- The annual Atlantic Class sailing championship was concluded today, with the top prize going to Briggs Cunningham, the noted yachtsman and sports car racer from Greens Farms, Conn.
The expression "close to a mother's heart" may have more than sentimental significance for a newborn child, a New York psychologist believes.

A CURB or low wall of natural stone or block can serve many purposes when properly in- stalled along the edges of a driveway, walk or lawn. It can be used to keep pebbles from scattering on graveled driveways or walks, or for holding brick and sand in place when installed along the perimeters of a terrace or walk made of these materials.

More than 1,000 guests are expected to attend "The Sound of Life" dinner in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria on the evening of Sept. 18. The event will be given in support of the Eleanor Roosevelt Institute for Cancer Research at the American Medical Center at Denver and also will honor Richard Rodgers and Oscar Hammerstein 2d.

THE new crop of college students, lining up to register this fall, will have a more diverse look than any that has come before. It will include more students from abroad, and they will be more widely distributed among American universities. From Brunswick, Me., to Claremont, Calif., hardly a college town will not welcome an Iranian or an Indian, a Brazilian or a Turk, to its campus and its homes.

TAIPEI, Taiwan, Aug 18 -- The International Cooperation Administration has been urged to allocate $750,000 in counter- part funds to the Taiwan Government to move Nationalist China's art terasures from central Taiwan to Taipei.
Cool weather in many parts of the nation sparked fall business last week, according to reports from resident buying offices.
The old White Star Line's buff-colored funnels with black tops, which have traveled the seas since the Victorian era, will disappear from the transAtlantic lanes this year.
The heir-apparent to a throne that isn't around any more arrived in New York yesterday and said he felt "exactly like any other boy."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 -- Mickey Mantle hit a double and Moose Skowron hit a homer. Elston Howard singled, Gil McDougald walked and Kent Hadley doubled. All this happened in the eleventh inning today, providing the Yankees with a 9-5 victory over the Washington Senators at Griffith Stadium.

"YOU know something?" says a character named Berry-berry Williams in James Leo Herlihy'a first novel, "I hate life." Berry-berry is a wild one in his twenties who had run away from home to take up the life of a wandering procurer.

RABAT, Morocco, Aug. 20 -- While a crowd of several thousand Moroccans chanted "Mauritania is Moroccan," King Mohamed V announced today that Morocco had demanded that the Mauritanian question be added to the agenda of the next session of the United Nations General Assembly.
JAKARTA. OF all the newly independent countries in Southeast Asia, Indonesia, a turbulent and fiercely nationalistic teen-ager, is among the most underdeveloped in a variety of fields.
ASHEVILLE, N.C., Aug. 20 (AP) -- Louise Suggs of Atlanta carded a 69 on the Asheyille Country Club course today and took the lead in the Asheville women's open golf tournament with a 41 total.

FAYETTEVILLE, N.C., Aug. 20 (AP) -- About 7,000 Strategic Army Corps paratroopers jumped today in the biggest United States air drop since World War II. One soldier was killed and forty-nine were injured, some seriously.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 -- Vice President Nixon released today a thirty-page analysis of the meaning of communism. It was the first of a series of reports setting forth the thinking of the Republican Presidential candidate on major issues facing the American people.

A restaurateur in Osaka, Japan, covered the walls of his tea shop with plain white paper and invited diners to practice "free scribbling" thereon as the spirit moved them.
MAPLEWOOD, N.J., Aug, 20 -- A property revaluation program carried out here by the local tax assessor has stirred a major controversy involving state and township officials, as Well as residents.
TEHERAN, Iran, Aug. 20 -- Charges that the national elections were rigged in favor of Premier Manouchehr Eghbal's National party were put today before Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi.

LONDON. THE vogue for "Victoriana," which started in England a few years ago as a humorous eccentricity, has now established itself and spread to America. People are beginning to collect Victorian pictures, and some of the minor objects of applied art: papier-mache tables inlaid with mother-of-pearl, bead - embroidered footstools, japanned boxes, paper-lace valentines.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 20 -- The open championship of the United Chess Federation, which was won by Robert Byrne, an instructor at the University of Indianapolis, ended yesterday with Paul Benko of New York rated in second place and Dr. Poschel of Ann Arbor, Mich., ranked in third.

HAVANA, Aug. 20 -- To meet increasing shortages of food available to Cubans, Minister of Commerce Raul Cepero Bonilla issued an order today that the Government's so-called stores of the people are to have priority over private commercial establishments, in receiving supplies.

He wins fights against odds, and scribbles immortal songs in his leisure, and dies in the end like some antique hero, with the lights burning low in the skies and the stage darkened.

Work has been started on Woodside, a development of forty-three homes on Park Avenue, north of Prospect Avenue, Park Ridge, N.J. One model is on dsplay and another is under construction. Prices start at $25,000.

LONDON. THE case of Huntington Hartford, a 49-year-old American multimillionaire, proves the axiom that giving away large sums of money is not all that easy. It is a trek into the jungle of unpredictable preference and prejudice, requiring on the part of the donor the hide of a rhinoceros, the instinct of a puma and the surefootedness of a mountain goat.
TO THE EDITOR: After reading Senator Goldwater's article, I am indeed thankful that the conservatives for whom Mr. Goldwater is spokesman are in a decided minority.

LONDON, Aug. 20 (AP) -- Burnley, the English League champions that will play in the European Cup series this year, defeated Arsenal in a thrilling finish today and made a good start in the new soccer season.

PARIS, Aug. 20 -- The Congo, south of the Sahara, hag been capturing the headlines lately, but north of the desert Algeria continues in a relatively quiet but continually deadly way to preoccupy French and foreign statesmen.
BERN, Switzerland, Aug. 20 (AP) -- Glenn Davis of Columbus, Ohio, equaled the world record of 22.5 seconds tonight for the 200-meter low hurdles around a curve.

WESTBURY, L,I., Aug. 20 -- Hairos II, on the outside throughout the mile-and-a-quarter race, captured the $50,000 International Trot at Roosevelt Raceway tonight before a record crowd of 54,861.

TO THE EDITOR: IN his review of Elizabeth Shepley Sergeant's book on Robert Frost, Winfield T. Scott may be justified in claiming that "very little of importance has been added" to the Frost canon since "A Witness Tree"; but that very little might well be noted.

JERSEY CITY, Aug. 20 (AP) -- Humberto Robinson blanked the Jersey City Reds with six hits as the Buffalo Bisons won the second game of a doubleheader tonight, 4-0. Jersey City captured the seven-inning opener, 10-1.

WASHINGTON. THE political victor, come Nov. 8, will have won the Presidency but lost his privacy. From that night on, a group of men, most of whom he may never have seen before, will begin to watch his every move, ride in his automobile, go to his church, inspect his hotel rooms, check his food, open his packages, plan his travel and be ready if necessary to give their lives to save his.

The Federal Reserve Board's seasonally adjusted index of production stood in July at 109 per cent of the average for the base period, the year 1957. The only exception to this apparent motionless state was recorded in May when the index showed a temporary rise of one percentage point.

ROME, Aug. 20 -- The sun shone brightly and hot and a few athletes moved about the Olympic Village. They wore the multicolored sweatsuits of Liberia, Kenya and the Soviet Union, the baseball caps of Japan, the turbans of Pakistan.

A DISPLAY of 100 bonsai trees -- dwarf potted plants -- can be seen from now through Aug. 31 at Sterling Forest Gardens, located on Route 210 near Tuxedo, N.Y. The gardens are open daily from 10 A.M. to sundown.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 21 (AP) -- Senator Lyndon B. Johnson charged tonight that the "socalled thrifty, frugal Republicans have turned out to be the biggest peace-time spenders in history."

PARIS, Aug. 21 -- Premier Mamadou Dia of Senegal has accepted "in principle" Presiident de Gaulle's invitation to come to Paris to discuss the rift with Sudan, Senegal's sister republic.

CHICAGO, Aug. 21 (AP) -- A three-run homer by Andre Rodgers enabled the San Francisco Giants to gain a 5-3 victory today after the Chicago Cubs had taken the first game of a double-header by the same score.
LONDON, Aug. 21 -- Prices on the stock market eased just a bit last week after the spurt of the preceding week.

PARIS, Aug. 21 -- Industrial production in the European Common Market is likely to grow about 11 per cent this year and another 6 per cent next year, according to the Executive Commission of the Common Market in Brussels.
Youths who have disrupted the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn recently by throwing milk bottles from roofs picked the police as their target over the week-end.

The Summer Visitors New York is a Summer Festival, and particularly so this year. On only two days (and one of them yesterday), at present writing, knock on wood, has the temperature climbed above the crucial 86-degree mark, which means the difference between comfort and misery for those who work here, live here and roam the streets.
CLEARFIELD, Pa., Aug 21 (AP) -- Curtiss-Wright Corporation disclosed over the week-end plans for an expansion and reorientation of its research activities.

KANSAS CITY, Aug. 21 (UPI) -- The Kansas City Athletics snapped a ten-game losing streak today, beating the Chicago White Sox, 8 -- 1, behind the three-hit pitching of Ray Herbert.

BERN, Switzerland, Aug. 21 (AP) -- The United States Olympic track team, winding up competitive training for the Rome games, dominated an international meet today. Even though taking it easy, the Americans equaled one world record and served notice of peak fitness for the 1960 test.
Norman Thomas, from the vantage point of a man who has run for the Presidency six times, had some generally kind words yesterday for the nominees of both major parties.

PURCHASE, N.Y., Aug. 21 -- The Meadow Brook All-Stars, sparked by Dave Ellis and Vinny Rizzo, defeated the Blind Brook All-Stars, 9 -- 7, today in the Eastern Polo League's high-goal all-star game. The city is about to take a first step toward the establishment of a 300-acre industrial park in College Point, Queens, Mayor Wagner announced yesterday.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Monday, Aug. 22 -- The United Nations Security Council early today declined to interfere with Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold's efforts to bring peace and security to the troubled area of the Congo.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 21 -- International trade in meat moved upward only feebly in 1959 after a five-year period of steady growth, the Food and Agriculture Organization has reported in its monthly bulletin of agricultural statistics.

NEWARK, Aug. 21 (AP) -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner said today that the Port of New York Authority, had not developed into a Sliper-state and that New York and New Jersey had "sufficient controls over the authority to prevent any abuses."

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 21 -- Senator John F. Kennedy made a "slip of the tongue" if he suggested he did not want the support of rank-and-file teamsters and longshoremen, his brother Edward said tonight.

TRENTON, Aug. 21 -- The spotlight of public hearings was turned last week on subsidy contracts being drawn between New Jersey and eight of its nine commuter rail lines. "The Secretary of State," a study of the office considered by many Americans as second in importance to the Presidency, will be published by Prentice-Hall Dec. 27. Edited by Don K. Price, the volume will consist of six chapters written by men who had major roles in the administration of foreign affairs and in the Department of State.

A Brooklyn nursing-home owner announced yesterday that he would raise the charges for Welfare Department patients who were not removed by Friday. He said higher costs made it "impossible to wait any longer" for an increase in allowances.
The pilot of the Air Force plane that snared a satellite space capsule at 8,500 feet last Friday said here yesterday that patience and practice were more important than luck in a recovery.

With the final vote in the Senate last week both Houses of Congress have completed action on bills providing for what might be termed the "fourth round" of the Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938. The original legislation called for a minimum wage starting at 25 cents an hour and reaching 40 cents an hour by 1945. In 1949 the figure was raised to 75 cents and 1,300,000 workers were added to the number covered.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 -- Senator Hugh Scott charged today that "a good deal" of the family fortune of Senator John F. Kennedy had been used in an attempt to buy votes in the Presidential race.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 21 -- The long-awaited upturn in steel order volume so far has failed to come as expected. Last week, the volume of new orders was considered to be far from satisfactory. But most steel people were hoping that the trend would change in the near future.
Dr. Roman Vishniac, one of the worlds leading photographers of microscopic life, has been enlisted to help to improve the teaching of biology in high schools and colleges.

A Unitarian minister yesterday branded all religions, including his own, as failures.

LEOPOLDVILLE, Aug. 21 -- Premier Patrice Lumumba said in an interview today that "there are secret accords among the United States, France, Britain and Belgium for the uranium of Katanga." "These powers believe Belgium must stay in Katanga because the Congolese Government is moving toward the East and will be able to exclude the Western Allies from the source of this essential material," he declared.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Majority Leader Lyndon Johnson's characterization of the Administration's request for additional lower Federal court judgeships as a matter of patronage is unfortunate. At the same time, it does serve to raise a domestic issue of major importance which has not been handled well heretofore by either party and which merits frank discussion by both sides in the Presidential campaign.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 -- Congressional leaders prepared today for the third week of the reconvened Congressional session. They foresaw a hard fight in the Senate this week over medical care for the aged, and a legislative stumbling block in the House Rules Committee.

Rookies seeking berths with the New York Giants and the Green Bay Packers will have another chance to impress their coaches tonight when the National Football League teams meet in an exhibition game in Jersey City.

ST. ANDREWS, Scotland, Aug. 22 -- The Central Committee of the World Council of Churches urged its members today to help "create the conditions" that would permit Communist Chine to be admitted to the United Nations.
LONDON, Aug. 22 -- The wildcat strike of British dockworkers collapsed today, while the seamen's strike appeared to be on the verge of collapse.
OTTAWA, Aug. 22 (Canadian Press) -- Canada's exports marked up an advance in July of 8.3 per cent from the 1959 level despite continued softness of United States markets.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., Aug. 22 -- A fleet of fourteen sail boats, the largest since the event was established for teenagers in 1957, set out on the Beach Point Yacht Club's junior overnight cruise today. The 47.8-nautical-mile race is for the Long Island Sound junior distance championship.

PARIS, Aug. 22 -- The Algerian rebels called today for the internationalization of the Algerian issue through a United Nations referendum. The rebel Provisional Government in Tunis issued a communique putting an end to any hope for the early resumption of direct negotiations with France.
The market for United States Treasury bills turned upward yesterday after two weeks of declining prices. This lent new support to the continued upward movement of other Government securities.
LONDON, Aug. 22 -- Industrial shares began the week today in good demand, with interest increasing in the leaders. The Financial Times index rose 3.1 to 330.8.
LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Aug. 22 -- Premier Patrice Lumumba bowed to the United Nations Security Council today.
CHICAGO, Aug. 22 (UPI) -- Ron Santo and Don Zimmer made five hits between them and drove in five runs as the Chicago Cubs scored a 6-3 victory over the Cincinnati Reds today.

MOSCOW, Aug. 22 (AP) -- A Polish-born United States soldier who deserted his military intelligence unit at Frankfurt three weeks ago has denounced American policy and asked for asylum in the Soviet Union, Izvestia announced today.

WESTBURY, L.I., Aug. 22 -- Richard and Joe F. Asher's Berrymite from New Holland, Ohio, scored a length victory over Adie Rainbow in the Shelter Island Handicap pace before 24,002 fans at Roosevelt Raceway tonight.

ROME, Aug. 22 -- Rafer Lewis Johnson of Kingsburg, Calif., the world decathlon record-holder, will be the United States flag bearer in the opening-day parade of athletes from eighty-five nations in the XVII Olympic Games Thursday.
The City Planning Commission was told yesterday that it was "absolutely imperative" that the city find $73,095,000 for a six-year program of relighting the streets.

ROME, Aug. 22 -- It was a horse race that would have given the screaming meemies to Francis Patrick Dunne and every other steward in the United States. However, an Eddie Arcaro might not have minded too much -- at least a pre-Renaissance Arcaro who learned his trade in an everything-goes era.

We welcome the restatement, in a letter published on this page today, of New York City firemen's promise never to strike. Thus, even while criticizing the "unjust principle" of the Condon-Wadlin Law enacted by the New York Legislature in 1947 -- whose sole central principle is to forbid strikes by state and city governmental employes -- the firemen voluntarily accept this principle as fundamental to their responsibility to be on call at all times.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 -- Arthur S. Flemming announced today that the Administration would soon propose a program to rehabilitate the handicapped for independent living.
Aircrafts and motors moved upward strongly, yesterday on the New York stock Exchange. Metals and drugs snowed more losers than gainers and most other major groups were irregular.

If there is to be big league baseball in 1962 in the $16,056,250 sports stadium planned for Flushing Meadow Park, the city must begin digging a foundation this fall, Park Commissioner Newbold Morris declared yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 (AP) -- The Saturday Evening Post said today that the Republican National Committee had distorted an article the Post published on Senator John F. Kennedy.

Draft indebtedness of Latin American importers to United States exporters rose $2,900,000 in July to $178,400,000, the highest total since May of 1957, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.

LOS ANGELES Aug, 22 (UPI) -- National Boxing Association middleweight champion Gene Fullmer and Sugar Ray Robinson will meet in the Sports Arena here in a fifteen-round title bout on Oct. 8, matchmaker George Parnassus said today.
Major commodities on New York exchanges moved irregularly lower yesterday. Trading was generally light.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 22 -- Tempted of the Mooring Stable demonstrated today that 124 pounds was an acceptable weight for a mare to carry in a distance race. At the same time, Reginald Webster's Quill indicated that 128 pounds could be a little too much for a filly.
COLD SPRING HARBOR, L.I., Aug. 22 -- The Noroton (Conn.) Yacht Club crew, skippered by James Crane, took the early qualifying lead for the Long Island Sound midget sailing championship today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 -- Senator Jacob K. Javits' contributory health-insurance plan for aged persons gained limited support from the Eisenhower Administration today.

The Manufacturers Trust Company, fifth largest bank in New York City and seventh largest in the nation, cut its prime lending rate yesterday from 5 to 4 1/2 per cent. The prime rate is the interest rate charged by the biggest banks to customers with the best credit ratings.
A two-story commercial structure will be built on the southeast corner of Ninth Avenue and Twentieth Street in the Chelsea section by an investing group headed by Joseph Howard Katz, lawyer.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 (UPI) -- Senator Albert Gore asserted today that public opinion polls had an "entirely unjustified" influence on elections and suggested an investigation. Two leading poll-takers challenged his conclusions.

Anxious to cater to the growing American taste for fancy foods, thousands of buyers for retail establishments flocked to the Astor Hotel yesterday for the sixth National Fancy Food and Confection Show.
An English mauscript of a Bible excerpt in the ancient Anglo-Saxon language has been brought to this country.
NEW DELHI, India, Aug. 22 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru firmly rejected today a demand for Government ceilings on individual incomes.

CANDY-STRIPED awning, host Billy Reed, a cafe atmosphere and tender chicken crepes swathed in a creamy cheese sauce are some of the outstanding attributes of the Little Club. Now at least one aspect of this popular restaurant, at 70 East Fifty-fifth Street, can be reproduced in the home.
The thrift season on passenger ships to Europe opens today and all signs point to success.
MINEOLA, L.I., Aug. 22 -- The use of political posters that mar the beauty of Nassau County was forsworn by Republican and Democratic leaders here today.
The Ice Wagon of Yore Gone are the days, for many of us that is, when fond memories of youth have time to penetrate the hurry-hurry existence of present-day life.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Your recent editorial pointing up the need for action to reconstruct the West Side Highway prompts me to write in behalf of what I call, for want of a better term, "reversible streets."

GREENWICH, Conn., Aug. 22 -- Russell F. Moon, representing the Chicago Yacht Club, finished second today in the second race of the international Luders-16-class sailing championship and remained in the series lead.

Heretofore, Elaine Perry produced three plays here, "Touchstone," "King of Hearts" and "Anastasia," the last two of which had lengthy engagements None was directed by her though. But she will take the step with her next one, "Catstick," to be introduced as soon as the leads are corralled.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Aug. 22 -- Communist East Germany has negotiated an agreement with Indonesia on the exchange of consulates general, its first such penetration in the Southeast Asian neutralist countries.
DETROIT, Aug. 22 -- secretary of Defense Thomas S. Gates Jr. assured the nation today that the United State was the "greatest power on earth."
WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 -- The Government's short-term borrowing costs rose again this week, for the third week in a row. The rise was contrary to other indications that credit was becoming easier.

DETROIT, Aug. 22 -- The national commander of the Veterans of Foreign Wars said tonight that Senator John F. Kennedy would not be permitted to address the organization's convention here by telephone if he could not appear in person.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 -- Until World War II interfered with his source of supply, Howard Worth Smith always wore wing collars.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., Aug. 22 -- The Harrison Country Club team of Jerry Desio and Herb Singer won first prize today in the Westchester County Golf Association's pro-amateur tournament at the Winged Foot Golf Club.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 -- A Marine battalion has been ordered to delay its scheduled landing exercises in the Caribbean until after the close of the current conference of the Organization of American States in San Jose, Costa Rica.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 (AP) -- The Senate Appropriations Committee has recommended that Congress leave unchanged the President's authority to withhold information on foreign aid projects. The House had voted to restrict it.

Richard Pecorara, the New York fireman who was released from a Cuban jail on Sunday, found himself in more trouble when he reported for duty yesterday morning at Engine Company 32, at 49 Beekman Street.
PARIS, Aug. 22 -- When America sneezes, Europe no longer catches pneumonia. It suffers from an excess of good health.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 22 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold began work today on plans to set up an advisory committee to assist him in handling the troubled affairs of the Congo.
ROME, Aug. 22 -- Avery Brundage, the president of the International Olympic Committee, remarked the other day that he was convinced that all competitors entered for the Games here are amateurs.
ALBANY, Aug. 23 -- Thirty-five prospective parolees in state prisons face at least two special psychiatric examinations under a new procedure ordered by Governor Rockefeller.
Record sales and earnings for the first half of 1960 were reported yesterday by the Tennessee Corporation, producer of agricultural and industrial chemicals, copper and iron sinter.
VIENTIANE, Laos, Aug. 22 -- A deadlock persisted today between the rebel-supported authorities in Vientiane and the opposing forces based in Savannakhet.

CEDAR BEACH, L.I., Aug. 22 -- A 70-year-old Brooklyn man and one of his sons drowned shortly after noon today when their fourteen-foot skiff capsized in a heavy swell in the Atlantic, just outside Fire Island Inlet.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 22 -- Pour teams remained in the masters' team contest in the American Contract Bridge League's national tournament here as the eighth round began tonight. They were survivors of sixty-four teams that started Wednesday night.

JERSEY CITY, Aug. 22 -- While conducting practical football I.Q. tests for freshman pros tonight, the New York Giants and Green Bay Packers also held rugged but ragged comprehensive reviews for their established practitioners.
Striking sheet metal workers yesterday rejected a new contract offer by the Sheet Metal Contractors Association.
Mayor Wagner's office announced yesterday that a major project in resettling 542 families had been completed.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 -- The House passed a bill today to clear the way for radio and television debates between the major Presidential candidates.

CHICAGO, Aug. 22 -- Attorney General William P. Rogers satd today it was important that this session of Congress provide financial and technical help to states incurring expenses in desegregating schools.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 (AP) -- Newspaper reports on stillsecret state papers say they show that former President Harry S. Truman allowed the Soviet Union to stall a Japanese peace offer three weeks before the first atomic bomb wrecked Hiroshima.

NOME, Alaska, Aug. 14 -- The westernmost radio broadcasting station in Alaska is considering a proposal to beam religious programs, in Russian, to the Soviet Union. The station is the closest Alaskan one to Soviet territory.

VANDALIA, Ohio, Aug. 22 (AP) -- Mrs. Van N. Marker, a 57-year-old housewife from Versailles, Ohio, broke 100 straight targets to win the Women's Senior championship in the Sixty-first Grand American Trapshoot which opened today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 -- The availability of blood for transfusions, especially in remoter sections of the country, will be greatly increased by an agreement reached between the two largest blood-banking systems.

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Aug. 22 -- The United States accused Cuba today of "establishing a training program for Communist agents and guerrillas to spread the Communist revolution throughout Latin America."

Television has decided it is ready for Samuel Beckett. The Irish playwright's "Waiting for Godot," a tragicomedy that has angered many, delighted others and puzzled everyone, will be presented next season by "The Play of the Week" over station WNTA-TV.

Committees are being formed to plan for the eleventh annual Fan Ball. Mrs. Dwight D. Eisenhower again will serve as honorary chairman of the event arranged for Oct. 28 in the Grand Ballroom of the Plaza.
LEADERS of the broadcasting networks expressed gratification yesterday over the forthcoming suspension of equal-time provisions during the campaigns for the Presidency and VicePresidency this year.

FIVE years ago, women with long feet did not want to be reminded of their length. It is typical of the new attitude that a shoe designer named Margaret Clark wistfully admitted recently that she "only takes a size 7."
DOYLESTOWN, Pa., Tuesday, Aug. 23 -- Oscar Hammerstein 2d, the Broadway librettist and producer, died early today of stomach cancer at his home, Highland Farms. His age was 65.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 -- Harold Russell Tyler Jr. of New York was approved by the Senate Judiciary Committee today as Assistant Attorney General to head the Justice Department's Civil Rights Division.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Your editorial of Aug. 4 titled "Illegal Strike Rewards" was a hodgepodge of thoughts and an opportunity seized by you to harpoon and abort the pension system of the New York fire fighters.
Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 1 point up, to 6 points off yesterday. A point is equal to 5 cents a bale.

EDINBURGH, Scotland, Aug. 23 -- It has become a tradition that the Old Vie Company try out at the Edinburgh Festival each year one of its autumn offerings. This year, John Fernald's production of Chekhov's "The Seagull" seems likely to be the high spot of the festival on its dramatic side.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The Public Education Association agrees fully with your Aug. 16 editorial praising Charles H. Silver president of the Board of Education, for his vigorous support of the nation-wide "Stay-in-School" campaign.

The Southern California Edison Company sold yesterday $60,000,000 of its first and refunding mortgage bonds to the First Boston Corporation and Dean Witter Co. at a net interest cost of 4.42 per cent.
DETROIT, Aug. 23 -- The Veterans of Foreign Wars formally proposed today that colleges and secondary schools teach the history and tactics of communism.
SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Aug. 23 -- Colombia urged Cuba today to renounce "unnecessary" Soviet military protection and return to the fold of the hemispheric community.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 23 -- Carole Caldwell of Santa Monica, Calif., seeded No. 4, fought off four set points at 2-5 and then defeated Sue Behlmar, Yonkers, 6 -- 3, 8 -- 6, to gain the fourth round in the United States girls' lawn tennis championship today at the Philadelphia Cricket Club.
LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Aug. 23 -- A new series of incidents involving Congolese soldiers, United Nations personnel and Belgian civilians kept the Congo in a state of chaos today.

The publishing rights to the proceedings of the trial of Francis Gary Powers as a spy before the Military Division of the Soviet Supreme Court have been obtained by Translation World Publishers, a Chicago concern, from the Soviet government book agency.

Unless the Board of Estimate approves the $88,000,000 Lower Manhattan Expressway at its meeting tomorrow, the project probably will be abandoned, Robert Moses warned yesterday.
The Port of New York Authority is one of the metropolitan area's major business enterprises.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 23 -- Henry Cabot Lodge said today that President Eisenhower was considering attending the United Nations General Assembly this fall.

The derailment of an empty tank car on a New Haven Railroad freight train at Stamford, Conn., early yesterday disrupted the line's travel operations for nearly, eight hours and delayed 35,000 passengers during the morning rush hours.
A gunman wearing a black cloth hood and gloves held up a midtown diamond merchant yesterday and escaped with gems whose value was placed tentatively at "nearly $100,000."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 (AP) -- Senator Estes Kefauver, Democrat of Tennessee, today accused James D. Norris, boxing promoter, of hiding out in Paris to avoid testifying in the Senate boxing hearings. He called it "obstruction."
THE following dinner menu is given as a guide to the use of foods that are reasonable in cost. A recipe is suggested for a main dish that is easy to prepare.

A reminder that there is a conflict in Algeria as well as in the Congo has come with the proposal by the Algerian rebels for a United Nations referendum on independence. The suggestion has only intensified the sense of frustration and gloom which has settled over Algeria in recent weeks.

Roger J. Browne, acting commissioner of the Purchase Department, vowed yesterday that future suppliers of the city's material needs would be bound by scandal-proof contracts.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 -- The Presidential campaign is running true to form, which is to say it is getting more petty and personal as it goes along.
Advertising and promotional concerns were among lessees reported talking new quarters in Manhattan yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 -- A former agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation has been appointed chairman of the Teamsters Union Board of Monitors.

CIUDAD TRUJILLO, Aug. 23 -- Porfirio Herrera Baez, Foreign Minister, and the other Dominicans who withdrew from the Organization of American States conference at San Jose, Costa Rica, received a rousing welcome on their return here today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 -- Mrs. Lyndon B. Johnson met the religious issue head-on today at a hews conference called to announce a Texas tour, for her and two woman relatives of Senator John F. Kennedy.

The fourteen-story and penthouse apartment building at 10 Sheridan Square, corner of Grove Street, in Greenwich Village, has been sold by Robert Robe to an investing client of George Ross, lawyer. The deal was for cash over a mortgage of $221,000.

CHICAGO, Aug. 23 (AP) -- The feed grains attracted major attention today on the Board of Trade and posted moderate to substantial gains. Other grains and soybeans generally eased.

CHICAGO, Aug. 23 (AP) -- The league-leading Pittsburgh Pirates, facing three pitchers in the seventh inning, pried four runs out of them today, to touch off an 8-3 victory over the Chicago Cubs.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 -- Republicans and Southern Democrats teamed today to kill the "Social Security approach" to medical care for the country's 16,000,000 aged persons. The vote was 51 to 44.

FOR an inexpensive holiday, it generally is cheaper to stay in the United States, But for a low-cost meal in New York, a turnabout often applies. CHESTNUT HILL, Mass., Aug. 23 -- The Longwood Cricket Club, rich in American tennis history, faces an uncertain future as the home of the United States Lawn Tennis Association's national tennis doubles championships.

Three winners of the 1960 Albert Lasker Award for distinguished service to the physically handicapped were named yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 (AP) -- A Federal judge turned down a request today by Dr. Linus C. Pauling, the nuclear scientist, to block a Senate committee order for him to name the Individuals who assisted him In petitioning against nuclear testing.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: A bill which purports to protect animals used for scientific research in laboratories supported by Federal grants has been introduced in Congress. It is known as S. 3570 and is sponsored by John Sherman Cooper and eleven other Senators.
ST. ANDREWS, Scotland, Aug. 23 -- The World Council of Churches, through its Central Committee, repeated today its conviction that segregation based on race or color was contrary to the gospels.

DEAL, N.J., Aug. 23 -- Mrs. George Van Tassel of the Glen Ridge Country Club and Bobby Jacobson of the Hollywood Golf Club captured the Garden State women's mixed best-ball tournament today at the Hollywood course on a match of cards.

Although Oscar Hammerstein 2d had a genius for the musical theatre, he had something finer than that. He had character. His death yesterday shatters the remarkable collaboration of Richard Rodgers, composer of the music, and Mr. Hammerstein, composer of the lyrics and most of the books of their plays. Now we must accept the doleful fact that there will be no successors to "Oklahoma,", "Carousel," "The King and I" and "South Pacific."

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 23 -- The Security Council voted today to admit eight new African states to membership In the United Nations.

BONN, Germany, Aug. 23 -- The chief of the Soviet military liaison mission in the southern part of West Germany was caught yesterday photographing the barracks of a United States Army tank unit, United States Army headquarters in Heidelberg announced today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 -- President Eisenhower will make his first political speech of the 1960 election campaign at a Republican fund-raising dinner in Chicago on Sept. 29, the White House said today.

Mass production of thermionic converters has begun at the General Electric Company.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 -- President Eisenhower asked Congress today to end most of the Dominican Republic's sugar quota in the United States market. Reeves Brothers, Inc., textile manufacturer, has acquired the Curon plastic products business of the Curtiss-Wright Corporation. The transaction involved about $1,000,000 in cash, according to trade sources.

WESTBURY, L.I., Aug. 23 -- Royal Scotchman snapped a twenty-nine-race losing streak tonight in scoring a head victory over Lieut. Byrd in the Bronx Pace before 22,021 fans at Roosevelt Raceway. Royal Scotchman had not won a race since Aug. 9, 1959.
Two days have been added to the city's fall registration period to avoid conflict with Jewish religious holidays, Mayor Wagner announced yesterday.
London marine underwriters are rewriting their war-risk insurance policies to cover "brush fire" conflicts, American ship operators reported yesterday. The shipowners welcomed the development.

The State of Vermont borrowed $13,662,000 in the bon market yesterday to finance highway and other public improvements. The money was raised by the sale of serial bonds secured by the general taxing power to a syndicate headed by Chase Manhattan Bank and Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc.

ROME, Aug. 24 -- It took a mere 2,040 years for the Olympic Games to return to the Eternal City. It was worth the wait. Against the backdrop of this shrine of antiquity, the gaudiest of all sports festivals will begin on the morrow, a show of such magnificence that it will dwarf in size the circuses of Nero and Caligula and Domitian.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (AP) -- James R. Hoffa, president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, succeeded for the time being today in blocking a Federal judge from installing Terence F. McShane as head of the union's monitors.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 -- The United States consumer price index inche'd upward once again in July to another peak.

Kennedy announced yesterday that a thorough investigation would be made of all patrolmen on light duty, men reported sick for long periods and the records of police surgeons.
