ST. LOUIS, Aug. 26 (UPI) -- Stan Musial's thirteenth homer of the season was unlucky for the Pittsburgh Pirates tonight. The St. Louis slugger's two-run blast in the seventh inning powered the Cards to a 3-1 victory over the National League leaders before 24,436 fans.

Domestic sugar options were firm yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange on word that the United States had severed diplomatic relations with the Dominican Republic. Prices closed 1 point (hundredths of a cent a pound) off to 3 up on I,750 tons.

NEW DELHI, India, Aug. 26 (Reuters) -- The lower house of Parliament gave the green light today to India's most ambitious five-year economic plan since the nation gained independence thirteen years ago.

The grounding of the Soviet fleet of Ilyushin-18 turbo-prop airliners was disclosed in Moscow yesterday. This apparently new experience for Soviet civil aviation seems to be a result of the crash of an Ilyushin Aug. 17 in which twenty-seven lives were lost.
CHICAGO, Aug. 26 (AP) -- The grain futures market worked generally higher today on the Board of Trade, without any significantly new trade influences and with dealings slow in most pits.
ATLANTA, Aug. 26 -- Vice President Nixon was almost mobbed by well-wishers in this Deep South capital today.
Governor Rockefeller returned yesterday from a three-week vacation in Maine saving he felt "more optimistic all the time" about Republican prospects for carrying New York State.

Rodman C. Rockefeller, the Republican party's answer to the youthful exhuberance of Robert and Theodore Kennedy, held his first press conference yesterday and handled himself with the political aplomb of an experienced campaigner.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 (AP) -- Following is the roll-call vote by which the Senate tonight overrode President Eisenhower's objections and passed a com promise $3,722,350,000 foreign aid appropriation bill:

ROSLYN, L.I., Aug. 26 -- Mrs. Stanley Knapp, Glen Oaks, shot the lowest round of her career, a 39, 41 -- 80, to take low gross honors in the senior division of the Women's Cross County Golf Association tournament at the Engineers Country Club today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 -- The National Labor Relations Board pronounced the Kohler Company guilty today of prolonging by unfair labor practices a six-year-old strike at its plumbing-fixtures plant.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. (AP) -- Norm Larker drove five runs in the first game Duke Snider observed a ni in his honor with a boom home run in the second ga as the Los Angeles Dodg beat the Cincinnati Reds tw tonight, 10 -- 1 and 2 -- 0.

OLD GREENWICH, Conn., Aug. 26. -- The Ridgeway team of Fred Annon and Mrs. William Rosen won the pro-women tournament of the Westchester Professional Golfers' Association today with a net best-ball card of 32, 31-63.

CARACAS, Aug. 25 -- Venezuela has the right to establish production quotas for foreign producers here in defense of international oil export prices, Juan Pablo Perez Alfonzo, Minister of Mines and Hydrocarbons, said today. The possibility of this action in the wake of crude oil price cuts by Middle East exporters has already produced serious disagreement between the oil companies here and the Government.
ROME, Aug. 26 -- Crowds, confusion and hotel rooms this Olympic city has in abundance, but no traffic jams so far.

J.C. Penney, founder of the J.C. Penney Stores and now chairman of the board of the Penney Company, will observe his eighty-fifth birthday Sept. 16. On that day Thomas Nelson, will issue his book, "View From the Ninth Decade," in which he discusses the precepts and philosophy that he has followed in building one of America's largest retail operations.
A clash between the managements of two incoming Broadway productions gave proof yesterday that a new and characteristically temperamental theatre season was well under way.
CHICAGO, Aug. 26 (AP) -- Lee Walls' three-run, inside-the-park homer and a solo clout by Johnny Callison helped Robin Roberts and the Philadelphia Phillies defeat the Chicago Cubs, 4 -- 2, today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 -- Legislation that will improve medical care for the needy aged neared enactment today.
The city has absolutely no chance of winning a complete or partial recount of New York's 1960 population, a top regional Federal census official said yesterday.
Homecoming week -- the annual pre-Labor Day rush of Americans from Europe -- will start tomorrow.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 (UPI) -- A proposed new agency to administer the recently enacted Great Lakes Pilot Requirement Act is "all chiefs and no Indians," according to Representative Albert Thomas.

A City Full of Pigeons The parks, of this city play unrequiting hosts to a large and unrestricted community of pigeons. Their population census has never been taken, but shrewd guesses estimate their number as somewhere between one pigeon for every ten people to ten pigeons for every one person.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 (AP) -- Farmers' financial position in the national economy showed little improvement last year, but continued comparatively favorable nonetheless.
ROME, Aug. 26 (AP) -- The United States defeated Italy in a first-round game of the Olympic basketball tournament tonight, 88-54.

ROME, Aug. 26 (AP) -- A record of 10 seconds in the 100-meter run by Armin Hary of West Germany and Harry Jerome of Canada was approved officially as a world mark today by the records committee of the International Amateur Athletic Federation.
SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 26 (AP) -- Warren Spahn hit a home run and pitched an eighthitter tonight as the Milwaukee Braves beat San Francisco, 3 -- 2.
TEHERAN, Iran, Aug. 23 -- A well-informed senior Iranian official urged an American visitor the other day to "tell your people there will be no revolution in Iran -- not for the time being."

The five-story walk-up apartment building at 2105 Mohegan Avenue, the Bronx, has been sold by Mrs. S. Bloustein to an investing client of Irving Bira, the broker in the transaction. The building, with thirty-two apartments and four stores, is on a plot 118 by 70 feet.
WEEHAWKEN, N.J., Aug. 28 -- Twenty-five of the twenty-seven homes along the north side of West Nineteenth Street here have been evacuated because of the danger of falling rocks.
Small fires along the south-bound local track of the IRT-Seventh Avenue Line caused delays up to thirty-five minutes yesterday afternoon.
A leader of the Zionist Organization of America yesterday emphasized the nonpartisan and nonpolitical character of the organization.
BONN, Germany, Aug. 26 -- Chancellor Adenauer had his Defense Minister on the carpet today to explain how the West German General Staff had become involved in a political controversy.

DAKAR, Senegal, Aug 26 -- In the city of the quiet secession officials of a brand new government have found a brand new kind of political problem to worry about. They are worrynig about whether they have enough Communists around to interest the United States.
KOTZEBUE, Alaska, Aug. 15 -- Except for an occasional fight among sled dogs, this was a typical week-end along the north Bering Sea coast and Kotzebue-Sound, an arm of the Arctic Ocean.

The Texas Gulf Producing Company had net income of $2,414,005 in the first half of this year, or 15 per cent more than the $2,092,112 cleared in the 1959 period, Lawrence S. Reed, president, reported yesterday.
DETROIT, Aug. 26 -- Senator John F. Kennedy today branded the Castro Government of Cuba an enemy and a Soviet satellite ready to do anything to bring the downfall of the United States.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: On Aug. 17, two days before the Russians sent up the dogs, I was shot into orbit inside a twelve-ton space ship. After seventeen revolutions around the earth I tilted my retro-rocket and landed safely within seven inches of a preselected target.

The little man with the big potential -- the average consumer -- has become of more and more concern to United States economists in recent years. The interest in consumer buying plans is shared by Canadian economists.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 26 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold held off today any United Nations intervention in the crisis in the two-month-old West African Federation of Mali.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 -- Top leaders of the labor federation, with only one dissent, endorsed the Democratic Presidential ticket today. They called on their 13,500,000 members to give "full and unstinting" support to Senators John F. Kennedy and Lyndon B. Johnson.
MILWAUKEE, Aug. 26 (AP) -- Arnold Palmer and Fred Hawkins recorded five-underpar 65's today and shared the lead with Ken Venturi at the Milwaukee open.

ROME, Aug. 26. -- Chris vom Saltza of Saratoga, Calif., broke the Olympic women's 100-meter free-style swimming record today in qualifying for the semifinals during the opening heats. This was the first full day of Competition in the Olympic Games.
The American and Foreign Power Company, Inc., and subsidiaries reported yesterday that all financial statements had been muddled by the present uncertain situation in Cuba.

MOSCOW, Aug. 26 -- The Soviet Communist party gave its blessing today to Communist states and Communist groups that want to work with bourgeois factions in former colonial nations while they get on their feet.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 26 -- The getaway program of the ninety-third season of thoroughbred racing here will be headed by the richest running of the Hopeful Stakes. With eleven 2-year-old colts listed to compete tomorrow, the stakes will have a gross value of $119,350, with $76,602 going to the winner.
WESTPORT, Conn., Aug. 26 -- Lindsay Western was the only triple blue ribbon winner in the second program of the three-day Fairfield County Hunt Club's junior horse show today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 -- Following are the texts of President Eisenhower's foreign aid statement today and the letter he sent to Lyndon B. Johnson, Senate majority leader; Everett McKinley Dirksen, senate minority leader; Speaker of the House Sam Rayburn, and Charles A. Halleok, House minority leader:

Seovill Mfg. Co. Scovill Manufacturing Company, Waterbury, Conn., announced yesterday its purchase of the assets of the International Couplings, Inc., division of the Gabriel Company, Cleveland. Products formerly manufactured by International Couplings will be consolidated with the Scovill line of industrial couplings.
BOSTON, Aug. 26 (UPI) -- Frank Baumann, a Red Sox reject, kept the Chicago White Sox in the thick of the American League pennant race by beating his former mates, 9-2, at Fenway Park tonight.
SOUTHAMPTON, England, Aug. 26 (Reuters) -- A London business man who believe world shipping fares are t high has started a drive to " the man in the street" a chance to see the world.

SAN JOSE, Aug. 26 (AP) -- Chile was reported tonight to have wide support for a compromise resolution that would condemn Communist penetration in Latin America without naming Cuba as a base of operations.
MERIDIAN, Miss., Aug. 26 (UPI) -- A white minister who has been trying to build a Negro college in rural east Mississippi said today he had been severely beaten by a white mob.
New North River ship terminals that would cost $33,500,000 to build were proposed yesterday before the City Planning Commission by the Commissioner of Marine and Aviation, Vincent A.G. O'Connor.

WESTBURY, L.I., Aug. 26 -- Bye Bye Byrd became harness racing's biggest money-winner tonight while losing to his arch rival, Adios Butler, in the $15,000 free-for-all pace on the Roosevelt Raceway strip.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Your Aug. 22 editorial criticizens severely an exposition of his views on the Communist. philosophy recently released by Vice President Nixon. Your principal criticism is that the statement is guilty of an elementary error in assuming that use is made of the market principle in the guidance of production in the Soviet Union.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 (AP) -- The Labor Department calculated today that it costs, about $6,000 a year to maintain a city worker's family of four on a modest but adequate living level.
A DREAM house for the woman who is her own chief cook and bottle washer went on view yesterday at 400 East Thirty-fourth Street.

The International Business Machines Corporation has leased two floors in 787 United Nations Plaza for occupancy by its Systems Research Institute. The unit trains personnel to use computer systems to find solutions to complex business and scientific problems.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 -- The wage-hour bill remained locked in dispute today after a series of test votes in the conference committee of the Senate and the House of Representatives.

YESTERDAY (Aug. 26, 1960) THE PRESIDENT Presented Distinguished Service Award to Sumner Whittier, Administrator of Veterans Affairs; met with Cabinet; saw John Anderson, Republican nominee for Governor of Kansas; asked Congressional leaders to reject cuts made in compromise foreign-aid appropriation bill; flew to Gettysburg farm for afternoon visit.

By way of toughening themselves for whatever greater oreals might lie ahead, the Yanees engaged the Indians last night in a twilight-night double-leader at the Stadium that started at 6 P.M. and wound p at 12:58 this morning.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 26 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold sent his chief aide and trouble-shooter to the Congo tonight for a general survey of the situation.

MANY warm, sunny days remain before the season for picnicking is over. They might be the occasion for introducing al fresco fare that has some elements of surprise dishes usually not associated with picnics but highly suitable for such outings.

SUMMIT, N.J., Aug. 26 -- Par scowled at the competitors is Al Mengert won the New Jersey Professional Golfers Association championship today, The 31-year-old Echo Lake representative, a former Pacific Northwest amateur champion, added the crown to his New Jersey open title with a 72-hole score of 293 at the Canoe Brook Country Club.

The city's seven municipal colleges, already crowded and lacking space to meet growing demands for admission, submitted a proposed capital budget of $18,734,926 to the City Planning Commission yesterday.

TULSA, Aug. 26 (AP) -- Jean Ashley, a 21-year-old smooth-stroking school teacher from Chanute, Kan., continued her giant-killer role in the national women's amateur golf championship today with a 1-up semi-final victory over the Western champion, Mrs. Ann Casey Johnstone of Mason City, Iowa.
Stage and screen rights to "Romancero," a long-running Parisian play by Jacques Deval, have been purchased by Ray Stark.

ROME, Aug. 26 (AP) -- Lee Allen of Portland, Oregon, pinned J. Gregorio of Portugal in the Greco-Roman feather-weight class today in the opening bout of the Olympic wrestling competition. The time was 9 minutes 20 seconds.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 26 -- No matter who wins the Presidential election, the next national administration will be more vigorous in the civil rights field, a Catholic interracial conference was told here today.
A fence made of bubbles was erected yesterday off the beach at Sea Girt, N.J., where a swimmer's leg was ripped by a shark last Sunday.
Two New York City detectives told yesterday how they had read 175,000 letters in the files of the Department of Health to find a despondent woman who was threatening suicide.

BRIDGEHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 26 -- A field of more than 150 cars, entered in the second annual interclub championship races tomorrow and Sunday, received the customary registration and technical inspection today.

LONDON, Aug. 26 -- Begining on Oct. 1 the producing countries belonging to the Inernational Tin Council will be free to export any amount of tie mineral they choose, Georges Peter of France, chairman of he council, announced today.

CAPE CORAL, Fla., Aug. 26 -- Slow-talking, fast-driving Ennie Argence of New Orleans shot his new 266-cubic-inch hydroplane, Gunshy, over a one-kilometer straightaway at 123.593 miles an hour today as six world records were established in time trials.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 (AP) -- The Air Force research chief said today an attempt would be made in October to send a monkey or monkeys into orbit in space and bring them back safely to earth.
VANDALIA, Ohio, Aug. 26 (AP) -- Roy N. Foxworthy of Indianapolis ended a sixteen-year absence from trapshooting today by winning the sixty-first Grand American Handicap.

MOSCOW, Aug. 26 (UPI) -- A Polish-bom defector from the United States Army tonight accused ten United States Army officers, including a United States military attache here, of espionage activities against the Soviet Union.

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo Aug. 26 -- The Republic of the Congo is facing a shortage of 1500 teachers and educational administrators for its secondary, technical and teacher-training schools, which normally open Sept. 15.
LONDON, Aug. 26 -- Stock market prices receded slightly today on light profit taking in a quiet session.

REHOVOT, Israel, Aug. 26 -- A conference representing the world's scientific community and emerging states of Africa and Asia ended here yesterday with an acclamation of its own success and a demand for more meetings like it.
Commenting on the suit filed against it by Sol A. Dann and Sam A. Schwartzberg on Wednesday in Federal Court in New York, Chrysler Corporation said yesterday:
Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy announced yesterday that he was setting up a new plan to prevent the police sick-pay procedure from becoming a racket.
LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo Aug 26 -- Premier Patrice Lumumba declared today that United Nations forces would have to withdraw from the Congo as soon as the Belgian forces left.
NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 26 -- Louisiana's Attorney General walked angrily out of a Federal court hearing on New Orleans school integration today.

The first count of a six-count indictment charging violations of anti-trust and anti-racketeering laws in the wholesale distribution of newspapers and magazines was reinstated yesterday by the United States Court of Appeals.
Pravda, the Soviet Communist party newspaper, has given the first public indication that an apparent ideological conflict with Communist China is being taken to the Russian people.

A SECOND wild turkey season of three days has been declared in two counties of New York State and prospects look good for a wider spread in future years. The turkey population, gone altogether for many years, is returning steadily.

ROME, Aug. 26 (UPI) -- John Thomas, the world high jump record-holder from Boston University, treated members of the Russian track and field team to an eye-blinking performance today during an Olympic workout.

ROME, Aug. 26 (UPI) -- A 22-year-old Danish cyclist died in a hospital today after collapsing from sunstroke while competing in the Olympic 100-Kilometer team race, which was staged in 93-degree heat in the morning.

SHEBOYGAN, Wis., Aug. 26 -- The emotions that flared repeatedly in the stormy early months of the Kohler Company strike, turning brother against brother and fattier against son in bitterness and violence, seemed remote today.
TOKYO, Aug. 26 -- Premier Hayato Ikeda authorized Foreign Minister Zentaro Kosaka today to visit Seoul Sept. 6 to explore the possibilities of improving relations between Japan and South Korea.

The Wheeling Steel Corporation said yesterday that it would schedule a five-day suspension of steel production over the Labor Day holiday period at its Steubenville, Ohio, works, the company's only ingot mill.
The prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 3 points off to 2 points up yesterday. A point is equal to 5 cents a bale.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 26 -- Dr. Hilary Koprowski, one of the original developers of a live-virus poliomyelitis vaccine, challenged today the Government's exclusive endorsement of the vaccine produced by Dr. Albert Sabin of the University of Cincinnati.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 -- The United States broke off diplomatic relations with the Dominican Republic today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 -- Congress rejected a last-minute appeal by President Eisenhower today and passed a $3,722,350,000 foreign aid appropriation bill. This was $559,354,000 under the President's original request.

The line-up of Swiss-held stock in the fight for control of the Baltimore Ohio Railroad Was more confused than ever yesterday as a Swiss banker and an American railroad president offered opposite versions of conversations that they held this week in Zurich, Switzerland.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 -- The House Commerce Committee today approved legislation that would permit the Government to sell the General Aniline and Film Corporation, seized as German property during World War II.
The New York State Board of Regents yesterday substantially raised the minimum requirements for new high-school teachers in academic subjects in a drastic move to improve the quality of teaching.

THE needle-thin heel may be in with the women, but there are a few souls to whom these spiked pins are a destructive menace. Not only have the needle heels ruined linoleum, but the unmistakable imprint has been left on most tar roads.

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Aug. 26 -- Secretary of State Christian A. Herter proposed to the conference of foreign ministers of the Organization of American States today the creation of a commission to investigate Cuba's charges that the United States is preparing military aggression against her.
Since the Manufacturers Trust Company reduced its "prime" interest rate from 5 to 4 1/2 per cent, the city's (and the nation's) leading commercial banks have been falling into line.

Stocks as a whole moved down a little yesterday despite spectacular performances by TelAutograph, Comptometer and a double handful of other low price issues. Nine of the fifteen moat active stocks closed below $25 a share.

MOONACHIE, N.J., Aug. 26 -- This small borough, which is trying to collect $2,400 in taxes from the Port of New York Authority for an industrial building on the Teterboro Airport property, will ask the Superior Court whether the agency has the right to a tax exemption.

EUROPE'S largest folk carnival, the Munich Oktoberfest, will mark its 150th year Sept. 24-Oct. 9 with parades, horse races, fire-works and beer-drinking. On opening day the Lord Mayor of Munich personally will tap the first fifty-gallon, barrel of beer, of which several million gallons will have been consumed by celebrators by the time the festival ends.

FROM 1951 to 1957 jazz critic, editor and collector Fred Ramsey made five field trips in Alabama, Mississippi and New Orleans, recording and photographing the musical activity of the Southern Negro -- people, places and things.

ZION NATIONAL PARK, Utah -- A series of highway-improvement projects recently undertaken in this state has succeeded in neatly tying together Utah's two national parks and a pair of the state's seven national monuments and providing the motorist with a scenic, 316-mile tour.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Aug, 27 -- A degree of racial integration is scheduled to come to the Dollarway School District in southeastern Arkansas on Sept. 6 after a year and a half of court maneuvering.

VIENTIANE, Laos, Aug. 27 -- Even in Laos there are manifestations of the spirit and conditions that prevail in Communist China today. HELSINKI, Finland -- For the European tourist who is weary of crowds, reservations and bustle, a trip north of the Arctic Circle to Lapland offers welcome respite. Here he finds the air aromatic with the sweet smell of pines; he discovers lakes am rivers of untouched beauty; he learns that reindeer are familiar sights and the midnight sun is a summer reality.

Air-conditioned buses took 225 Puerto Ricans to central voter registration offices In Manhattan, Brooklyn and the Bronx yesterday morning. Most of the prospective voters found the literacy test was not the bogey they had feared.

ROME, Aug. 27 -- If the United States doesn't win the Olympic basketball championship every field house In America should be razed and every barn with a backboard on its front door should be burned to the ground. Department store sales in the nation in the week ended on Aug. 20 rose 5 per cent from the 1959 level, the Federal Reserve Board has reported. A week earlier there was a decline of 1 per cent from the year before.

THE design of the United States 4-cents stamp honoring Andrew Carnegie, Industrialist, philanthropist and the founder of the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, was announced yesterday by Postmaster General Arthur E. Summerfield.

There is little tranquility in the tranquilizer business these days.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 -- Every Presidential election creates some new historical precedent and this one is no exception. For it is the first time in the long story of the American Union when two men have run for the Presidency on the Jack Paar television show.
Two treasure-laden ships from Denmark will arrive here Tuesday with thousands of ancient and modem Danish art objects for a nation-wide exhibition in major museums.

A group of international investment houses are participating in a capital increase of a Peruvian installment credit and export-import financing concern, Peruano-Suiza de Fomento the Inversiones, S.A., Peruinvest.

LONDON, Aug. 27 (Reuters) -- Holdouts in the dwindling sixteen-day-old wildcat strike of British seamen were urged today to turn In their war medals in protest against an 1894 shipping act under which several strikers have been convicted in court.

PERTH AMBOY, N. J., Aug. 27 -- Toot Gonzalez of Manhasset Bay, L. I., held, the lead today after three races in the first annual international Blue Jay Class regatta on Raritan Bay.

BEDFORD HILLS, N.Y., Aug. 27 -- The New York Unit of the Herb Society of America, a nonprofit organization, will hold a benefit herb fair here on Sept. 24 at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Albert W. Moss, Broad Brook Road.
BOSTON, Aug. 27 -- Roy Sievers of Chicago took over the American League batting lead today as he and Sherm Lollar led the White Sox to a 9-6 victory over the Boston Red Sox. Each hit a home run.

AS an adventure story, "First Men to the Moon" is average but the book Is a standout, primarily because Wernher von Braun has brought his authority to it. Von Braun and his associates put up America's first satellite.

DETROIT, Aug. 27 -- A top Michigan Republican, who is a Roman Catholic, injected a religious note today in a gibe at Senator John F. Kennedy.

THE buyer of grass seed is protected by law against fraud and deception on the part of the seedsman. The seedsman welcomes legal control as a protection against unfounded claims. BY now, most Americans are aware of the ANTA tours. That is, they know that many United States musicians are going abroad on tours sponsored by the State Department and administered by the American National Theatre and Academy.
TEHERAN, Iran, Aug. 22 -- In one of the banks here, a young Iranian with a degree of doctor of philosophy works as a translator, dreaming of the day when he can go back to the United States.

ALBANY, Aug. 27 -- A study ordered by the Legislature on how to finance public schools has been delayed five months so far and probably will not be ready for the 1961 session.

HAS British novelist James Barlow ("One Half of the World") tried to write an English "Crime and Punishment"? His hero, Reg Mills, is an exparatrooper with bitter memories of Sicily and Arnhem. Driven by poverty and a desire to prove himself to a world that now rejects his toughness, he commits robbery and murder.
MONTICELLO, N.Y. -- It is an established fact that resorts in the southern Catskills long have been the proving ground for the many who seek recognition in the fields of show business and athletics.

INDUSTRY and agriculture are working side by side to give the lawnsman the kind of tools and seed that he needs. To date several new types of Kentucky bluegrass and fescue have reached the market and they are proving their worth by increased demand.

WILLIAMSPORT, Pa., Aug. 27 -- Joseph Mormello Jr., a 12-year-old athlete from Levittown, Pa., put his 108 pounds behind a strong right arm today and produced one of the finest performances in the history of the Little League world series.

KITCHAWAN, N.Y., Aug. 27 -- A search for hidden relationships between plant organisms and human welfare has been started at a new laboratory here of the Brooklyn Botanic Garden. A chief goal is to improve public health.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 -- For safety's sake, all civilian plane flights in the United States and Canada will be grounded for six early morning hours on Sept. 10 to make way for Operation Sky Shield, the first continent-wide test of North America's defenses against aerial attack.

ROME. ONE of the fastest-rising young film directors in Italy today is Mauro Bolognini. News that his most recent effort, "Il Bell' Antonio" ("Handsome Antonio"), won the Locarno Film Festival Grand Prix, therefore, came as no surprise to those who hold him in high esteem.

A PINNACLE in splendor was reached some years ago when His Highness the Maharajah of Patiala ordered six Rolls-Royces on a single sales slip. That regal gesture set off a discreet buzzing in such nobby locales as Mayfair, Deauville and St. Moritz.

A dozen teen-age rocketeers have built a missile they hope to blast up to 12,000 feet -- if they can find a suitable launching site.

POLLY BERGEN long ago discovered that the way to solve the problem of leisure time was not to have any. In the last fifteen years, she has been, more or less at the same time, a singer, actress, night-club entertainer, recording artist, television personality, a designer of custom-made carpets, partner in a dress-manufacturing concern, owner of a women's clothing shop and a dabbler in real-estate ventures.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 -- Voters in thirteen states will be deciding simultaneously in November on whether to adopt almost identical state constitutional amendments.

CAMBRIDGE, England. PARADOXES, like all violent contrasts, have always had a fascination for me, and that provides one reason for choosing just now to write about the Georgian poets. They lived and wrote in the calm before the storm, in an orderly and confident world, divided from ours by a barrier as real as that which separated the Middle Ages from the Renaissance, or the Age of Reason from the Industrial Revolution.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 27 -- Leonard Bernstein directed the New York Philharmonic orchestra and doubled as the piano soloist last night in the Civic Auditorium here. A standing-room-only throng greeted the visiting conductor's performance with wild enthusiasm.
MIAMI, Fla., Aug. 27 -- Construction on the new $20,000,000 Port of Miami is scheduled to start early this fall, Arthur Darlow, port director, reported this week.

HOLLYWOOD. TO THE AVERAGE filmgoer, the directorial device known as "the long master scene" has no meaning. But it has been the subject of considerable discussion among movie directors for some years cause of its artistic and economic influence on movie making.

CRABGRASS is abundant and obnoxious at this time of year. It is easily spotted in the lawn by its coarser, yellow leaf color and "chickenfoot" type of seedhead. With the arrival of cool weather, however, the crabgrass will turn purple-bronze and die with the first hard frost.
