Jet-watching is a new and popular spectator sport these days.
LIDINGO, Sweden, Aug. 8 -- An American sculptor has received "deeply moving" recognition in a garden of this seaside resort near Stockholm.

DETROIT, Aug. 28 -- The Chrysler Corporation issued a brief statement today criticizing an amendment to a stock-holders' suit filed against some of its officers and other companies in Wilmington, Del.

Basically, the mechanism of the Federal Reserve System is comparatively simple. When the system is pursuing a positive policy -- whether it be one of credit expansion or contraction -- it conducts its operation with the purpose in mind of either increasing or decreasing the nation's bank reserves, as the case may be.
STILLWATER, Okla., Aug. 28 -- Biologists were proudly examining copies of three new textbooks here today.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 28 -- The St. Louis Board of Education, rocked by scandal and torn by controversy, is taking steps to reorganize its administrative operations and restore public confidence in the system.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 -- A group of business men has urged the United States to think metropolitan.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Aug. 28 -- Leading nuclear physicists believe it would be both desirable and feasible to build accelerators three to ten times as powerful as the biggest of the giant atom smashers in existence today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 (AP) -- The Navy is preparing a force of men, ships and aircraft for its sixth consecutive Antarctic expedition. Work will start this year on an atomic power station to provide electricity for the permanent scientific exploration of the South Polar continent.

More than $6,000,000,000 in negotiable bonds and stocks was transferred between two offices of the Chemical Bank New York Trust Company yesterday in what the bank described as the largest transfer of securities ever reported.
Yesterday was the hottest day in New York this summer -- 89.2 degrees at 2:20 P.M.

IN the serenity of an East Forty-eighth Street brown-stone garden recently Russel Wright and one of his able assistants, Liz Constantine, were discussing what had happened to the United States Government's program for developing the crafts of Vietnam and Taiwan.
In its television coverage of early events of the Olympic Games over the week-end, the Columbia Broadcasting System has done an outstanding job.
TAIPEI, Taiwan, Aug. 28 -- The dispute between, the ruling Kuomintang and dissident politicians trying to form an opposition party appeared to have entered a new stage over the weekend.
The Great Mace and Civic Sword of the Ancient Corporation of the City of Galway will be returned to the Irish city after more than a century's absence.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 28 -- Steel men expect a moderate increase in the volume of orders over the next few weeks. Last week showed a little improvement from earlier in the month. But one has to look carefully to see any sign of a trend.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 28 (AP) -- Joe Cunningham's sacrifice fly in the fourth inning provided the margin today in a 5-4 victory by the St. Louis Cardinals over the Pittsburgh Pirates. The Cards thus swept the three-game series.
ENGLEWOOD, N.J., Aug. 28 -- Seventeen youths in a "burglary-for-kicks" gang were rounded up today. The police said they had amassed $10,000 in cash and jewelry in seventeen home and store break-ins.

THE dream of youngsters going to college is a financial nightmare for 13,000,000 American families. The problem of college funds for children rapidly is becoming a more perplexing one than ever before because of increasingly costly tuitions.
PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Aug. 28 -- The wind deserted the skippers of the Yacht Racing Association in today's regatta on Western Long Island Sound. Of the 135 sloops that started, only seven finished.
Fatigue finally overtook the Yankees yesterday. But only to the extent they had to settle for an even break in their third successive double-header.

ELISABETHVILLE, the Congo, Aug. 28 -- Congo Army units have moved to within twenty miles of the northern frontier of rebellious Katanga Province, a Katanga Army spokesman said today. He announced that Katanga's soldiers had advanced to the border to meet the threat.

NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 28 -- Louisiana segregationists remained adamant today against even token integration of New Orleans public schools next month despite a reaffirmed Federal Court order that the first grades must be integrated.
HYANNIS PORT, Mass., Aug. 28 -- Senator John F. Kennedy announced today creation of a New York State Committee of Business and Professional Men and Women for Kennedy-Johnson.

The state president of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People said yesterday that he had joined in applauding the New York City Housing Authority for its policy of promoting racial integration in housing projects.

The annual tide of tattered humanity that follows the harvest up the Atlantic seaboard has reached its high mark in New York and adjacent states. About 60,000 migrant farm workers -- men, women and teen-agers, and uncounted myriads of children -- have settled down for the duration of the "pickin' season."

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Aug. 28 -- Cuba walked out of the Conference of American Foreign Ministers tonight minutes before the conference unanimously voted a declaration that, in effect, censured her for accepting Soviet military aid.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 -- As Congress headed into the fourth, and possibly final, week of its pre-election session, Senate and House leaders prepared today to deal with foreign aid, a higher minimum wage and medical care for the aged.

Television will seek to prove conclusively that it does not dodge controversial issues when it presents two special programs within two days on a subject that always draws strong pro and con comment -- women's fashions.

The Time Is Almost Here It is almost time, now, to begin loading the family car with suitcases, tennis racquet, typewriter, clothing that will not fit into suitcases, books, blankets and such other gear as the young man of the house will need during the next eight months or so, and then to head the car in the direction of a certain university.
ROME, Aug. 28 -- "At the end of the race," said John Devitt of Australia, "I thought I was second, So I congratulated Lance Larson, climbed out of the water, and tried not to think about it.''
MOSCOW, Aug. 20 -- Despite recent difficulties in the Soviet-American exchange program, Russian scientists seem determined to keep the door to the West as wide open as possible.
Five films will arrive in local theatres this week. The program follows:

DAKAR, Senegal, Aug. 28 -- An American passing through Orly Airport in Paris last week saw an African from Guinea spot an African from British Sierra Leone'and walk to him across a waiting-room crowded with Frenchmen.
ROME, Aug. 28 -- The United States lost its protest today against the awarding of an Olympic gold medal to John Devitt of Australia.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 (AP) -- Senate investigators accused the Department of Agriculture today of inexcusable waste and lax attention to conflicts of interest in its grain storage program.
The Police Department began checking complaints yesterday that policemen illegally holding outside jobs have been working in union shops, even though they do not hold union cards.
Week Ended Aug. 26, 1960 During the past week in the foreign exchange market, the British pound sterling and the Canadian dollar continued to slump. A good volume of business was reported.
An off-Broadway waiter is getting ready to produce a revamped version of "A Tree Grows in Brooklyn."

Gerhart Reichlin of this city has received a maintenance fellowship from the Eugene F. Saxton Memorial Trust, which was established by Harper to enable promising writers to have free time in which to finish books.
Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 4 points up to 5 points off yesterday, with near months the steadiest. (A point equals 5 cents a bale.)

A number of changes in the direction of merchandising activities in the Lever and Pepsodent divisions of Lever Brothers Company were announced yesterday to meet the increase and diversification in the company's growing line of products.
A group of 100 New Jersey long-distance truck operators yesterday joined Teamster Union contract talks here for the first time.
An attempt will be made within the next few months to make a success of duckpin bowling in New York.
Youngstown, Ohio, is planning the sale of $6,000,000 of bonds on Sept. 20 to finance the construction of arterial highways. The obligations will come due serially from 1962 to 1986.
LAKE ALBANO, Italy, Aug. 29 (AP) -- Canoeists from the Soviet Union swept to three Olympic gold medals in seven events today.
NEW DELHI, India, Aug. 29 -- Gen. K.S. Thimayya, army Chief of Staff, has protested the publication in the United States of a book about his career.
A three-point program designed to improve rural conditions in Latin America was announced yesterday by the American International Association for Economic and Social Development.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 -- Vice President Nixon entered the Walter Reed Army Medical Center today with an infected knee that will require about two weeks of hospital treatment. All campaign appearances, including a Labor Day engagement in New York, will be canceled until the treatment is completed.
ROME, Aug. 29 -- "I've been up this early for golf," said Dutch Lonborg in a voice that seemed still half asleep, "but never in my life have I been up so early to watch basketball."
ROME, Aug. 29 -- Gary Tobian of Glendale, Calif., won the United States' first gold medal in the 1960 Summer Olympics today.
The New York Shakespeare Festival, which had been in the red for about $11,000, will be able to conclude its current season of free Shakespeare in Central Park on Saturday with all of its bills paid.
Mrs. Francis Gary Power arrived in New York from Paris yesterday, walked 100 feet from her jet airliner and collapsed.
DETROIT, Aug. 29 (AP) -- Auto production has passed its low point for the year and is headed upward.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 -- The State Department's experts in the Middle East expressed the view today that a wideranging plot against King Hussein might lie behind the bombing of the Jordanian Foreign Ministry.

A strike of 2,000 production and maintenance workers against five major baking concerns in the metropolitan area was settled yesterday morning with a wage increase. The workers began returning to their jobs immediately.
A report of frost damage to crops in Idaho spurred buying of Maine potato futures yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange. The volume was heavy, reaching 719 carlots of 50,000 pounds each.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 -- Following is a transcript President Eisenhower's informal talk today before the assembly session of the American Bar Association:

Who is the "Organisation Man?" College graduates hired last spring by large corporations are undoubtedly right at this moment, busy attempting to identify the number of "organization men" among their co-workers.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 -- President Eisenhower moved today to correct cumbersome proedures, unnecessary expense and delays in the administrative methods of independent Government agencies.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 -- The Government's short-term borrowing costs advanced slightly this week, for the fourth week in a row, contrary to the recent downward trend in other money rates.
MILWAUKEE, Aug. 29 (UPI) -- Larry Jackson of the Cardinals beat the Milwaukee Braves tonight, 3 -- 0, with a three-hitter that put St. Louis in second place in the National League.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Aug. 29 -- What is believed to be the largest and most powerful cosmic-ray shower ever observed was reported by the Massachusetts Institute of Technology today.

MIDDLETOWN, R.I., Aug. 29 -- The speaking schedule which will absent Senator Kennedy from Washington during most of the final phase of the bobtail session of Congress concludes the evidence of the great mistake of the Democratic leadership in convening it.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 -- State Department officials had scant hope today that Cuba would heed the plea of her sister nations in Latin America, to, negotiate her differences with the United States.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 29 (AP) -- The United States Third Circuit Court of Appeals stood firm today on its decision of last month requiring faster integration of Delaware's public schools.
WESTPORT, Conn., Aug. 29 -- The state police began a new drive this week to fake some of the roar out of Connecticut Turnpike traffic.
WASHINGTON, Aug 29 (AP) -- The Navy has dipped impartially into Civil War history to name two new guidedmissile ships.

The stickiness of bank lending rates has been puzzling economists and politicians. They note that the reduction last week in the prime rate from 5 to 4 1/2 per cent came seven months after interest rates generally began to turn downward and five months after the Federal Reserve began to lift its restraints on money.
A Norwegian doctor pleaded here yesterday for "real" acceptance of harmless differences and deviations in mankind.

PARIS, Aug. 29 -- The Air France crash off Dakar early today was said to have been the worst civil air disaster in French history. The four-engine plane left Paris last night with Dakar scheduled as the first stop.

SWEET corn is as important a part of the American summer scene as iced watermelon and blueberry pie. Although fresh corn is available virtually the year around now that Florida ships supplies north in winter, the vegetable is at its sweetest and best when it comes from near-by farms, as it does this month and next.

The New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad registered a net operating loss of $8,731,970 in the first seven months of this year and incurred a $3,847,636 deficit before fixed charges which amounted to $4,043,363 in the period.

The Kingdom of Jordan has a population of 1,500,000, of which a third are Palestine refugees who have no real loyalty to King Hussein. There are about 40,000 loyal nomads and about 100,000 nomads who are considered only partly, loyal.
Sixty scholars explored yesterday the role of ethics in modern large-scale organizations -- industrial, political and even academic.

STILLWATER, Okla., Aug. 29 -- A special kind of cold storage may be the answer to the problem of preserving living tissues for a long period of time, biologists were told, here today. Dr. Peter Mazur of the Biology Division of the Oak Ridge National Laboratory reported on studies of yeast cells at low temperatures.
IT is an open secret that the laws of Contract Bridge are "up for revision;" that is, the committees charged with making the laws are working on a new code to replace the present one.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, Aug. 21 -- At high levels of the new administration of President Victor Paz Estenssoro the possibility is being raised of wooing Antenor Patino, one of the socalled former "tin barons," to put capital back into Bolivia's sick tin industry.
LONDON, Aug. 29 (Reuters) -- Yorkshire today clinched the English county cricket championship for the second straight year by taking 4 points for a first-innings lead against Worcestershire.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 (AP) -- If the Echo I satellite seems to grow brighter or dimmer as you look at it that is not unusual, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration said today.

THE practice of inquiring into the makeup of an unusual man to find the core of his unusualness is a fascinating one, and some readers follow it tirelessly. It is best by far to do this with writers, for they provide a greater fund of subjective material than do musicians, painters or statesmen. Still, the quest, interesting though it may be along the way, must end up in failure.
Three walk-up apartment houses that form the corner of Brook Avenue and East 136th Street in the Bronx have been acquired by Geisinger Germain, real estate operators, from the Weisoll Realty Company.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Aug. 29 -- The Indonesian Army's current crackdown on the Communist party has spread to the southern half of the island of Celebes.

William Ewing's steady-going Four Lane again exhibited his attachment for the Aqueduct race track yesterday by winning the forty-seventh Fall High-weight Handicap. The race was the feature of Aqueduct's fall re-opening following the close of the Saratoga meeting.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., Aug. 29 -- A 17-year-old Long Island flying student took off last Thursday for an 800-mile flight to see his girl friend in Bay City, Mich. Instead, he landed in the arms of the Royal Canadian Mounted Police.

Automatic Retailers of America Automatic Retailers of America, Inc., a leading operator of vending machines, has an- nounced a merger with the Tennessee Service Company and its affiliates. Tennessee Service conducts vending machine operations in Tennessee, South Carolina, Georgia and Virginia.

TOKYO, Aug. 29 (UPI) -- Davey Moore, the fast-punching and fancy-stepping world featherweight champion, retained his title tonight with an easy fifteen-round victory over Kazuo Takayama, a Japanese challenger.
The Philips Incandescent Lamp Works (N.V. Philips' Gloeilampenfrabrieken), showed a sharp increase in sales and earnings for the six months ended on June 30, according to the report issued yesterday.
Midsummer madness is having its innings. Baseball fans are clanging bells in Pittsburgh, throwing ripe tomatoes in Kansas City and catching foul balls with fishermen's nets in Los Angeles.

The return movement of American tourists from Europe gathered momentum yesterday, the first big dayof the week before Labor Day, the traditional end-of-summer rush period. More than 9,000 persons debarked from airliners and ships some of which were slightly delayed by morning fog.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 -- Lord Evershed, a leading British Judge, told his American and British legal colleagues tonight that the courts should have greater freedom in interpreting statutes.
SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Aug. 29 -- The Organization of American States adjourned its conference of foreign ministers today after having signed the Declaration of San Jose.
SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 29 -- A rookie right-hander, Art Mahaffey shut out San Francisco on two singles tonight as the Philadelphia Phillies scored a 2-0 victory over the Giants.

WESTBURY, L.I., Aug. 29 Pacing on the outside for more than three-quarters of a mile to gain the lead, Adios Paul, a 5-year-old bay son of Adios, scored a neck victory over Blending Well in 2:00 1/5, paying $4 as the favorite before 20,576 fans at Roosevelt raceway tonight.

ROME, Aug., 23 (AP) -- Italy opened an Inquiry today into the death of a young Danish cyclist in a sixty-two-mile Olympic race. The investigation will take several weeks, but the outcome already seems clear.
AMMAN, Jordan, Aug. 29 -- Premier Hazza Majali and ten other persons were killed today when time bombs exploded in Government offices. Forty-one other persons were wounded.

Stocks had a ragged time of it yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. There were a lumber of strong gains, but the list as a whole moved lower, nore stocks fell than rose and volume failed to pick up.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 -- Senator Mike Mansfield, assistant majority leader in the Senate, proposed today that the United States seek an agreement with the Soviet Union to keep Africa clear of military bases of either country.

LEOPOLDVILLE, Aug., 29 (AP) -- Dr. Ralph J, Bunche, just after visiting eight United States, airmen and two Canadians who he said had "had the hell beaten out of them," said today he believed he had never been any place where misunderstanding is so deep as in the Congo.

BOGOTA, Colombia, Aug. 29 -- The third of the current round of inter-American conferences, this one concentrating on economic problems, will open here next Monday with Under Secretary of State Douglas Dillon heading the United States delegation.

CHICAGO, Aug. 29 (AP) -- Grain futures came under fairly general selling in late dealings today on the Board of Trade and prices weakened in all commodities. All of the market closed at the day's lows.
Steel production this week should show a slight decline from last week's level, the American Iron and Steel Institute said yesterday.
WILMINGTON, Del., Aug. 29 -- The Chrysler Corporation today filed a $30,000,000 libel and slander suit against Sol A. Dann, Detroit lawyer and Chrysler stockholder.

BALTIMORE, Aug. 29 (UPI) -- Jack Fisher shut out the Chicago White Sox, 4 -- 0, on four hits tonight and raised the Baltimore Orioles to within one and a half games of the idle first-place New York Yankees.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 (UPI) -- Senator Joseph C. O'Mahoney made his last speech on the Senate floor today.

CHICAGO, Aug. 29 (AP) -- Golden Notes, a 6-year-old gelding owned by the King Ranch, defeated Calumet Farm's favored On-and-On by one length in the $15,625 Mrytlewood Handicap in Arlington Park today.
THE PRESIDENT Addressed Assembly of American and British bar associations. Held reception for them on White House lawn.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 (AP) -- Jim (Mudcat) Grant of Cleveland, who does it with clocklike regularity, tonight defeated Washington again. The score was 6 -- 4.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 -- President Eisenhower, appealed today for removal of the limits on this country's adherence to the International Court of Justice.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 (UPl) -- Republicans conceded today, in response to Democratic taunts, that different versions of their party's civil rights plank were in circulation. They said, however, that it was all a mistake.
STANLEYVILLE, the Congo, Aug. 29 -- Premier Patrice Lumumba appeared to be changing his dominant theme here today after weeks of violent incitement of the Congolese to hunt "Belgian spies."
ROME, Aug. 29 (AP) -- American athletes showed strong resentment today over what they called a growing "anti-American" and "knock down the Yanks" sentiment in the Olympics.
The giant unions of the future will cover many industries, be highly centralized and increasingly dominated by white-collar workers, two University of Illinois sociologists said yesterday.
The city's Commission on Intergroup Relations is urging members of the Board of Education to join it in meeting with citizen groups on the problem of racial integration in the public schools.

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Aug 29 -- Foreign Minister Raul Roa of Cuba, declared today that the Declaration of San Jose "constitutes a deliberate attack against Cuba intended to deliver Cuba, tied hand and foot, into the voracious jaws of North American imperialism, which word by word dictated its terms."
IF American teen-agers have any romantic illusions about Frenchmen, they should not be disenchanted by Jacques Esterel, who now is in the United States.
ROME, Aug. 29 (AP) -- Four members of the United States track and field team turned up with mild viruses today with the start of the Olympic competition in that sport only two days away.

COLD SPRING HARBOR, L.I., Aug. 29 -- Richard Bensen and Tom Strafaci scored 32, 31 -- 63, eight strokes under par, and won the Long Island Professional Golfers' Association amateur-pro tournament at the Cold Spring Country Club today.

The American Research Bureau, an organization that supplies audience measurements of television broadcasts and markets, has taken a lease on 1,900 square feet on the fourteenth floor of the General Dynamics Building at 1 Rockefeller Plaza, according to Rockefeller Center, Inc.
A freighter and a Hudson River ferryboat with 700 aboard collided in a lifting fog yesterday morning. Thirteen ferry passengers were injured, none seriously.

HOUSTON, Tex., Aug. 29 -- Mrs. Lyndon B. Johnson, the wives of several members of Congress, and two women relatives of Senator John F. Kennedy began a 1,200-mile tour of Texas today. They encountered a serious problem in the weather.
MANY men have founded political parties, but few can claim the distinction of Dr. Manouchehr Eghbal. He sponsored his own party and its opposition.

The Graham-Paige Corporation, an investment company, reported yesterday unaudited net income for the first six months of this year at $204,116. The figure included the operations of the Madison Square Garden Corporation, which was merged into Graham-Paige as an operating division on April 20.

NEW HAVEN, Aug. 29 -- The New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad reported today that it needed $24,500,000 yearly to rehabilitate its passenger fleet and provide "comfortable and efficient" service.
NEW DELHI, Aug. 29 -- The Indian Government warned Western oil companies today to "consider seriously" a further reduction in prices of crude oil imported by them into this country.

The Lehigh Valley Railroad, which has been carrying passengers for more than a hundred years, intends to discontinue the last of its passenger runs Oct. 1. The Interstate Commerce Commission could delay this for three more months.

NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 29 -- A Federal judge took under advisement today a request by the New Orleans School Board that he permit it more time to present an acceptable school integration plan. Members of the board expressed optimism that their request would be granted.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 29 (UPI) -- Hal Smith's three-run homer, his seventh this season against Los Angeles, sparked the Pittsburgh Pirates to a 10-2 victory tonight, snapping a four-game losing streak and bringing Vern Law his nineteenth triumph.
The directors of Seeman Brothers, Inc., and of the Seabrook Farms Company have approved an agreement providing for the merger of Seabrook into Seeman, it was announced yesterday.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: On Aug, 10 The Times reported on protests against discrimination in the city's public schools, mentioning that "the assignment of teachers was also discussed," and adding that "many Negroes and Puerto Ricans have charged that the schools in their areas have a higher proportion of inexperienced and substitute teachers."

ATLANTIC CITY, Aug. 29 (AP) -- Bald Eagle of the United States and Tulloch of Australia were rated the world's outstanding horses by Handicapper James P. Ross, Jr. today when he listed weights for the Sept. 17 running of the $100,000 United Nations Handicap here.
Ambassadors to the United Nations will be guests of honor at the second annual Salute to the United Nations Ball. Mrs. Perle Mesta is chairman of the event, to be held Oct. 25 at the Waldorf-Astoria.
SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 29 -- A new national Blue Cross structure was established today. It will become effective on Oct. 1.
Governor Rockefeller and Mayor Wagner engaged in a political debate yesterday without appearing on the same platform at the same time or seeing each other face to face.
The 1946 debate over compulsory Jurisdiction of the World Court embroiled many leading Americans concerned with world affairs.

CARACAS, Venezuela, Aug. 29 -- The withdrawal of Dr. Ignacio Luis Arcaya as head of the Venezuela delegation to the San Jose foreign ministers' conference aroused considerable excitement here, but it did not point to any immediate break in Venezuela's coalition Government.

Gains in industrial output by Western Europe's two trade blocs from 1954 to 1959 were more rapid than in the United States and Canada, according to an analysis by the National Industrial Conference Board.
LUANG PRABANG, Laos, Aug. 29 -- King Savang Vathana called today upon Prince Souvanna Phouma to form a new government in Laos.
Trading in United States Government securities and other high-grade debt obligations was listless yesterday.
CHICAGO, Aug. 29 -- Hilton Hotels Corporation today announced a gain in revenues but a dip in net earnings in the first half of 1960.
HAVANA, Aug. 29 -- The United States and Latin-American government were bitterly denounced today by the Government-controlled press and radio.
DAKAR, Senegal, Aug. 29 -- An Air France Super-Constellation from Paris crashed into the sea a mile off the West African city of Dakar this morning. All sixty-three persons on board were killed.

SALT LAKE CITY. Led by Lieut. Gen. Bernard A. Schriever, who commands the Air Force air research and development force, and Dr. Richard S. Morse, director of research and development for the Army, with a score of military leaders and civilian production experts have been touring the nation's new solid fuel missile complex.

Net income of the Southern Pacific Company declined in July to $3,655,472 from $5,208,687 in the 1959 month, the road announced yesterday. Gross operating revenues were $54,957,280 and $61,552,809 in the respective months.
BOSTON, Aug. 29 (AP) -- Frank Malzone and Lou Clinton crashed second-inning home runs tonight and paced the Boston Red Sox to a 4-1 victory over the Kansas City Athletics.
KOHLER, Wis., Aug. 29 -- Since Friday, the telephone in the office of Local 833 of the United Auto Workers Union in near-by Sheboygan has rung repeatedly.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., Aug. 29 -- Electric power failed today in several Westchester commuities, halting refrigerators and air conditioners as the temperature soared to 90 degrees -- the county high for the year.
DAKAR Senegal, Aug. 29 -- West African leaders are trying to work out new political and economic alliances in the great sweep of jungle and desert that was once the heart of French African empire.

As Congress presses for adjournment two Federal aid to education bills remain in the cold storage of the House Rules Committee. The Senate measure would provide $1,800,000,000 over two years for school construction and teachers' salaries. The House bill authorizes $1,300,000,000 over four years for construction only.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 29 -- The top executives of the Pennsylvania Railroad held "harmonious" talks today with the heads of two unions in an effort to avert a system-wide strike set for 12:01 A.M. Thursday.
JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Aug. 29 (AP) -- A young Negro was killed and another hurt in a new outbreak of violence tonight in Jacksonville.
THE following menu is suggested as a guide to the use of foods that are reasonable in cost. A recipe is given for an easy-to-prepare main dish.
LEONIA, N.J., Aug. 29 -- Leonia officials expressed doubt tonight that seventeen youths in a "burglary for kicks" gang had planned their crimes in the Leonia Recreation Center.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The letter of Norman Thomas printed on Aug. 17 raises some very important questions both as to the policies of the Communist-controlled states and of universal disarmament.

GREENWICH, Conn., Aug. 29 -- A birdie 3 on the first hole to day gave Pat Circelli of the Cross County Driving Range and Nick Perri of the Harrisson Country Club first prize in the Westchester County Golf Association's pro-amateur event at the Tamarack Country Club.
JERUSALEM, (Israel Sector), Aug. 29 -- The High Court of Israel lifted today an injunction by which it had earlier obstructed the election of a new Chief Rabbinate.

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Aug. 29 -- Dr. Ralph J. Bunche, ending his mission as Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold's personal representative in the Congo, said today that never before had so much patience and effort been required of the United Nations.
LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Aug. 29 -- All Belgian combat troops will be withdrawn from the Congo "by dawn tomorrow," Under Secretary Ralph J. Bunche of the United Nations said here today.

The first private export sale of nuclear fuel elements from Canada will be made to the Japan Atomic Energy Research Institute by AMF Atomics Canada, Ltd., Port Hope, Ont. This was announced yesterday by Moorehead Patterson, chairman of the board of the American Machine Foundry Company, parent organization of AMF Atomics Canada.
PORTHCAWL, Wales, Aug. 29 (UPI) -- Dick Richardson of Wales retained his European heavyweight boxing title tonight when Brian London retired in the eighth round of their scheduled fifteen-rounder.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 -- A bipartisan coalition voted 56 to 31 in the Senate today to provide an additional $190,000,000 in foreign aid funds.

Ordinarily the big textile and fiber manufacturers are heavy advertisers, and apparel manufacturers who use their products go along for the ride, contributing the lesser portion of the expenditure on advertising of the finished goods.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 29 -- Marilyn Monroe was hospitalized late last night and the movie on which she was working was virtually halted. The actress was said to be suffering from exhaustion.

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Aug. 29 (AP) -- Eight crewmen of a United States Globemaster and two Canadian technicians beaten by a Congolese mob in Stanleyville Saturday were listed in good or fair condition today.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Aug. 29 (AP) -- Wasfi El Tal, Jordan's Director of National Guidance, said in Beirut today that it had been the Premier's day to see people in his office.
A study of the life of an actual American family's life since the turn of the century will be the subject of a forthcoming National Broadcasting Company telecast.

Although nearly every monthly release by the Bureau of Labor Statistics shows the consumer price index at a new all-time high, this much, at least, must be said for these reports. Their resourcefulness in discerning the brighter spots in what some observers regard as a picture of unbroken dreariness seems at times to be virtually boundless.

THE game-law violation market is remaining firm under steady selling and brisk profit-taking by the state, with general advances over the list and sharp rises in selected violations. Volume is down as compared to sales of a year ago, but receipts register a heartening gain.
ROME, Aug. 29 -- The doping of bike racers in Europe has been going on for years. It probably will continue.
The H.J. Heinz Company has bought 114-year-old Reymer Bros., Inc., Pittsburgh manufacturer of fruit-base drinks. The transaction involves about $1,000,000 in stock.

OAKLAND, Calif., Aug. 29 (AP) -- Maxim Radin, an 80-year-old barber, couldn't find his way back to his New York hotel last week. He had more than $15,000 in a valise there, but couldn't remember the name of the place.
General of the Army Omar N. Bradley announced plans yesterday for publication of an authorized biography of the late Gen. George C. Marshall.
CAMDEN, N.J., Aug. 29 -- Six persons were killed and two others critically hurt late today when two autos collided head-on on the White Horse Pike at Chesilhurst, twenty-miles south of here.
A suspended patrolman accused of having worked on outside jobs while on sick leave was dismissed from the force yesterday.

CIUDAD TRUJILLO, Dominican Republic, Aug. 29 -- An anti-Trujillo paper hawked on a main street here tonight warned the Trujillo regime that unless it permitted the people to recover "their liberties and rights" through democratic processes, the country "will be converted to a land of terror and bloodshed."

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Aug. 29 -- The proton, one of the fundamental building blocks of matter, appears to be a diffuse cloud of magnetism surrounding a hard core of electric charge, according to a report here today.
The wheels of the auction market maintained by the New York Stock Exchange ground to a halt yesterday for the common stock of the TelAutograph Corporation.
TEHERAN, Iran, Aug. 29 -- Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi accepted the resignation of Premier Manouchehr Eghbal today in a political crisis over charges that the recent national elections had been rigged.
SOMETHING has gone wrong with the projected fishing statistics, lovely as they are, and it would be nice if the amateur statisticians would attack the pros, defeat them, and straighten us all out.
The steamship industry said yesterday that the Government's offer to have a private steamship line act as agent for the Government-owned Panama Line was unrealistic.
CHICAGO, Aug. 30 -- The path a mysterious reddish object took through the sky Friday night was reconstructed from memory tonight by two men who had seen it.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 (AP) -- Nelson Fox bounced a ground-rule double into the right-field stands in the tenth inning tonight to drive in two runs and an error by Billy Gardner let two more score to give the White Sox an 11-10 victory over the Washington Senators.

An issue of $125,000,000 of long-term debentures of the Republic Steel Company will be offered for public subscription today by a syndicate of investment banking houses headed by the First Boston Corporation and Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Smith, Inc.
BALTIMORE, Aug. 30 (AP) -- Chuck Estrada held the Cleveland Indians to four hits tonight in pitching a 4-1 victory, his fifteenth of the season.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 -- Three more Atlas intercontinental ballistic missiles were declared combat-ready in Cheyenne, Wyo., today in the lagging ICBM base-construction program.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 -- Under the steaming Washington sun this afternoon the president-elect of the American Bar Association, John Creighton Satterfield, was asked how the weather compared in his native Mississippi.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., Aug. 30 -- In the hope of bolstering sales, which this year fell behind 1959, the Studebaker-Packard Corporation will add a luxury V-8 compact to its 1961 line. The company has also developed a new OHV, or overhead valve, power plant for its austerity six-cylinder Lark.
About 150 persons were treated for heat exhaustion as a result of an hour-and-forty-minute tie-up on the IND subway in the Fifty-third Street tunnel under the East River.

CARACAS, Venezuela, Aug. 30 -- The three-party coalition Government appeared today to be able to survive Venezuela's latest crisis, but the impasse with regard to Foreign Minister Ignacio Luis Arcaya remained unresolved.
PEIPING, Aug. 30 (Reuters) -- A leading Chinese historian warned the Communist world today that "imperialism will not stop making trouble until its death."
SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 30 (AP) -- Sam Jones struck out fourteen batters and drove in the winning run today as the San Francisco Giants beat the Philadelphia Phils, 2 -- 1.
The fall movie season is off to a lively start on the local scene with the booking of six new features at various showcases.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Aug. 30 -- Princess Wilhelmina, who reigned as Queen of the Netherlands from 1898 to 1948 and then chose to retire to her present rank, will celebrate her eightieth birthday tomorrow.
AMMAN, Jordan, Aug. 30 -- King Hussein said tonight that "responsible authorities in the United Arab Republic, mainly in Syria," had advance knowledge of the plot to assassinate Premier Hazza Majali.

MILWAUKEE, Aug. 30 (AP) -- Warren Spahn hurled the fiftieth shutout of his career with a five-hitter as the Milwaukee Braves broke out of a batting slump for a 10-0 victory over the St. Louis Cardinals tonight.
MOSCOW, Aug. 30 -- Premier Khrushchev said today he would favor as the next President of the United States a man who followed a policy of improving American-Soviet relations.
A personalized fashion advisory service is being offered by designer Stephanie Koret of California to assist women with their wardrobe problems.
LUANG PRABANG, Laos, Aug. 30 (Reuters) -- The new neutralist Premier, Prince Souvanna Phouma, broadened his Cabinet tonight to include five members of the pro-Western regime ousted in a coup Aug. 9.

DU QUOIN, Ill., Aug. 30 -- A fortnight or so ago, the thirty-fifth Hambletonian was rated wide open. But when the blue ribbon event for 3-year-old trotters is staged here tomorrow, there will be a solid favorite -- the high-stepping, fastmoving Uncle Sam.
A large area of the lower West Side was blacked out for twenty-five minutes last night as a result of a power failure that also temporarily interrupted national news wires.
If Southern whites knew what Negroes really want, white resistance to change and racial tension might be lessened, two Southern sociologists said here yesterday.
ROME, Aug. 30 -- The stars and stripes was raised twice in victory ceremonies tonight as United States swimmers won two gold medals and broke three olympic records to the cheers of 15,000 spectators.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 (AP) -- The civilian space agency said today the Echo I satellite was now "blacked out" by the earth's shadow for about twenty-seven minutes of each 118minute circuit around the globe.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 -- A Senate-House conference on differing minimum wage bills collapsed today, apparently killing any prospects for such legislation this year.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Whatever day this letter is read the chances are that the front page of The New York Times on that morning will have carried a story about some anti-American activity somewhere in the Caribbean or Central America.

The bombing in which Premier Hazza Majali of Jordan and ten others were killed was, indeed in President Eisenhower's words, "a wanton criminal act." There can be no justification for such a horrible deed, and the sympathy that Mr. Eisenhower expressed to King Hussein will certainly be shared by all Americans.

Atlanta, Ga., borrowed $12,725,000 in the bond market yesterday to finance public improvements. The money was raised by the sale of general obligations due serially from 1960 to 1986 to a syndicate headed by Chase Manhattan Bank, First National City Bank of New York and the Trust Company of Georgia.
Mayor Wagner pledged yesterday that the city, as a tenement landlord, would henceforth live up to the standards it has imposed with increasing vigor on the owners of private slum dwellings.
The Anderson-Prichard Oil Corporation announced yesterday plans to dispose of its producing properties and other assets in a transaction involving four companies.
Senator John F. Kennedy conceded yesterday that there was now no change of passing major social legislation at the present pre-election session of Congress.

Creative Telefilms and Artists, Ltd., of Toronto has leased a large part of a floor in the new Union Carbide Building, 270 Park Avenue, at Forty-seventh Street, for the distribution of its new film library to the television industry.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 -- Senator John F. Kennedy set up a four-man group of national security experts today to advise him as President-elect if he should win in November.

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo Aug. 30 -- The pan-African conference meeting here decided today to urge Premier Patrice Lumumba to maintain "close cooperation with the United Nations." This became known as it was announced that the last Belgian combat troops had left the secessionist province of Katanga.

YESTERDAY (Aug. 30, 1960) THE PRESIDENT Had breakfast with Republican Congressional leaders; saw Robert Cutler, executive director of the Inter-American Development Bank; sent personal condolence message to King Hussein on the assassination of the Jordanian Premier; visited Vice President Nixon at Walter Reed Army Medical Center.

While Wall Street continued to focus attention yesterday on the stocks of the TelAutograph Corporation and the Comptometer Corporation, the two companies quietly continued their work of several years on devices that touched off the furor.

In the most forthright step yet to bring about the expansion of major league baseball, the American League voted unanimously yesterday to increase its membership from eight to ten teams no later than the 1962 season.
Last night's subway tie-up recalled the historic subway jam created in July of 1956 when the old John Wanamaker department store burned.
CASTEL GANDOLFO, Italy, Aug. 30 (AP) -- It was a black day for the United States at the opening of the Olympic rowing competition on Lake Albano today.
The Union Bag-Camp Paper Corporation announced yesterday that it had abandoned its $156,000,000 project to acquire the Crossett Company, a leading Southern manufacturer of forest products.
A judge held here yesterday that the constitutional right of free speech could not be invoked to permit Nazi advocates of violence to make public speeches in New York City.
Traffic in Queens became one giant snarl yesterday as short, violent rainstorms flooded parkways, disrupted power and caused at least two deaths.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 -- United States exports held steady in July, which is better than usual for the month, the Department of Commerce reported today.

Another World Congress It is almost a full century since a group of kind-hearted citizens organized the New York Society for the Relief of the Ruptured and Crippled and established a special hospital in the city, now the Hospital for Special Surgery.

A corporation headed by Samuel Silk and William Halpern has subleased the twelve-story bank and office building at 3 West Fifty-seventh Street from the Greenwich Savings Bank. As part of the deal, the bank leased back the space it occupies for a branch In the basement and on the first and second floors.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Aug. 29 -- The special congress of the Nationalist party in Bloemfontein foreshadows a bitter political fight on whether South Africa should become a republic even at the risk of losing membership in the British Commonwealth and valuable tariff concessions.

QUALITY, relatively easy to judge in fresh foods, often is difficult to discern in commercially frozen products. Shoppers, especially working wives who rely heavily on frozen foods for quick meals, might keep the following suggestions in mind:

ROME, Aug. 30 -- If Parry O'Brien had not opened his big mouth once too often, he would have a far better chance of winning his third Olympic shot-putting championship than he will have tomorrow. That's when this international festival for the glorification of muscles reaches the main part of the ritual, track and field.
CHICAGO, Aug. 30 (AP) -- Ernie Banks' thirty-seventh homer of the year, leading off the last half of the ninth inning, powered the Chicago Cubs to a 5-4 victory over the Cincinnati Reds today.
The Air Force has yielded to Civil Aeronautics Board demands for minimum rates paid to commercial airlines for hauling military passengers overseas, it was reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 -- Senator Estes Kefauver charged in the Senate today that "the country is being flooded with false and libelous anti-Catholic materials" intended to defeat John F. Kennedy, the Democratic Presidential nominee.

The stock market retreated on a broad front yesterday, giving up about $3,400,000,000 in paper values. The decline, the fourth in a row, affected just about every major group, although scattered specialties resisted the general sell-off.

The Carrier Corporation yesterday reported that its earnings for the fiscal quarter ended on July 31 were $4,083,000, equal to $1.48 a common share. This was in sharp contrast to the net loss of $1,530,000 incurred in the previous quarter, when operations were affected by strikes at the company's Syracuse plants and those of its Elliott Company division.
The Transit Authority signed contracts yesterday with the St. Louis Car Company for the purchase of 260 subway cars at a cost of $32,100,000.

HAVANA, Aug. 30 -- Premier Fidel Castro said today that Cuba would continue to depend on the "rocket support" of the Soviet Union against the "imperialistic United States" despite the declaration of the foreign ministers of the Organization of American States.
LOS ANGELES, Aug. 30 (UPI) -- Elroy Face of the Pittsburgh Pirates checked a Los Angeles rally in the eighth inning tonight and saved a 5-2 victory for Bob Friend.

Teamster Union negotiations for an area-wide contract covering 60,000 long-distance truck drivers were extended yesterday for forty-eight hours past the expiration of the old pacts at midnight tonight.
Barber Oil Company Directors of Barber Oil Corporation have declared a 2 per cent stock dividend payable on Jan. 2, 1961, to stockholders of record of Dec. 9.

"Sea Bears: The Story of the Fur Seal" is told by Fredericka Martin in a book that will be published Sept. 13 by the Chilton Company of Philadelphia. The author tells of the seal's migratory characteristics, sex life, herds and harems and how the herds in the Aleutians and Pribiflofs were brought to the threshold of extinction by fortune hunters until Congress put a stop to the slaughter.
LONDON, Aug. 30 -- Share prices drifted lower in a dull stock market here today. Only South African gold-mine shares displayed any confidence.

ROME, Aug. 30 (UPI) -- Max Ritter of the United States Olympic Committee tonight branded the Olympic swimming judges "a bunch of timid, unemployed pussy-footers" and was backed by the American diving coach, Sammy Lee, who said that there were two standards -- American vs. world.

ROME, Aug. 30 (AP) -- Bob Beck, a bespectacled 23-year-old Navy lieutenant from San Diego, captured the individual lead among fifty-eight athletes in the Olympic modern pentathlon today after the fourth event, swimming.

Alfred E. Perlman, president of the New York Central Railroad still asserts that he has "neutralized" three big Swiss commercial banks in the battle for control of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad that the Central is waging against the Chesapeake and Ohio Railroad, But the Swiss bank that is the biggest foreign holder of B. O. shares and second largest after Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner and Smith, Inc., still is contradicting Mr. Perlman.

Trading stamps are riding high. The Trading Stamp Institute of America reports that 77 per cent of the country's households save stamps of one kind or another. The figure is 10 per cent more than in 1959, with the trading stamp companies expected to gross $600,000,000 this year, a rise of $50,000,000, and the number of retailers handling the stamps up 5 per cent.
Channel 13's drama series, "The Play of the Week," will return to television here on Sept. 19.

The widely accepted fiction that New York State "elects" most of its judges has again been exposed as myth. A news story in The Times revealed that Joseph T. Sharkey, Democratic leader of Kings County, and John R. Crews, Republican leader, had reached an agreement to bestow the nomination for a full fourteen-year term in the Supreme Court on Justice Lewis W. Olliffe, now sitting briefly in that court by appointment of Governor Rockefeller.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 -- Secretary of State Christian A. Herter returned early this morning from San Jose, Costa Rica, and pronounced the conference of American foreign ministers an unquestioned success.

For one minute yesterday the New York Stock Exchange succeeded in maintaining a market in one of its most spectacular performers of late -- the common stock of the TelAutograph Corporation. No trading at all was permitted in the shares of the Comptometer Corporation, another stock that has been actively traded recently.
EAST MEADOW, L.I., Aug. 30 -- A high school graduation ceremony was held at the Nassau County Jail here today.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I do not know James B. Osgood, whose letter you published regarding a letter by President Gideonse of Brooklyn College, who spoke out his views on the action of the Senate Internal Security in connection with Linus Pauling.
CHICAGO, Aug. 30 (AP) -- A bearish feeling crept through the grain futures market today and turned prices sharply lower again in spots on the Board of Trade.

Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 1 point up to 8 points off yesterday. A point equals 5 cents a bale.

CIUDAD TRUJILLO, Dominican Republic, Aug. 30 -- A small private group of supporters of Generalissimo Rafael Leonidas Trujillo Molina urged President Joaquin Balaguer today to resign in favor of the Generalissimo.
After a fairly firm opening, prices of United States Government securities began sliding yesterday and continued a moderate decline through a day of little activity.

ROME, Aug. 30 (AP) -- An official of the Philippines amateur athletic federation warned today that Asia might not send basketball players to future olympics and world meets unless something was done about the disparity in height among players of various nations.

There is no end in sight to new fibers, new fabrics, new blends, new treatments and new applications. At any rate, it seems so, and the laboratories of fiber producers and fabric manufacturers are working long hours to that end.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 -- The two missing mathematicians employed by the National Security Agency went to the Soviet Union with valuable cryptographic information, Representative John W. McCormack of Massachusetts charged today.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Aug. 30 -- Nuclear physicists may have to lift their experimental devices about 115,000 feet into the sky to solve a new puzzle uncovered in cosmic-ray research, a physicist said here today.
A deputy inspector of detectives was reduced to captain and suspended without pay yesterday in the inquiry into charges of police involvement with tow-truck operators.
Close to 100,000 homeward-bound New Yorkers were stranded or delayed during the evening rush hour yesterday when flash floods caused by the afternoon's heavy rains tied up subways in Queens.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 30 -- The Transport Workers Union reported today that negotiations to avert a system-wide strike on the Pennsylvania Railroad Thursday at 12:01 A.M. were "hopelessly deadlocked."
Kansas City, which in recent years has come to be regarded as an ace in the hole for the Yankees, put in another evening of utter frustration against the Bombers at the Stadium last night.
The Spence-Chapin Adoption Service will benefit from two preview theatre parties this autumn.

INWOOD, L.I., Aug. 30 -- Mrs. Bernard Freeman, Inwood, and Mrs. Murray Gordon, Harbor Hills, were the winners of the John B. Mackie memorial tournament conducted by the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association at the Inwood Country Club today.
CHICAGO, Aug. 30 (AP) -- Butcher hog prices suffered their sharpest loss in almost a month of steady decline today as prices slipped as much at 50 cents a hundred pounds.
OCEAN CITY, N.J., Aug. 30 -- A Korean medical student had his leg severely torn by a shark early tonight as he swam in the ocean a quarter of a mile offshore.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: As an independent voter I read with intense interest in The Times of Aug. 21 the article by W.H. Lawrence, "Problem for Kennedy" -- namely, the problem of choosing the next Secretary of State.

Large production costs for a new line of its farm and industrial tractors were blamed for a severe drop in earnings and a 20 per cent decline in sales of Deere Co. for the nine months ended on July 31.

CHICAGO, Aug. 30 -- A suit for an injunction to restrain the Air Line Stewards and Stewardesses Association from seceding from the Air Line Pilots Association was dismissed in United States District Court here today.

JACKSONVILLE, Aug. 30 -- The police and leading Negro integrationists agreed today that criminals and delinquents with little interest in the race problem were responsible for the continuation of violence here.
PARIS, Aug. 30 (Reuters) -- Mrs. Joseph P. Kennedy said today she would go after the grandmothers' vote when she returned to the United States to campaign for her son, Senator John F. Kennedy.

MOSCOW, Aug. 30 -- The Soviet Union, rejected today United States charges that it was interfering in Cuba's internal affairs and charged that it was the United States that was doing so. Moscow promised full Soviet support to offset any suck interference.
Commodity prices moved generally downward yesterday on the New York exchanges. Spiritless trading prevailed in most markets.
ROME, Aug. 30 (UPI) -- Is one of the members of the Soviet Union Olympic team actually a Red Chinese?

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 -- Sometimes a small incident tells more about what is happening in the politics of the nation than all the contrived propaganda of both parties. Here is a little story that illustrates both the cunning and the weakness of the anti-Catholic campaign against Senator Kennedy.
SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 30 -- A $20,000,000-a-year advertising campaign for five years was proposed today to the annual meeting of the American Hospital Association.
THE city's beaches are expected to remain the main attraction for youngsters confined to the city limits during the Labor Day week-end.

FREEPORT, Tex., Aug. 30 -- Ground was broken here today for the first of five saline-water conversion plants to be erected in various parts of the country under the supervision of the Department of Interior's Office of Saline Water.

LBOPOLDVILLE, Aug. 30 (AP) -- The Congo Government sent more troops to Kasai Province today in an apparent build-up for an invasion of Katanga. The central Government was reported to have Communist help.

MORE than 400 years ago an obscure Polish canon named Copernicus established in a treatise dedicated to a Pope that the sun was the center of the solar system and that the earth was only one of the planets that circled it. That revolutionary discovery was the first of an unending series that forced civilized men, often reluctantly, to keep changing their beliefs about the universe and their place in it.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 (AP) -- Senator Jacob K. Javits, seeking to force another test vote on civil rights, legislation before Congress adjourns, ran into a parliamentary wall today.
GARDEN CITY, L.I, Aug. 30 -- An electrical storm halted play after one round today in the Metropolitan district qualifying trials for the United States Golf Association's amateur championship.

ONE consolation about the Garden of Eden incident is that it introduced the apple. And despite all the trouble it caused, the fruit always has been put forward as a preventive for all ills. Delicious and nutritious as apples are, however, they form only one part of an ideal diet.

JERSEY CITY, Aug. 30 (AP) -- The Jersey City Jerseys swept a double-header from the Columbus Jets tonight, running their winning streak to seven games. They won the first game, 4 -- 2, and took the second, 3 -- 0, on the two-hit pitching of Orlando Pena.
Twenty-one gun salutes, water jets from fireboats and whistle signals from harbor craft greeted two Danish ships that arrived here yesterday with a valuable cargo of art.

COLOMBO, Ceylon, Aug. 30 -- A team of Ceylonese Government officials will visit India next month to study India's oil refinery project and collect information on the establishment of such a facility. The mission stems from Ceylon's plan to set up a $30,000,000 refinery.

STILLWATER, Okla., Aug. 30 -- Man and all his works -- including rockets and radioactive fall-out -- have been taken right in stride by one of the lowliest of all organisms, it was suggested here today at the annual meeting of the American Institute of Biological Sciences.
New Yorkers who have left their cars past the one-hour limit at parking meters are discovering that the city's new meter maids cannot be pushed around with impunity.

BOSTON, Aug. 30 (AP) -- Pete Runnels slammed nine hits as the Boston Red Sox swept a twilight-night bill from the Detroit Tiger tonight, 5 -- 4 in fifteen innings and 3 -- 2 in ten. The second game was marred by a head injury to Don Buddin.
The Wagner Administration took another stride yesterday toward setting up the 1964-65 World's Fair as a glittering city within a city.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 -- The American Bar Association recommended today a program to explain the "nature, objectives and tactics of communism" to schools and civic groups.

With Neale Fraser, the crack southpaw from Australia, heading the list, foreign players occupy half of the eight seeded places in the draw of the men's national tennis championships, which was made yesterday.
A small coastal tanker and a tugboat collided in the narrow, tricky Hell Gate Channel of the East River yesterday morning. It was the city's third marine collision in twenty-five and a half hours.
Harry Horner, the Broadway designer, has acquired two plays, "The Poison Tree," by Hugh Brooke, the novelist, and "Simone," a Bertoit Brecht work that Ben Hecht will adapt.
THIS deal was played in Boston by a new Bostonian named Dan Rotman.

ROME, Aug. 30 -- Encroaching age, his growing family and the demands of business have obliged Jack Kelly to shorten his dream. Since he cannot win an Olympic gold medal alone, perhaps he and Bill Knecht can win.
The Transit Authority said last night that inadequate storm drains had caused the fast flooding and the long hours of waterlogged conditions in Queens subways.

The first objective of the United Nations intervention in the Congo has been achieved. Pursuant to Security Council resolutions the last Belgian troops, which Secretary General Hammarskjold regarded as a source of friction, have left the country, thereby completing the severance between Belgium and its former colony.

The Greentree Stable's Weatherwise was the odds-on choice of the 20,105 fans to win the feature race at Aqueduct yesterday. The colt responded satisfactorily, scoring by two lengths over William Ingram's Scotland in the one-mile event.
The partly demolished Roxy Theatre was sold yesterday to a pair of New Jersey realty men who will build an office building on the site.
CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Aug. 30 (UPI) -- An operational model of the Titan intercontinental ballistic missile successfully lofted a dummy warhead 5,000 miles down the Atlantic test range today.

NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 30 -- The New Orleans school board won a delay of ten weeks today in admitting Negro pupils to all-white schools under Federal court order. The schools will presumably open next week on a segregated basis.

BERLIN, Wednesday, Aug. 31 -- The Communist East German Government ordered last night a temporary closing of transport routes to West Berlin for West Germans intending to take part in a series of meetings of refugees from Eastern Germany there this week.

Anne Bancroft, star of "The Miracle Worker" on Broadway, wept and barely got through her lines in a real-life drama yesterday morning. Her performance, intended to be inspirational, far surpassed the script.

The Mayor's citation for distinguished and exceptional service was presented yesterday to Nathan M. Ohrbach at City Hall. And in Mr. Ohrbach's office in the Thirty-fourth Street store that carries his name were messages congratulating him on his seventy-fifth birthday today from President Eisenhower and Governor Rockefeller.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 -- Congressional investigators said today they had found indica-today that they had found indications of "irregularities and even possible corruption" in the Interstate Commerce Commission's regulation of trucking.

Eight railroads operating in New York State received permission yesterday to increase their basic passenger fares within the state by amounts up to 5 per cent. The increases will take effect at 12:01 A.M. tomorrow.
ST. LOUIS, Aug. 30 (AP) -- The Eighth Circuit United States Court of Appeals held today the rural Dollarway, Ark., School District had not made a reasonable start toward desegregation of its schools.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 -- Vice President Nixon was reported responding satisfactorily today to hospital treatment of his infected left knee.
A hold-up man was shot dead and two policemen were wounded yesterday in a running gun battle that terrified crowds in Rockefeller Center.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 -- The House sent to the White House today a bill to penalize broadcasters who deceived the public through radio and television shows.

E.A. Hugill Jr., corporate secretary of the Shell Oil Company, will take on the additional duties of assistant to the president on Jan. 1, 1961. He will succeed P.H. Swinchatt, who will retire after forty years of service with Shell.

The Long Island Rail Road announced early today that because of a strike by the Transport Workers Union against the Pennsylvania Railroad none of its commuter trains would come into Pennsylvania Station until the strike ends.

Directors of the Chock Full O' Nuts Corporation propose yesterday a four-for-one split of the common stock. The board also intends to raise the dividend by 20 cents a year on the split shares, effective Dec. 30, depending upon prevailing conditions.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 31 -- A real estate deal by one of the major studios here has highlighted the expensive changes under way in the movie industry
DUNN, N.C., Aug. 31 (AP) -- Two persons were arrested today as Indian children tried to gain admission to the all-white Dunn High School.
A rank-and-file revolt forced the leadership of the state labor movement yesterday to withdraw proposals for a series of constitutional changes.
ROME, Aug. 31 -- Australia swept the board clean in the men's swimming tonight, but it took a couple of old men (by swimming standards) to do it.

HOUSTON, Tex., Aug. 31 (UPI) -- Three Negro children tried to register in white schools today and were turned away. Meanwhile authorities tried desperately to delay the integration of the first grade in Houston schools on Sept. 7.
Bob Elliott's Athletics finally got around to wearing out their welcome at the Yankee Stadium.
A harbor pilot aboard the Seatrain Georgia when the cargo vessel collided with the ferry Chatham charged yesterday that the ferry captain had failed to heed his signal.

ROME, Aug. 31 -- Hotter than Vulcan's Forge, the sun blazed out of a cloudless Roman sky today at the start of the track and field program in Stadio Olimpico. This international muscle jamboree finally had reached the main part of the show, the phase put in motion by Coroebus of Elis in 776 B.C.

New York City's decision to permit Negro and Puerto Rican junior and senior high school students to transfer to schools outside their regular residential zones is a historic move. A theatre party at the Nov. 15 performance of ''Period of Adjustment" will benefit a fund or student scholarships and teachers'. pensions at the Lenox School, 170 East Seventieth Street. The Tennessee Williams play is scheduled to open at the Helen Hayes Theatre Nov. 10.

STILLWATER, Okla., Aug. 31 -- Evidence from bacteria studies suggest that half of all radiation - induced hereditary damage might be prevented by treatment with chemicals. This finding was presented here today at the close of the eleventh annual meeting of the American Institute of Biological Sciences.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Aug. 31 -- Three members of the host Western Long Island Sound fleet tied for the lead in the North American championship of the International 5-0-5 Class as the first two races in the five-race Series Were sailed off the Larchmont Yacht Club today.

Charges that some lending institutions are reluctant to make mortgage loans to owners of small homes thus forcing them to pay higher discount and interest rates, will be investigated by the Legislature.

OKLAHOMA CITY, Aug. 30 (AP) -- United States District Judge Ross Rizley today ruled that the Admiral Corporation had infringed on two television patents of the Zenith Corporation. He also denied a counterclaim by Admiral that Zenith had moved in on Admiral's license for a phonograph spindle.

UNIONDALE, L.I, Aug. 31 -- A motorist who sought to recover 50 cents in tolls that he had paid on the Hutchinson River Parkway was in jail today because he had written a "threatening" letter to the State Highway Department.

Paul Scofield, a prominent London star, is eager to make his stage debut here during the 1961-62 season in "A Man for All Seasons." Mr. Scofield conveyed this information to Robert Whitehead, the producer, who confirmed it yesterday.
The Government announced yesterday new financial support for research abroad in rehabilitation.

The dog population is rolling ahead at a record rate. According to a recent survey by Consumer Reports magazine, it is growing more than twice as fast as the human population in this country. The magazine estimates that there are 26,000,000 dogs in the United States, almost four times as many as in 1930.
Although there was nothing in her record to show that she could "go in the mud" the Circle M. Farm's Mommy Dear demonstrated clearly yesterday at Aqueduct that sloppy footing was to her liking.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (UPI) -- Norman Prescott, a former Boston and New York disk jockey contradicted today testimony given to House payola investigators by his one-time station manager.
Sales of Sears, Roebuck Co. for the six months ended on July 31 set a new record for the period, but earnings declined from the peak net attained a year earlier, the company announced yesterday.
Rank and file stocks did little yesterday, providing a neutral background, for the fireworks of a dozen of their excited companions.

Given any address in the metropolitan area, a clerk in the office of the Teamsters Joint Council 16 at 265 West Fourteenth Street can tell in a few seconds exactly how many of the group's 165,000 members live in the immediate election district.

PHILADELPHIA, Thursday, Sept. 1 -- The Pennsylvania Railroad was shut down at 12:01 A.M. today for the first time in its 114-year history. A strike of 20,000 shop employes halted operations for the country's biggest rail carrier.
The Board of Education announced a major change in school zoning policies yesterday to speed racial integration.
Forty policemen and agents of the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals spent several hours yesterday trying to find a bear on the West Side. They were not successful.

CHICAGO, Aug. 31 (AP) -- Doug Jones of New York unloaded a left-right combination and knocked out Carl (Bobo) Olson of Portland, Ore., tonight in 1:30 of the sixth round in a scheduled ten-round light-heavy-weight bout at the Chicago Stadium.

The Phillips Petroleum Company and the Sunray Oil Company have agreed to sell their oil and gas properties and other holdings in Canada to Pacific Petroleums, Ltd., in exchange for Pacific common stock worth about $81,000,000.

ELISABETHVILLE, the Congo, Aug. 31 (UPI) -- The Katanga Government threatened today to put the huge former Belgian military base at Kamina out of action if the United Nations did not guarantee that Congo army troops would be barred from landing there.

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Aug. 31 -- The delegates of thirteen African states warned Premier Patrice Lumumba today in a private meeting that such incidents as the beating of eight Americans and two Canadians last Saturday "must come to a halt."

DU QUOIN, Ill., Aug. 31 -- If little Joe O'Brien, the trainer-driver of the winning colt, had had his way. Blaze Hanover would not have returned to the track for the fourth and deciding heat of today's thirty-fifth Hambletonian Stake.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (AP) -- House foreign-aid investigators charged today that their inquiries into United States aid programs had "been plagued with roadblocks, delays and denials of information imposed by the Executive Branch."
Two months of painstaking detective work resulted yesterday in the arrest of three men accused of the $30,000 jewel robbery of Cartier's last June 25. All of the stolen diamonds were recovered.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 -- Inventories held by manufacturing companies turned downward in July, the Department of Commerce reported today.

FUR fakery will reach an alltime high this fall. The fashion for frankly make-believe furs has overwhelmed every phase of the apparel industry: coats and suits, at-home wear, millinery and accessories. At the same time, real fur-from budget to bankbook breakingis all over the fashion picture.

CHICAGO, Aug. 31 (AP) -- The third straight general setback in the grain futures market dropped corn futures to their lowest levels of the season today and left several oats and rye contracts within fractions or so of their lows.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The hemispheric threat of economic sanctions against the Dominican Republic may be one way of striking at Trujillo. But the most devastating effect will be experienced by the less than three million people whose economic plight always has been grave.
MILFORD, Mich., Aug. 31 -- A new series of special-purpose vehicles will be introduced by Chevrolet this fall as part of an expanded line of rear-engine Corvairs.
The fall semester at the United States Merchant Marine Academy, Kings Point, L.I., ripened yesterday without a dean for the 900 students at the training school.
JERSEY CITY, Aug. 31 (AP) -- The Columbus jets scored three runs in the top of the tenth inning to gain a 5-2 victory over Jersey City and snap the home club's seven-game winning streak.

UNIONS -- Transport Workers Union, representing 15,000 car cleaners, oilers, mechanics, repairmen and other nonoperating employes in forty-six locals of the Pennsylvania System Railroad Division; System Federation 152, representing 5,000 sheet metal workers, blacksmiths and mechanics of the International Association of Machinists, Sheet Metal Workers Union and Blacksmiths Union.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 31 -- Following is the text of the third report by Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold to the Security Council on the situation in the Congo:

CHICAGO, Aug. 31 -- Secretary of Agriculture Ezra Taft Benson advised Vice President Nixon today that the way to win the farm vote was to "keep hammering" at the Administration's "sound" farm program "right down the line."
QUITO, Ecuador, Thursday Sept. 1 -- Jose Maria Velasco Ibarra assumed the Presidency of Ecuador for the fourth time last midnight.
SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 31 (UPI) -- The Pittsburgh Pirates spotted the San Francisco Giants a three-run lead today, then rallied for a 7-4 triumph.

CASTEL GANDOLFO, Aug. 31 (AP) -- The Naval Academy rowing eight and the Jack Kelley-Bill Knecht double sculls team went down to defeat today as the United States suffered another series of crushing blows in the Olympic rowing championship.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 31-- Congress sent to the White House today three minor housing measures, designed mainly to keep current programs from lapsing for lack of funds.
HONOLULU, Aug. 31 (AP) -- A 136-foot motor yacht with a 4-year-old heart patient and seventeen other persons aboard appeared today to be winning a battle to stay afloat in the South Pacific.
The Royal Dutch-Shell Group, a leading international oil organization, reported yesterday that its earnings in the quarter and six months ended on June 30 were below the 1959 levels.

LONDON, Aug. 31 -- British exports to Yugoslavia could be trebled in five years if Britain's terms of credit were eased and modernized, the leader of an industrial mission to Yugoslavia reported today.
ROME, Aug. 31 (AP) -- The International Basketball Federation today gave two rival American groups -- each wanting to control the game in the United States -- one year to make up their difference.

CHICAGO, Aug. 31 (AP) -- The Milwaukee Braves bounced back for an 11-7 victory today after the Chicago Cubs had taken the first game, 5 -- 4, on Bob Will's tenth-inning homer. A crowd of 18,568 saw the double-header.
RICHMOND, Va., Aug. 31 -- Gov. J. Lindsay Almond Jr. accused Vice President Nixon today of attempting to capitalize on the religious issue in the Presidential campaign.
The nation's gasoline inventories registered a small decline last wek as the peak summer vacation driving period neared a close.

The candidate, with the confidence of a man who knows his ability to pull votes, is said to have replied with some asperity:
