ROME, Aug. 31 -- In days of yore the fate of a nation could hang on a single courier. If his vital message got through, a battle might be won, or a war. If not his beleaguered cohorts might be destroyed and history altered.
The increasing concern over the tendency of teen-agers to "go steady" was minimized yesterday by a group of sociologists who felt the youngsters were merely doing what comes naturally.

DES MOINES, Aug. 31 (AP) -- Wallaces Farmer said today that a poll it took of Iowa farmers early this month failed to show a definite trend on how they would vote for President Nov. 8. However, it did give a clue to the way the campaign is going.

Railroad presidents are seldom guilty of understating their gloomy financial outlook, but the decline in passenger service that has already occurred in the New York metropolitan area justifies corporate and public pessimism. George Alpert, president of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad, told an Interstate Commerce Commission hearing that his company's present financial position was "precarious.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 31 (AP) -- A six-hit pitching performance by Ray Sadecki and a two-run homer by Walt Moryn carried the St. Louis Cardinals back into second place in the National League tonight as they whipped the Cincinnati Reds, 2 -- 1.

EDINBURGH, Scotland, Aug. 31 -- Mary Queen of Scots makes a pathetic figure in history and many English and Scottish dramatists have tried in vain to make her an equally pathetic figure on the stage. They fail because they fall in love with her and try to make her out a more romantic heroine than she actually was.

BERLIN, Aug. 31 -- The three Western Allied commandants in Berlin protested to the Soviet Union today about travel restrictions to Berlin and within the city clamped down by the East German Communist regime at midnight last night.
On June 28, in its extensive report on school integration, New York's Board of Education insisted that the principle of the "neighborhood school" must be preserved as far as possible.
No officer of the TelAutograph Corporation has sold his stock in the company since the issue began its sharp climb on Aug. 23, Raymond E. Lee, president, declared yesterday.

A City Hall spokesman said yesterday that Mayor Wagner had not approved the Fire Department's permission for honorary deputy chiefs to display the department's official red and white emblem on their private cars.

Swelled by the offering of several large issues of steel, public utility and financing company bonds, the value of new bonds offered publicly here in August jumped to $2,055,819,000 in 223 issues from $1,222,889,000 for 119 issues in July.
TEHERAN, Iran, Aug. 31 (Reuters) -- Premier Jafar Sharif-Imami will act also as Foreign Minister, according to the Cabinet list he presented tonight to Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi.
The market for United States Government securities was moderately active yesterday, with most of the trading taking place in Treasury bills.

MIDDLETOWN, R.I, Aug. 31 -- Before the Democratic candidates have got around to discussing it, a collateral campaign issue in their interest is being shaped by political writers who are presumed to have great influence among independent voters.

A fire at the Essex-Delancey Street IND subway station last night halted two trains and forced nearly 175 passengers to walk 200 feet along a catwalk and then climb six flights of emergency stairs to safety.

A new automatic factory control system was introduced yesterday by the Farrington Manufacturing Company. William M. Tetrick, president, said yesterday that it was geared to increase output as much as 20 per cent while substantially reducing labor costs.
Strategists of both major parties are worried over the marked apathy of what they call "the Jewish vote" in New York.
EVERYBODY around here keeps talking about how many black bass he has caught this summer, and how big they are. Individually and collectively, it is the best bass year they ever have seen.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Aug. 31 -- Finance Minister Levi Eshkol of Israel and Baron Edmond de Rothschild of Paris signed contracts today transferring to a group of international financiers control of the operation of a new oil pipeline between the Gulf of Aqaba and the Mediterranean.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 -- Sweet fellowship was as thick as Washington's pea-soup air today among the major figures in the Presidential campaign.

CARDIFF, Wales, Aug. 31 -- Sir George Thomson, a Nobel laureate and a leading physicist, Indicated tonight that entirely new theories of energy and matter were emerging from recent discoveries about the properties of the fundamental particles of nature.

Volkswagenwerk, GmbH, the world's fourth largest automotive producer, increased gross sales 30.4 per cent to a record of $835,000,000 last year from $580,000,000 in 1958, the annual report disclosed yesterday.
Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz moved yesterday to dissolve the corporation that owns a decaying tenement at 433 West Fifty-fourth Street.
A lawyer employed by the city License Department resigned yesterday amid widening inquiries into alleged tie-ups between the police and public officials and tow-truck operators.

BALTIMORE, Aug. 31 (AP) -- Two "old men" among the youthful Baltimore Orioles carried them to a 6 -- 3 victory over the Cleveland Indians tonight as Gene Woodling hit a grand-slam homer and Hal (Skinny) Brown pitched eight scoreless relief innings.
The Maritime Administration extended yesterday its war-risk insurance binders covering United States flag-ships and their cargoes and personnel for three more months.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (AP) -- Following is the rollcall vote by which the House adopted today a Senate amendment to a money bill adding $65,000,000 for defense support to the foreign-aid program:

WEST POINT, N.Y., Aug. 31 -- On the theory that a football can't possibly again take as many unfunny bounces as it did in his first season as Army's head coach, Dale Hall takes a generally hopeful view of West Point's 1960 prospects.

The Chase Manhattan Bank, trustee for a pension fund, has made a first mortgage loan of $1,400,000 at 6 per cent for a thirteen-story and penthouse apartment building to be constructed at 333 East Fifty-fifth Street, Ivor B. Clark Jr. and Peter J. Shear, vice presidents of Ivor B. Clark, Inc., brokers, arranged the financing.

An innovation that will enable theatregoers to attend regular Broadway shows as well as premieres on Wednesday nights and return home at a reasonable hour was the subject of a luncheon-news conference yesterday.
An overhaul of nursing-home operations here was urged in a report yesterday to Mayor Wagner by City Administrator Lyle C. Fitch.

A long-pending $340,000,000 financing program by Trans World Airlines, Inc., is still hanging fire. Yesterday the directors of the airlines met here. It had been expected in some circles that they would either announce the choice of a new president or the consummation of the financing program. They did neither, and adjourned until this morning. The directors, however, did disclose that no action was taken regarding a proposed merger of T.W.A. and Northeast Airlines, Inc.

BALTIMORE, Aug. 31 -- Alfred E. Perlman, president of the New York Central Railroad, insisted here today that his company's intense struggle with the Chesapeake and Ohio Railway for separate control of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad would end with the three carriers merging into one.

IN "RIGHT-HAND MAN,"* John A. Garraty of the Columbia University history faculty introduces us to George W. Perkins, whose life story is a window on the American business and political scenes of a half-century ago. Perkins was not an extraordinary man in intellect, but he had remarkable energy and perseverance.

The Archaeological Pioneers The challenge of the Space Age has so gripped the attention of the world that little recognition is given to the dedicated men and women who have been working in the opposite direction.
PARIS, Aug. 31 -- President de Gaulle began today an intensive effort to reinforce the diplomatic and military cohesion of Western Europe.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (AP) -- The Washington Senators scored a run in the last of the ninth inning on Earl Battey's sacrifice fly to beat the Chicago White Sox, 2 -- 1, tonight.
CHICAGO, Aug. 31 -- The nation's major railroads announced today that they would request an across-the-board increase in freight rates to meet increased costs of operation.
WASHINGTON, Thursday, Sept. 1 -- An eager Eighty-sixth Congress moved close to final adjournment early today, but it was balked by a Senate-House deadlock on sugar legislation.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 31 (AP) -- Roger Craig, a right-hander, gained his fifth straight victory and Jim Gilliam drove in all the Dodger runs tonight as Los Angeles defeated the Philadelphia Phils, 3 -- 1.

ROME, Aug. 31 -- A trio of American giants sent the Stars and Stripes to the top of the flagpoles of the main Olympic Stadium today with a sweep of the gold, silver and bronze medals hi the shot-put as track and field competition got under Way.

Commodity futures prices worked generally downward yesterday on the New York Exchanges in listless trading. Gains at the close were listed for sugar and wool. Copper, hides, lead, potatoes and zinc declined, and rubber, coffee, cocoa and cottonseed oil were mixed.

Mass distribution, its application in all phases of industry and its importance to the world economy is discussed by Walter Ioving chairman of Tiffany Co., in a volume titled "The Distribution Revolution." ROCHESTER, N.Y., Aug. 31 -- In the last year, physicists in this country and abroad have accumulated a vast amount of new information on the so-called "strange" nuclear particles.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I have read your recent editorial "Road to Nowhere" and must agree that "a road ending up in the air is of no benefit to anybody but birds." However, an explanatory note is necessary.

WHITE PLAINS, Aug. 31 -- The Westchester District Attorney's office today completed reports on 251 persons 13 to 25 Years old who it said had used narcotics "for kicks" at dances, club meetings and parties.
Prices of stocks changed little on average last month as the market failed to sustain gains made in the first half of the month. Trading was the heaviest for any August since 1932.
BAMAKO, Sudan, Aug. 31 -- Premier Modibo Keita of the Republic of Sudan announced today that he would visit Paris Friday to discuss with President de Gaulle the rupture in the Mali Federation.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture reported today that prices of farm products declined 2 per cent between mid-July and mid-August.

The prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange were unchanged to 13 points off yesterday. A point equals 5 cents a bale.

BOSTON, Aug. 31 (AP) -- Chico Fernandez, the Detroit Tigers' shortstop, bunted home the winning run in a 4-2 victory over the Boston Red Sox tonight. The setback snapped Boston's winning streak at five games.

Bonds called for redemption before maturity aggregated $4,107,000 in August, compared with $36,036,000 in the preceding month and $7,482,000 in August, 1959. Last month's figure was the smallest for any month since this compilation started in 1927.

Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa announced yesterday that New York had borrowed $35,000,000 on tax anticipation notes due Nov. 7 and subject to repayment on or after Oct. 28. The interest rate carried by the notes was 2 1/8 per cent.
The battle of the men's hair dressing market was settled yesterday, with Bryclcreem retaining its title as champion.
AMMAN, Jordan, Aug. 31 -- King Hussein declared today that Jordan would fight "if we have to" in her mounting dispute with the United Arab Republic.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 -- The State Department has disclosed that a former United States intelligence official is in Moscow working for the Soviet Government.

Dominic S. Rinaldi, a Municipal Court justice, was nominated yesterday by both Democrats and Republicans for a fourteen-year term as Kings County judge at $34,500 a year.

YESTERDAY (Aug. 31, 1960) THE PRESIDENT Had picture taken with Republican candidates for Congress; saw Senator Mundt, South Dakota Republican; met with Treasury Secretary Anderson, Budget Director Stans and Presidential Assistant Persons.
WASHINGTON, Aug., (AP) -- Pennsylvania Railroad strikers will be eligible for up to $10.20 a day, or $51 a week, in Government benefits while they are idle.
A patrolman rented his automobile to three gunmen who wanted to use it for a Bronx robbery, police charged yesterday.

The hard-won victory of the United States at the foreign ministers' meeting in San Jose, Costa Rica, is having after-effects that are disturbing. INDIANAPOLIS, Aug. 31 (AP) -- Directors of Dow Chemical Company and Allied Laboratories, Inc., approved yesterday a merger subject to stockholders' ratification.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 -- Delegates of the American Bar Association voted 114 to 107 today for repeal of the Connally Reservation, which limits this country's adherence to the International Court of Justice.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 -- The Senate passed a bill today to create an academy like West Point aid Annapolis at which the free world would be taught how to fight a "cold war" against communism.
The city Youth Board recommended yesterday that more care be given to delinquent children to reduce the number who return to court on more serious charges.
Ford Frick, the commissioner of baseball; ruled yesterday that the league president's decision on a protest could not be appealed by the Chicago White Sox.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 31 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold has protested formally to the Belgian Government over its reported failure to withdraw all of its troops from the Congo. He has requested that the last contingent be evacuated "immediately."

SALEM, N.H., Aug. 31 (AP) -- Turppa, a 2-year-old bay colt owned and bred by David Borenstein of Melrose, Mass., today won the $25,475 New England Futurity before a closing-day crowd of 12,678 at Rockingham Park.
A compromise plan for Cadman Plaza, a Federally aided slum-clearance and housing project in Brooklyn, was announced yesterday by the city's Housing and Redevelopment Board.
A director of the Fairchild Engine and Airplane Corporation, C. Leo DeOrsey, sold 20,000 shares of the company's common stock, according to the latest insiders' report of the New York Stock Exchange.

The National Dairy Products Corporation plans to expand its milk and ice cream operations to Canada through the proposed acquisition of Dominion Dairies, Ltd. of Montreal.

With fair and pleasant weather in prospect for the week-end hundreds of thousands of New Yorkers made ready yesterday to leave late today or tomorrow for a Labor Day holiday out of the city.

QUITO, Ecuador, Sept. 1 -- Ecuador will no longer subordinate her border dispute with Peru to continental harmony, President Jose Maria Velasco Ibarra said today.

America's big tennis carnival -- the national grass-court singles championships -- moves into the West Side Tennis Club in Forest Hills, Queens, this afternoon. Players from six continents, representing more than a dozen nations, are primed for the ten-day jamboree.

NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 1 (UPI) -- Lloyd Rittiner, chairman of the Orleans Parish School Board, pleased by today's Supreme Court confirmation of a sixty-five-day delay in school integration, said the board would be able to "work out some kind of plan" for integration Nov. 14.

Loans to business at the fifteen weekly reporting member banks in New York City rose by $89,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. This compared with a rise of $1,000,000 in the comparable 1959 week.

MOSCOW, Sept. 1 -- Premier Khrushchev will head the Soviet delegation to the United Nations General Assembly when it opens in New York Sept. 20. He is expected to be joined by the heads of all other Eastern European Communist countries.

CIUDAD TRUJILLO, Dominican Republic, Sept. 1 -- Public demonstrations calling on Generalissimo Rafael Leonidas Trujillo Molina to assume the Presidency abated today after the dictator, who has held power here for thirty years, declared that "it is not necessary now."
Dr. Edward V. Sittler's plea for the restoration of his United States citizenship should be denied an examiner of the Immigration and Naturalization Service recommended yesterday.
Three appointments involving high executives of Texaco, Inc., were announced yesterday by Augustus C. Long, chairman of the oil company.
ROME, Sept. 1 -- The Vatican published today its newly abbreviated directions for the order to be followed in the mass and other sacred rites of the Roman Catholic Church.
CHICAGO, Sept. 1 -- Several psychologists today reported the results of their researches into family life, but warned parents not to take them as gospel.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 -- Following are tables-listing the voting records of the Representatives from Connecticut, New Jersey and New York on nine major issues in the second session of the Eighty-sixth Congress. At right are tables listing the voting records of all Senators on ten major issues of the second session.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 -- Department store sales in the nation for the week ended Aug. 27, were 4 per cent aboye the year-earlier level.

WEST ORANGE, N.J., Sept. 1 -- Ray Noack, a 33-year-old electronics engineer from the Shore View Club in Brooklyn, led both the gross and net scorers today in a Metropolitan Golf Association one-day tournament at the Crestmont Country Club.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 -- Rail freight loadings last week were above and truck loadings slightly below last year's levels. Both industries reported mixed volumes for the preceding week, with rails below and truck freight above levels of the prior week.
ROME, Sept. 1 (UPI) -- America's talented basketball team crushed outmanned Yugoslavia, 104-42, today in one of the most one-sided games in the history of the Olympic tournament.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 1 (AP) -- Most of the 72,000 employes of the Pennsylvania Railroad will be eligible for unemployment compensation if the walkout lasts two weeks.
Contemplating the Latin-American scene these days one is tempted to ask with Jefemiah: "Is there no balm in Gilead?"
WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 -- Governor Rockefeller flew here today to cheer up Vice President Nixon, who is abed with an infected knee at Walter Reed Army Medical Center.

The Halstead, an apartment house for eighty-six families at 232 to 256 Marline Avenue, White Plains, has been purchased for investment by Harvey Sorkin, president of the Sorkin Corporation, New York realty operators.

Two further incidents yesterday, following a Federal court order to makers of Valcream to cease imitating Brylcreem hair dressing, pointed up the necessity for advertisers to make sure of their ground.

MOSCOW, Sept. 1 -- The Communist party warned Soviet youth today against "idle" contacts with visitors from the United States. It branded as renegades those who had become attracted to the "notorious American way of life."

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Sept. 1 -- Mr. and Mrs. Leo Jaffe have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Marcia Ann Jaffe, to Eugene Margoluis, son of Mr. and Mrs. Mortimer Margoluis of Mamaroneck. The wedding is planned for December.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 -- The Eighty-sixth Congress adjourned tonight after abandoning efforts for a sugar bill designed to relieve President Eisenhower of a foreign policy embarrassment.

MIDLAND, Texas, Sept. 1 -- At Sheppard Air Force Base in North Texas, three women with tired orchids on their shoulders stood by a silver airplane, posing for photographers under an immense sky gleaming with clouds.

ROME, Sept. 1 -- Two Russian high jumpers, each attaining a height of 7 feet 1 inch, beat John Thomas of the United States in the Olympic Games today. On the most disappointing day the Americans have known in track and field in the Olympics in many years, the defeat of Thomas was felt most keenly.
KANSAS CITY, Mo., Sept. 1 (UPI) -- Barry Latman of the Cleveland Indians weathered a fourteen-hit Kansas City attack tonight en route to a 7-3 victory over the Athletics.

The city's Department of Purchase moved yesterday to prevent the awarding of any new rock salt contracts to four suppliers who have been accused of collusive bidding practices by the State Investigation Commission.

THE pungent sweetness of A blue-purple Concord grapes, which are just beginning to appear in fruit stands, heralds the approaching fall. Other indications of the coming season that shoppers will note as they go about their marketing for the long holiday week-end include acorn squash and sweet potatoes.
The Board of Higher Education challenged the State Commission Against Discrimination in court yesterday to prove it had jurisdiction over the employment of teachers by the board.
ROME, Sept. 1 -- American swimmers partly atoned tonight for the disastrous afternoon suffered by American runners and jumpers.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 (UPI) -- Five Senators and nineteen Representatives headed for voluntary retirement today with the adjournment of Congress. Among them is Senator Theodore Francis Green, Democrat of Rhode Island, the oldest man ever to serve in Congress.

The unexpected and rapid growth of round-the-world air travel has caused Trans World Airlines to revise earlier estimates of this traffic, the airline told the Civil Aeronautics Board in Washington yesterday. By 1962 a total of 78,000 passengers are expected to fly around the world.

The nuclear age at sea, whose start is foreseen in the liner Savannah, now nearing completion as the world's first commercial vessel propelled by atomic reaction, will be a major topic when the International Union of Marine Insurance meets in Washington.

Cartagena, the fine jumper owned by F. Eugene Dixon Jr. won the forty-second running of the Harbor Hill Steeplechase Handicap at Aqueduct yester day. The accomplishment was noteworthy more than usual because the horse who Cartagena beat for the $7,008 winner's share was Mrs. Ogden Phipps' famous campaigner, Neji.

ROME, Sept. 1 -- Etched against a darkening Roman sky, the Olympic Flame glowed with steadily increasing brightness this evening. Floodlights bathed Stadio Olimpico for the end of the high jump, a competition that had begun at 9 o'clock in the morning and was approaching a shocking climax ten hours later.

The state of the economy is examined by the First National City Bank in its latest monthly review of business conditions and the diagnosis is, on the whole, rather reassuring. It is, in brief: "over-all stability."

Budget Director Abraham D. Beame advised Mayor Wagner yesterday that the city could safely borrow $580,716,148 within its debt limit to finance capital construction projects in the eighteen months ending Dec. 31, 1961.
JACKSONVILLE, Sept. 1 -- Fear could be measured in dollars and cents here this week.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 -- The Supreme Court refused today to put off racial integration of schools in Houston and New Orleans and in Delaware.
LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Sept. 1 -- Reports circulated here today of disorders at various places in the Congo among undisciplined army units.
A middle-aged professor fought off ten youths who attacked him Wednesday night on Morningside Drive near 113th Street.
CHICAGO, Sept 1 -- Chicago, which is served by more railroads than any other city in the country, was little affected by the strike.

M.N. Shansby of Los Angeles, who won the national predicted-log cruiser championship in 1957, is heading the point-scoring race again, according to figures complied by Donald R. Rimbach of the New York A.C. Yacht Club.
ROME, Sept, 1 (AP) -- Five Ameircan boxers advanced today in the Olympic tournament.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Sept. 1 -- Foreign Minister Subandrio summoned the United States Ambassador Howard P. Jones, today and is reported to have apprised him of the seriousness with which Jakarta viewed the forthcoming visit of the Netherlands aircraft carrier Karel Doorman to Japan.
LONDON, Sept. 1 -- Industrial shares prices scored widespread gains in the stock market here today in response to increased demand.
BERLIN, Sept. 1 -- East Germany tightened controls today on all routes leading to Berlin from the West and on all East-West crossing points within the city.
GENEVA, Sept. 1 -- The outside world began to batter at the tariff walls of the European Common Market here today, and prospects were that the beseigers would have heavy going.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 -- There is only one word that describes Nikita Khrushchev's bland announcement that he will be coming over to New York later this month.

ROME, Sept. 1 (UPI) -- International Swimming Federation (F.I.N.A.) officials today viewed a video tape of the disputed 100-meter free-style Olympic final between Lance Larson of El Monte, Calif., and Australia's John Devitt.

THE PRESIDENT Saw Secretary of State Herter and Army Secretary Brucker; addressed fifth International Congress on Nutrition; issued statement saying he was disappointed at Congressional failure to act on sugar bill and considered it "extremely serious."
PARIS, Sept. 1 -- Despite a 7 per cent increase In Government spending next year. Frenchmen will pay slightly less in taxes on their incomes.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 -- Officials said today that President Eisenhower would almost certainly appear before the United Nations General Assembly this fall, but not while Premier Khrushchev was there.

American Brake Shoe The American Brake Shoe Company has acquired the assets of Herscott Corporation, manufacturer of electrical resistance heating units. Terms of the transaction were not disclosed Herscott will be liquidated and its plant at Rockford, Ill., will be operated as the Reslec plant of Brake Shoe's AmForge Division.

Leases reported yesterday include a contract by Ginn Co., publisher, for an additional floor in 72 FiftH Avenue, at Thirteenth Street. The company now will have three floors with a total area of 15,000 square feet. Adams Co. Real Estate, Inc., was the broker.
JESSUP, Md., Sept. 1 (AP) -- Two men who tried to get two American League umpires to influence the outcome of a baseball game have been charged with attempted bribery, the state police said tonight.
The October cotton future on the New York Cotton Exchange advanced 5 points yesterday, but other positions were unchanged to 15 points down (a point equals 5 cents a bale).

CASTEL GANDOLFO, Italy, Sept. 1 (AP) -- The United States qualified in five straight Olympic rowing events today before the streak was broken by the defeat of the doubles sculls team of Jack Kelly and Bill Knecht.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 (UPI) -- The United States has denounced as "ridiculous" Premier Castro's charge that Washington had plotted the assassination of Dr. Raul Roa, Cuban Foreign Minister.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Sept. 1 -- Werner Heisenberg, one of the great figures of modern theoretical physics, is putting his controversial theory of matter to the test of detailed mathematical proof. He said today that he and his colleagues were making progress in this effort.

Consolidated net income of the Bowater Paper Corporation, Ltd., and its subsidiaries in the first half of I960 rose to $9,607,000 from 8,857,000 in the corresponding 1959 period, Sir Eric Vansittart Bowater, chairman, announced yesterday.

THIS will be the Great Statistical Week-End, in fishing as well as in slaughter by automobile, except that fishing will depend largely upon the weather. If the weather is good, records will surely be set in the number of boats and people fishing, the amount of chum and bait used, and the amount of money spent.

THE husky, gray-haired six-footer who mediated the recent Long Island Rail Road strike and is now mediating the Pennsylvania Railroad strike for the Federal Government is a man who believes in solving the basic human equation in all labor disputes.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 1 -- Leonard Bernstein, as triumphant as a movie star who has just signed a fantastic contract, was getting almost as much attention as a film idol here today as he prepared for tomorrow's concert at the Hollywood Bowl.

The Columbia Broadcasting System has received during the last several months program ideas from people who think they can deflect some of the limelight from the "Jack Paar Show" on National Broadcasting Company TV.

The America Corporation, a diversified company formerly known as Chesapeake Industries, Inc., has purchased 403,932 outstanding shares of the Universal American Corporation common stock for an undisclosed amount of cash.
A testing crew at a ship-repair yard in Brooklyn put concrete weights in a big plastic lifeboat yesterday and then filled it with water until it sank beside the dock.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 -- Representative Francis E. Walter, chairman of the House UnAmerican Activities Committee, called today for an investigation of all United States intelligence agencies.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 -- Senator John F. Kennedy pledged himself today to support a drive early in the next session of Congress for passage of the Democratic platform plank on civil rights.

BAMAKO, Sudan Republic, Sept. 1 -- Modibo Keita, Premier of the broken Mali Federation in West Africa, plans to warn President de Gaulle that the future of six French air bases in Sudan are in jeopardy.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: If ever there was a need for a third party in American politics -- a party not only representing the aspirations of the plain people, but a party of utter integrity -- it is now.
Broadway was blacked out for a minute last night in memory of Oscar Hammerstein 2d.

"El hijo del Gobernador" -- Governor Rockefeller's 28-year-old son, Rodman -- campaigned through Spanish Harlem yesterday, teling the city's Puerto Ricans "su poder es votar (your strength is in voting)."
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y. Sept. 1 -- Under Secretary Ralph J. Bunche said today that "the worst is over" in the Congo.

UNIONS -- Transport workers Union, representing 15,000 car cleaners, oilers, mechanics, repairmen and other nonoperating employes in forty-six locals of the Pennsylvania System Railroad Division; System Federation 152, representing 5,000 sheet metal workers, blacksmiths and mechanics of the International Association of Machinists, Sheet Metal Workers Union and Blacksmiths Union.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 1 (AP) -- Vada Pinson struck out in his first two times at bat tonight, but his three-run homer in the seventh was the decisive blow as the Cincinnati Reds defeated the St. Louis Cardinals, 7-4.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 (AP) The Comptometer Corporation informed the Securities and Exchange Commission today that its Electrowriter device was not likely to pay its own way in the near future.
VENTIANE, Laos, Sept, 1 -- The Laos political crisis was declared over today by Capt. Kong Le.

Daily average borrowings by member banks of the Federal Reserve System rose 80,000,000 to $273,000,000 in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. Daily average reserves in excess of requirements rose 109,000,000 to $574,000,000.
CHICAGO, Sept. 1 (AP) -- The grain futures market mustered its first general advance of the week today. Wheat, corn and rye gained major fractions or more on several contracts.

AMERICANS abroad will bring home many things from many lands this summer, but none will bring back more good will than a group of 180 American college and graduate students fresh from two months in the back-country of ten West African nations.

The New Jersey Bell Telephone Company announced yesterday that its board had authorized $80,000,000 of financing. Included were the Issuance of $60,000,000 in capital stock to the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, the sole stockholder in New Jersey Bell, and sale of $20,000,000 in fortyyear debentures to the public.
ROME, Sept. 1 (UPI) -- John Thomas, shaken by his surprise defeat in the Olympic high jump today but taking it calmly, said: "I don't have any alibis -- I was beaten fair and square."
BLAIRSTOWN, N.J., Sept. 1 -- On a day more suitable for swimming, Princeton opened its football training for the 1960 season today.

LONDON, Sept. 1 -- Great Britain, benefiting from a heavy inflow of money attracted by high interest rates, is expected to announce a repayment of four monthly installments of its debt to the International Monetary Fund.
Detours and delays caused by highway construction will be fewer over the Labor Day week-end than at any time in the last year.

DUNN, N.C., Sept. 1 (AP) -- Seven Indian children were arrested today as they persisted in efforts to be admitted to the all-white Dunn High School and five Indian adults backing them in the effort were also arrested.

WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 1 -- The Double Decade, a 25,000 mile pace tomorrow night at Roosevelt Raceway, will mark the twentieth anniversary of the track and bring together Adios Butler and Bye Bye Byrd.
Two directors and the secretary of the TelAutograph Corporation sold 8,488 shares of the company's stock during the two weeks ended last Wednesday, the New York Stock Exchange disclosed yesterday.
A 16-year-old boy accused of tormenting a Queens couple over the telephone was charged with a misdemeanor and released on $500 bail last night. He will get a hearing today in Queens Adolescent Court.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 (AP) -- The Washington Post and Times-Herald reports that a Southern Baptist minister who circulated an anti-Catholic statement falsely attributed to Thomas Jefferson apologized when he received evidence of his mistake.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 1 (AP) -- Roberto Clemente's three-run homer plus Clem Labine's steady relief pitching led the league-leading Pittsburgh Pirates to a 6-1 victory over the San Francisco Giants today despite a fourteen-hit attack by the losers.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., Sept. 1 -- Ralph W. Johnston of Jackson Heights, Queens, and Texas A. and M. University posted an eagle 3 today in leading thirteen metropolitan qualifiers for the United States amateur golf Championship in St. Louis, Sept. 12-17.
"It seems like that iron thing works even cheaper than we do. The picking machines have already hurt us some and I see a time coming when a lot of us folk are going to need a lot of looking after."

Once again the stock market was either up or down, depending on the yardstick used. The New York Times average of fifty stocks fell moderately. Standard and Poor's index off 500 industrial stocks registered a small gain.

ITHACA, N.Y., Sept. 1 -- Eight union members have received two-year scholarships at Cornell University. They will be the first group to study under the International Labor Training Program set up by Cornell's New York State School of Industry and Labor Relations.
A research team is developing what it considers a foolproof means of measuring an individual's capacity for work.

A woman who will not wear a hat but considers herself well-dressed may change her mind if she will spend thirty minutes in the sixth-floor millinery salon at Bonwit Teller. After trying on some of the new French and Italian originals, imported exclusively for the store, she is almost sure to be converted.
Higher Canadian production figures and forecasts of more rain in Maine caused declines in potato futures prices yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange.
A group of shipbuilders here said yesterday that the next supercarrier for the Navy should be built in a private shipyard.
A broadcast in their native languages bounced off Echo I has been heard by the people of East Europe, Radio Free Europe reported yesterday.

Prices of United States Government securities drifted downward yesterday in a quiet trading session. Otherwise market values quoted for prime corporate bonds and other high-grade debt investments generally were unchanged.

Among the cheering aspects of the $38,000,000 cooperative housing project being planned for Greenwich Village is the simple, direct way in which the enterprise took form. A housewife and her lawyer husband last February put a want ad in the papers. It said: "Anyone interested in a true middle-income housing project write Box 460."

The Board of Education's program to promote racial integration in the school system was supported yesterday by many individuals and organizations, including James E. Alien Jr., the State Education Commissioner.

Nikita S. Khrushchev's coming appearance in the General Assembly of the United Nations is being viewed as a major step in the deepening ideological and political split between Communist China and the Soviet Union.

A 26-year-old former guide at the United States exhibition in Moscow last summer stepped off a plane at New York International Airport yesterday and learned that a Soviet newspaper has accused her of spying.

Jack, Scott and Harry Skodnek, Nassau County industrial builders operating under the name of the Brothers Skodnek, have purchased about seven and one-Half acres in the Town of Oyster Bay, L.I., for development.
LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Sept. 2 -- The Soviet Union appears to be providing Premier Patrice Lumumba with air and surface transport for a possible invasion of secessionist Katanga Province.
SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 2 -- The San Francisco Giants defeated Los Angeles, 4 -- 3, tonight, checking a Dodger rally in the ninth.

Market bids for United State Government securities turned upward yesterday, shrinking slightly the price declines that prevailed in a week of desultory trading. Prime corporate bonds and other investment-grade securities were firm.
Prices for cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 5 points up to 15 points off yesterday. A point equals 5 cents a bale.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 (AP) -- The space agency said today the Echo satellite "still looks good" and at 8 A.M. daylight time this morning completed its 268th orbit of the earth.
BONN, Germany, Sept. 2 Fifteen United States soldiers were killed and twenty-eight were injured this morning when an eight-inch artillery shell exploded at the Grafenwoehr training ground in Bavaria.

TRANSPORTATION difficulties cut opening-day attendance yesterday at the Knickerbocker Championships, usually one of the most popular tournaments played annually in New York. The tournament at the Statler Hilton Hotel will continue through Monday.

UNIONS -- Transport Workers Union, representing 15,000 car cleaners, oilers, mechanics, repairmen and other non-operating employes in forty-six locals of the Pennsylvania System Railroad Division; System Federation 152, representing 5,000 sheet metal workers, blacksmiths and mechanics of the International Association of Machinists, Sheet Metal Workers Union and Blacksmiths Union.
CHICAGO, Sept. 2 (AP) -- The grain futures market slipped into general weakness again today but held most of the gains of the preceding session on the Board of Trade.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 2 -- Paul Richards' Orioles, a strange mixture of brash youngsters and staid oldsters who steadfastly have refused to believe they don't belong in this year's American League flag race, nudged into it a little farther tonight.

ROME, Sept. 2 -- The United States finally emerged from the watery depths where it had been winning most of its Olympic championships and today planted its collective feet on dry land. At long last the American track and field performers took a cue from the swimmers, who had been showing them how it should be done.
A LAST, bittersweet fling of exciting summer fun will be enjoyed by many Manhattan youngsters and their parents this final holiday week-end before school bells ring.

ROME, Sept. 2 -- In a smashing comeback from its stunning setbacks yesterday, the United States swept all three medals in the men's 400-meter hurdles, took the gold and silver medals in the men's broad jump and the gold medal in the women's 100-meter sprint before 75,000 spectators in Olympic Stadium today.

BACK in Vermont, old Hez Applegate used to laugh at the young men who forsook rural independence and spent their lives making money doing something that they didn't want to do. Edwin Eustace frequently quoted Hez Applegate as the rustic prophet whose advice he foolishly had ignored.
Commodity futures prices drifted lower yesterday on the New York exchanges in listless trading. Evening of positions prior to the Labor Day weekend accounted for most of the volume.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 -- Average wholesale prices for the week ended last Tuesday fell 0.1 per cent to 119.3 per cent of their 1947-49 average, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today.
City school officials said yesterday they were willing to meet, but not negotiate, with a group of Negro parents who have threatened to boycott the schools to protest segregation.

The Allied Stores Corporation, which includes Stern's and Gertz stores here, showed a sharp drop in earnings for the three and six months ended on July 31 from those of a year ago. Results for the twelve months to July 31, however, registered gains over those of the year before.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Sept. 2 -- Negro gangs patterned after those in New York have declared a truce in their "rumble" warfare here and have adopted a common policy of reprisals for white violence against Negroes.

In a wild scramble for $500 discarded in a Brooklyn lot by a fleeing thief, more than a score of persons made off with all but $20 of the money yesterday. It had been stolen from a rent collector in the BedfordStuyvesant district.
PORTLAND, Me., Sept. 2 -- Senator John F. Kennedy barn-stormed across New England today. He advocated protection for the textile and shoe industries as part of a broad program of economic revival.
An unemployed mechanic who posed as a Coast Guard officer "for the glory of it" found himself in trouble with the Government yesterday after trying to discipline some beer-drinking teen-agers.

CARDIFF, Wales, Sept. 2 -- Plans to harvest Britain's most productive fish pond, the North Sea, include putting fishermen in frogsuits and the deployment of a fleet of submarine juggernauts with spiked rollers.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 -- A vegetable fluid nutritionally equivalent to milk is being provided for protein-starved children of underdeveloped countries, the Fifth International Congress on Nutrition was told today.
After a highly successful introductory year with its 1959 compact auto, the Lark, the Studebaker-Packard Corporation has had rough going this year and faces even graver problems in the year ahead.

Brendan Behan, the uninhibited, fun-loving Irish play wright with the awesome reputation for quaffing the "sauce," arrived in New York yesterday as sober as the proverbial judge and as amiable as a vote-getting politician.
HELSINKI, Finland, Sept. 2 -- Premier Khrushchev arrived here by train today to join in tomorrow's celebration of the sixtieth birthday of Finland's President, Urho Kekkonen.
Although more issues on the New York Stock Exchange rose than fell yesterday, all the leading market yardsticks showed that prices had fallen a little.
Many churches here will celebrate tomorrow as Labor Sunday, in connection with the national observance of Labor Day on Monday.

El Paso County, Tex., sole yesterday $3,700,000 of hospital district bonds due from 1961 to 1990 and callable in 1975 to Rowles, Winston Co. and associates at an interest cost of 3.672 per cent. The bonds were priced on reoffering to yield 1.75 to 3.75 per cent.
ST. LOUIS, Sept. 2 (UPI) -- Don Cardwell slammed two home runs and pitched the Chicago Cubs to a 10-4 victory over the St. Louis Cardinals tonight.

MILWAUKEE, Sept. 2 (AP) -- Plans to build a 200-mile petroleum products pipeline from the refineries at the foot of Lake Michigan to Milwaukee and the Fox River Valley of Wisconsin were disclosed today by ten major oil companies.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 2 -- Two proposed schedules for a $10,163,000 rate increase were filed by the Public Service Electric and Gas Company today with the Public Utilities Commission here and in Trenton.
DALLAS, Sept. 2 (AP) -- Tommy Bolt of Crystal River, Fla., and the home pro, Earl Stewart, shot 3-under-par 67's today and shared the first-round lead in the $25,000 Dallas open golf tournament.
The state has asked the Supreme Court to enjoin Richard Randall, producer of "Aquarama," a pool show in Flushing Meadow Park, from selling stock in his film producing company.

The post-convention session of the Eighty-sixth Congress that petered out Friday night must be marked down as a disappointment. Republicans and Democrats reached out for campaign advantage, and the national interest was often trampled in the melee.

BOSTON, Sept. 2 (UPI) -- Jim Lemon hit his thirty-second and thirty-third home runs of the year tonight as the Washington Senators beat the Boston Red Sox, 5 -- 1 and 3 -- 2, in a twilight-night double- header.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 -- Legislation appropriating $3,787,350,000 for military and economic foreign aid in the current fiscal year was approved by President Eisenhower today.
ROME, Sept. 2 (AP) -- A wrestler from communist Bulgaria was accused today of helping a Russian beat a Yugoslav and a Swede for a gold medal in the Olympic Games.
ALBANY, Sept. 2 -- The Republican and Democratic State Committees will hold conventions a dozen floors apart in the same Albany hotel Sept. 12.

BERLIN, Sept. 2 -- The East German police have arrested about a dozen "troublemakers" in the first forty-eight hours of a five-day limitation on West German travel in Soviet-controlled areas, the Communist organ Neues Deutschland said today.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I was one of the subway commuters caught on Aug. 30 in the snarl of the aftermath of the rain. Putting aside the problem of the sewerage system in Queens, which apparently rendered the subways' pumping system ineffective and which seems always to be inadequate for more than heavy dew, certain aspects of the New York City Transit System are clearly in need of investigation and reorganization.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 (AP) -- Congress having adjourned last night, Senator, Lyndon B. Johnson of Texas, the Democratic Vice Presidential nominee, announced today his campaign schedule through Oct. 22.
The eighth world congress of the International Society for the Rehabilitation of the Disabled closed here yesterday.
WHITE PLAINS, Sept. 2 -- A two-mile stretch of highway was opened here today to bypass downtown White Plains and end a bottleneck that had slowed and confused motorists for three years.

ROME, Sept. 2 -- For the second straight day the United States swimmers and divers won all there was to win in the Olympic pool. Again, all of the victories were landslides, again, two of them were in world record time.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: On the occasion of the convention to be held in Detroit on Sept. 4 of the Association of Bulgarians of American and Canadian descent, I consider it my duty to state the following:

LONDON, Sept. 2 (AP) -- Talks between Abdul Karim Kassim's Iraqi Government and the Iraq Petroleum Company (I.P.C.) have been broken off to allow company representatives to consult the board in London.

Temperatures throughout the Southwest have been high much of the summer. This probably has nothing to do with the fact that Joe M. King, a rancher, spent some time recently inking a $500 check to himself on a six-by-three-foot cowhide.

A drawbridge left open over a Toledo river, untended grain elevators on Buffalo's waterfront and flatcars of heavy machinery outside of Indianapolis stood in silent evidence yesterday of the Pennsylvania Railroad strike.

STAMFORD, Conn., Sept. 2 -- There were no startling rigging experiments, of the kind that made the event memorable last September early this evening when the Stamford Yacht Club's Vineyard Trophy race began.
BEACON, N.Y., Sept. 1 -- With, the carefree idealism of youth, a group of high school boys and girls from the metropolitan area discussed broadly this week the melancholy way of the world.

ROME, Sept. 2 -- Ways to avoid a trade war between the six-nation European Common Market and the seven-nation European Free Trade Association were discussed in a top-level Italian-German meeting in Varese in northern Italy this evening.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 (UPI) -- Senate investigators said today they had subpoenaed Charles (Sonny) Liston to determine whether he was managed secretly by "by underworld figures."
A 71-year-old "fireball," who, friends'and associates say, also looks like Woodrow Wilson, heads the Studebaker-Packard Corporation.
Mail to and from the city is being handled with normal speed despite the shutdown of the Pennsylvania Railroad, Postmaster Robert K. Christenberry reported yesterday.
WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 2 -- Adios Butler virtually turned the $25,000 Double Decade Pace into a one-horse-and-sulky race at Roosevelt Raceway tonight.
HEIDELBERG, Germany, Sept. 2 (UPI) -- The shell that killed fifteen United States soldiers overshot its target by a mile because the powder charge was too heavy, the Army said today.

JESSUP, Md., Sept. 2 (AP) -- Two Washington men and a former Baltimore night club dancer were arraigned today on charges of trying to extort money from two American League umpires, Bill McKinley and Ed Runge.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The voters of New York are asked to consider some nineteen amendments to the State Constitution which have been proposed by the Legislature and which, if approved by the new Legislature to be elected this fall, will be presented to the voters for ratification in 1961.
Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy told forty high-ranking officers yesterday that he wanted results in the investigation of collusion between policemen and tow-truck operators.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Sept. 2 -- Henry Schefter of Mamaroneck, placing fourth in the final race of the series today, won the North American sailing championship of the International 5-0-5 Class by 2 points.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 -- Heavy bidding cut the Government's short-term borrowing costs today for the first time in five weeks. However, the reductions were slight.

Manuel Ycaza returned to action at Aqueduct yesterday, after five days off because of illness, and he steered Clara L. Ostriker's Really Sumthin to victory in the feature race. Exhibiting a tremendous rally in the stretch, Really Sumthin crossed the wire a length and three-quarters ahead of a long shot, Fading Sky, ridden by Braulio Baeza.
Directors of Studebaker-Packard Corporation, at a special meeting here yesterday, elected Clarence Francis. 71, as chairman and chief executive officer of the company.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 (AP) -- Herbert G. Klein, Vice President Nixon's press secretary, said today that Mr. Nixon did not expect that either he or Senator John F. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, would be invited to meet with Mr. Khrushchev.
KANSAS CITY, Sept. 2 (UPI) -- Home runs by Marty Keough and Harvey Kuenn were the highlights tonight as Cleveland defeated the Kansas City Athletics, 6 -- 2.

A survey of American political thought and the men who shaped the country's political traditions is given by Dr. Saul K. Padover in "The Genius of America." The author discusses the careers of nineteen political leaders and thinkers who contributed most of the political development.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 2 -- Six governors and eleven mayors united today in urging labor and management to end the two-day-old Pennsylvania Railroad strike this holiday weekend.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 (AP) -- The Interstate Commerce Commission said today that its regulations covering safe operation of trucks took precedence over any labor union contract.

There was a concert for loiterers yesterday at Pennsylvania Station. Recorded music continued to pour out over the nearly empty central concourse, but the sleek new sedan on display was pointing north-north-east on its no-longer-revolving stand.

The news for many stockholders -- at least for those who had been hoping for a fatter dividend check -- was disappointing last month. In fact, it has been disappointing five months in a row. In August, according to Standard Poor's Corporation, the statistical and advisory service, the number of dividend increases were fewer than those of 1959 for the fifth consecutive month.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 -- The State Department denounced as an "unscrupulous forgery" today a purported official United States document that is being distributed in Latin America.

Radiation, Inc. The assets of Electronics Services division of American Bosch Arma Corporation have been acquired by Radiation Service Company, a subsidiary of Radiation, Inc., of Melbourne, Fla. LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Sept. 2 -- Fighting between Congo Army forces and dissident troops at Bakwanga, in Kasai Province, is assuming the dimensions of a civil war, according to reports reaching United Nations headquarters here.
DAHLGREN, Va., Sept. 2 (AP) -- In a gay mood, President Eisenhower and his four grandchildren set out tonight on a Labor Day week-end cruise on the Potomac River.
HAVANA, Sept. 2 -- Premier Fidel Castro told a cheering crowd of hundreds of thousands of Cubans tonight that Cuba would recognize Communist China and break off relations with Nationalist China.
The annual flight from the city for the Labor Day weekend took place without significant trouble yesterday, despite the Pennsylvania Railroad strike.
CHICAGO, Sept. 2 -- How a "helpless" emotional atmosphere can stimulate suicides was described today by a clinical psychologist.

THE homemaker with limited storage space in her kitchen would be wise to buy versatile dining accessories, such as the footed dessert dishes of white ceramic at Stuart Becker. Four inches in diameter, these multiple-purpose pieces stand three-and-a-half inches high and could be used for individual por- tions of shrimp cocktail, soup or even champagne.

A paper delivered in Washington yesterday at the Fifth International Congress on Nutrition had as its senior authors two very junior researchers -- a boy and a girl, both of New York, both 17-year-olds.

CHICAGO, Sept. 2 -- A leading economist and educator proposed today that the United States build universities in the underdeveloped nations to enable poor countries to help themselves through education.

ROME, Sept. 2 (UPI) -- Ray Norton, the star United States sprinter who finished sixth in the Olympic final of the 100-meter dash, tonight indignantly denied his and other bad American performances were attributable to night life.
Four sportive porpoises, leaping out of the water in pairs, sent bathers scurrying for land yesterday as a shark scare flashed across the beachfront from Far Rockaway to Neponsit.
Thomas E. Trotter, 33 years old, has been appointed racing secretary and handicapper for the New York Racing Association. He succeeds Frank E. (Jimmy) Kilroe.
The Columbia Broadcasting System will repeat its televised study of the Dominican Republic Sept. 15.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Sept. 2 -- With food spotlighted as the theme of the 114th annual State Fair being held here through Sept. 10, visitors are in no danger of going away hungry. Appetites whetted by exhibits of prize examples of some of the state's most important food products can be quickly appeased.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Sept. 2 -- Premier Gaston Eysken formed a new Cabinet today with Count Harold d'Aspremont-Lynden in the sensitive post of Minister of African Affairs. The new Minister has been acting as coordinator of aid to Katanga since that province proclaimed its independence from the Republic of Congo early in July.

LONDON, Sept. 2 -- Industrial shares ended the fortnighty bookkeeping account period on a buoyant note. Persistent demand enabled most leading share groups to extend yesterday's advance and raise The Financial Times industrial shares index 1.6 points to 336.8.

BOGOTA, Colombia, Sept. 2 -- Troops, policemen and armored vehicles were ordered to occupy Bogota between 9 and 11 o'clock tonight as a show of preparedness for any trouble during the Americas conference on economic problems.

Nerves Seasonally on Edge Now, before the crisp, cool days of autumn come to revive man's sense of humor and his perspective of life, both being made soggy and limp in the humidity of late summer, the suburbanite is particularly sensitive to certain sounds of his environment.
MARBLEHEAD, Mass., Sept. 2 -- The Manhassett Bay Challenge Cup was won by the Cohasset Yacht Club on Massachusetts Bay today.

JIMMY SALVATO said over the telephone that a great many people in New Jersey had stopped worrying about fishing and were immersed in preparations for long hunting trips to places such as Wyoming and Alaska.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 2 -- Leonard Bernstein and the New York Philharmonic were warmly received here tonight at the Hollywood Bowl, when they gave the first of three concerts.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Aug. 26 -- "USDEK!" shouted President Sukarno. "USDEK!" echoed his Cabinet. "USDEK!" Preechoed the Indonesian people -- not all of whom knew exactly what it meant.
ROME, Sept. 2 (AP) -- The United States Olympic basketball team, warming up for tomorrow night's semi-final showdown with Russia, crushed Uruguay, 108 -- 50, today for its fifth straight victory.

A smoky fire caused by a faulty brake shoe on an East Side IRT train disrupted service on the Woodlawn-Jerome subway line for fifty minutes yesterday. It was the first of four incidents that delayed IRT passengers during the morning.

SEOUL, Korea, Aug. 16 -- Vastly increased artillery fire power, a constantly improving troop training program and the existence of a battle-trained ready reserve make it feasible for the South Korean Government to reduce its armed forces.
Barely more than a long lob from Queens Boulevard's noisy traffic clatter, the eightieth national grass courts singles championships opened on a quiet note in Forest Hills yesterday.
CIUDAD TRUJILLO, Sept. 2 -- President Joaquin Balaguer has signed decrees shifting Governors in three provinces.

WASHINGTON -- Sept. 2 (AP) -- Representative Cecil R. King charged today that a "campaign pay-off is being engineered for Richard Nixon" in the Government's seizure of a Long Beach, Calif., savings and loan company.

BESSEMER, Ala., Sept. 2 (AP) -- A witness was jailed today for refusing to give satisfactory answers In a grand jury investigation of The New York Times' articles on racial conflict in the Birmingham area.

In a grim warning to the violent elements in the Congo, United Nations forces, which have seen United Nations personnel subjected to attacks and numerous indignities, have now fired into an attacking mob of armed civilians.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 -- The foreign ministers will lead the major Western powers' delegations at the opening of the General Assembly in New York Sept. 20, diplomatic sources said today.

CASTEL GANDOLFO, Italy, Sept. 2 (AP) -- The United States Naval Academy eight today defeated Britain's Oxford University crew and gained tomorrow's finals of the Olympic rowing championships along with four other United States entries.

After several years of riding the merger merry-go-round, the paper industry is developing a case of antitrust nerves. Federal authorities are attempting to slow the efforts of leading paper manufacturers to integrate their operations from forests to finished products.
New Yorkers who stay at home for the Labor Day weekend cart look forward to fair weather and two parades.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 -- A scientist has challenged the traditional lobster pot, whose wooden ribs have long been familiar on the coast of Maine. He proposes in its stead a durable plastic trap with flexible slats that the lobster can push in but not out.
CINCINNATI, Sept. 2 (AP) -- The Milwaukee Braves made seventeen hits tonight and trounced Cincinnati, 9-6, keeping their slim pennant hopes alive.
ON the Kremlin's blacklist of enemies inside the Communist movement, the name of Edvard Kardelj, the theoretician behind Yugoslav "revisionism," cannot be far from the top.
Vice President Nixon and Senator John F. Kennedy endorsed yesterday a statement by the American Jewish Committee sharply denying that a "Jewish bloc vote" existed in national elections.
LENINGRAD, U.S.S.R., Aug. 12 -- A young Soviet astronomer believes that an event of unusual and awesome intensity may be taking place in the core of the galaxy of which the solar system is a part.
The town house at 7 East Tenth Street, a Greenwich Village landmark embellished with delicately carved teakwood imported from India, has been sold my Maria Sermolino.

"WHERE have I failed?" This question was asked by the wealthy father of one of the 251 Westchester County teen-agers and young adults who confessed this week to being narcotics users. The question is doubtless also troubling the parents of teen-age members of two "burglary for kicks" gangs that were apprehended recently in two suburban communities.
Tax-exempt bond issues will make up the bulk of the new capital issues coming to market in the holiday week ahead.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In an editorial on Aug. 22 you criticized the fact that "we have departed from the realistic objectives of the Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938." You also point out that arguments for the bill giving broader coverage and a higher minimum wage relate to the last two objectives concerned with "increased purchasing power" and "a high wage structure in depressed periods."
Henry Cabot Lodge bade farewell to the hushed and carpeted halls of the United Nations yesterday and prepared to take off for the 1960 national political campaign.
MOSCOW, Sept. 2 -- The Soviet Union pressed its own ideological attack on Communist "dogmatists" today, but declined to align itself with Yugoslav criticism of Communist China.
HOBOKEN, N.J., Sept. 2 -- A 78-year-old retired Pullman porter today started on the last half of a round-trip to Los Angeles in the Pullman car he had chartered for $7,500.
CHICAGO, Sept. 2 (UPI) -- Earl Averill's pinch single scored Al Smith and Minnie Minoso in the eighth inning tonight, lifting the Chicago White Sox to a 7-5 victory over the Detroit Tigers.

The head of the Federal Maritime Board toured the United States Merchant Marine Academy in Kings Point, L.I., yesterday and said he found no evidence to support charges that student morale there was low.
College students who think they fall far short of their ideal of themselves have significantly more anxiety symptoms than other students, a group of Roman Catholic sociologists were told yesterday.
James M. Landis, who was chairman of the Civil Aeronautics Board during President Truman's early years in the White House, has agreed to run for president of the Air Line Pilots Association.
HONG KONG, Sept. 1 -- Love, beauty and truth are being redefined in Communist China to fit the harsh realities of the new society.
Orison S. Marden, president of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York, has announced the appointment of committees to serve for 1960-61.

CIUDAD TRUJILLO, Dominican Republic, Aug. 31 -- The espresso cafe, refuge of the long-haired, bearded set addicted to poetry, philosophy, wrinkled sweaters and creaseless slacks, has arrived.

FOREIGN AFFAIRS -- The frequent charge that American college graduates are ignorant of foreign affairs, history, geography and economics will be -- literally -- put to a test. Dr. Percy Bidwell, former director of studies for the Council on Foreign Relations, has arranged with the Educational Testing Service, Princeton, N.J., for the testing of college seniors throughout the nation.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 -- Union leaders called today for a record-smashing Kennedy-Johnson vote in November and a "real forward push" in organizing non-union workers next year.

THE contemporary composer, especially the composer who scores for such unusual instruments as auto brake drums, thunder sheets, water-buffalo bells and Japanese temple gongs, will be spotlighted when the 1960 New York High Fidelity Show opens at the New York Trade Show Building on Wednesday.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 3 -- Yale is putting all its football eggs in one basket. The anticipated result, to quote Coach Jordan Olivar, is "a real good first team." "After that, though, things begin to get dubious," he adds.
NEW DELHI, India, Sept. 3 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru and his ruling Congress party have come in for considerable public criticism on an issue that has touched off sharp controversy.

Although city school bells will not be ringing for another week, more than 400 youngsters turned out for classes -- tennis classes -- at the West Side Tennis Club in Forest Hills yesterday.

GOTTFRIED BENN died in 1956 at the age of 70. Little known outside his country, he occupied a unique place in German literature. In his last years, numerous books were written about him, while only a few posthumous fragments were added to a body of work that, in its entirety, comprises only a few volumes.
AMMAN, Jordan, Sept. 3 -- The Cairo radio, President Nasser's Voice of the Arab World, solemnly pronounced its epitaph this week on two fallen premiers of Moslem countries.

HOLLYWOOD. JAMES POE, the movie writer who combined William Faulkner's "Sanctuary" and "Requiem for a Nun" Into the movie now being filmed as "Sanctuary," was fishing in his wallet the other day for the source of the movie.
ROME, Sept. 3 (UPI) -- Eddie Crook, a middleweight from Fort Campbell, Ky., knocked out Ion Monea of Rumania in the second round tonight and joined two other Americans in the Olympic boxing finals.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 3 -- A week-end settlement of the Pennsylvania Railroad strike seemed hopeless today as top union and management officials reported no progress.

MONTREAL, Sept. 3 -- Proposals for a radical revision in Montreal's administrative system have produced an atmosphere of doubt and uncertainty in the City Council with the approach of the first administrative election in three years on Oct. 24.

Twenty years ago this week -- on Sept. 7, 1940 -- The Battle of Britain, Hitler's massive and savage air attack on British cities and industries, began. Weeks before it started, Winston Churchill knew it was imminent and said to the British people: "Let us therefore * * * so bear ourselves that, if the British Commonwealth and Empire lasts for a thousand years, men will still say, 'This was their finest hour.'"
PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Sept. 3 -- Ivo Matkovic, sailing Ripple, captured the Manhasset Bay One-Design honors today in the interclub racing at the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club.

YOU have to know the rules of the game to master a hi-fi show. This writer offers some how-to-win pointers, not as a virtuoso, but as an audio John Doe who has learned from both defeat and victory during a decade of shows.

ROME, Sept. 3 -- A 19-point splurge by Jerry West of West Virginia led the United States basketball team to an 81-57 victory over a surprisingly scrappy team from the Soviet Union tonight. The Americans thus virtually clinched the Olympic basketball championship.

LEOPOLDVILLE, The Congo, Sept. 3 -- Keeping the "cold war" out of the Congo is probably the major preoccupation of the United Nations, of other African powers and of the United States. Marshall Pease, Howard R. Stevenson, and Harvey A. Wagner have been elected assistant vice presidents of the Detroit Edison. Mr. Pease will continue as manager of purchases and real estate. Mr. Stevenson will retain his duties as head of sales and Mr. Wagner will continue as manager of system development.

MERIDEN, Conn., Sept. 3 (AP) -- Representative Frank Kowalski said today that he had called for a Congressional investigation of the reported use of enlisted men to perform personal chores for officers, at the Naval Academy in Annapolis.

The four players who have been representing the United States in American zone Davis Cup play made their debuts in the national tennis singles championships at Forest Hills, Queens, yesterday. For three of them, the appearances served as nothing more than tune-ups.

THE voice of William Francis Guess is from South Carolina, but not from the inner citadel. His pungent, provocative Annals, which recall Ben Robertson's memorable "Red Hills and Cotton," has a definite tongue-in-the-cheek quality.

A New Jersey court decision that prohibits a mortgage or title company from practicing law unless it is involved as a principal has stirred considerable interest because, by inference, it deals with the question whether home buyers should engage lawyers to handle their purchases.

IN recent years television has been coming up with occasional documentaries that show the effects of discrimination in the South. Rarely, however, has the subject of discrimination in the North been touched upon.

SAN JUAN, P.R., Sept. 3 -- Moving against the opposition of the island's three political parties and especially against Gov. Luis Muffoz Marin's Popular Democratic party, a new political force has come into being here.

THE strength of Eugene Ziler's first book lies in the effective characterization of "little" individuals almost lost in the maelstrom of contemporary metropolitan life. Mr. Ziller's New Yorkers -- garment workers, second-generation shopkeepers, professional men, tenement and apartment dwellers -- are created with understanding, clarity and admirable seriousness of purpose.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Sept. 3 -- One more Arkansas school district is scheduled to be added Sept. 6 to the nine which already have some degree of desegregation. The Dollarway School District, near Pine Bluff in southeastern Arkansas, has accepted a 6-year-old Negro girl for the first grade in a previously all-white school.

ONE of the most highly publicized and eagerly awaited TV series in the medium's short history took shape last week. This was marked by announcement in Washington that Vice President Nixon would finally meet Senator John F. Kennedy face to face in a discussion of campaign issues on all networks starting Monday, Sept. 26.

ATLANTA, Sept. 3 -- The opening of public schools across the South may bring one of the most decisive years in the desegregation struggle since 1954. No significant rise is likely in the number of Negroes attending previously white classes.

THE uses of anchovies are legion. It is therefore surprising that in the average American kitchen they are used primarily as a garnish for canapes and, less frequently, as a salad ingredient. Throughout the Mediterranean, anchovies give savor to pasta and potatoes and to certain bland dishes, including several made with veal.

STAMFORD, Conn., Sept. 3 -- Leaders of the fleet in the twenty-sixth Vineyard race were nearing Stamford Yacht Club late tonight. An 11 P.M. report by radio from Nina, the yacht designated to advise the committee of estimated times of arrival, established that the Nina and four other craft were in the vicinity of the Long Island shore off Port Jefferson.

For Ages 7 to 9. ONCE a staple item among girls books, the boarding-school story is a rarity now, at least in America where most children go to day school. Ursula Nordstrom's gentle, acutely observed picture of the boarding-school world, is doubly unusual because it is for a much younger group -- the heroine is only 8 -- than most such stories.

Detectives who had hidden in a Queens apartment for two weeks seized an ex-convict yesterday with a cache of twentyfive pounds of nearly pure heroin. The police estimated that the heroin would have had a retail value of $3,300,000 in the underworld market.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Sept. 3 (UPI) -- The Chicago Bears, led by the passing of Zeke Bratkowski, whipped the Washington Redskins, 17 -- 0, tonight in a professional exhibition football game before 13,970 in the Gator Bowl.

The announcement by Premier Fidel Castro of Cuba's Intention to recognize Red China and break relations with Nationalist China was like the explosion of a time bomb. We all knew it was coming, but could not know just when. The declaration of San Jose, with its implied condemnation of Cuba's relations with the Soviet bloc, was the challenge that the fiery Cuban leader, accepted as his reason to explode the bomb.

PEOPLE in the motion-picture business are eternal optimists, despite their familiar disposition to cry frequently into their beer. WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 (AP) -- For $3.50 you can find out how many babies are born each year without the aid of a physician, how many tramps are killed by trains, and how much the average Cincinnati dentist charges to fill a tooth.

When the 1960-61 school year gets under way, the number of American children expected to be enrolled in every kind of school, from kindergarten through high school, will be 44,670,000. This up-to-the-minute estimate prepared by the United States office of Education last week compares with 42,970,000, given as the revised total for last year.

BERLIN, Sept. 3 -- Walter Ulbricht, Communist leader of East Germany, warned the 2,000,000 West Berliners tonight that they must negotiate a peaceful settlement of the "abnormal" conditions in their divided city "in time."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 (AP) -- The Rev. Dr. Norman Vincent Peale of New York, minister and author, will be chairman here Wednesday of a meeting of Protestant clergymen and laymen "concerned about the political aspects of Roman Catholicism."
