CHICAGO -- The joys and sorrows of traveling with children have been set forth elaborately on these pages recently. The contrasting views expressed have been those of parents, but little has been written on the plight of the youngsters themselves.
A flock of ten sheep, led by a goat, balked at crossing the George Washington Bridge yesterday, giving an unexpected twist to a publicity gimmick.

ELISABETHVILLE, the Congo, Sept. 3 -- The vanguard of Albert Kalonji's volunteer army moved into Kasai Province today to help guerrillas battling Congolese Government troops. Casualties there now are reported at 1,000, with 300 slain.

LONDON, Sept. 3 -- An Albanian refugee who gave up the home and job provided for him in a little Somerset town because of the lure of London has been called an ingrate by the British Council for Aid to Refugees.

WALNUT GROVE, Calif., Sept. 3 -- A mechanical harvester, hailed as foreshadowing a revolution in California's 200 square miles of tomato fields, was demonstrated here this week in the Sacramento Valley.
LOS ANGELES, Sept. 3 -- The owlish but scrappy executive of the nation's third largest city, who told Premier Khrushchev where to head in, decided this week to run for a third four-year term.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 -- There appears to be a hidden bonus of about $70,000,000 for some states, especially Southern states, under the medical-care program for the aged awaiting the President's signature.

Foreign traders who may have been growing gloomy over the seeming epidemic of crises in key market areas got a good antidote for pessimism last week. It came with a report by the Department of Commerce indicating that United States exports might be on the way to their second highest total for any year.
LENINGRAD, Aug. 12 -- During the last five years Soviet explorers have made scientific observations on bare ground at come sixty points around half the coast of Antarctica.

Resident buying offices report that adaptations of the latest European fashions are beginning to appear on the market. National advertising campaigns will begin early this month to promote the new fashions.

HOUSTON, Tex. Sept. 3 -- Schools in a number of areas throughout Texas have been integrated since soon after the Supreme Court handed down its school desegregation decision in 1954. It is likely that first grade classes of the Houston school system, the largest segregated system in the country, will be integrated when schools open Wednesday.

FORTUNE, a divinity who delights in breaking the rules of her golden game, has a way of specially favoring the foot-loose and the fancy-free. Witness the case of the author of these scandalously extrovert reminiscences, a British-born engineer-adventurer-inventor who was obviously destined from the start to become a beneficiary of the goddess.

THE title character of "Anna Teller" is a 74-year-old grandmother who comes to the United States as a refugee from the 1956 Hungarian uprising. The novel primarily deals with her. personality and relationship with her family and son's friends and, secondarily, with the adjustment of a newcomer to America.

MONTREAL. THE clouds of dust rising from the rubble where many buildings are being demolished in one of the most blighted areas of this old city, are slowly taking the shape of a concert hall that will eventually form the main component of a Place des Arts complex worth $13,500,000.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 -- The 1960 Presidential campaign yed off the floor of Congress and back to the hustings this week-end.
AUTOMATION is the principal feature of a group of assorted still and movie cameras and projectors announced last week by Eastman Kodak. The new products will be on the market shortly.

TWO specialty flower shows are scheduled for this week. On Wednesday, the Connecticut Unit of the Herb Society of America will stage its third annual herb show at the Eddy Barn in Southport, from 2 to 6 P.M.
On the sixth floor of the Custom House in Bowling Green, on a closed door, a sign warns: "Visitors Prohibited."

WHEN a visitor at radio station WNEW asks to see Gene Klavan and Dee Finch, he may be told: "Go through that door marked 'exit' and go down the corridor until you hear a lot of noise and confusion. That's them."
NAIROBI, Kenya, Sept. 3 -- Efforts by Communist China to establish a foothold in East Africa are causing official concern in the area.

ROME, Sept. 3 -- The United States capped a climb back to world domination in swimming tonight as it added two gold medals -- by Lynn Burke in the women's 100-meter backstroke and by the women's 400-meter free-style relay -- for a total of eleven in the Olympic Games.
EL PASO, Tex., Sept. 3 (AP) -- Land speculators, investing on the time payment plan, are buying up vast tracts of the Southwest's plains.
NASHVILLE, Tenn., Sept. 3 -- Desegregation is being undertaken or planned this fall for the first time in fourteen Southern school districts, according to the Southern Education Reporting Service.

Enforcement of safety standards la the sole function of a city building inspector, according to a warning to home buyers, who are advised not to expect a municipal inspection service to guarantee the work of the contractor.
Fourteen newspaper executives from the Middle East and North Africa will begin a two-month visit to the United States on Thursday at a seminar at the American Press Institute, Columbia University.

LABOR Day finds labor and management near failure on a do-it-yourself project of great importance to the survival of a free society. They have been seeking, with a dismaying lack of progress, to devise their own formula for industrial peace and for solution of the new problems presented by automation and intensified foreign competition.

A young man who quarreled with his father back in 1922 because he-wanted to write and produce movie romances and his father wanted him to become a big flour-and-feed man is a top corporate executive in his own right today -- and still is uncertain about whether his father planned it that way.

A HUNDRED-YEAR war has been won by the English sparrow. Its victory became official the other day when the United States Department of the Interior lifted its ban against importing the bird, on the grounds that nobody would want to bring in any more because so many are here now.

FICTION A JOURNAL OF THE PLAGUE YEAR. Daniel Defoe. (New American Library-Signet. 50 cents.) What happened when the Black Death ravaged London in 1665 -- a classic of imaginative and graphic journalism written in 1721. Prof. J.H. Plumb of Cambridge sets the stage in a foreword.
A new organization for the inspection and certification of shipboard cargo-handling equipment has been formed here by a group of men with long experience in the maritime industry.

THERE has been a plethora of special bids proposed, and by some players adopted, in the last few years. Casual players, who play for relaxation and do not like to work too hard or memorize top much, almost unanimously dislike such bids, They maintain, with considerable justice, that too many artificial bids can ruin the game.

NEW art museums are springing up all over the land. Perforce, they have a new look and often they serve new purposes. But frequently they leave a question as to whether the new look and the new purposes aren't achieved at the expense of what art museums are built to serve -- in a word, art.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 -- The post-convention Congressional session, whose adjournment this week was mourned by no one, raised more questions than it answered, but in this process sharpened the Presidential campaign issues between Vice President Nixon and Senator John F. Kennedy.

HACKENSACK, N.J., Sept. 3 -- A proposal that the Bergen County Park Commission expand Rockleigh Golf Course received impetus this week from the Golf Needs Advisory Committee, which was appointed by the commission several months ago.
PITTSBURGH, Sept. 3 (AP) -- The Brotherhood of Railroad Trainmen called a strike today against three subsidiary railroads of the United States Steel Corporation in a contract dispute.
PARIS, Sept. 3 -- France has more serious problems to deal with but none has caused more general hand-wringing than what has become known as "the Olympic catastrophe."

To the Grass Roots The Presidential campaign has now entered the phase which Lord Bryce said "rises in September and boils furiously through October" -- the phase of "commotion and excitement * * * of speaking, writing, telegraphing and shouting."

NDOLA, Northern Rhodesia, Sept. 3 (Reuters) -- The police took strong measures to prevent further racial violence today after whites and Africans clashed, in Northern Rhodesia's copper-mining area last night for the second time in two days.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The deteriorating cycle of mutual recrimination which so regularly disturbs attempts to carry on business between the United States and the Soviet Union is nicely demonstrated in the exchange of polite invective in the letter column in The Times of Aug. 16.

THE nation's first "automated post office" will receive postal tribute on Oct. 20. On that date, the new post office, in Providence, R.I., will be dedicated and officially placed in operation; A horizontally arranged red and blue on white 4-cent commemorative stamp will have its first-day sale in the new post office on Oct. 20.
STILLWATER, Minn., Sept. 3 (AP) -- Disgruntled convicts surrendered to National Guard bayonets today after a fifteen-hour holdout on the baseball field of the Minnesota state prison.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Sept. 3 -- The state of emergency in South Africa that was imposed on March 30 nine days after the Sharpeville dedemonstrations in which sixty-seven Africans were killed and 186 wounded by police bullets -- has been lifted.

FAIRBANKS, Aug. 20 -- Alaskans are still grumbling over the lack of highways befitting a state twice as big as Texas. But the state administration at Juneau is promising the complainants that by next year Alaska will be swinging into a road-building program in the $40,000,000-a-year category.

UNIONS -- Transport Workers Union, representing 15,000 car cleaners, oilers, mechanics, repairmen and other non-operating employes in forty-six locals of the Pennsylvania System Railroad Division; System Federation ,i52, representing 5,000 sheet metal workers, blacksmiths and mechanics of the International Association of Machinists, Sheet Metal Workers Union and Blacksmiths Union.

The increasing evidence of Soviet intervention in the chaotic and dangerous situation existing in the Republic of the Congo raises moat serious possibilities. By turning over to Premier Lumumba's regime planes and trucks capable of use for troop movements the Soviet Government has clearly intervened in favor of one side in this new nation's complicated political and military struggle.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 (AP) -- Five of President Eisenhower's nominations for posts in Federal regulatory agencies were left unconfirmed by the Democratic-controlled Senate when Congress adjourned Thursday night.

ROME, Sept. 3 -- Kenneth L. (Tug) Wilson, the president of the United States Olympic Committee, today called a meeting of all United States Olympic officials to answer charges that American athletes had been going too much for "wine, women and song" in Rome.

The steel industry finds itself in something of a predicament these, days., Most steel users seem to have lost the habit of buying steel. But one group of customers is practically begging the industry to increase production.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Sept. 3 -- Six homes in the Southport area will be opened to visitors on Sept. 17 for a tour arranged by the Junior League of Bridgeport. The event will benefit the league's Community Trust Fund.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., Sept. 3 -- Clyte III, owned by Benjamin H. Bryon Jr., scored a decisive victory in the Rhodes-18 Class today as the Seawanhakas Corinthian Yacht Club conducted the sailing program of the Eastern Long Island Sound Yacht Racing Association in variable air.

A novel urban renewal project -- thirty attached private house -- is planned for Perth Amboy, N.J., by a team of builders who dislike the institutional look identified with neighborhood rehabilitation.

CASTEL GANDOLFO, Italy, Sept. 3 -- America's traditional Olympic supremacy came to an end in another sport today as Germany's famous Ditmarsia Kiel-Ratzeburger eight-oared crew won the gold medal in the second fastest time ever made in the quadrennial games.
"If the Presidential election were held today, Texas would go for Nixon -- and the main reason would be Southern Baptist opposition to putting a Catholic in the White House."
THE last dozen years have seen changes in the technology of the art, craft and science of recording that have brought joy and misery alternately to the lives of dedicated record collectors.

HERSHEY, Pa., Sept. 3 -- The Penn football team has a new look. Back at a pre-season training ground where the Quakers have been reporting since 1937, the team has a new coach, a new offense and a new title to defend.

BRUSSELS. BELGIUM is a dialogue. Comment and retort, Fleming and Walloon, Roman Catholic and freethinker, royalist and republican, Germanic civilization and Roman, all debating spiritedly while the world pays little attention.

PRINCETON, N.J., Sept. 3 -- A $250 increase in tuition and other annual charges for undergraduates at Princeton University, effective next September, was announced today by Robert F. Goheen, the university's president.

William G. Carr, executive secretary of the National Education Association, after calling the failure of Congress to enact Federal aid to education "a tragedy for the entire nation," asked: "How can this incredible failure be explained to the American people?"

HELSINKI, Finland, Sept. 3 -- Premier Khrushchev used a birthday dinner for President Urho Kekkonen tonight as a forum to denounce the West and warn that the international situation had "worsened in past months."

ONE Of the high points of the Handel bicentennial in New York was the performance of the composer's L'Allegro ed II Penseroso in Fre'deric Waldman's "Music Forgotten and Remembered" series at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

IN the theatre the fall is the season of new birth. The promised projects, like tender shoots, are full of hope for growth and robust maturity. May Broadway and Off Broadway discover a multitude of gardeners with green thumbs!

JOHN D. MacDONALD, a product of the Harvard Graduate School of Business Administration and the U.S. Army, who did not turn to novel-writing until he was in his thirties, has published thirty-five books in a little over a decade.

EVERY fourteenth child in the United States today lives in a fatherless home. This statistic, based on the latest census figures available, includes homes of women who are separated, divorced, widowed or who have borne children out of wedlock.
Kelso of the Bohemia Stable took the ninety-first running of the Jerome Handicap yesterday, scoring by a head over Louis Haggin's Careless John.
THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Sept. 3 (Reuters) -- The Government canceled today a visit to Japan by its aircraft carrier Karel Doorman after the Japanese had withdrawn their invitation.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Sept. -- President Sukarno devoted himself energetically today to two power factors that coexist uneasily in Indonesia -- communism and Islam. At stake was the success or failure of his drive for "unity" among nationalists, Moslems and Communists.

THERE have been many books written in America about insects since Fred Melsheimer, minister of the Gospel, compiled a list of 1,363 insects, back in 1806, and wrote fn his preface "I have but few predecessors in the United States in this undertaking."
The diffusion of light coming into a house during the day and going out of it at night is the basis of an unusual exhibit planned for a Westchester County home show.

Premier Khrushchev's announcement last week that he would head the Soviet delegation to the United Nations General Assembly meeting has set the stage for an attempt to pull off a major propaganda coup, Western diplomats believe.
NEW ROCHBLLE, N.Y., Sept. 3 -- No club ever tried harder with less success to give away a trunkful of silverware than, did the Echo Bay Yacht Club.

LEONARDTOWN, Md., Sept. 3 -- President Eisenhower enjoyed a relaxed Labor Day week-end today with two of his favorite diversions -- golf and his grandchildren. He left the cabin cruiser, Bar- bara Anne, to play golf on the course at Patuxent Naval Air Station along the Potomac River in the morning.

The decline in recent years of the bacchanalian office party at Christmas time has pleased one group of people even more than it has delighted the wives left waiting at home and the employers obliged to foot the bill.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 (UPI) -- The National Aeronautics and Space Administration announced today the appointment of twenty-five scientists as consultants in five fields of space science.

PANAMA, Sept. 3 -- The "Declaration of San Jose" had hardly time to dry this week when the United States and the Latin American governments that begrudgingly joined with it in condemning Soviet Intervention in this hemisphere through Cuba were faced with the question of the practical value of this laboriously constructed document.
An emergency communications system, employing a high-flying rocket to reach around the horizon, has been tested successfully by the Air Force.

The revolution in mathematics teaching, which has been making headway in fits and starts in the past few years, last week promised to shift into high gear. The Mathematical Association of America, aided by a grant of $350,000 from the National Science Foundation, announced the launching of a crash program which, it says, will attempt ''to wipe out a one-to-four-century lag in most American mathematics teaching."

The stock market staged one of its most spectacular performances of the year last week. Excitement stemmed in part from a sharp decline in the general list, the first in four weeks. This erased more than half of August's earlier gains -- and those gains had been good.

NORTHAMPTON, Mass., Sept. 3 (UPI) -- An award-winning author and a Greek instructor, both male members of the Smith College faculty, pleaded not guilty today to morals charges in the wake of a police raid that uncovered thousands of pornographic pictures.
Moving to suburbia does not necessarily change Democrats into Republicans, according to a survey by the University of Michigan.

COSMIC RAY -- A cosmic ray shower believed to be the most powerful ever observed was reported last week by the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. It is believed to have stemmed from a primary cosmic ray particle which had an energy of between twenty and forty billion billion electron-volts -- more than 500,000,000 times the energy capability of the world's most powerful atom smasher.

ANCHORAGE, Alaska, Sept. 3 -- Senator John F. Kennedy appealed to voters today to remove the threat of Republican Presidential vetoes that he said had blocked legislation for higher minimum wages, medical care for the aged, housing and school aid.

HAVANA, Sept. 3 -- The "Declaration of Havana" proclaimed by Premier Fidel Castro at a mass meeting in the Plaza Civica yesterday dismayed and frightened many Cubans. These Cubans have become finally convinced that Cuba has moved into the Communist orbit.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 -- Senators are already preparing for next year's biennial battle over changes in the Senate's rules. Even before the Eighty-sixth Congress adjourned last Thursday, plans were being made for action in January.

WEST CORNWALL, Conn. IS there a national sense of humor, or does it vary regionally, like accents, climate, idioms, crops and politics?

CINCINNATI, Sept. 3 (UPI) -- Lew Burdette's four-inning scoreless relief stint, after Milwaukee had squandered a seven-run lead, helped the Braves defeat the Cincinnati Reds, 10 -- 9, in twelve innings today.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 -- The long-held theory that the pregnant woman must "eat for two" was challenged by several scientists at today's sessions of the Fifth International Nutrition Congress.

WHEN Franz Liszt played the piano, ladies flung their jewels on the stage instead of bouquets. They shrieked in ecstasy and sometimes fainted. Those who remained mobile made a mad rush for the stage to gaze on the features of the great man.

HELSINKI, Sept. 3 -- Premier Khrushchev, in a sweeping attack on the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, warned Denmark and Norway tonight that they were endangering peace with their continued membership in the alliance.

WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 3 -- Countess Adios, the queen bee of the harness-horse set, proved be a honey of a horse for her owners and most of the 36,169 fans at Roosevelt Raceway tonight. She won the $25,000 Governor's Cup pace by three-quarters of a length after fighting off a stretch challenge by one of the upstart drones.

Department store sales in the nation in the week ended Aug. 27 rose 4 per cent from the comparable 1959 level, the Federal Reserve Board has reported. In the prior week there was a gain of 5 per cent from the year before.
A week ago today the vanguard of some 3,000 delegates from seventy-nine nations arrived in New York for the eighth world congress of the International Society for the Welfare of Cripples.
BOSTON, Sept. 3 (AP) -- A bases-filled walk drawn by Carroll Hardy enabled the Boston Red Sox to defeat the Washington Senators today, 5 --4.

JACKSONVILLE, Sept. 3 -- Heavily reinforced contingents of city, county and state police put on a well-publicized show of force here tonight. It helped to prevent Jacksonville's week-old race crisis from erupting in renewed violence.

LONDON, Sept. 1 -- For centuries the crowded air above London's streets has been punctuated with smells, typically British smells that have been comfortable and familiar to the leisurely stroller and his nose -- fish and chips, cooking cabbage and Brussels sprouts, the incisive odor of frying sausages.
Synthetics, some good, some not so good, have been going after the leather industry's customers for quite a while, and the leather people are doing something about it.

THE hero of this highly readable report about underwater adventures is a young ex-Marine named Robert Marx, a sort of Typhoid Mary of the underwater-treasure disease, who infected the author by proclaiming that he had discovered the wreck of the U.S.S. Monitor off Cape Hatteras.

WHITE PLAINS, Sept. 3 -- The Republican organization in Westchester County is distributing a record number of big jobs for this time of the year. But it is having trouble picking a District Attorney. The job pays $21,410.

A LETTER of suspicious origin, since it is postmarked last week yet bears the supposed signature of William Adolphe Bouguereau, a notoriously conservative painter who died in 1905, has been delivered to this department.
ROME, Sept. 3 (AP) -- Harold Connolly blamed stupidity and lack of strength today for his failure to qualify for the final round of the Olympic hammer throw.
DETROIT, Sept. 3 -- After a traumatic summer on a couch of corporate self-analysis, the Chrysler Corporation is approaching a period of important decisions about the company's future.

THE countries of Africa below the Sahara are very different from one another, and the position and future of the white man in one of them may differ greatly from his position and future in another. However, one generalization can safely be made -- there is no longer any room on the continent of Africa for any white person who considers that the color of his skin entitles him to special privileges.
MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Sept. 3 -- Henry Cabot Lodge opened his Vice-Presidential campaign today with a tour of the Catskill resorts in brilliant September weather.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Dr. Paul Diederich's plan for "saving English composition," as described in The Times of Aug. 28, fills me with misgiving. IN issuing three more volumes or Horace Walpole'a "Correspondence" this summer, the Yale University Press continues one of the most prodigious publishing ventures of our time. The first volume in the series appeared exactly twenty-three years ago; and it will take about fifty stately volumes in all to print and annotate the more than seven thousand letters that passed between Walpole and his friends.

AMMAN, Jordan, Sept. 3 -- A bomb exploded today in an open field on an Amman hill. A Jordanian official immediately blamed President Gamal Abdel Nasser of the United Arab Republic for the new explosion.
RUTLAND, Vt. -- The annual six-day Rutland County Fair, one of the most colorful in New England, will get under way here tomorrow, and the occasion will mark a sharp break with tradition.

RABAT, Morocco, Aug. 30 -- The Algerian Provisional Government has begun a major diplomatic offensive to win the support of Latin-America countries at the coming session of the United Nations General Assembly.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 -- The principle that nations should submit their disputes with each other to binding decision by an international tribunal won a narrow but important victory this week in the American Bar Association.

The Presidential campaign, as expected, will really begin after Labor Day. IN September the hardy summer-flowering phlox (P. paniculata) climax their long display of color. It is a good time to select varieties for fall or spring planting.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 3 (AP) -- Mike McCormick blanked the Los Angeles Dodgers for the third time this season today and Felipe Alou's fourth-inning homer produced a 1-0 victory for the San Francisco Giants.

LEOPOLDVILLE, The Congo, Sept. 3 -- Gen. Victor Lindula, commander of the Congolese Army, flew to Luluabourg today in an Ilyushin-14 aircraft to inspect troop units in Kasai Province, where more than 1,000 soldiers are now stationed.

GRAFENWOEHR, Germany, Sept. 3 (AP) -- A sixteenth American soldier died today on injuries sustained when an over- charged eight-inch howitzer shell hit a United States Army tent area. Another victim is on the critical list.
"Great circle route" is a phrase of various meanings to various skippers. Offshore in the North Atlantic, it means an approach to Northern Europe, perhaps with some help from the Gulf Stream.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 (AP) -- Apparent variations in the brightness of the Echo satellite balloon are probably due to slight wrinkling of the skin of the 100-foot sphere, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration said today.

ROME, Sept. 3 -- The Holy See is almost sure to participate in the New York World's Fair of 1964-65, Pope John XXIII intimated today to a committee of New Yorkers who called on him to extend an invitation.

TRENTON, Sept. 3 -- More widespread, realistic and clear municipal zoning codes were urged this week in a state report. In a review of zoning methods and procedures in New Jersey since 1920, the state recommended improvements it said were "long overdue."

CHICAGO, Sept. 3 -- Crozier's speed held up all the way and Fred W. Hooper's Kentucky-bred colt won the twenty-second Washington Park Futurity at Arlington Park today. CHICAGO, Sept. 3 -- Congratulatory messages were piling up today on Thomas Edward Trotter's desk in the racing secretary's office at Arlington Park. He's a young man with a big, new job.

Following is the text of a speech in Detroit yesterday by Senator John F. Kennedy, Democratic candidate for President. The speech was recorded in Detroit and transmitted to New York by telephone.

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 5 (AP) -- C. Mahlon Kline's Conestoga, who battled most of the mile and an eighth with William G. Sims' Leddysmaun, finished half a length in front of that rival in today's Atlantic City Handicap.
A lease between a cooperative corporation and a garage operator has been arranged to assure apartment house tenants that their parking charges will not be raised arbitrarily or unnecessarily.
GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. 5 -- Fire swept the Greenwich Country Club early today, destroying all but a small wing of the three-story clubhouse.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 (UPI) -- President Eisenhower tried his hand and eye at trap shooting today before ending a three-day week-end cruise on the Potomac with his family.
BELLPORT, L.I., Sept. 5 -- It took three days to do it, but the weather finally cooperated and provided a full racing day as the Heliport Bay Yacht Club's invitation regatta closed today.
A report highly critical of the city's supervision of private nursing homes has been suppressed by Mayor Wagner to "protect high city officials," a Republican Assemblyman charged yesterday.
HELSINKI, Finland, Sept. 5 -- Many Finns were taking a new look today at President Urho Kekkonen.
ROME, Sept. 5 (AP) -- Wilma Rudolph -- who runs faster than any other girl in the world -- thinks a track is the only place to hurry.

PARIS, Sept. 5 -- An "Algerian Algeria" was pictured by President de Gaulle today as a political entity for which the paramount question was whether it would break with France or develop in cooperation with her.

By way of serving notice on a gathering of 37,544 and thousands elsewhere that they aren't ready to be counted out of the American League pennant race, the Yankees returned to their Stadium yesterday and immediately elbowed their way right back into the struggle.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Sept. 5 -- The Government was said today to have decided to ask the United Nations to place Netherlands New Guinea under supervision of a trusteeship group to prepare the Pacific island for independence.
Bald Eagle of the Cain Hoy Stable showed the stuff that a thoroughbred champion is made of before the biggest Labor Day racing crowd in local history at Aqueduct yesterday.

CHICAGO, Sept. 5 (AP) -- The St. Louis Cardinals edged the Chicago Cubs, 2 -- 1, in ten innings today. The second game of the double-header was called at the end of ten innings because of darkness with the score tied, 4 -- 4.

BOGOTA, Colombia, Sept. 5 -- Latin America is on the edge of an economic and social "crisis without precedent in its history," Dr. Alberto Lleras Camargo, President of Colombia, said today in opening the Americas conference on economic aid.
THIS fall marks the first time Martin's has imported ready-to-wear from Europe. At a press preview last week, the Brooklyn store presented its collection of designs from France and England.

Screen rights to "The Light in the Piazza," a novel by Elizabeth Spencer to be published next month by McGraw - Hill, Have been purchased by Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer for production by Arthur Freed. A novelette version of the book dealing with an American woman whose daughter falls in love, with an Italian appeared in The New Yorker magazine in June.

DETROIT, Sept. 5 (UPI) -- The Cleveland Indians blasted Paul Foytack for four runs in the first three innings and went on to defeat the Detroit Tigers, 4 -- 2, today after the Tigers had won a battle of home runs in the opener, 4 -- 3.
Henry Cabot Lodge yesterday ate hot dogs at Coney Island, kissed a pretty baby girl at Jones Beach and shared a paper cup of root beer with a freckledfaced teen-age girl admirer.
A change will be made in the sponsorship of "The Free Thinkers," written by Leonard Spigel-glass. The playwright scored a bullseye with his first Broadway effort, "A Majority of One."
LOS ANGELES, Sept. 5 -- Alfred E. Green, motion-picture director, died yesterday after a long illness. He was 71 years old.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 5 (UPI) -- Timely hitting by Willie Kirkland and Jim Marshall, combined with four Los Angeles errors, tonight helped the San Francisco Giants to a 12-8 victory, their fourth straight over the Dodgers, in the first game of a twilight-night doubleheader.

The United States Supreme Court was said yesterday to be (clearly divided five-to-four between conservative and liberal opinions. That was the finding of an analysis of civil rights and civil liberties cases decided during the term that ended in June.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 (UPI -- Vice President Nixon started his second week in the Walter Reed Army Medical Center today. He worked on speeches and "position papers" to present to the voters when he returns to the campaign trail.

Union Square, once a thriving political forum on Labor Day, was mostly a graveyard of memories yesterday. A score of speakers took their stances but the enthusiasm was dim. George Lincoln Rockwell, a self-styled Nazi leader, was absent but hardly missed.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 5 -- On this Labor Day, generally an occasion for jubiliation by unions, some of the leading unions in the movie industry are distressed at the condition of movie-making in Hollywood.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., Sept. 5 -- "The League Levities" will be presented in the Congregational Hall of the Reformed Church here Nov. 5 by members of the: Bronxville League for Service. The event will celebrate the league's Golden Jubilee and benefit its community service program.
DAKAR, Senegal, Sept. 4 -- The leaders of the West African republics of Senegal and Sudan, deep in political vendetta, talk quickly of differences between them.
Leonid Kogan, Russian violinist; Morton Gould, American composer and pianist, and a group of ten singers will be among the soloists with the New York Philharmonic this season.

THE team contest in the Knickerbocker Championships, which ended last night, was won by Manny Reiss, Larry Blum, Mark , Berger and Moe Greenspan with thirty-five matches won out of a possible fifty-four.
LITTLE ROCK, ArK., Sept. 5 (AP) -- Seven Negro students will take tomorrow morning what used to be for other members of their race the long walk to Central High School here.

LET us now turn to bird dogs, thousands of which will be loosed totally unprepared in the woods and fields on Oct. 10, the opening day of the upland game season in New York, in the often fatuous hope that they will find, point and retrieve grouse and woodcock for their masters.

ROME, Sept. 5 (AP) -- Cassius Clay, an 18-year-old Louisville light heavyweight, gave the United States its third gold medal in boxing tonight when he soundly whipped Ziggy Pietrzykowskl, an experienced Polish Olympian, in the 178-pound Olympic final.
Sharp-eyed marchers in yesterday's Labor Day parade noted that one of the smug marble lions flanking the Public Library's entrance at Fifth Avenue and Forty-first Street had changed color.

CHICAGO, Sept. 5 -- The abuse of mass college-entrance examinations was denounced here today by a psychologist. He suggested that the colleges that first instituted the tests now try to "break out or their vicious circle."

NORTHAMPTON, Mass., Sept. 5 (AP) -- A former Williston Academy instructor and a Northampton printer were under arrest today on morals charges by state police investigating alleged pornographic activities of two Smith College faculty members.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 -- The chemist who first synthesized vitamin B-1 criticized a team of food experts today for failing in 1962 to recommend rice enrichment to prevent beriberi in the Philippines.

DETROIT, Sept. 5 -- Senator John F. Kennedy told massed thousands of cheering labor supporters today that restrictive Republican economic policies had cost the average worker $7,000 to $10,000 in the last eight years in reduced income and higher interest rates.
Following is a summary of services available for commuters of various lines in the metropolitan area affected by the strike against the Pennsylvania Railroad:

VIENTIANE, Laos, Sept. 5 -- The leaders of the Communist-led Pathet Lao movement in effect rebuffed today a peace talk proposal made last week by Prince Souvanna Phouma as the first act of his new neutralist Government.
PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Sept. 5 -- Ray Kaufman's Furious II was best in an eleven-boat Snipe Class fleet today in the Interclub sailing on Manhasset Bay.

SAN JUAN, P.R., Sept. 5 (AP) -- Hurricane Donna left seven dead in the Leeward Islands today as it veered on a west-northwesterly path. There was increasing hope the storm would turn away from the southeastern United states.

YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio, Sept. 5 (UPI) -- Senator Henry M. Jackson, the Democratic national chairman, called on labor today to sacrifice and work harder in this decade "so we'll be stronger in the Nineteen Seventies."

MONTREAL, Sept. 5 (Canadian Press) -- The Canadian Stock Exchange, Montreal's junior market for securities, will put into effect tomorrow a new style of grouping the 500 stocks on which it gives quotations.

ROME, Sept. 5 (UPI) -- When winning medals are presented at the Olympic Games, the national anthem of the victorious nation is played in abbreviated form. But this was not good enough today for thousands of United States tourists.

Taking a long step forward and a half step backward on the road toward Western unity, President de Gaulle now provides a first outline of his ideas for the reorganization of both Europe and the North Atlantic community to meet the Communist challenge in Europe, in Africa and in the Middle East apart from the United Nations.
From Headlines to Routine Getting into the big, black letters of a newspaper headline in this day and age is an achievement of no little distinction to which few can aspire.

CHICAGO, Sept. 5 (UPI) -- Spokesmen for five unions that will open talks on work rules Wednesday with the nation's railroads said today that rail workers lacked benefits other industries had enjoyed "since World War II and before."
Almost two dimes out of every dollar in the $482,100,000,000 gross national product last year represented passenger and freight transportation services.

Two young Wall Street lawyers brought back a little old-fashioned campaigning yesterday as they stumped from a soapbox on Manhattan's West Side for Senator John F. Kennedy for President.

Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy yesterday defended the action of a policeman who issued a summons Sunday night to an ambulance driver tot speeding on the Franklin D. Roosevelt (East River) Drive.

THE newest landmark on "architecture row," the West Fifty-third Street block between Fifth and Sixth Avenues, is America House at No. 44. It shares the block with such distinguished company as St. Thomas' Church, the Museum of Modern Art, the Museum of Contemporary Crafts, the Donnell Branch of the New York Public Library and a corner of the Tishman Building at 666 Fifth Avenue.
A program to help small retail concerns get into shopping centers by offering to help finance such projects has been started by the Small Business Administration.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 -- A decisive stage in the Venezuelan Government's effort to extradite former President Marcos Perez Jimgnez will begin in United States District Court in Miami Wednesday.
PARIS, Sept. 5 -- President de Gaulle announced today that France would call for a referendum in Europe to give a popular basis to new political institutions.
DENVER, Sept. 5 -- Colorado voters think the most important issues in the November election campaign are world peace, farm problems, civil rights and foreign policy, an election poll indicated today.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Sept. 5 -- Foreign Minister Subandrio said today that President Sukarno would emphasize Indonesia's dispute with the Netherlands over Netherlands New Guinea at the United Nations General Assembly.

DALLAS, sept, 5 (AP) -- Johnny Pott won his first major golf tournament today. He beat Ted Kroll on the third hole of a three-way play-off and captufed the $3,500 first prize in the $25,000 Dallas Open.

The municipal colleges expect to enroll about 3,300 more students this year than last. To help meet the increase, the colleges will have $2,000,000 more to spend, according to a report made yesterday by Mrs. Pearl Max, administrator of the Board of Higher Education.
Two patrolmen were suspended from the police force and two women were arrested yesterday on charges of having been involved in an abortion case.
Plans to present another of its popular Motoramas as a setting for its new model cars, trucks and household appliances were announced yesterday by the General Motors Corporation.
AMMAN, Jordan, Sept. 5 -- King Hussein I declared tonight that the assassination of Preimier Hazza Majali was "intended to destroy the Jordanian nation."
A description of what nursing education is like now in the United States was issued yesterday by the National League for Nursing.

Premier Khrushchev ended his short stay in Finland with a sort of birthday gift for President Kekkonen, whose sixtieth anniversary was the official pretext for the visit to Helsinki. The Soviet leader now indicates that, "understanding Finland's desire to remain competitive in Western markets," the Soviet Union will not object to Finland's becoming an associate member of the European Free Trade Association, the "Outer Seven" group.

ROME, Sept. 5 -- Lee Calhoun of Gary, Ind.; Willie May of Chicago and Hayes Jones of Pontiac, Mich., all flashed home ahead of Germany's world record-holding Martin Lauer in a United States sweep of the Olympic 110-ineter high hurdles today.
BERLIN, Sept. 5 -- East German Communists refused passage today to twenty-three West German barges bound for Berlin from Hamburg with coal, cement and other heavy goods, city officials said.

NORFOLK, Va., Sept. 5 (UPI) -- An impatient sailor was flown here today from Shreveport, La. and placed under guard to await prosecution for taking a four-engine plane to San Diego Calif., and flying it halfway across the continent.
Traffic deaths stayed below the predicted total of 460 as the Labor Day week-end ended at midnight yesterday.
Opening Statement I want to thanK all of you, so many of you, for having come here at my invitation.

CHICAGO, Sept. 5 (UPI) -- T.V. Lark came from last midway down the backstretch to score a head victory today in the $122,600 Washington Park Handicap and became the fifth 3-year-old ever to win the rich stake.

The public relations concerns are in the news-making business. On the assumption that if phrase means the use of news columns rather than advertising, it is a man-bites-poodle affair when the public relation man becomes a full-fledged advertiser.

HONG KONG, Sept. 5 -- A Communist North Vietnam spokesman asserted in Hanoi today that the "revolutionary movement in South Vietnam was winning its struggle against the regime of President Ngo Dinh Diem.
ALEXANDRIA, La., Sept. 5 -- Earl Kemp Long, three-time Governor of Louisiana, died of a heart attack early today. He was 65 years old.

EDINBURGH, Scotland, Sept. 5 -- Tonight saw the presentation of the last new play on the official schedule of this year's Edinburgh Festival. The piece was "The Dream of Peter Mann" by Bernard Kops, an allegory of humanity's plight under the "threat of the atom bomb.

ELISABETHVILLE, the Congo, Sept. 5 (AP) -- A Katanga Government spokesman said today that Congo Army troops were rumored to have penetrated fifty miles into Katanga and to have taken prisoners before returning to Kasai Province.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 (UPI) -- Thomas E. Murrey, former member of the Atomic Eneryg Commission, urged to day that the candidates for President espouse resumption of nuclear weapons tests under the ground and in outer space.

Frederick II of Prussia started life as an aesthetic, almost effeminate young prince, suppressed and bullied by his father, who humiliated him in public and tortured, imprisoned and executed his best friend. But after ascending the throne of Prussia in 1740, at the age of 28, he made an indelible mark on the military, social and economic future of Germany and all Europe.

BAKWANGA, the Congo, Sept. 1 -- Congo Government forces and Baluba tribesmen clashed near here today in a short but violent battle in which more than fifty persons were killed, including an American correspondent.

THOMPSON, Conn., Sept. 5 -- George Constantine of Southbridge, Mass., wound up his big Kelso Chevrolet to an average speed of 72.41 miles an hour today and won the feature in the Sports Car Club of America national meeting for the second year in a row.
The Linde Company, a division of Union Carbide Corporation, said yesterday that full-scale production of liquid hydrogen had gotten under way at its Torrance, Calif., plant.
Four executives with the Diesel Construction Company have been promoted, the company announced yesterday.
A Canadian tug and her drifting charge -- the stern section of a wrecked tanker -- appear to be headed for a reunion in the Atlantic about 1,300 miles east of here.
CHICAGO, Sept. 5 (AP) -- A single-engine plane crashed a half mile off shore in Lake Michigan tonight. The body of a girl, about 6 years old, was recovered.
The United Philippine Lines, a new shipping company with three freighters recently delivered and others being built, plans to start service between the Far East and New York in October.

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Sept. 5 -- President Joseph Kasavubu dramatically ousted Patrice Lumumba from the Premiership of this tortured country tonight, but a later broadcast by Mr. Lumumba challenging the legality of the move spread chaos in the Congo.
Meteorites can serve, retrospectively, as space probes to plumb cosmic ray conditions across far reaches of the solar system, according to a report from Brookhaven National Laboratory, Upton, L.I.

NAPLES, Italy, Sept. 5 (UPI) -- The United States yacht Minotaur, her red, white and blue spinnaker ballooning in a good breeze, skimmed home for her second victory in the Olympic 5.5-Meter Class today. She increased her over-all lead and remained America's best bet for a gold medal in yachting.
An officer of the Jacksonville Urban League said yesterday that recent incidents in the Florida city had produced greater cohesiveness of Negroes there.

WITHIN the next few weeks two million more students than last year will crowd Into the nation's schodls. The expected total, 48,650,000, will set a national record. When school begins, according to the United States Office of Education, nearly 30 per cent of our population will be in attendance.

When Secretary of Labor Mitchell declared that Michael J. Quill, president of the Transport Workers Union, had ignored the public interest in calling a strike against the Pennsylvania Railroad he stated a truth so evident that hardly anybody can be found to differ with him except Mr. Quill and his union friends. But such courage or outspokenness from a public official is unusual enough to provoke Mr. Quill to new indignation.

CARDIFF, Wales, Sept. 5 -- Contrary to widely held belief, available statistics indicate that the world's food production has been increasing at a slightly faster rate than world population in recent years, it was reported here today.
CHICAGO, Sept. 5 -- The 100th anniversary of the birth of Jane Addams, founder of Hull House, will be observed tomorrow.

MUSKEGON, Mich., Sept. 5 -- Senator John F. Kennedy called tonight for an investigation of whether Soviet aircraft headed for the troubled Congo were being refueled at a North Atlantic Treaty Organization base in Athens.
DETROIT, Sept. 5 (AP) -- Two railroad strikes last week put at least a temporary damper in plans of the automotive industry to move 1961 model production into high gear.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 -- Resuits of the 1960 census show that the last ten year's population trends have brought new distortions into the apportionment of representation in Congress.

ROME, Sept. 5 -- The most astonishing part of the Olympic Games to date has been the unbelievable exactitude with which these noblest of Romans have run them off. The Italians have conducted them with the meticujous precision of Germans. No detail is too small, no nuance, overlooked.

A 53-YEAR-OLD poet and philosopher who wears large spectacles and speaks Polish and French was elected President of the Senegalese Republic yesterday. Leopold Sedar Senghor is a man of small stature and large capabilities.
PITTSBURGH, Sept. 5 (AP) -- The Pittsburgh Pirates and Milwaukee Braves split a double-header today.
KANSAS CITY, Sept. 5 (UPI) -- The Kansas City Athletics scored seven runs in the first inning tonight but needed another in the fifth to defeat the Chicago White Sox, 8 -- 7.

Baseball's "Black Sox Scandal" of 1919 will be the subject of a television play. It will be dramatized on the opening program of this season's "Show of the Month" over the Columbia Broadcasting System television network on Friday, Sept. 30, from 8:30 to 10 P.M.

ALL that can be said for Ida Lublensk Ehrlich's "Top Secret" is that its intentions are honorable. Like Mrs. Ehrlich herself, who has spent her savings on a number of occasions to be part of the theatre, "Top Secret" has aspirations.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The letter from Dorvan Manus published Aug. 17 demonstrates the growing awareness on the part of the public for more effective air pollution control measures. Mr. Manus is to be congratulated for his comments; but a few points may help to make the picture of automotive exhaust pollution clearer.
VIENNA, Sept. 5 -- Vyacheslav M. Molotov flew ou t of obscurity in Outer Mongolia and arrived unannounced here today.

DOUGLAS, Isle of Man, Sept. 5 -- The British Trades Union Congress opened its annual conference here today. The group was dispirited by internal troubles and badly split on defense and foreign policy.
Golfers and rowers at Van Cortlandt Park have had two unscheduled divertissements this summer: stereophonic music and a cluck that loves it.

MARION, Ind., Sept. 5 -- Former President Harry S. Truman assailed the Republicans today and accused them of appealing to bigotry at the back doc while Vice President Nixon proclaimed charity and tolerance at the front door.
LONDON, Sept. 5 -- Stock prices on the London market advanced all along the line today as demand strengthened in the face of a scarcity of offerings.

GREEN BAY, Wis., Sept. 5 (AP) -- Lamar McHan scored one touchdown and passed for two others today as the Green Bay Packers downed the St. Louis Cardinals, 35-14, for their fourth straight victory of the exhibition season.
A match between two unranked players, Charles (Chuck) McKinley and Martin Riessen, captivated a crowd of 9,000 in the Forest Hills tennis stadium yesterday.
TEL AVIV, Israel, Sept. 5 -- Farmers from ten former French and Belgian colonies in Africa began today a study of new patterns of cooperative life that have been developed in Israel.
Mary Louise Young, Houston's woman bowler of the year, started a career in the sport by being so badly injured she had to be carried from the bowling lanes.
ROME, Sept. 5 (AP) -- United States athletes and officials greeted with mixed anger and amusement today a Soviet claim that the Americans are "choking up" with fear in the Olympics.

THE jet age has done more than merely hasten passengers about the globe. It has spurred an interest in wine drinking in America. This is a recent observation of Sam Aaron, one of the city's leading wine merchants.
One of New York's handsomest rooms -- the West Room in the Pierpont Morgan Library -- will be open to the public Monday through Saturday, beginning today.
BOGOTA, Colombia, Sept. 5 -- There were two vacancies at a preliminary meeting of the inter-American economic conference held at the Military Club here this morning.
Samuel Reshevsky defeated Pal Benko in fifty-four moves yesterday, taking the second game of their match for the George P. Edgar trophy at the Manhattan Chess Club.
Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange were unchanged to 10 points off yesterday. A point is 5 cents a bale.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In the first half of this century I.R. and F.D.R. were outstanding exemplars of noblesse oblige in action in a democratic society. They disdained primacy "where vacuity is trimmed with lace" and grasped the opportunity for public service.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 -- The cold war goes on, despite the vacation season, but the battlefield is changing. The main focus has moved from the Yellow Sea, and the Baltic, from the Persian Gulf and the Mediterranean, to the South Atlantic and even to the Caribbean.

ATLANTA, Sept. 6 -- "There's no doubt about it -- we're at our low point now," conceded William C. Battle, director of the Democratic Presidential campaign in Virginia. An "uphill battle" for Senator John F. Kennedy in South Carolina was forecast by Gov. Ernest F. Hollings.

Five of the seven foreign players in the United States Amateur golf chainpionship drew first-round opponents yesterday. The tournament gets under way Monday at the St. Louis Country Club in Clayton, Mo.

The flow of food into the metropolitan area was unchecked yesterday by the Pennsylvania Railroad strike. In general, the resumption of normal business activity after the long holiday week-end produced few indications of pronounced economic impact.
MOSCOW, Sept. 6 -- The Soviet Union presented today two young United States defectors from the top-secret National Security Agency in Washington.

HOUSTON, Tex., Sept. 6 (UPI) -- The Houston School Board tonight ordered its superintendent of schools, John McFarland, to receive all applications for admission to Houston schools regardless of race.

The massive sports car transporter-machine shop-observation decked rig owned by Mrs. Harry Clark Boden of Wilmington, Del., is being prepared for its longest journey of the year. In a week or two it will start on a trek to California, carrying the racing machines of three of the Bast's outstanding drivers.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 -- Dr. Abraham Horwitz, director of the Pan American Sanitary Bureau, told the final session of the Fifth International Nutrition Conference today that nutritionists should concentrate on heads of state "as well as on the so-called grass roots."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 -- Following is the text of a statement made today by Douglas Dillon, Under Secretary of State at the Americas conference on economic aid in Bogota, Colombia, as issued here by the State Department:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 (AP) -- United States negotiators will go into a multilateral air conference at Copenhagen next Monday confronted with a demand by American carriers that the Scandinavian Airlines System (S.A.S.) be forced to eliminate at least half of its flight schedules to the United States.
GROSSINGER, N.Y., Sept. 6 -- Governor Rockefeller spelled out tonight his plans for a Federal old age health-insurance program to be financed by an additional Social Security tax.
Steel production this week is expected to fall to 50.6 per cent of capacity from 52 per cent last week, partly as a result of the Labor Day holiday.
ROME, Sept. 6 (AP) -- Rafer Johnson was crowned as the world's greatest amateur athlete tonight, and then announced his retirement from such competition.

Warner Brothers Pictures won its court fight yesterday with the American Federation of Musicians over the right to sell 122 films made from 1948 to 1958 to a Canadian television distributor for more than $11,000,000.

PARIS, Sept. 6 (Reuters) -- The organization for European Economic Cooperation (O.E.E.C.) said here today that the Spanish financial stabilization program has "achieved unquestionable success" in its short-term objectives.

The Studebaker-Packard Corporation has expanded further into non-automotive activities through the purchase of the privately owned Clarke Floor Machine Company, Muskegon, Mich., manufacturer of floor maintenance equipment.
CHICAGO, Sept. 6 (AP) -- Soybean futures reacted strongly here today to reports that the crop had begun to deteriorate in some areas because of dry weather.

The seven-story loft building on lot 23 by 100 feet at 36 West Twenty-second Street, between Fifth Avenue and the Avenue of the Americas (Sixth Avenue), has been purchased by the Pettinelli Electric Company, electrical contractors here for almost fifty years.

BOGOTA, Colombia, Sept. 6 -- Douglas Dillon, Under Secretary of State, outlined today a United States plan for a liberally financed, far-reaching attack on the "poverty, ignorance and lack of social justice" in Latin America.
PITTSBURGH, Sept. 6 (AP) -- The Westinghouse Electric Corporation propsed a new three-year agreement today to four unions with which it bargains nationally.

An attempt will be made to stave off a threatened strike by musicians Saturday night in the Broadway playhouses at a conference to be held at 3 P.M. today in the Astor Hotel. Representatives of the League of New York Theatres, consisting of stage producers and theatre owners, and the American Federation of Musicians, Local 802, will meet.
Occupancy by November has been set for Salisbury Manor, a cooperative apartment development under construction on a tract overlooking the Hudson River in South Nyack, N.Y.

The spotlight at the national tennis singles championships suddenly became focused on a familiar name yesterday when Hamilton Richardson, the former American Davis Cup star, registered an unexpected triumph.
Samuel Adrian Baugh, a rancher from Rotan, Tex., returned to the Polo Grounds yesterday with fifteen ounces of pigskin and 7,030 pounds of beef.
ITHACA, N.Y., Sept. 6 -- Count on Cornell to be in the thick of the wide open fight for the 1960 Ivy League football title.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 -- President Eisenhower called the two defectors from the National Security Agency traitors today after they had denounced the United States in Moscow.
Martin Schulman, a real estate operator embroiled in a dozen law suits, wandered tardily into Magistrates Court yesterday just as a warrant was being ordered for his arrest in a new case.
A city meter maid was found guilty yesterday of having disobeyed a "No Left Turn" signal, and of having crossed a double white line while on duty Aug. 10 in the East Bronx.

UNDER the inviting title of "Gourmet Explorations," new course will be introduced is the fall term at the New School 66 West Twelfth Street. It will consist of a series of luncheo visits to restaurants offering various foreign cuisines.

Despite some inclement weather and a pleasant Labor Day that lured potential moviegoers to suburban beaches, attendance at local movie showcases ranged generally from brisk to outstanding over the Friday-through-Monday holiday period.

CHICAGO, Sept. 6 -- Twin trade shows, called by their officials "the biggest industrial exhibit in the world," opened here today. The shows were hailed as the harbinger of a new industrial revolution.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 -- Two more campaign committees were added today to the rapidly growing complex of citizens groups assisting Vice President Nixon's Presidential campaign.
The Police Safety Bureau reported yesterday that 1,141 persons were injured in traffic accidents in the city last week, an increase of twenty-six over the same period in 1959.
A jury of ten men and two women was chosen yesterday in Supreme Court to try a $100,000 suit against Carmine G. De Sapio and three other persons who served on the Board of Elections ten years ago.

VIENTIANE, Laos, Sept. 6 -- Premier Souvanna Phouma declared today that Major Gen. Phoumi Nosavan would be considered a rebel if he did not end his resistance to the new Laotian regime and return here.
The passing of the Labor Day holiday did little to stir the high-grade bond market yesterday from the impasse into which it lapsed in late August.
RICHMOND, Va., Sept. 6 -- Two teen-age Negro girls attended classes at a formerly all-white school here today, marking the beginning of school integration in this former capital of the Confederacy.

The Reliance Manufacturing Company, maker of men's, women's and boys' apparel, has contracted to acquire the assets and business of the Puritan Skirt and Dress Company of Boston. Reliance will pay 52,000 of its common shares plus about $1,000,000 in cash.
WEST LONG BRANCH, N.J., Sept. 6 -- The Guggenheim estate, a thirty-five-room mansion on eight acres, has been given to Monmouth College to serve as a library.

CHESTNUT HILL, Mass., Sept. 6 -- A year ago, Boston College had a football squad that was expected to raise the stock of the Eagles high in the intercollegiate gridiron world. It didn't. The Eagles finished with a five-won, four-lost record and dismissed their coach.
RUMSON, N.J., Sept. 6 -- The parents of nine debutantes from the Rumson area gave a joint supper dance for them this evening at the Seabright Lawn Tennis and Cricket Club here.

PARIS, Sept. 6 -- President de Gaulle went off to Brittany tonight to meet the people. He left behind him little enthusiasm and some disappointment by way of reaction to his farranging news conference yesterday.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 6 -- Representatives of 20,000 maintenance men on strike against the Pennsylvania Railroad rejected today its plan for ending the six-day walkout.

The "Du Pont Show of the Month" has canceled plans to present a play about baseball's 'Black Sox Scandal" of 1919. It was to be televised Sept. 30 as Du Pont's seasonal premiere over the Columbia Broadcasting System network.
A forecast of a decline in the potato crop in Maine and reports of frost damage caused sharp advances in potato future prices yesterday in active trading on the New York Mercantile Exchange.
ABINGTON, Pa., Sept. 6 -- Henry Cabot Lodge declared tonight that the United States would win the "cold war" by bringing it to an end -- thus averting the danger of a hot war.
AMMAN, Jordan, Sept. 6 -- King Hussein accused the United Arab Republic and President Gamal Abdel Nasser today of direct responsibility for the assassination of Premier Hazza Majali.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 -- Secretary Arthur S. Flemming attached Senator John F. Kennedy today for "completely distorting the record" of Vice President Nixon and the Republican party on teachers' salaries and medical care for the aged.

Facts About How We Grew This year the Bureau of the Census is in the market with a historic, if not altogether world-shattering, document. It contains statistics about the United States, including comparative figures of almost every description since the days of our founding fathers.

The long-smoldering bitterness between Lumumba and Kasavubu that has now erupted into open conflict in the Congo is no mere Gilbertian farce being acted out by rival chieftains. It includes all the most dangerous elements of personal, tribal and sectional conflict; and it goes beyond them all to the deeper problem of the structure of the state.

BESSEMER, Ala., Sept. 6 (AP) -- A grand jury indicted Harrison E. Salisbury of The New York Times today on forty-two counts of criminal libel. The indictment grew out of articles about race relations in the Birmingham-Bessemen area published in the Times in April.

Mike Sorrentino is a jockey who is "good on grass." He was good yesterday at Aqueduct, where he came through with a victory on Sauchrie, owned by Mrs. John W. Galbreath, in the feature event of a mile and a sixteenth.
ROME, Sept. 6 (AP) -- Doug Blubaugh, Terry McCann and Shelby Wilson, three Oklahoma wrestlers, won Olympic gold medals for the United States tonight in the finals of the freestyle competition.
ROME, Sept. 6 -- At the age of 18, Herb Elliott had given up running, liked to smoke, drink beer, keep late hours and tool around Perth, Australia, on his motor scooter.

Dr. James E. Alien Jr., Commissioner of Education, disclosed yesterday that he would file a brief as a "friend of the court" in the current conflict on jurisdiction between the Board of Higher Education and the State Commission Against Discrimination.
ROME, Sept. 6 (AP) -- Floyd Patterson, the world heavyweight champion, fought one of his toughest fights today -- and barely staggered through to a draw.

The appearance in Moscow of the two former employes of the National Security Agency, Bernon F. Mitchell and William H. Martin, recalls the similar defection to the Communists of two members of the British Foreign Office.
SAN JUAN, P.R. Sept. 6 -- Raging flood waters and high tides of Hurricane Donna left at least 102 persons dead in Puerto Rico tonight.

TOKYO, Aug. 28 -- The Ministry of Finance is seriously studying plans to institute a securities yen system along with the problem of floating Japanese stocks on the New York market through the American Depository Receipt system.

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Sept. 6 -- Shots echoed through the downtown area of Leopoldville for nearly an hour tonight as the police broke up a demonstration of several hundred young supporters of President Joseph Kasavubu.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 (AP) -- The Atomic Energy Commission announced today sharply lowered radiation-exposure limits for workers in atomic-industry plants.
Airline service between New York and Mexico City, limited till now to propeller-driven craft, will graduate to pure jets by the end of the year.
DUST disturbs any meticulous housewife, but it can have a much more alarming effect. It can make a woman sneeze, cough, sniffle, itch and weep.
The Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. accused the Democrats and Republicans last night of being "hypocritical" on civil rights.

ROME, Sept. 6 (AP) -- The Soviet Union pulled away from the field in compulsory exercises tonight and virtually clinched the Olympic women's gymnastics team gold medal with the event only half completed. The United States was ninth with 179.726 points.

Hailing their five-day "baby blockade" of West Berlin as a victory because it produced no other Western counter-action except verbal protests, the East German puppet rulers now threaten more drastic action to isolate and strangle the Western stronghold behind the Iron Curtain.
A Siberian curiosity known as a Pallas' cat was on view at the Bronx Zoo yesterday.

PARIS, Sept. 6 -- The controversial decision by the French Government to permit the final export of the French masterpiece "The Fortune Teller" has been inferentially linked to a donation to the Louvre by Georges Wildenstein, an art dealer in Paris and New York.

ODENTON, Md., Sept. 6 (AP) -- Ed Runge testified at a Magistrate's Court hearing today that a rendezvous with two women at a suburban Washington motel led to an attempted extortion against him and a fellow American League umpire, Bill McKinley.
LONDON, Sept. 6 -- President de Gaulle's failure yesterday to outline anything new on the Algerian question has caused disappointment and concern here.
TORONTO, Sept. 6 (Canadian Press) -- One of Canada's oldest manufacturers of television antennas and industrial electronic equipment has been sold to American interests.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 6 -- Former Judge Robert S. Marx, founder and the first national commander of the Disabled American Veterans, died in his sleep last night at his summer home in Charlevoix, Mich. He was 71 years old.
NAPLES, Italy, Sept. 6 (UPI) -- An American boat builder, a Soviet factory worker and a Danish sail maker clinched gold medals today in the Olympic yachting regatta.
THE scheduled "great debate" between Vice President Nixon and Senator John F. Kennedy looks as if it may emerge as a spectacular news conference for two.

Felix Tyroler, executive secretary of the National Tulip Society, was on hand yesterday to express his pleasure as the first of 300,000,000 flower bulbs from the Netherlands arrived at Hoboken. It did not seem to offend Mr. Tyroler at all that the shipment included hyacinth and daffodil bulbs.

WHITE PLAINS, Sept. 6 -- Supreme Court Justice Elbert T. Gallagher announced from his bench today that, true to his promise of Aug. 25, he would call his court to order an hour earlier tomorrow and recess it an hour later than has been customary for many years.
THE following dinner menu is given as a guide to the use of foods that are reasonable in cost. A recipe is offered for an easy-to-prepare main dish.

Last spring R.E. Moxley, an assistant vice president of the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company, the largest issuer of American Depositary Receipts, traveled to Japan to describe the process to Japanese business men and Government officials.
DETROIT, Sept. 6 (AP) -- Ken Aspromonte slammed a two-run homer in the tenth inning tonight as the Cleveland Indians defeated the Detroit Tigers, 10 -- 8.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 6 (AP) -- The Pittsburgh Pirates defeated the Milwaukee Braves, 5 -- 3, with an eighth-inning rally tonight. But they lost the services of their shortstop, Dick Groat, for about four weeks.

The battle of the Bermuda shorts at Barnard College seems to have been won by the students. They raised a tempest on the small Broadway campus in May when the college president, Millicent C. McIntosh, outlawed slacks and shorts in class.
CHICAGO, Sept. 6 -- There is really no such thing as hypnosis, a psychologist declared here today.

SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., Sept. 6 -- Eugene F. Kinkead, chairman of the executive committee of the Colonial Trust Company, Rockefeller Center, New York, died today in his home at 273 Scotland Road. His age was 84.
HARTFORD, Sept. 6 -- Gov. Abraham A. Ribicoff opened a "get-out-the-vote" campaign in Connecticut tonight.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 -- Twenty-two years ago the incoming Secretary of State was horrified to learn that the State Department maintained a crew of codebreakers that had, among other feats, cracked the Japanese code during the Washington naval disarmament negotia- tions of 1921-22.

ARTHUR M. SCHLESINGER JR. (Harvard 1938, summa cum laude) is one of the ablest contemporary American historians. Ever since the publication of "The Age of Jackson" in 1945, when Mr. Schlesinger was only 27 years old, there has been no doubt about that. His diligence in research is phenomenal, his mastery of a lively and readable style unusual.

Michigan is planning the sale of $25,000,000 of serial bonds on Sept. 20 to finance construction of trunk line highways. The securities will come due from 1961 to 1985. The bonds will be secured by a pledge of the state's motor vehicle revenues.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Your editorial of Aug. 30 under the title "'Things' and 'Services,'" which quotes me in connection with the release of the Consumer Price Index for July, seems to imply that I and members of my staff minimize the significance of continuing price increases, especially for services, in assessing current price trends.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 6 (AP) -- Five singles in the tenth inning enabled the Cincinnati Reds to score five runs and post a 6-1 victory over the last-place Philadelphia Phillies tonight.

The drive toward regional economic integration, a major factor in Western Europe, is emerging in Latin America. This development is pointed up in the latest monthly review of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.
HONG KONG, Sept. 6 -- Soviet and Chinese Communist spokesmen agreed in Hanoi today that war between Communist and capitalist worlds could be prevented.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 (AP) -- President Eisenhower today appointed Gen. Clyde D. Eddleman, now Army commander in Europe, to become Vice Chief of Staff for the Army this fall. He will succeed Gen. George H. Decker, recently confirmed as Army Chief of Staff.
The Transit Authority disclosed yesterday that it was exploring a two-way communication system between moving subway trains and a central office.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 -- President Eisenhower said today that the nation must remain prepared to "face resolutely the dangers of any possible war" until powerful aggressors renounce their aims of world conquest.
SAN SALVADOR, Sept. 6 -- The Government announced today that it had smashed a "widespread Communist plot to usurp power and destroy our republican institutions."
A group of Japanese department store executives toured the offices of the Associated Merchandising Corporation at 1440 Broadway yesterday.
During the Labor Day weekend 415 persons died on the nation's highways.
KANSAS CITY, Sept. 6 (UPI) -- Hank Bauer's two-run single in the ninth inning gave a 3-2 victory to the Kansas City Athletics over the Chicago White Sox tonight.

An effort to obtain a worldwide agreement to delay the purchasing of supersonic airliners may be made during the forthcoming annual meeting of the International Air Transport Association in Copenhagen.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 -- The United States Court of Appeals ruled today that Dr. Linus C. Pauling would have first to be tried for contempt of Congress before he could obtain a court decision on whether the could be required to disclose the names of persons who helped him circulate a petition.
ROME, Sept. 6 -- Herb Elliott and Otis Davis today ran the two most brilliant races probably ever seen on the same day in the Olympic Games.

Directors of Investors Diversified Services, Inc., giant Minneapolis investment company, voted on Aug. 31 to call a special stockholders meeting for Sept. 19 on a board proposal to remove Clint W. Murchison Jr. and John Murchison as directors.

YOUNG tennis enthusiasts who are struggling over a weak backhand or a poor service may want to see the masters perform at the United States Lawn Tennis Association's national championships at Forest Hills.
ELISABETHVILLE, the Congo, Sept. 6 (AP) -- President Moise Tshombe of Katanga sided today with President Kasavubu in his battle with Premier Lumumba.

The Meadow Brook National Bank, second largest in Nassau County, announced plans yesterday to become the first suburban institution to extend its operations into New York City. Augustus B. Weller, chairman, said that merger agreement had been signed with the Colonial Trust Company and the Queens National Bank.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 6 -- The Soviet Union formally asked the General Assembly today to consider the perennial question of admitting Communist China to the United Nations.

MARCEL MARCEAU belongs to the rare, noble line of clowns whose creations tremble between laughter and tears. And in "The Overcoat," which he has based on Gogol's pathetic tale of a clerk who makes a fine fur coat the sum of his, life, he moves over almost entirely into heartbreak.
