Pier 23 on the Brooklyn waterfront, completely rebuilt a year ago for the Moore-McCormack Lines, was the scene last night of one of the busiest peace-time cargo operations in recent waterfront history. And it will be busier today.

For the last year and a half the justices, clerks and office workers in Brooklyn's large new Supreme Court building have been frequent hosts to a wide assortment of touring pupils, law students, civic workers and jurors.

MOSCOW, Sept. 6 -- A New York University Hebrew scholar said today that he had uncovered manuscripts that record original, uncensored sections of the Talmud -- the Jewish Interpretation of Biblical law.
LONOON, Sept. 6 -- Prices moved downward on the stock market here today as buying petered out after yesterday's splurge.

THIS year the child is the most designed around member of the household. Both here and abroad architects, interior designers and furniture manufacturers seem to be involved in a "crash" program to create the most suitable furnishings and backgrounds for children's rooms.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Permit me to compliment you and your staff upon the informative treatment of the Cuban imbroglio. The European edition of the "News of the Week in Review" for Aug. 28 was well received here on the Continent, and I think did much to clarify the present situation vis-a-vis Cuba and to show the patience and understanding which the United States has applied in this difficult problem.
Some of the "glamor stocks" made broad retreats yesterday, but the market as a whole preferred moderation. Most groups were weak but the losses were relatively small.
DETROIT, Sept. 6 -- The Ford Motor Company said that its German subsidiary would introduce a new small car in October that will be marketed both abroad and by the company's United States dealers.
FOR several years a small, irksome dispute has been going on among public officials and people who deal professionally with children as to whether children's fishing "derbies" are good or bad.

Hospitals Commissioner Morris A. Jacobs said yesterday that ambulance drivers were technically required to obey traffic regulations while on emergency calls. However, when the emergency is serious enough to require passing a red light, they should do so with extreme caution, he added.
Governor Rockefeller said yesterday that industry needed a tax break from the next national Administration to retool.

MOSCOW, Sept. 6 -- The United States defectors from the National Security Agency have given the Soviet Union new evidence to support its contention that the United States plane that went down in Soviet Armenia in September, 1958, was on espionage mission.

The Yankee pennant drive went completely into reverse at the Stadium yesterday as the Bombers, on the eve of their final swing around the West, came down with one of their worriest performances of the year.

Whenever President de Gaulle says anything about Algeria the world eagerly searches for some new word and most of all for some reason to hope that a solution is on the way. At his Paris press conference on Monday the General provided some crumbs to feed that hope. They were not much more.

The harness horse breeding industry in New York State gained an assist yesterday when five New York tracks joined Yonkers Raceway in extending the New York Sire Stakes No. 1 to carry an aggregate of $182,000 in added money.

Herbert Gold, 36-year-old author of nearly forty published stories and of five novels, has written a play, "Love and Like," based on his novel of the same name. It has been bought for production this season by Milton Perlman, film producer, who will be making his Broadway debut.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 6 -- Albert J. Hayes, president of the International Association of Machinists, assailed both political parties today for failing "to serve the majority of our people." He said the result might be the eventual formation of a third major party.

It was a bit warm yesterday for football. But the day was so clear and there was such a promise of autumn in the air that an imaginative man could have easily seen in his mind's eye a referee briskly stepping off a fifteen-yard penalty for holding.
SEATTLE, Wash., Sept. 6 -- Senator John F. Kennedy pressed a multi-issue appeal emphasizing the pledge of Presidential "action" as he campaigned across the Pacific Northwest today.
A Negro parents' group, demanding greater school integration, has submitted to the Police Department a list of seventy-six public schools in Brooklyn where it plans to hold "sit-out" demonstrations.
WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 6 -- Roosevelt Raceway today made known the fields for three major races.
NEWARK, Sept. 6 -- The State Chamber of Commerce and the State Federation of Labor were at odds today over the merits of a fifth race track in New Jersey.
ROME, Sept. 6 -- "My right hand hurts," said Wilbert McClure, the American light middleweight, as he returned to his corner at the end of the second round in the Olympic boxing finals last night.

NEW YORKERS back from Europe and homesick for the good life of the Continent find consolation in many ways -- from reading wine labels in a liquor shop to investing in a Mercedes-Benz. Another popular restorative is a visit to Bloomingdale's All Gourmet Shop.

THE scoring procedure in tournament bridge does not permit a player to know surely how well or badly he is doing until after the last deal of a session Has been played, but experienced tournament players try to estimate their scores as they go along by guessing what others have done with the same cards.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 -- A Federal rule aimed at restraining liberal dividend payments by savings and loan associations is being repealed before it becomes effective. The ruling was made by the Federal Home Loan Bank Board last March, to take effect next Jan. 1.

CHICAGO, Sept. 7 -- Secretary of Labor James P. Mitchell achieved an agreement today that he said could lead to a solution of the long dispute over work rules between the country's railroads and the operating unions.

The nation's seventh largest steel producer, the Youngstown Sheet and Tube Company, announced yesterday that it planned to raise $60,000,000 in its first public financing in twenty years. The money would be used for capital improvements.

Fifty prospective teachers for the city school system were fingerprinted yesterday under a new Board of Education policy.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Sept. 7 -- The Manhasset Bay Yacht Club's twenty-eighth annual fall race series began to day, with 205 starters and as fine a breeze as any small-boat sailor could possibly desire.
THE "H.M.S. Pinafore" that sailed into the Phoenix Theatre last night is a saucy ship and a beauty.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 7 -- George Meany made an impassioned plea to representatives of labor today to get out the vote for the Democratic party. Unless they do, he said, a serious recession might occur as early as this winter.
WHEN he was 22 years old, Erwin Service Wolfson made a fortune in real estate. When he was twenty-four he lost every cent of it. But he is doing all right again now.

DETROIT, Sept. 7 -- Retail sales of 478,900 domestically built cars in August were 3.5 per cent higher than the July volume but 5.3 per cent lower than the dealer volume of August, 1959, according to Ward's Automotive Reports.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 -- Henry Cabot Lodge dropped by the White House today to discuss diplomacy, politics and hot dogs. The Republican Vice-Presidential candidate, who resigned Saturday as United States delegate to the United Nations, strolled into President Eisenhower's office just in time to see James J. Wadsworth, his former United Nations deputy, sworn in as his successor.

Directors of Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, Inc., increased the dividend to $1.60 a year from $1.20 a share with the declaration yesterday of 40 cents a quarter. It is payable on Oct. 14 to holders of record of Sept. 16.

Lukens Steel Company said yesterday that it had begun shipments of the 5,500 tons of carbon steel plates that will form the heart of the Argonne National Laboratory's giant $29,000,000 "atomic race track" at Chicago.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 (UPI) -- The Agricultural Research Service said today preliminary figures indicated that farm real estate debt would rise more slowly this year than in 1959.

The First National City Bank of New York announced yesterday that it was extending its "in-plant" banking plan to the full range of consumer services offered by the bank. Under First National City's Ready Banking Service, employes of participating companies will be able to initiate savings, checking and Christmas Club accounts, apply for personal and automobile loans and Citybank Ready-Credit, a check credit plan, without leaving their places of business.
The Foxcatcher Farm's 9-5 favorite, Berlo, and Ogden Phipps' 13-1 shot, Sarcastic, divided the honors at Aqueduct yesterday in the sixty-fifth running of the Gazelle Handicap for 3-year-old fillies.
School officials and community representatives will meet today in an effort to head off a threatened "sit-out" demonstration when the city schools reopen Monday.

CLAMS and not oysters are far and away the favorite on-the-half-Shell dish of New York. Last year, according to the annual survey of receipts at Fulton Market, 714,000 pound of oysters arrived. During the same period, more than 4,000,000 pounds of clams were received.

The Securities and Exchange Commission ordered yesterday a hearing on Oct. 1 on plans of the Kentucky Power Company and its parent, the American Electric Power Company, to borrow $40,000,000 for construction of a generating plant.

IN the next two weeks, thousands of women will buy a new coat or suit or dress designed in Paris or Rome. Many will be under the happy illusion that their purchase has come fresh from the hands of the creator.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 7 -- It's been forty-one seasons since Harvard University last captured an Ivy football championship. The 1919 team won the title in the then unofficial Ivy League.

Dresser Industries, Inc. cleared $2,603,000 or 54 cents a share, on sales of $62,585,000, in the quarter ended on July 31, the company disclosed yesterday. WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 -- The United States Court of Appeals denied today a Teamsters Union motion that District Judge F. Dickinson Letts be prevented from installing a former agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation as chairman of the union's board of monitors.

MIAMI, Sept. 7 (AP) -- Hurricane conditions will probably affect the southeast Florida coast from Cape Canaveral to Key West, the Miami weather bureau said late this afternoon.

Paul A. Castelli, a Republican candidate for the Assembly, took a ferryboat to Liberty Island yesterday to talk with five voters who dwell in the morning shadow of the Statue of Liberty. He was treated like an enemy agent.
ROME, Sept. 7 (AP) -- Japan tonight won the gold medal in the Olympic men's gymnastic team competition, defeating the Soviet Union.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 -- President Eisenhower denounced the religious question as a political campaign weapon again today. He said Vice President Nixon and other Republican leaders felt as he did on the subject.
A team of education experts charged yesterday that unsound financing procedures were costing New York State school districts millions of dollars.

The builders of Manhattan's major new office buildings and apartment houses announced yesterday that they endorsed "enthusiastically and unequivocally" the City Planning Commission's final draft of its proposed new zoning code as it applied to Manhattan.
The Archdiocese of New York will start a $25,000,000 campaign on Sunday to expand its educational facilities.

ATLANTA, Sept. 7 -- Senator John F. Kennedy's campaign manager said tonight that the Democratic Presidential candidate faced an uphill struggle in six Southern states and Kentucky because of the religious issue.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Sept. 6 -- Many elderly voters in this famous gathering city of the aged have a low opinion of the old-age medical care bill that emerged from Congress last week.

Canada continues to be a magnet for foreign investment. This is underscored in a new report by the commonwealth's Bureau of Statistics, which shows that Canada gained $107,000,000 in foreign capital from international dealings in stocks and bonds during the second quarter of this year.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: To promote informed discussion of a vital national problem, may I criticize, I hope thoughtfully, your editorial advocacy (May 10, Aug. 14 and Aug. 25) of the Social Security approach to provide health aid for the elderly.

MIAMI, Sept. 7 -- Counsel for Venezuela's ousted dictator, Marcos Perez Jimenez, asked a Federal judge today to dismiss extradition proceedings against him.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 -- President Eisenhower said today that the Soviet Union would create a serious situation if it insisted on supplying the Congo Government with planes and equipment for military use.
EAGLE BRIDGE, N.Y., Sept. 7 -- Grandma Moses celebrated her 100th birthday today by dancing a jig with her doctor.

CEDARHURST, L.I., Sept. 7 -- Mr. and Mrs. William C. MacMillen of Cedarhurst and Dr. and Mrs. T. Dennie Pratt of Lawrence gave a small dinner dance here tonight at the Rockaway Hunting Club to introduce to society their debutante daughters, the Misses Anita MacMillen and Virginia Conant Pratt.

ROME, Sept. 7 -- Not long after two Soviet high jumpers unexpectedly had punctured the bubble of invincibility surrounding John Thomas of Boston University, the usually humorless Gabriel Koropkov, the Soviet commissar for track and field, was discovered in a rare expansive mood.

HAMILTON, N.Y., Sept. 7 -- A year ago, Al Kelley had to float a new football issue at Colgate from a hospital bed. Having to install an unfamiliar style of play and evaluate players he barely knew in absentia was a harrowing experience for the intense young coach who had done such a fine job of restoring Brown to its football feet before transferring allegiance to the Red Raiders.
The 7:30 o'clock curtain time for Wednesday evening performances got off to a smooth start last night in an experiment designed to attract more commuters to Broadway's legitimate theatres.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Sept. 7 -- Machine has lost out momentarily to man.

The five programs Sviatoslav Richter, Soviet pianist, is to play in Carnegie Hall in October will include one given over entirely to works by Beethoven and one devoted to the music of Prokofieff. Three will feature works of a wide variety of composers ranging from Haydn to Hindemith.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 (UPI) -- The Senate Antimonopoly subcommittee accused major wholesale bakers today of using discriminatory prices and other "predatory" practices to further a trend toward concentration in the industry.

Commercial bank investment money began to flow into the bond market yesterday in noteworthy fashion for the first time since recent moves of the Federal Reserve System released to the deposit institutions $650,000,000 formerly committed to vault cash and statutory reserves.

An issue of $16,500,000 of bonds of the Alameda-Contra Costa Transit District 1, Calif., was sold at public bidding yesterday to a syndicate headed by Bank of America National Trust and Savings Association and associates at an interest cost of 3.19932 per cent.

ELISABETHVILLE, the Congo, Sept. 7 -- Katanga, the copper-rich province whose bid for independence is a focus of trouble in the Congo, received a shipment of ammunition today accompanied by some hopes that it would not be used.

The possibility of a strike by musicians in the Broadway playhouses on Saturday night was averted yesterday when the American Federation of Musicians, Local 802, extended its deadline for another week through Sept. 17.

Abraham D. Levy, a Bronx Republican leader, was appointed yesterday by Governor Rockefeller to an interim vacancy on the Supreme Court in the First District. The district consists of New York and Bronx Counties.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 -- Ambassador Mikhail A. Menshikov of the Soviet Union announced today that Premier Khrushchev would arrive in New York Sept. 19 aboard the Soviet ship Baltika. Mr. Khrushchev will head his country's delegation at the meeting of the United Nations General Assembly beginning Sept. 20.

A new electric lamp, said to project light rays fifty miles, has been developed by the Duro-Test Corporation and the United States Army Research and Development Laboratories.

The address by Under Secretary Dillon to the hemispheric economic conference in Bogota on Tuesday proposing a "new social development program" for Latin America had a double importance. It was a practical program to initiate an attack on a social and economic crisis of the first magnitude. More than that, it represented a historic change in United States economic policies toward Latin America.

The latest insiders report by the American Stock Exchange of major changes in ownership by officers, directors and large stockholders shows that a joint venture by the Alleghany Corporation and Clint M. Murchison Sr. has been dissolved.

Among the competitors on Sunday at the Westchester Kennel Club show at Purchase, N.Y., will be a small, sturdy, rough-coated blue-and-tan terrier. She is 16-month-old Syndum Solitaire of Sheslie, an Australian terrier owned by Mrs. Valerie Donaldson of Lincroft, N.J.

MILWAUKEE, Sept. 7 (AP) -- Billy Bruton's triple and Del Crandall's long single off the left-field wall lifted the Milwaukee Braves to a 6-5 victory over the San Francisco Giants in eleven innings tonight. Carl Willey earned his first triumph in more than a month with brilliant relief pitching.
CINCINNATI, Sept. 7 (AP) -- Frank Robinson singled off the scoreboard in the last of the fifteenth tonight and drove in the run that gave Cincinnati a 4-3 victory over the Los Angeles Dodgers.
Washington market, the sprawling, historic, inefficient, noisy, dirty, romantic, outmoded trading place of night-working wholesale produce men, moved closer to oblivion yesterday.
An action was brought yesterday in State Supreme Court to set aside a settlement reached on last Dec. 24, to pay the Alleghany Corporation $3,000,000 in cash and certain stock.
Plans to form a new bank holding company were announced yesterday by the Bankers Trust Company of New York, and the County Trust Company of White Plains.
KANSAS CITY, Sept. 7 (AP) -- Ted Sadowski, a relief hurler, checked a ninth-inning rally tonight to help the Washington Senators beat the Kansas City Athletics, 5 -- 3.

More than 300 persons gathered yesterday for this dedication of the Brooks Atkinson Theatre. Formerly the Mansfield, the completely refurbished playhouse at 256 West Fortyseventh Street has been named for the former drama critic of The New York Times, who relinquished his post last June after thirty-five years.

IT IS "get-back-in-shape-forthe-city" time for many women this week. After a season, or even a few weeks in the sun, hair needs taming, figures a little controlling, city clothes need sprucing up, and complexions need special care to keep summer's golden glow.
TRENTON, Sept. 7 -- A group of new laws designed to protect the New Jersey consumer from usurious interest rates on installment loans and other questionable practices went into effect today.

MOST people realize a beautiful home and a charming room are not just the results of spending money or even acquiring rich, individually handsome pieces. WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 (AP) -- Equity Annuity Life Insurance Company, Washington, today won official approval for the sale of variable annuities designed to provide a varying income to cushion the effects of inflation. NEW CANAAN, Conn., Sept. 8 -- A dance was given here tonight by Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Thacher Richmond and Mr. and Mrs. William Morrison Tingue to introduce to society their debutante daughters, the Misses Katharine Hoppin Richmond and Marjorie Cooper Tingue.

PORT WASHINGTON, L. I, Sept. 8 -- The best finish of the second day of the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club's series on this fine sailing afternoon put the International One-Design Class yacht Reb IV, owned by Jens Louv Jr., a scant two feet ahead of Warner Willcox, sailing Stardust.
The Presbyterian Outlook, an independent weekly paper, called upon American voters yesterday to elect the best available leader as President regardless of religion.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 8 (AP) -- Victor P. Geffine announced today a settlement with Canadian Javelin, Ltd., disposing of his $6,785,000 lawsuit and said he had been named president and a director of the Jubilee Iron Corporation, a Canadian Javelin subsidiary.
THERE is a typical Hattie Carnegie customer, well-heeled and comfortably chic, who wears clothes that maintain a special kind of quiet good taste.

UNIONS -- Transport Workers Union, representing 15,000 car cleaners, oilers, mechanics, repairmen and other non-operating employes in forty-six locals of the Pennsylvania System Railroad Division; System Federation 152, representing 5,000 sheet metal workers, blacksmiths and mechanics of the International Association of Machinists, Sheet Metal Workers Union and Blacksmiths Union.

THE expectant mother who does her expecting in the fall and winter has an advantage over the woman who waits for a baby during the summer. Autumn fabrics and the jackets and coats she wears in cooler weather go a long way toward concealing her figure.

IT IS not enough to have a machine in the home that reluces a woman's work load. There must be an intelligent person to operate it. This act, which millions of women have known since engineers be an inventing gadgets for the home, was borne out yesterday when the Singer Sewing Machine Company introduced two versions of its combination rug leaner and floor polisher.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- Secretary of State Christian A. Herter said today that Premier Khrushchev's proposal for a world-wide summit conference at the forthcoming United Nations General Assembly was "ludicrous in the extreme."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 (UPI) -- The Commerce Department reports that Japan is actively engaged in re-establishing aircraft manufacturing and civil-aviation industries as important factors in economic development.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 (AP) -- A Senate investigator said today that some drug manufacturers had offered an antibiotic to the Veterans Administration at nearly twice the price they quoted to a military procurement agency.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 8 -- When a script was delivered today to Screen Gems, the television subsidiary of Columbia Pictures, it was the fulfillment of a sixteen-month dream that had touched off more excitement in the ranks of Hollywood writers than anything since the writers strike.

Employer interest in mutual aid plans to offset the financial impact of strikes has grown rapidly in recent years. A court suit filed yesterday by unions objecting to the railroad industry's strike insurance program is an indication of the concern the employer moves have aroused in organized labor.

MIAMI, Fla., Friday, Sept. 9 -- Hurricane Donna, a storm whose 150-mile-an-hour winds are responsible for at least 116 deaths, turned slightly northward late last night, portending a push of its destructive winds farther into south Florida and the Keys.

BOGOTA, Colombia, Sept, 8 -- Senator Wayne Morse told delegates to the inter-American economic conference here today that the United States decision to support the social, educational and economic development of Latin America would be backed by Congress.

In the world of pleasure boating the season of I960 will be stamped indelibly as the one when big, corporate business empires became marine-minded and merged into their hierarchies boat firms, most of them successful, profitable manufacturers.

Daily average borrowings by member banks of the Federal Reserve System declined $12,000,000 to $261,000,000 in the week ended. Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. Daily average reserves in excess of requirements declined $42,000,000 to $583,000,000 from a revised figure the week before.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- A settlement between the Post Office Department and the nation's railroads on higher pay for transportation of mails appeared near today. The Postmaster General, Arthur E. Summerfield, conceded higher transportation costs might entitle the rail carriers to additional pay.
Governor Rockefeller and legislative leaders of both major parties dug into the state's emergency fund yesterday to step up the campaign against slum landlords in New York City.

WITHIN a fifty-mile radius of Florida, a small town in Orange County, N. Y., more onions are grown than anywhere else in the country. Earlier this week, this year's bumper crop of that vegetable was celebrated there and in near-by Pine Island with a parade, a blessing of the fields by the parish priest and a gay spectacle of Polish dances.

ROME, Sept. 8 -- In Moscow's Gorky Park, 15,000 persons sat outdoors in the rain to watch the Americans compete against the Soviet weight-lifters. Thousands more, who couldn't get in, stood outside in the rain watching on special television sets.

ROME, Sept. 8 -- Far too much acclaim has been showered on the Romans for their impeccable handling of these Olympic Games. It's about time someone said a kind word about the Greeks. After all, they started this festival of muscle almost 3,000 years ago and even sought the advice of the gods in order to have only the most propitious circumstances surrounding their athletic program.

WORCESTER, Mass., Sept. 8 -- Henry Cabot Lodge opened a two-day swing through his home state of Massachusetts nere today. But even the bravest Republican politicians held out only a forlorn hope for the state's sixteen electoral votes for the Nixon-Lodge cause.

Britain's Lord High Chancellor called overspecialization and narrowness "the biggest pitfall" in modern education, at Columbia University convocation yesterday. The gathering honored the legal profession of Britain and this country.
Sir Thomas Beecham will be the conductor Sept. 25 when the first of a tape-recorded series of concerts featuring the Chicago Symphony Orchestra is televised over Channel 13.
TRENTON, Sept. 8 -- The State Highway Department awarded $11,000,000 in contracts today and disclosed that it would not lose $25,000,000 in aid that had been in danger.

BOSTON, Sept. 8 -- Senator Lyndon B. Johnson deplored tonight what he termed the declining world prestige of the United States. He listed that as "the overriding issue" of the 1960 political campaign.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 (AP) -- A score of cities from coast to coast made final appeals to the Civil Aeronautics Board today for more direct and convenient air service to Hawaii and the Orient.

Events in the Dominican Republic are following unusually complicated courses these day. So far, it appears, a policy of gradual "democratization" under President Joaquin Balaguer is still being attempted.

Safeway Stores, Inc., has sold the large plot of vacant land bounded by Sound View, Story Noble, Lafayette and Rosedale Avenues in the Bronx to Leo Silver Sons, Inc., realty investors and builders. The buyers plan a shopping center with a parking lot for 150 cars.

Litigation concerning the Alleghany Corporation and its officers and directors became more involved yesterday with the filing of two new lawsuits in Federal District Court in the wake of one instituted on Wednesday.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- Truck freight loadings last week were only slightly ahead of the comparable 1959 period, but almost 7 per cent greater than the preceding week of this year.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 8 -- The United States said today that the American republics wanted to settle their own problems and wanted "alien ideologies" to stay out of inter-American affairs.
The first Invasion of the Yale Bowl by professional teams and the opening of the American Football League season by the New York Titans will highlight Sunday's football program.
ROME, Sept. 8 (UPI) -- Sergei Filatov of the Soviet Union, riding Absent, won the Grand Prix de Dressage event of the Olympic equestrian competition today. He scored 2,144 points.
Mayor Wagner announced yesterday that he had accepted "with regret" the resignation of Dr, Alfred J. Marrow as a member of the Commission on Intergroup Relations and as its chairman.
Mrs. Marion du Pont Scott's 5-year-old Nala set a course record of 4:31 for the approximate two and a half miles of the $11,500 Bushwick Hurdle Handicap at Aqueduct yesterday.

Three sisters 2 to 4 years old who had been missing since Wednesday were found happy and unharmed last night while a door-to-door search was being made by scores of detectives and patrolmen in Harlem.

ROME, Sept. 8 (UPI) -- The towering and talented United States basketball team virtually clincned the Olympic championship tonight with a spurt in the second half that defeated Italy, 112 -- 81, to the hoots and catcalls of a crowd of 15,000.
The last $50,000,000 of the $500,000,000 authorized state-guaranteed bonds of the New York Thruway were placed or the market yesterday.
OPA-LOCKA, Fla., Sept. 8 -- The Chrysler Corporation took over the deactivated naval air base north of Miami today for a preview of its new luxury-trim compact car, the Dodge Lancer.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 8 -- The Soviet Union is graduating specialists in automatic controls at a much higher rate than the United States, six engineers reported here tonight.

The women's 100-meter backstroke champion, Lynn Burke of Flushing, Queens, said yesterday that she would like to compete in tthe 1964 Olympics as a javelin thrower.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 8 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold sharply questioned Belgium today on reports that Belgian arms had been sent by air to the secessionist province of Katanga in the Congo.

DETROIT, Sept. 8 (UPI) -- Ted Williams, making his last appearance here as an active player, blasted three hits, including his 519th major-league home run, and led the Boston Red Sox to a 6-1 victory over the Detroit Tigers today. Ton Brewer, who yielded four hits, was the winning pitcher.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 8 -- There were indications tonight that the eight-day strike against the Pennsylvania Railroad may soon be settled.

GARDEN CITY, L. I., Sept. 8 -- An Italian expert in the restoration of art has been retained to determine whether a large mural depicting the pre-Lindbergh era of aviation can be removed from the plaster wall of an old airplane hangar at Roosevelt Field.
Mayor Wagner said yesterday that the Eisenhower Administration had failed in its responsibilities toward this country's growing cities.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- Ezra Taft Benson extended a helping hand to the Nixon campaign today and wound up with his foot in his mouth.
Three schools of nursing graduated 129 students here yesterday.

Loans to business at the fifteen weekly reporting member banks in New York City resumed their decline in the week ended on Wednesday, falling $22,000,000, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.
More than 800 women volunteers signed up yesterday for a Republican registration and getout-the-vote drive here. This was twice as many as had been expected.

CHICAGO, Sept. 8 (AP) -- Grain futures prices moved up slightly today in generally slow dealings on the Board of Trade.

ANNUAL pleadings to stop or reduce the loss of crippled game birds and animals are coming from all sides now. Probably they won't do much good; no arguments can have much effect on hunters who willingly or carelessly let crippled game escape to die in pain and waste.
W. R. Grace Co. reported higher earnings and record sales for the half-year yesterday. The company is engaged in international trading, shipping, chemical, paper, oil and airlines activities.

Commodity futures price moved in a narrowly mixed range yesterday on New York's exchanges. Trading was generally quiet and dull, with evening up of positions prior to the week-end accounting for the bulk of the volume.

Sears Roebuck Acceptance Corporation, a subsidiary of Sears Roebuck Co., yesterday reported net income for the six nonths ended July 31 at $2,047,548. This is 38.6 per cent more than the $1,477,728 net for the 1959 period.

One of the dullest weeks in the bond market ever the pos-twar period came to a close yesterday with quoted values little changed from the level that prevailed before Labor Day.

The American Press Institute at Columbia University yesterday announced nine two-week seminars for experienced newspaper men and women. A seminar on Investigative and Public Service Reporting is offered for the first time.

Steels, motors, chemicals, electronics and building materials joined wholeheartedly yesterday in a stock market rally that added $2,200,000,000 to aggregate market values on the New York Stock Exchange.

San Francisco, Cal., sold yesterday $21,455,000 of bonds for various purposes to investment bankers led by Bank of America, National Trust and Savings Association.

On the recommendation of United States Olympic officials in Rome, New York City dropped plans yesterday to hold a parade on Friday for returning American competitors.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 13 -- The wheels of the nation's busiest railroad, the Pennsylvania, rolled again today in thirteen states and the District of Columbia.

CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Sept. 13 (UPI) -- A Polaris missile fired from a submerged nuclear submarine crashed in the Atlantic Ocean today, slowing Navy plans to get its new weapon combat ready by October.

ROME, Sept. 13 -- Conrad N. Hilton watched today while the cornerstone of a six-story hotel bearing his name was laid in Rome.

Premier Khrushchev's battlecry to "overtake and surpass the United States" is the theme that has replaced the Communist dream in the Soviet Union today.

THE average age of the thirty painters in the exhibition "Young America -- 1960," opening today at the Whitney Museum of American Art, is just under 31 years. Mrs. James Miles Hubball, chairman of the twelfth annual Debutante Ball of the Junior league of New York, has announced the names of the debutante provisional members of the league who will be presented at the fete.

There seems to be no end to the plots against the Betancourt Government in Venezuela. The latest was the seizure of a radio station in Caracas on Monday with a vain call to revolution. Last week a military plot was foiled. In June President Betancourt narrowly escaped death when Venezuelan military officers, helped by high Dominican officials, blew up the President's automobile and wounded him.

Investment Corp. of Florida Earnings of the Investment Corporation of Florida for its first fiscal quarter ended on Aug. 31 will total 46 cents each on 558,334 shares outstanding, Gilbert Edwards, president, told shareholders at the annualmeeting in Port Landerdale, Fla., yesterday.

Ordinarily it would not appear that much persuasion would be necessary to convince a man to go to a tropical paradise where he can be caressed by gentle trade winds -- all the while enjoying his morning kippers on a sun-drenched private terrace.
ST. LOUIS, Sept. 14 -- More than 11,500 persons, 1,500 of them delegates to the machinists union convention, jammed Kiel Auditorium at 8 A. M. today to see Senator John F. Kennedy.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 14 -- In a match that was in vivid contrast to his seven-under-par victory of the morning, Jack Nicklaus, the defending title-holder, bowed in the fourth round of the United States Golf Association's amateur championship today.
Federal loan funds became available to property owners in Queens, Nassau and Suffolk yesterday when those counties were officially designated as disaster areas in the wake of Hurricane Donna.
Protests by viewers against television coverage of Premier Khrushchev's visit to the United Nations are mounting at the networks.

PARIS, Sept. 14 -- Are European central banks purposely losing a little money in order to avoid embarrassment to the United States in the form of a still-larger outflow of United States gold?

Stocks were hammered down yesterday as the market tested the lows -- or support -- levels of the year. For the third time this year prices came close to piercing those lows, but they did not quite do so. If and when stocks do sink below the 1960 lows, they will be back to the lowest levels since late 1958.

NEW ROCHBLLE, N. Y, Sept. 14 -- The parents of twelve Negro children in a predominately Negro downtown school district here tried unsuccessfully today to enroll the children in a new all-white school on the edge of the city.
LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Sept. 14 -- The army took over the Congo tonight.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 (AP) -- An authority on antibiotics testified today that drug manufacturers were confusing physicians with printed advertising about their products.

POUGHKEEPSIDE, N.Y., Sept. 12 -- Gore Vidal, Democratic candidate for Representative in the Twenty-ninth Congresslonal District, sprawled barefooted in a gilded fauteuil of his luxurious, octagonal, Empire study as he considered the question whether he would win the election.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 -- Following is the State Department transcript of Secretary of State Christian A. Herter's news conference today:

In a gratifying display of leadership, President Eisenhower has moved to seize the initiative at the momentous forthcoming session of the United Nations General Assembly. He will appear personally at the start of the general debate to state again the case and the cause of the United States before the assembled Communist chieftains convert the session into a propaganda circus.
Senator John P. Kennedy made his first major stumping tour of New York City yesterday and put in eight hours of whirlwind campaigning within a square mile of midtown Manhattan.

WITH such a ballet as Frederick Ashton's "La Fille Mal Gardee" in its possession, it seems sheer prodigality for the Royal Ballet to have brought a repertory overseas with it. From the local premiere of the piece last night at the Metropolitan Opera House, it is safe to say that it could settle down quite comfortably for a run.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 -- The United States Navy is preparing to send a sizable carrier-based force; including 1,100 marines, to patrol the South China Sea.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 (UPI) -- President Eisenhower signed legislation today reducing some income taxes of American corporations operating abroad.
SRINAGAR, Kashmir, Sept. 2 -- Bakshi Ghulam Mohammed strode briskly onto the concrete veranda of his office building today, donned heavy-rimmed spectacles and settled in an armchair at a small table.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Thursday, Sept. 15 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold and the Soviet Union ran into a head-on collision this morning over the crisis in the Congo.
Taxicab owners were authorized yesterday to install thick plastic partitions between the driver and passenger compartments to protect the cabbies against hold-up attacks.

Hadassah, thet women's Zionist organization of America, yesterday adopted a budget of $9,875,000. Most of it was earmarked for the support and maintenance of its network of social-service and medical programs in Israel.
MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., Sept. 14 (UPI) -- Former Representative Coya Knutson won an upset victory for the Democratic-Farmer-Labor party's Ninth Congressional District Nomination.

NEW ORLEANS, Thursday, Sept. 15 -- Hurricane Ethel howled across the Gulf of Mexico toward Pensacola, Pla., early today with 150-mile-an-hour winds. It was scheduled to strike the upper Florida coast about 4 A. M., Central standard time (6 A. M., New York time).

JERICHO, L.I., Sept. 14 -- Sybil Wolfensolm of the Engineers Club withstood a six-stroke penalty to win the medal with 41, 37 -- 78 in the qualifying round of the Women's Long Island Golf Association match play championship at the Meadow Brook Club today.

WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 14 -- Joseph Masiello's Greentree Joey from Westbury, L.I., scored his eleventh victory in a row in the Tappan Zee Pacing Handicap before 17,188 fans at Roosevelt Raceway tonight.

PRINCETON, N. J., Sept. 14 -- Man is not really "born" until he is 8 or 10 months old and during these months he is particularly vulnerable to elements in his culture that may induce mental illness, an anthropologist said here tonight.

IT is odd that the cabbage family has a lengthy association with royalty. Lewis Carroll spoke of cabbages and kings and Marie Jeanne Becu gave her royal name to many dishes made with cauliflower. The lady in question was the Comtesse Du Barry, the favorite of Louis XV.
PITTSBURGH, Sept. 14 (AP) -- Stan Williams held league-leading Pittsburgh to seven hits and struck out thirteen batters tonight as Los Angeles downed the Pirate, 5 -- 2.

"THE PATTERN OF PERFECTION,"* Nancy Hale's new short story collection, is a chronicle of crucial battles. They take place decisively or indecisively in the human heart.

PEORIA, Ill., Sept. 14 -- In his first three days of intensive national campaigning, Vice President Nixon has shunted aside regional and domestic issues in favor of a plea for positive thinking about the future of mankind.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), Sept. 8 -- Israel is negotiating with some African countries to provide them with teachers of the Arabic language.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept 14 -- The Pennsylvania Railroad reported today that the strike settlement would cost the carrier less nan $1,000,000 annually.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 -- Secretary of State Christian A. Herter reaffirmed today his disagreement with President de Gaulle's recommendations on Western strategic planning and the organization of the Atlantic alliance.
LONDON, Sept. 14 -- Stock market prices here receded again today in a quiet session.

David Wayne, Burgess Meredith, Courtney Burr and sundry others are sharing a problem. Mr. Wayne has agreed to star in ''After I'm Gone," which Mr. Burr is eager to place in rehearsal on Oct. 1 for a Broadway premiere in late November.

ELEANORA GARNETT, whose creations are designed and made in Rome, has gained her reputation from her late-day clothes. In her fall and winter collection presented yesterday to the fashion press, Miss Garnett turned deft hand to daytime clothes with a definite penchant for plaid.

LONDON, Sept. 14 (AP) -- The United States crushed the British Empire and Commonwealth in a damp track and field meet at White City Stadium tonight. The Americans won thirteen events and the British four.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 -- President Eisenhower named George W. Abbott as Assistant Secretary of the Interior today. Mr. Abbott, former solicitor of the department, succeeds Roger Ernst, who resigned because of "overriding personal considerations."
WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 -- A young defector from the Soviet Navy, making his first public appearance in the United States, warned today that Soviet military doctrine was based on surprise attack.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 14 -- Stockholders of the Chesapeake and Ohio Railway gave their management overwhelming approval today of its plans to acquire up to 80 per cent of the voting stock of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad as a "first step" toward ultimate me ger of the two systems.

Mayor Wagner will preside at a ceremony opening the first municipal parking garage in midtown Manhattan today. This useful building at Eighth Avenue and Fifty-third Street, which cost $1,850,000, will have space for 455 automobiles. Like most effectuation of city traffic policy-such as initiation of one-way travel on Manhattan avenues and use of meter-maids to police parking -- the opening of this garage to serve the public is unnecessarily belated.
LONDON, Sept. 14 -- Prime Minister Macmillan may attend the United Nations General Assembly meeting opening in New York Tuesday.

The architects' plans for Mary K. Simkhovitch Houses, a non-profit cooperative on the Lower East Side, have been filed with the Department of Buildings.
CLEVELAND, Sept. 14 (AP) -- The Cleveland Indians scored seven runs in the third inning and went on to beat the Boston Red Sox tonight, 11 -- 7.
The Labor Day holiday, the last big week-end for summer motoring, failed to dent the nation's heavy inventories of gasoline.

THE homemaker who feels that family life in a cramped New York apartment is just a bare existence might change her mind after viewing the five model apartments that are opening today at Park West Village.

Speculation among aviation experts yesterday held that the temporary shortening of La Guardia Airport's one operating runway might have been a contributing factor in the crash of the American Airlines Electra there.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 -- President Eisenhower decided today to address the United Nations General Assembly Sept. 22.

The State Superintendent of Insurance has granted subscriber premium rate increases averaging 33.45 per cent effective Nov. 1 to the Associated Hospital Service of New York (New York City's Blue Cross) and approved an amended formula for reimbursement of hospitals for member patient care. Electric power production fell in the holiday week ended last Saturday to 14,216,000,000 kilowatt-hours. This compared with the peak of 14,941,000,000 kilowatt-hours the week before the Edison Electric Institute reported yesterday.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 15 (UPI) -- George Shaw, listed as the New York Giants' third-string quarterback, threw tonight for one touchdown and set up another with his passes as New York defeated Los Angeles, 20 -- 6, in their final preseason game.
Four Connecticut Congressional candidates pursued commuters into New York yesterday in an attempt to win votes.

THE Royal Ballet last night gave the first performance this season of its fulllength "Swan Lake" (or "Le Lac des Cygnes," as it is here termed) at the Metropolitan Opera House, with Svetlana Beriosova as Odette-Odile and Donald Macleary as Prince Siegfried.

Businesses increased their borrowings from New York City banks $160,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday in anticipation of quarterly corporate tax payments due yesterday. Surprisingly, however, finance companies, factors and other business credit concerns reduced their borrowings $163,000,000.

Inspired by a vesper performance of "The Bible Salesman" at the Broadway Congregational Church last winter, Albert C. Lasher and Paul Lehman have prevailed upon Jay Thompson to write a companion musical piece, "The Oldest Trick in the World."
MORRISTOWN, N.J., Sept. 15 -- Mike Cestone of Forsgate shot his second straight 73 at the Spring Brook Golf Club today and virtually wrapped up the New Jersey Golf Association's seniors championship.

Speed boating's great super-powered craft now face the autumn period when they earn their fame as they perform on the rivers and lakes. Once they were Known as the Gold Cup Class but in recent years George J. Trimper of Buffalo and others have succeeded in popularizing the Unlimited Class.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 -- The Republican national chairman said today that the Democratic chairman, former President Harry S. Truman and other "highly placed Democrats" were keeping the religion issue alive deliberately, to use it "for their own political advantage."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 (UPI) -- The National Conference of Citizens for Religious Freedom said today that it had not intended to "criticize" Gov. Michael V. DiSalle of Ohio when it asserted in a recent statement that Roman Catholic nuns were teaching in Ohio public schools.

The Appellate Division granted a temporary injunction yesterday barring the city from enforcing a new municipal law that requires the date of pasteurization to be stamped on milk and cream containers.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 (UPI) -- Vice President Nixon's campaign headquarters announced today that he would make a 5,000-mile swing starting Sept. 26 through eleven states east of the Mississippi River.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 15 -- Western nations rallied today behind Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold, who was attacked by the Soviet Union last night for his direction of United Nations activities in the Congo.
TACOMA, Wash., Sept. 15 (AP) -- Don January of Dallas shot a record 63 on the fogshrouded Firerest course today for the first-round lead in the $25,000 Tacoma open golf tournament.
Two off-duty policemen, both in civilian clothes, faced each other at gunpoint early yesterday outside a Bronx drugstore. No shots were fired, but one arrested the other as a suspected burglar.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 15 -- A three-way contest for the presidency of the General Assembly will confront the eighty-two member states when the fifteenth session opens Tuesday
SHARP words are being exchanged between the august House of Christian Dior in Paris and George Farkas, the angry Chairman of the Board of Alexander's Department Stores.
A warm, but not friendly, welcome was being planned yesterday by various groups for the arrival here next week of Premier Khrushchev and other heads of states many Americans do not like.
Premier Khrushchev has accepted an invitation to address the Overseas Press Club during his New York stay.
The election of James Lutz as president of McCrory Corporation was announced yesterday.

TOMORROW is Constitution Day, since 1952 called Citizenship Day. On Sept. 17, 1787, "the Twelfth Year of our Independence," the delegates to the Constitutional Convention in Philadelphia adjourned to City Tavern for a farewell dinner after completing more than four months of anxious deliberations.
CHAUTAUQUA, N.Y., Sept. 15 -- Gerald M. Lynch, vice president and treasurer of the Chautauqua Institution, died today of cancer in near-by James-town General Hospital. He was 52 years old.

California has designated Sept. 28 as the date of sale for $75,000,000 of bonds to finance advances to school districts for construction and advances to war veterans buying dwellings and farms. The bonds will come due serially from 1962 to 1986.

FROM beneath a way mop of red-brown hair, which she cuts herself, peek the piquant features of Mile. Arlette Ricci, the 19-year-old daughter of Paris couturier, Robert Ricci. Mlle. Ricci is in New York for the first time, on a ten-day visit with her father, head of the house of Nina Ricci.

The route for the long-awaited lower Manhattan expressway was approved by the Board of Estimate last night. It will link the Holland Tunnel and the West Side Highway with the Manhattan and Williamsburg Bridges on the Lower East Side.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 -- Department store sales in the nation in the week ended Sept. 10 were 2 per cent below the year-ago level.

A twenty-year lease between the Cunard Steam-Ship Company, Ltd., and the Department of Marine and Aviation, calling for the construction of a $5,500,000 cargo-ship terminal at West Fifty-fourth Street, was approved yesterday by the Board of Estimate.
HAVANA, Sept. 15 -- Mrs. Marjorie Lennox, American secretary in the economic section of the United States Embassy, was arrested early this morning by the Cuban Army Intelligence Service.

Arthur S. Flemming -- acting as a Nixon-for-Presldent advocate and not as the Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare -- addressed fifty-three leaders in health, education and welfare here yesterday.

ABOUT midway through the Mainbocher press showing this week, four mannequins entered the salon, one at a time, wearing what appeared to be simple, conservative dinner dresses with short, voluminous skirts.

MINNEAPOLIS, Sept. 15 -- Probably more than 80 per cent of the Americans who developed thyroid cancer by late teen-age had earlier received radiation treatments for some non-cancerous condition, it was reported today at the fuorth National Cancer Conference.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 (AP) -- The Court of Appeals ruled today that an employer could not give a union shop contract to an individual. Any such arrangement requiring maintenance of membership must be with an organized union.
THE mixed-pair contest in the regional tournament now under way at Asbury Park, N.J., will be played today in two sessions at 2:30 and 8:30.

A wage contract providing 122 days of paid leave a year for 1,300 unlicensed seamen will be signed today between, the Esso Seamen's Association and the Esso Division of the Humble Oil and Refining Company.

THE HAGUE, The Netherlands, Sept. 15 -- Honduras called on the International Court of Justice today to direct Nicaragua to yield 300 square miles of territory along the boundary between the two Central American countries.
Adlai E. Stevenson accused the Republicans last night of following a foreign policy fatal for America in a revolutionary world.
The $3,500,000 luxury airliner Britannia of the Cubana Airlines was seized here yesterday by Queens deputy sheriffs on a writ of attachment issued by Supreme Court Justice Henry Epstein.

LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., Sept. 15 -- Althea Knickerbocker rode Mr. and Mrs. Henry D. Paxson's gray gelding Flying Curlew from Holicog, Pa., to victory in the Frank Melville Jr. Memorial Trophy event as the fifty-fifth Piping Rock horse show opened today.

"I have no comment about what Mrs. Kennedy wears or what she says," Mrs. Richard M. Nixon said yesterday in reply to Mrs. John F. Kennedy's statement that the Vice President's wife spent more on clothes than she.
BAYONNE, N.J., Sept. 15 -- A shipment of Canadian Arctic ice and snow weighing several tons was unloaded here today at the Navy's supply depot.
A push-button exhibit on "How to Look at Sculpture" will be the central attraction today when the Junior Museum of the Metropolitan Museum of Art reopens.

A men's ticket-selling committee headed by Alexander McIlvaine has been formed for the New York City Mission Society's benefit theatre party at a preview of "Tenderloin", on Oct. 11. The new musical comedy starring Maurice Evans is scheduled to open at the Forty-sixth Street Theatre on Oct. 17.
ELISABETHVILLE, the Congo, Sept. 15 -- Katanga's harried two-month-old regime tried today to make political peace with a Congo Government it is not sure exists any longer.

VISITORS to the 1958 World's Fair in Brussels may have seen a tall, slim, bespectacled young Congolese who was In the Belgian Congo section as a representative of the Congolese press. If they did, they were seeing a possible "strongman" of the Republic of the Congo, Col. Joseph Desire Mobutu, who, as Chief of Staff of the Congo Army, has taken over temporary control of the country.

The Basic Products Corporation, Milwaukee, Wis., maker of electrical, electronic and other industrial products and a leading producer of barley malt, yesterday reported that its sales rose to a record $53,653,888 in the fiscal year ended on July 31.
The two top executives of the Erie Lackawanna Railroad Company that will come into existence officially on Oct. 15 believe strongly in rail transportation.
A state legislative hearing on nursing home conditions here erupted yesterday with a charge that Mayor Wagner was being "whiplashed" for political reasons.
Maj. Gen. John B. Medaris, former head of the Army's missile program, expressed confidence yesterday that, come what may, this country could match the Soviet Union in space.

THE recent highly emotional weather undoubtedly will have an adverse effect on citrus and apple supplies in the future However, during the calm that follows the storm few food prices have yet been troubled, with the exception of a few vegetables.

The twenty-five officers and firemen of Ladder Company 5, victors over raging holocausts, collapsing walls and barricades of beams, have been forced to retreat before an ignoble enemy -- an army of fleas.
TRENTON, Sept. 15 -- Senator John F. Kennedy made what is generally known as the independent vote the main target of his New Jersey campaign today.
The city's fear that a new "mad bomber" was at work ended yesterday, less than twenty-four hours after it arose and safely before the impending visits of controversial foreign leaders.
NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Sept. 15 -- The Negro principal of a school with almost all white pupils refused today to enroll thirteen Negro pupils from a poorer section of the city.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 15 -- Following are the texts of draft resolutions introduced by the United States and Soviet Union today during the debate over the Congo in the Security Council:

Daily average borrowings by member banks of the Federal Reserve System rose $38,000,000 to $299,000,000 in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. Daily average reserves In excess of requirements rose $198,000,000 to $864,000,000.
Gian Carlo Menotti, who has composed three operas for the National Broadcasting Company, has been commissioned to do another.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 15 -- Tin Pan Alley is going to college here. What are said to be the only college courses in writing lyrics for popular songs are being given as part of the Extension Service of the University of California at Los Angeles.
Plans to dock "Premier Khrushchev's ship here on Monday were involved in a dispute last night over the payment of $30,000 for the rental and repair of a municipal pier.
ATLANTA, Sept. 15 -- Georgia voters have advised the state's twelve Democratic Presidential electors to withhold their support from Senator John F. Kennedy if the electors so choose.
The Rev. Dr. Norman Vincent Peale is sharply reprimanded in editorials scheduled to appear this week-end in Roman Catholic newspapers in the New York area.

LEOPOLDVILLE, The Congo, Sept. 15 (AP) -- Angry Congolese soldiers tried twice today to lynch Patrice Lumumba. They were twice foiled -- first by United Nations troops from Ghana, then by Congolese policemen sent by Col. Joseph Mobutu, the Congo's emerging strong man.

C. Mahlon Kline's Gridiron, the betting outsider with 23,135 fans at almost 14 to 1, led all the way at Aqueduct yesterday and won the two-mile Broad Hollow Steeplechase Handicap by two lengths. Sanford Stud Farm's Sun Dog was second.
EVERYWHERE you look and listen these days, it seems as though Gerald Tarack is playing.
ALTHOUGH television sets dominate the scene in most living rooms today, one General Electric designer looks forward to the time when they will be "as inconspicuous as wrist watches."
NORMAN LEWIS, a talented English writer with a sardonic mind and little love for the twentieth century in which he is forced to live, is a specialist in hot countries.

Steel stocks have been in the doldrums this week, partly beause of the lower-than-expected operating rate announced early in the week. Atop this came an article in the highly respected Iron Age magazine to the effect that recovery for the steel industry would not come in October and possibly not before next March.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 (AP) -- The American Veterans Committee said today that Negro veterans and service men continued to have difficulties in the South because of racial discrimination.
MEXICO CITY, Sept. 15 -- Injection of the dispute over Cuba has marred Mexico's 150th independence anniversary celebrations.

IN olden times potatoes were considered poisonous. Now we are more enlightened, we just think they are fattening. However, even this concept is hardly accurate, since a medium potato yields approximately the same number of calories as fair-sized apple.
Aluminum Company of America announced yesterday three changes in its top management.

A pilot plant for the manufacture of skirts and sportswear was opened yesterday at 245 Seventh Avenue to back the thesis that garment makers in this city, a major producing center, can compete fully with manufacturers in areas where wage rates are lower.
The Long Island Rail Road was authorized yesterday to put a $3,677,400 annual fare increase into effect on Wednesday, under a proposal it had made Aug. 12.
Howard J. Morgens, president of the Procter Gamble Company, last night answered critics of advertising who have charged that advertising is being used to foster the wrong kind of American dream.
Mayor Wagner's statutory letter to the City Planning Commission which is supposed to be helpful in preparation of the capital budget for 1961 sets an impossible task.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 (AP) -- Major airlines asked the Civil Aeronautics Board to expand the merger proceeding of United Air Lines and Capital Airlines into a broad investigation of air service to Chicago, New York and other Eastern metropolitan centers.
CHICAGO, Sept. 15 (AP) -- Grain futures prices scarcely budged today from preceding closes in dull dealings on the Board of Trade.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 -- Congressional investigators were told, today that two defecting experts could give the Soviet Union no damaging secrets on United States codes.
WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 15 -- The Lady Suffolk Division of the Dexter Cup Trot had its first staging at Roosevelt Raceway tonight. Six outstanding 3-year-old fillies competed for the $20,176 purse.

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 15 -- Vice President Nixon waited in second place on the program while his wife, Pat, received the first welcome. She also preceded him as speaker before the National Federation of Republican Women here today.
COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Sept. 14 -- American-Scandinavian talks on the part Scandinavian airlines should play in trans-Atlantic traffic have progressed little here.

Sales of the nation's leading retail chains were 3.4 per cent higher in August than they were in the 1959 month, according to a survey yesterday by The New York Times. It was the fifth consecutive month to show an increase.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The purpose of writing you is to clarify the new position in which the tyrant Rafael L. Trujillo has placed himself so as to confound international public opinion.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 15 (UPI) -- The United States Davis Cup tennis team will face Venezuela tomorrow in the opening of the American zone finals, with Bernard (Tut) Bartzen of Dallas a surprise choice for the singles.

MORGANTOWN, W. Va., Sept. 15 -- Gene Corum, West Virginia's new football coach, is in a dreadful fix. He has about seventy tough football players but not one whose padded image will ever appear on the cover of a national magazine.

Work will start soon on a ten-story office building at 247 Lexington Avenue between Thirty-fourth and Thirty-fifth Streets. It will erected by Lou Kraft Associates from plans by Lama, Proskauer Prober, architects.

Never in recent years has the similarity in approach between Khrushchev's Soviet Empire and Hitler's Nazi Empire been more clearly revealed than in Russia's position in the Congo crisis, both as spelled out at the U.N. and as carried out in Central Africa.
MIAMI BEACH, Sept. 15 -- Senator John F. Kennedy characterized the Eisenhower Administration today as a "Government frozen in the ice of its own indifference."
WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 -- The United States Government is turning to private agencies and educational institutions as instruments of United States policy in the newly independent nations of Africa.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 -- President Eisenhower entered Walter Reed Army Medical Center for his annual physical check-up today after his third afternoon round of golf of the week.

The presence of Premier Khrushchev and President Tito of Yugoslavia in New York next week promises to provide a dramatic and important chapter for the United Nations General Assembly, opening Tuesday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 -- Sudan will probably expel French troops and close six French air bases in retaliation against French recognition of Senegal, State Department dispatches from Bamako, the capital of Sudan, indicated today.
A "ribbon" of theatre-ticket envelopes strung together with staples was cut by Mayor Wagner and other city officials yesterday to open the first municipal garage in midtown Manhattan.
Prices for cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 3 points up to 8 points off yesterday. A point equals 5 cents a bale.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Your editorial of Sept. 14 entitled "The Religious Issue" interests me because it only serves to sustain an underlying inference of the whole religious discussion. The inference is this -- that Protestantism is in a position to criticize the Catholic Church concerning union of church and state.
MOBILE, Ala., Sept. 15 (AP) -- Hurricane Ethel, accompanied by heavy rains, moved slowly inland tonight after lashing three cities along the Mississippi Gulf Coast.
Mayor Wagner advised the City Planning Commission yesterday to allocate more school construction funds in its proposed 1961 capital budget than it did for 1960.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 15 (AP) -- Bob Skinner's two-run homer in the first inning and the six-hit pitching of Bob Friend earned a 3-1 triumph for the Pittsburgh Pirates over the pesky Los Angeles Dodgers today.
Premier Fidel Castro will arrive in New York Sunday, but he has not yet found a place to stay.
The Federation of Jewish Philanthropies of New York will seek $21,250,000 in its forty-third annual appeal to support its 116 affiliated medical and welfare services here. The goal is a record.
A settlement has been reached in the wage dispute between the American Federation of Musicians, Local 802, and the League of New York Theatres, representing stage producers and theatre owners.

SAVANNAKHET, Laos, Sept. 15 -- Prince Boun Oum declared today that there was no possibility of the settlement of differences between his revolutionary group and the Government of Prince Souvanna Phouma in Vientiane.
NEW DELHI, India, Sept. 15 -- India was reliably reported today to be likely to place a sizable order for Soviet helicopters.
The Board of Estimate approved last night a plan by New York University to take Over the unfinished part of a slum-clearance project south of Washington Square.

The Interstate Commerce Commission's approval yesterday of the merger of the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railroad with the Erie Railroad was the second for major lines by the commission since World War II.

MILFORD, Conn., Sept. 15 -- Richard Stearns of Northfield, Ill., placed fourth today in the fourth race of the five-race series for the North American Star Class championship at the Milford Yacht Club and maintained first place in the over-all standing Stearns, who was at the tiller of the Glider, has yet to win a race.

The resumption of the series between Andover and Lawrenceville after a lapse of thirty-six years will provide one of the highlights of a private school football season that promises to be one of the busiest in years.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I agree with Arthur Daley, who in his column of Sept. 13 states that Russia's success, and our comparative failure in the Olympiad, stems from a narrow base of interest and participation in athletics.

Airline pilots disclosed yesterday that they had been expressing concern over conditions at La Guardia Airport, where an American Airlines Electra crashed Wednesday coming in on a runway shortened during a construction program.
VANDENBERG AIR FORCE BASE, Calif., Sept. 15 (AP) -- The capsule of the Discoverer XV satellite has been spotted -- and lost again -- in the seas off Christmas Island.
One percentage point separated the first-place Yankees and the Baltimore Orioles as they arrived in New York yesterday for a four-game series that may decide the American League pennant.
CHICAGO, Sept. 15 -- The first draft of a bill to remove barriers to information in the hands of the Federal Government was announced here today.
ST. LOUIS, Sept. 15 -- The first "debate" of the Presidential campaign ended today with the International Association of Machinists voting overwhelmingly to endorse Senator John F. Kennedy.
CHICAGO, Sept. 15 -- Henry Cabot Lodge campaigned through the rich cornfields of Illinois today. These and the full storage bins he saw on every hand reminded him of the World's hungry peoples.
Following is the text of a statement by the Rev. Dr. Reinhold Niebuhr and the Rev. Dr. John C. Bennett on the issue of religion in the Presidential campaign:

LAS VEGAS, Nev., Sept. 15 -- Senator Lyndon B. Johnson resumed a strongly partisan campaign line here tonight after a few tentative bows to powerful conservative elements in Arizona before leaving that state.
BLOOMFIELD, N.J., Sept. 15 -- Danny Williams Jr. of the Knoll and Mrs. Philip Cudone of the home club won the qualifying medal today in the fifth annual New Jersey pro-woman golf championship.
Extraordinary police precautions were announced yesterday for the protection of sixteen foreign leaders who will be here for the opening of the United Nations General Assembly next Tuesday.
DETROIT, Sept. 15 -- The new small Pontiac Tempest probably will be the most interesting 1961 car because of its mechanical features.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 15 -- Deane Beman, the little reddish-haired golfer from the District of Columbia who won the British amateur crown last year by beating Bill Hyndman 3d in the final, moved into the semi-finals of the national amateur championship by beating Hyndman again today.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Your editorial entitled "The Religious Issue" gives proper credit to Senator Kennedy's frank and forthright statement of his position on the church-state angle of the religious controversy which is now in progress.
MILWAUKEE, Sept. 15 (AP) -- Lew Burdette pitched a two-hitter for his seventeenth victory today as the Milwaukee Braves defeated the Chicago Cubs, 3 -- 1.
The Budget Finance Company, Los Angeles, announced yesterday it had sold for $2,-

The British Petroleum Company, London, announced yesterday that it had offered to acquire the outstanding capital stock of Apex (Trinidad) Oilfields, Ltd. Apex shares, which were traded on Wednesday at $5.40 in the foreign over-the-counter market, were quoted yesterday at $7.25 bid and $7.62 1/2 asked.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 15 (AP) -- The Westinghouse Electric Corporation and the General Electric Company were indicted today on a charge of having fixed prices on etectrica machinery sold to utilities and industrial concerns for about $24,000,000 a year.
Puerto Rican groups called on education officials yesterday to ease literacy test procedures to encourage more Spanish-speaking residents to register to vote.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 (UPI) -- Representative Chester Bowles of Connecticut, foreign policy adviser to Senator John F. Kennedy, said today that the Democrats faced an uphill battle in trying to convince the voters their party was the more competent to deal with foreign affairs.

SAVANNAKHET, Laos, Saturday, Sept. 17 -- Gen. Phoumi Nosavan reported yesterday that six battalions of Communist troops "from the other side of the North Vietnamese border" were attacking all along the northeast frontier of Laos.
LONDON, Sept. 16 -- The stock market here ended the bookkeeping account today on a dull note.

MINNEAPOLIS, Sept. 16 -- Four Twin Cities banks have sold their competing charge account plans to an Indiana concern so that, beginning Sept. 26, a single charge card will replace the four bank charge account cards.

Belding-Corticelli Ltd. (Canada) Belding-Corticelli Ltd. (Canada) has again omitted the common share dividend after resuming payment in May after a two-year lapse. The company paid 55 cents a share in May, of which 40 cents was for the year ended Dec. 31, 1959, and 15 cents for the March quarter.

ELISABETHVILLE, the Congo, Sept. 16 -- The Katanga Government denounced the United Nations peace mission in this secessionist state today as a "complete failure." It said the mission had only led to more trouble and disorder.
CLEVELAND, Sept. 16 (UPI) -- Barry MacKay and Bernard (Tut) Bartzen scored lop-sided victories today and the United States gained a 2-0 lead over Venezuela in the American zone Davis Cup finals.

THE Civil War, Scott Fitzgerald once said, is always the broken link in our history. How that link was broken is the subject of Arnold Whitridge's hard-hitting and illuminating new book, "No Compromise!"* This is a good introduction to the march of hundred-year Civil War anniversaries that is already under way.

TRENTON, Sept. 16 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner said today the State Senate appeared to be "trying to pursue a political advantage" in setting up a committee to investigate the Port of New York Authority.

PELHAM MANOR, N.Y., Sept. 16 -- The New York Athletic Club took a commanding lead after ten events today in the junior national outdoor track and field championships of the Amateur Athletic Union at Travors Island.

WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 16 -- Su Mac Lad, I.W. Berkemeyer's 6-year-old gelding, won the $25,000 free-for-all trot at Roosevelt Raceway tonight. Stanley Dancer got his high-stepping star in front on the second turn and kept him there.

Nor do they care how much the candidates' wives pay for them or, furthermore, whether they wear their hair bouffant or simply growing out of their heads.

John Deere Credit Co, John Deere Credit Company, a subsidiary of the farm equipment maker, Deere Co., filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday covering a $50,000,000 issue of debentures due in 1985.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 (AP) -- Chuck Stobbs, with an assist from Ray Moore with two out in the ninth, shut out the Boston Red Sox tonight for the Washington Senators. The score was 3-0.

On a foggy September night in 1923 the United States Navy suffered its worst disaster before that of Pearl Harbor. Squadron 11, Destroyer Force, Battle Fleet, consisting of fourteen destroyers, was heading for its home port of San Diego from San Francisco.
DETROIT, Sept. 16 (AP) -- Harry Chiti's eighth-inning home run brought a 4-3 victory to the Detroit Tigers over Chicago tonight and dealt a damaging blow to the White Sox' pennant chances.

The Car Pool Again Now that vacations are over, the car pool is running again. It's surprising how quickly everyone gets back into the swing of things. New York City banks, which have operated under fairly tight reserve conditions in recent weeks despite a surfeit of funds in smaller centers, were swamped yesterday with offers from country banks to lend them reserves.

AS far as American women are concerned, the climax of the Paris furor was reached this week. Beginning last Monday the copies and adaptations of the Paris haute couture originals were presented to the public via jam-packed public showings, television extravaganzas and large-scale promotions within the stores.

JONES BEACH, L.I., Sept. 16 -- The Aurora (Ill.) Sealmasters, the defending titleholders, started the defense of their crown tonight by blanking the Forbes (Kan.) Air Force Base, 3-0, in the opening contest of the twenty-eighth annual men's world softball championship.

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Sept. 16 -- President Joseph Kanavubu and his Premier-designate, Joseph Ileo, were understood to have ordered the Soviet and Czechoslovak Ambassadors and their staffs out of the country within forty-eight hours.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES :. During this campaign, those of us dedicated to the civil rights pause should do our utmost to see to it that the bipartisanship on this issue which has produced results in Congress is not imperiled.

RABAT, Morocco, Sept. 16 -- In Morocco's eyes, the major issue of the coming session of the United Nations General Assembly will be the question of Mauritania -- a complicated boundary problem typical of this period of Africa's "decolonization."
AN estimated 2,000 members attended the morning and afternoon fashion show of French imports presented by the Fashion Group.

PASCAGOULA, Miss., Sept. 16 (UPI) -- Hurricane Ethel reduced to a ragged low pressure area, exacted a toll of inconvenience and hardship from residents of two states today despite its weakened status.
MILFORD, Conn., Sept. 16 -- Richard Stearns of Northfield, Ill., won the North American Star Class sailing championship today at the Milford Yacht Club.

Eleonore Schreiber, the pianist who made her Town Hall debut late yesterday afternoon, played Mozart's Fantasy in C minor (K. 475) and Sonata in C minor (K. 457), Schumann's "Carnaval," Beethoven's Sonata in D (Op. 28) and a Chopin group consisting of three Mazurkas, the Barcarolle in F sharp and the Scherzo in B flat minor.

LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., Sept. 16 -- Mr. and Mrs. Henry D. Paxson's gray gelding, Flying Curlew, took his third blue ribbon in the working hunter class on the second day of the fifty-fifth annual Piping Rock Horse Show today.
Kenneth L. (Tug) Wilson, the president of the United States Olympic Committee, yesterday called for an accelerated program in those sports in which the United States had not done wella.

With final figures reported by all but four schools, the Board of Education said yesterday that the parents of 384 Negro and Puerto Rican pupils had applied for transfers for their children under the new "open enrollment" integration program.
LOS ANGELES, Sept. 16 -- -- Governor Rockefeller ended seventy-two hours of campaigning California for Vice President Nixon today.
MILFORD, Mich., Sept. 16 -- For the customer with "an old small garage" Cadillac will market a 215-inch car for 1961.
Harry S. Truman engaged in a friendly tug of war yesterday with Michael H. Prendergast and Carmine G. De Sapio over the number of campaign speeches the former President will make here.

RAILBIRD shooting has been going on for a couple of weeks now all along the coast from Connecticut south and, as usual, it hasn't been attracting much attention. But a couple of things have come up recently to throw some light on the matter, not all of it good.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 -- The Federal Communications Commission refused by a vote of 4 to 3 today to strip the television networks of their power to control time segments on local stations.
CLEVELAND, Sept. 16 (AP) -- The Cleveland Indians hit three home runs in the third inning and went on to defeat Kansas City, 4-2, tonight. It was their fourteenth straight triumph over the Athletics.
Taxicab drivers for fifty-seven employer groups here have turned down a teamster local in its bid to represent them in collective bargaining, the National Labor Relations Board said yesterday.

The eighty-sixth annual convention of the American Bankers Association, which begins today, is the fifth the association has held in New York City in its eighty-five-year history. In 1877, 1904, 1922 and 1950, the association held full-scale national meetings here.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 -- Traditionally the President of the United States entertains each year six to ten visiting chiefs of state -- kings, queens, presidents and in some cases prime ministers.
