A COLORFUL collection with enough variety to delight all of her customers was shown last week at the Elizabeth Arden Salon. All the fashions, including both custom made and ready to wear for fall and winter, were designed for Miss Arden by leading French couturiers.
OKLAHOMA CITY, Sept. 18 (AP) -- Midwest Democrats called on persons of all faiths today to reject attacks on Senator Kennedy because of his Roman Catholic religion.
MEMPHIS, Tenn., Sept. 18 (UPI) -- Mickey Wright of San Diego won the Memphis women's open golf tournament by twelve strokes today and set a women's record for 72 holes.
DEER PARK, L.I., Sept. 18 -- Portable radar sets weighing thirty-five pounds have been ordered from a concern here by the Signal Corps.
GENEVA, Sept. 18 -- Prices retreated on a broad front last week on the Swiss stock markets. The decline was accompanied by a noticeable slackening in volume.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 -- Chuck Thompson, a graying, 48-year-old electrical contractor from Detroit, today became the first speed-boat pilot to win the tradition-packed President's Cup four times.
Direct obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public that will mature within twelve months amount to $78,945,539,971. They consist of Treasury securities as follows:

Mortem H. Engel's Huntress, a glass-hulled Bermuda-40 yawl launched only three months ago, was the over-all winner of the Stuyvesant Yacht Club's thirteenth annual day race on Saturday. The Beach Point Y.C. craft headed the fleet of forty-eight on corrected time.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 (AP) -- Bill Monbouquette, with a helping hand from Mike Fornieles in the eighth inning, pitched the Boston Red Sox to a 3-1 victory over the Washington Senators today. Willie Tasby's homer in the fourth and Lou Clinton's two-run single in the sixth supplied the Red Sox punch.
The United States Golf Association yesterday selected Deane Beman, winner of the amateur championship Saturday, and three others for the world team tournament.

AGANA, Guam, Monday, Sept. 19 -- A four-engine World Airways plane carrying eighty-six military passengers and a civilian crew of eight exploded in the air and crashed into the side of a jungle hill early today. Seventy-seven were killed.

MILWAUKEE, Sept. 18 (AP) -- Bill Bruton and Joe Adcock backed up Joey Jay's four-hit pitching with home runs as the Milwaukee Braves scored a 7-1 victory over the Philadelphia Phillies today. The game was called in the bottom half of the eighth inning because of rain.

As we were saying in 1946, the lower Manhattan crosstown expressway to connect the Holland Tunnel and West Side Highway with Manhattan and Williamsburg Bridges on the East Side would be a fine thing. The Board of Estimate has at last approved the route, and a resolution authorizing condemnation or purchase of property needed will be introduced soon.

I. Rokeach and Sons, Inc., former food manufacturer, has announced the details of its plans to acquire Exquisite Form Brassiere, Inc., maker of women's foundation garments. The proposal, subject to approval of Rokeach stockholders at a special meeting on Oct. 14, also calls for changing the company's name to Exquisite Form Industries, Inc., it was disclosed over the week-end.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Monday, Sept. 19 -- Sixteen Asian and African nations last night came to the assistance of Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold, and supported him against charges by the Soviet Union that he had bungled the crisis in the Congo.
The rapidly growing billion-dollar-a-year American soybean industry has a major "foreign" problem.

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 18 -- The ability of the United Steel-workers of America to hold its ranks solid through last year's 116-day steel strike was fortified by the payment of more than $22,750,000 in government aid to strikers.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 18 (AP) -- Walt Bond drove in three runs with a home run and a double in a fourteen-hit attack that carried Cleveland Indians to a 9-2 victory over the Kansas City Athletics in the second game of a double-header today.

Expanded educational programs and, in many instances, higher enrollments, will mark the start of the new college year here. Although a few institutions began their fall semesters last week, most of the colleges and universities will start classes this week or next.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 -- Senator John F. Kennedy said today he was much encouraged by the results of his first fifteen days of non-stop campaigning but knew he had "a hard fight ahead."

New York, as the world's capital housing the United Nations, has become at the moment the gathering place for the largest collection of rulers, statesmen and diplomats since the Versailles Peace Conference. They are coming here to attend the United Nations General Assembly, and they are coming in such numbers in order to join in a great battle in the cold war that could involve control of the United Nations itself.
The Rev. Donald S. Harrington condemned United States foreign policy yesterday.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 18 -- The volume of new steel orders was off last week, probably because of the delayed effects of the Labor Day holiday. And the outlook for steel production was slightly confusing. In recent weeks some steel makers have been producing more steel than orders called for, to have enough stocks to fill rush business.

THERE may be some unusual business at the United Nations this week, but in the building's stainless steel kitchens, it promises to be business as usual. The menus in the fourth-floor dining rooms overlooking the East River will list the dishes that would be served on any old workaday day.
CHICAGO, Sept. 18 (AP) -- Soybean futures attracted almost undivided interest last week on the Board of Trade as prices skidded broadly, while grains held generally about steady in slack dealings.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 -- The Air Force was charged by the Senate Small Business Committee today with waste and inefficiency. The committee cited the awarding of a defense subcontract to a company inexperienced in the job to be done.
MOSCOW, Sept. 18 -- The Soviet Union declared today that it would retain friendly relations with the Congo despite the withdrawal "temporarily" of its diplomatic mission there.
The head of the Communist party in the United States has published an article that straddles the issue between the Soviet Union and Communist China in their ideological controversy.
ASBURY PARK, N.J., Sept. 18 -- Long Island players finished one-two in the open-pair contest of the New York-New Jersey regional tournament, which was played here over the week-end.

Joseph Curran, president of the National Maritime Union, and co-chairman of the seafarer's section of organized labor's Maritime Trades Department, yesterday endorsed a Senate subcommittee's critical report of the Interstate Commerce Commission.
ST. LOUIS, Sept. 18 (AP) -- Ernie Broglio scored his twentieth victory today, pitching a four-hitter for the St. Louis Cardinals in a 4-3 triumph over the San Francisco Giants.
Among both Republican and Democratic leaders the conviction is growing that the suburbs may decide how New York's forty-five electoral votes will go in this year's Presidential election.

Supreme Court Justice Benjamin Brenner of Brooklyn withdrew yesterday as the Liberal candidate for associate judge of the Court of Appeals. This action gave the Liberal party an opportunity to review its position regarding the court.
SAVANNAKHET, Laos, Sept. 17 -- Gen. Phoumi Nosavan said today that at least some of the Communist forces attacking Samneua, in northeast Laos, were North Vietnamese.

PARIS, Sept. 18 -- A brief whirl in international diplomacy at the United Nations so confused a Congolese laundryman turned-diplomat that he decided it was time to get back to the Congo and his laundry.
TACOMA, Wash., Sept. 18 (AP) -- Ernie Vossler of Midland, Tex., won the $25,000 Tacoma open golf tournament today with a four-round total of 272 -- twelve under par.
George Gershwin's music will be used to reflect American life in the Nineteen Twenties and Thirties in a ninety-minute television show to be produced by Leland Hayward.
GOTEBORG, Sweden, Sept. 18 (UPI) -- Herb Elliott of Australia sprinted in the final yards today and beat Dan Waern of Sweden in one of the most exciting 1,500-meter races ever run in this country.

PRINCETON, N.J., Sept. 18 -- Americans "ought to recognize the truly fatal adversary is less likely to be Russia than our own shortcomings," Dr. Robert F. Goheen, president of Princeton University, said today.
LARCHMONT, N.Y., Sept. 18 -- Donald Mackenzie sailed Black Arrow to a solid victory in the International Class today in the de Coppet Trophy post-season series off Larchmont.

RABAT, Morocco, Sept. 18 -- The conservative Moroccan Government, headed by King Mohamed V and Crown Prince Moulay Hassan, appears to have adopted a foreign policy that is further to the left than that of the preceding Left-wing Government of Abdallah Ibrahim.
In two decades Federal spending for public assistance has increased 685 per cent and state and local payments have risen 117 per cent, a public assistance survey has found.

Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy defended and reaffirmed yesterday his order canceling all police vacations and days off for the duration of the United Nations General Assembly session.
LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Sept. 18 -- Col. Joseph Mobutu, the Army Chief of Staff who holds the reins of power here, foiled an attempt to assassinate him today.

WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 18 -- The Belle Acton Pace, the first of four stakes for 2-year-olds initiated this year at Roosevelt Raceway, will be contested tomorrow night by eleven top-flight fillies. The distaff diviaion of the $73,881 Roosevelt Futurity, scheduled for Saturday, the Belle Action, carries a purse of $22,764.

The Rev. George C. Bonnell yesterday attacked the recent statement on the Presidential campaign by the National Conference of Citizens for Religious Freedom as showing a misunderstanding of the true nature of the Roman Catholic Church.

PLOVDIV, Bulgaria, Sept. 18 -- The United States made its first appearance at an international trade fair in Communist-ruled Bulgaria today as the nine-teenth annual Plovdiv Fair opened in this picturesque little city.

BUFFALO, Sept. 18 (UPI) -- Frank Tripucka, the quarter-back, and a defensive halfback, Johnny Pyeatt, paced Denver in a second-half comeback today as the unbeaten Broncos rallied for a 27-21 victory over the Buffalo Bills in an American Football League game before 15,229.
The Brooklyn Academy of Music is a venerable cultural institution now going into its 102d season, but in at least one respect it is as practical and modern as tomorrow.

CARACAS, Venezuela, Sept. 16 -- The Act of Bogota, adopted by the recent inter-American economic conference in Colombia, is a plan to prevent communism from taking advantage of poverty and backwardness in Latin America.
ELISABETHVILLE, The Congo, Sept. 18 -- Congolese government soldiers received orders today to withdraw from the secessionist state of Katanga and South Kasai.
CINCINNATI, Sept. 18 (AP) -- Vern Law and Wilmer Mizell pitched Pittsburgh's Pirates to a double-header sweep over Cincinnati, 5 -- 3 and 1 -- 0, today.

THE week-end schedule of the Royal Ballet at the Metropolitan Opera House contained season's "firsts" by two ballerinas. Saturday afternoon, Anya Linden danced "The Sleeping Beauty" for the first time in New York, with Roland Hynd as the Prince; and last night Nadia Nerina was OdetteOdile in "Le Lac des Cygnes," with David Blair as Siegfried.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 18 -- Bowling will get the Hollywood treatment beginning tomorrow, with Milton Berle starring as master of ceremonies, and with prizes that may run into six digits.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 18 (UPI) -- Earl Buchholz and Chuck McKinley powered their way past a stubborn Venezuelan doubles team, 6 -- 4, 6 -- 1, 7 -- 5, today and enabled the United States to clinch the American zone Davis Cup tennis finals.

Week Ended Sept. 16, 1960 Trading in the British pound sterling was the main point of interest in the foreign exchange market during the past week. The pound continued strong with a good volume of business reported. The Canadian dollar was higher after moving in irregular fashion.
When Premier Khrushchev comes ashore from the Soviet liner Baltika today he will find the political climate harsher than on his first visit here a year ago.

KARACHI, Pakistan, Monday, Sept. 19 -- India and Pakistan announced today the details of a treaty that will end their bitter thirteen-year-old dispute over the use of the Indus River waters.
NEW DELHI, Sept. 18 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru will go to the United Nations General Assembly meeting, the Ministry of External Affairs announced today.

The Federal Maritime Board has been asked to take action to end a rate war in the West Coast trade to Japan. Attorneys for the Transpacific Freight Conference said yesterday they hoped the Federal agency would issue regulations against the practices of the Taiwan Navigation Company, Ltd., and other carriers.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 (AP) -- Maj. Gen. John B. Medaris, retired missile chief of the Army, has strongly suggested that President Eisenhower's military knowledge is outdated. General Medaris implied this had hurt United States missile and space programs.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 -- There is evidence that President Eisenhower's estimate of a $4,200,000,000 budget surplus in the present fiscal year is farther off base than has been generally acknowledged.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: During the course of the last few months you have repeatedly commented on the railroad strikes and frequently stated that unless the railroad labor organizations accept the principle of voluntary arbitration they might well face the prospect of compulsory arbitration, a procedure which you are reluctant to accept.

The Rev. Dr. Norman Vincent Peale's self-portrayal as an innocent dupe in the controversy over the fitness of a Catholic for the Presidency was accepted apparently without question yesterday by his congregation at Marble Collegiate Church.
Pal Benko of Hungary failed last night to reduce Samuel Reshevsky's lead for the George P. Edgar Trophy at the Manhattan Chess Club.

The greeting this country and this city are giving the United Nations Assembly is marked by uproarious illogic. Regardless of how we esteem, them, history's most distinguished group of leaders is about to gather here. Yet we accept our obligation as host with immature bad taste.

"A mutual fund is a satisfactory medium of investment for a person of very moderate means, but a wealthy investor, because of his tax problem, would be better off if he retained an [investment] adviser who can supply the personal element."

IT is impossible to imagine that 25-year-old China Machado, one of the world's most memorable fashion models, would ever have to cope with problems that affect mortal women. It is almost defeating to find out how she does.

MOSCOW, Sept. 18 -- A Soviet writer complained yesterday that juvenile delinquents were coming in increasing numbers from workers' homes. A campaign against juvenile delinquency has identified the problem mainly with idle youths from well-to-do families.
Farmers of the Midwest Corn Belt are not defecting to Senator John F. Kennedy, regardless of their opinions of Secretary of Agriculture Ezra Taft Benson.
PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Sept. 18 -- Bob Smith's December, a Tiger Cat from the Noroton (Conn.,) fleet, today won an invitation multihull regatta staged by the Knickerbocker Yacht Club.

Wladyslaw Gomulka, the Communist chief of Poland, and Antonin Novotny, the President of Czechoslovakia, arrived at New York International Airport last night, leading a parade of Soviet-bloc leaders to the United Nations General Assembly.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 -- Representative James M. Quigley announced the other day that he had sent a check for $2 to the Postmaster General to cover the cost of four-cent stamps that should have been placed on fifty envelopes that went out with Mr. Quigley's frank.

Mounted and foot patrolmen clashed last night with screaming anti-Khrushchev demonstrators who converged on the Soviet headquarters building for United Nations personnel at Park Avenue and Sixty-eighth Street.
ROME, Sept. 17 -- The flags of twenty-three nations were flying again today atop a stadium in Rome from which the colors of eighty-odd participants in the Olympic Games were struck a week ago.
"The curse of Cain has fallen heavily on our generation," the Rev. Dr. David H.C. Read told his congregation yesterday.
The creation of labor courts as a move toward keeping industrial peace is being urged by Justice Samuel H. Hofstadter of the State Supreme Court and Theodore B. Richter, a New York lawyer.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I want to thank you for your editorial (Sept. 11) regarding the Chinese Nationalists' arrest of Lei Chen on Taiwan.

THE 62-year-old preacher who tucked in his chin yesterday on the pulpit of the Marble Collegiate Church and told his congregation that he was a "willy-nilly" man is known to millions as the apostolic therapist of positive thinking.
Claudette Colbert, last seen here in "The Marriage-Go-Round," has been signed to star in "Julia, Jake and Uncle Joe."
A growing marketing headache is the matter of misredemption of coupons issued to induce housewives to try new products or to get them in the habit of using old ones.
Further reductions in bank lending rates are not likely this year, John W. Remington, president of the American Bankers Association, said yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 -- The United States Information Agency reported today that it was expanding its facilities to carry information to Africa.
PANAMA, Sept. 18 -- Most Panamanians reacted favorably today to President Eisenhower's order that Panama's flag be flown over the Canal Zone as evidence of the republic's titular sovereignty.

PIC DU MIDI, France, Sept. 16 -- The observatory atop this peak of the Pyrenees is carrying out, for the United States Air Force, an intensive study of that area of the moon where the first space ships are most likely to land.
LONDON. ONE question almost sure to start a friendly argument at London cocktail parties is: "Does the fact that something is American help to sell it to the English or does it detract?"
Mrs. Joseph P. Kennedy of Boston, formerly of the Bronx, returned to that borough yesterday to tell women why she thinks her son John would make a splendid President.

THE death of John P. Marquand at the age of 66 last July was an incalculable loss to American letters. No other novelist of his generation excelled him in technical mastery of the art of fiction; none equaled him as a brilliant recorder of life in the United States in the twentieth century. Mr. Marquand's ten distinguished novels are as imperishable a chronicle of the upper classes as Trollope's Barchester series.

VIENTIANE, Laos, Sept. 18 -- Vientiane was shelled in a pre-dawn attack today. Premier Souvanna Phouma charged that the shells had been fired from across the Mekong River, in the territory of Thailand.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y. Sept. 18 -- One of the most significant General Assembly sessions in the history of the United Nations will open here Tuesday.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 -- Americans for Democratic Action called today for the election of Senator John F. Kennedy to provide "strong liberal executive leadership."
ABILENE, Tex., Sept. 18 -- Senator John F. Kennedy's religion seems to be subsiding as a factor in the contest for Texas' twenty-four electoral votes in the November Presidential election.

Alan Paton, whose new volume of short stories, "Tales From a Troubled Land," is scheduled for spring publication by Scribner, has been named winner of the Freedom Award for 1960. Archibald MacLeish, the poet and playwright, will make the presentation to Mr. Paton on behalf of Freedom House at its nineteenth annual celebration next month.
Premier Khrushchev will arrive here today. He will find a tense atmosphere and extraordinary security precautions.
A system for detecting the presence of satellites with a telescope carried aloft by balloon is under development for the Air Force.

TWO blind, aging performers and a volatile young Irish quartet saved a folkmusic program from mediocrity at Town Hall Saturday night. It fell to the Rev. Gary Davis, Sonny Terry and the Clancy Brothers and Tommy Makem to offer the evening's rare moments of artistry.

Perhaps as a harbinger of things to come, the putative mighty already have begun to fall in college football. In the season's first week-end of varsity competition, with barely more than half of the nation's major teams in action, five presumed colossi were cut down to average size.

THE National Broadcasting Company has revised its early Sunday evening schedule this season with an eye to catching the family trade. Its television effort will prove a boon to hearthside felicity seems rather in doubt in light of last night's initial three premieres.

A low-rent housing project designed for the future as well as the present will be built in Glen Cove, L.I., at a cost of $897,000. The project will be the first state-aided unit designed for easy conversion into a middle-income cooperative.
The Mutual Broadcasting System has invited Premier Khrushchev and nine other heads of state to appear on its radio network during their visit here to the United Nations General Assembly.

Thirteen American students returned here last night from an exchange visit to Iron Curtain countries after a trip filled with harassment, intimidation and arrest at the hands of Communist authorities.

CHILDHOOD in New York can be a many splendored thing. In contrast to the theory that the city-bred youngster grows up unhappily deprived of the free and natural country life, is the testimony of a few born and bred New Yorkers.

A big bowwow of a ferocious era is presented with masterly skill in David Donald's "Charles Sumner and the Coming of the Civil War." This is unquestionably one of the outstanding biographies of the year.

MONTREAL, Sept. 19 -- Public administration of ports in the United States is seriously threatened by the Congressional investigation of the Port of New York Authority, D. Leon Williams, president of the American Association of Port Authorities Inc., charged today.
WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 19 -- Sweet Miriam won the $22,764 Belle Acton Pace for 2-year-old fillies at rain-soaked Roosevelt Raceway tonight. The race is the distaff division of the Roosevelt Futurity.
Premier Khrushchev's curiosity caused him to see direct evidence of hostility to his policies and to his visit even before his vessel docked here yesterday.

WE train our children to be many things -- to be airline hostesses, doctors, machinists, secretaries and all the rest -- but we do not train them in the serious business of spending money, according to Sidney Margolius, one of the country's foremost experts on consumer problems.

We have too much confidence in the good judgment of the voter to doubt passage of the proposition up for referendum on the November ballot to authorize New York State to issue $75,000,000 in bonds for purchase of park lands. Nevertheless, we welcome Mayor Wagner's declaration of support, given at a conference with Governor Rockefeller.

ALBANY, Sept. 19 -- Governor Rockefeller hinted today that New York State would delay participation in the Eisenhower Administration's medical care program for the aged until it knew whether the next Administration would change it.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Sept. 19 (AP) -- The United Mine Workers, in a sworn statement put on file in United States District Court here, reports that it has made multimillion-dollar loans to various individuals and companies.
CHICAGO, Sept. 19 -- Adlai E. Stevenson said today that Vice President Nixon's Quaker faith was as "irrelevant" as Senator John F. Kennedy's Roman Catholic faith.

Harold H. Helm, chairman of Chemical Bank New York Trust Company, believes that a business revival this fall could result in higher bank lending rates at the end of three or four months.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass, Sept. 19 -- Seventy - five years ago, while President Grover Cleveland was fighting corruption in Washington and stage coaches still rattled along this village's elm-shaded streets, Williams was being drubbed by such football powers as Yale, Harvard and Dartmouth.
HONG KONG, Sept. 19 -- Communist China denounced the idea of overpopulation today. It held that the concept was fallacious whether applied to China or to any other country.
WASHINGTON, Sept, 19 (AP) -- The Internal Revenue Service is instructing the nation's race tracks to report the names of all big money winners' in daily double and other pool betting.

WIN, lose or draw, this may be Casey Stengel's last year in baseball. Some say it is. Others say it isn't. The parties directly involved -- meaning the Yankee owners and 70-year-old Casey himself -- are remaining discreetly silent.
NICE, France, Sept. 19 -- The games of the seventeenth modern Olympiad may have ended, but Olympian echoes still resound througnout Europe.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., Sept. 19 -- The Nassau County Medical Society came out today for the election of Vice President Nixon and Republican candidates for Congress and the State Legislature. The move brought immediate protest from local Democrats.

NOGAL, N.M., Sept. 19 (AP) -- The Pecos Valley Presbytery, in a report on the religious issue in the Presidential campaign, says Vice President Nixon, "in his public utterances already [has] gone against the teaching of his religion to embrace a military policy of massive retaliation."
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 19 -- Premier Khrushchev is in a position to make a United Nations speech even before President Eisenhower arrives in New York.

Samuel Reshevsky and Pal Benko played the tenth game of their match for the George P. Edgar Trophy at the Manhattan Chess Club yesterday and went to an adjournment after forty-one moves with Benko holding a 5-4 pawn advantage.
The New York Yankees, with the pressure eased considerably by their four-game week-end sweep of Baltimore, will return to action tonight at the Stadium.

SCRANTON, Pa., Sept. 19 -- Thousands braved rains tonight to cheer assertions by Vice President Nixon that a "rash and immature" President would play directly into the hands of Soviet Premier Khrushchev.

The Socialist Party-Social Democratic Federation is circulating a first copy of a proposed publication, "New America." Norman Thomas, six-time Socialist candidate for President, hopes it will become a biweekly.
VENICE, Italy, Sept. 19 (AP) -- Italy's Olympic champion, Raimondo D'Inzeo, riding Cowran Girl, won the first qualification trial of the world equestrian championship today.

VIENNA, Sept. 19 -- John A. McCone, chairman of the United States Atomic Energy Commission, arrived in Vienna today to represent the United States at the annual General Assembly of the International Atomic Energy Agency.

The United Nations General Assembly convenes today for its regular annual session after a prior emergency meeting in which the Soviet Union suffered a major initial defeat. This defeat was administered by the very Afro-Asian countries which the Soviets hope to captivate. It came when the Assembly adopted a widely supported resolution sponsored by seventeen African and Asian nations.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- The Government's short-term borrowing costs dropped sharply today, following the sudden easing in the short-term market late last week. The break today carried discounts on the Treasury's ninety-one-day and 182-day bills to their lowest levels in five weeks, but they remained higher than the two-year lows of early August.

When "The Threepenny Opera" begins the sixth year of its record off-Broadway run tonight, two members of the cast will take particular pride in marking the milestone. They are Marion Selee and William Duell, who have been with the musical at the Theatre de Lys since opening nignt on Sept. 20, 1955.

Traffic Commissioner T.T. Wiley has had to fight every step of the way for his program of reforms to cope with the automobile in New York, and not the least of his problems has been fellow city officials who bend too easily when the wind of opposition begins to blow. Mr. Wiley expressed concern on a week-end television program about the future of his plan for construction of fifteen municipal parking garages in midtown Manhattan.
Polylad, owned by Mrs. Quentin A.S. McKean, made a successful closing bid for victory in the $28,600 Nassau County Handicap at Aqueduct yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- The inspiration and proceedings of the Congressional post-convention, session (may Heaven forfend another!) were so totally enveloped in 1960 Presidential politics that certain useful legislative products escaped public attention.
DALLAS, Tex., Sept. 19 -- How disgruntled Texans are about the Democratic national platform may be indicated tomorrow when several thousand delegates meet here in the party's state convention.
The Zeckendorf Hotels Corporation is considering the sale of its leaseholds on the Astor, Manhattan and Commodore Hotels to the company that operates Freedomland.
AN intelligent community effort to start boys and girls on the right road to hunting and target shooting is now under way at Hempstead, L.I., and other American cities.

"If Jack Kennedy thinks he has the Catholic vote in his back pocket, he's wrong," a city official who is Irish, Roman Catholic and a Democrat from the Bronx said over lunch last week.

Copper futures dropped 29 to 54 points (hundredths of a cent a pound) yesterday on the Commodity Exchange. The volume, 357 lots (50,000 pounds to a lot), was the best in almost two months but well below the year's high of 1,325 on June 14.

THE toothbrush rack in most bathrooms can hardly accommodate the average family, especially when each person has more than one toothbrush. Instead of a glass to hold extra toothbrushes, there is a charming container at Henri Bendel that will hold seven of them.

HAMILTON, Ont., Sept. 19 (Canadian Press) -- Canadian ports suffer losses to United States import points because of port charges leveled after goods are unloaded at transit warehouses, the Canadian Port and Harbor Association was told yesterday.

Gov. Abraham A. Ribicoff of Connecticut opened the Queens County drive for Senator John F. Kennedy's Democratic Presidential candidacy last night in a borough that last voted Democratic for President in 1936.
CAIRO, Sept. 19 -- President Gamal Abdel Nasser will arrive at the United Nations this week eager to measure public opinion on his first visit in the West.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- Senator John F. Kennedy, in a move aimed largely at the Negro vote, today called a national conference on Constitutional rights and American freedom. It will be held in New York on Oct. 11 and 12.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 (AP) -- The six preliminary winners in the nation-wide contest to select an architect for the Franklin D. Roosevelt Memorial were announced today. The memorial is to be constructed between the Potomac River and the Tidal Basin.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- Mrs. John F. Kennedy said today she would record some foreign language broadcasts for use in her husband's campaign for President.

A proposal that commercial banks be permitted to organize savings subsidiaries that would operate under the same rules as Federal savings and loan associations was made yesterday to the American Bankers Association.

ELISABETHVILLE, the Congo, Sept. 19 -- In the province of Katanga, the great mineral treasury of the Congo, a few thousand Belgians still control just about everything, but they have no real political power.

Steel production should show improvement for the second successive time this week, the American Iron and Steel Institute said yesterday. Mills are scheduled to operate at 53.9 per cent of capacity against 53 per cent last week and 49.2 per cent two weeks ago.
Police security plans worked smoothly yesterday for the arrival of Premier Khrushchev and the first day of his visit.

The ousting yesterday of Clint W. Murchison Jr. and John D. Murchison as directors of Investors Diversified Services (I.D.S.), Inc., may lead to one of the biggest and bitterest proxy fights in years -- for control of the Alleghany Corporation, which controls I.D.S.

BAMAKO, Sudan, Sept. 19 -- Sudan, which feels that it is the aggrieved partner in the dissolved Mali Federation, has adopted an unexpectedly moderate attitude in reacting to Senegal's withdrawal from the federation.

The Police Department -- with an international gallery of potentates to guard -- has set massive forces to the task, but it is also following an old military rule: Do not commit all of your forces; hold some in reserve for the unexpected.

CHICAGO, Sept. 19 (AP) -- The United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit refused today to interfere with a lower court order banning the Air Line Pilots Association from boycotting twenty-one airports in the South.

The American Bowling Congress has indicated that it may withdraw its sanction of tournaments conducted by the Bowling Proprietors Association of America if the proprietors' organization enforces its new eligibility rule for such tourneys.

HALIFAX, N.S., Sept. 19 -- The sixth annual conference of the Atlantic Provinces Economic Council met in the Nova Scotian Hotel today. About 300 business men of the Maritime Region registered for the two days of discussions.
The Tennessee Valley Authority's first move to raise capital in the public market will take place on Nov. 15, the Federal Government electric power development agency announced yesterday.
Mayor Wagner summoned Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy to City Hall yesterday and scolded him for having apparently "set himself up as a judge of whether anyone else is religious."

Patronesses for the Mayfair Assembly dinner dance for debutantes of the season have been announced by Miss Clementine Miller. Most are mothers of the young women to be honored at the event, which will take place at the Pierre on Dec. 31.

THE appointment of Sir Patrick Henry Dean as Britains permanent representative at the United Nations took him from the quiet backrooms of Whitehall to one of the most publicized posts in Britain's diplomatic service.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Sept. 19 -- A side issue in the "cold war" waxed hot today at Rutgers University.
CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Sept. 19 (UPI) -- The United States sent an Atlas missile 9,000 miles down the Atlantic and an exploring rocket 1,200 miles above the Pacific today.
NEXT Sunday two or three hundred Greene County residents, summoned by The Green County Examiner-Recorder, will assemble at the Durham Center Museum to celebrate Vernon Haskins Day.

THE latest rage with those who wish to lose weight is the 900-calorie powdered food formula. Get-thin-easy schemes always have been snatched up eagerly, if only temporarily, by those who need to reduce or think they do.
Mrs. John J. Boland, chairman of the St. Barnabas Hospital benefit fashion show and card party, has had the assistance of a debutante committee in planning the Sept. 27 event scheduled for the Plaza.

GENEVA, Sept. 19 -- Ireland's formal bid for membership in the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT) will be considered at the session that began here today of the trade group's new permanent council.

The housing violation trial of Jacob Brownstein and George S. Meissner finally began yesterday in Special Sessions. The Brooklyn lawyers are accused of permitting hundreds of violations over a period of years in buildings they reportedly owned.
Franchot Tone has with drawn from his starring role in Ibsen's rarely staged play, "When We Dead Awaken, just two weeks away from its revival at the Fourth Street Theatre.

SARANAC LAKE, N.Y., Sept. 19 -- Merit pay for teachers, a controversial issue in education, was endorsed here today by the resolutions committee of the State Council of City and Village School Superintendents.
THE Living Theatre last night produced three of the later plays of William Butler Yeats. In doing so it rendered meritorious service to students and admirers of the late Irish poet-dramatist.
DUESSELDORF, Germany, Sept. 19 -- The Ruhr, grimy heartland of German industrial power, is to get a face-lifting, not to make it beautiful but to change its character.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 19 -- Premier Khrushchev's arrival in New York today was full of symbolism.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 19 -- American movie-going tastes have changed so substantially in recent years that the time will soon come when the majority of theatres in the United States will be showing foreign films as a matter of course.
The Liberal party took a highly significant political step last night and endorsed Judge Sydney F. Foster of Liberty, N.Y., the Republican nominee, for the Court of Appeals.

IN December, 1938, "Here Come the Clowns" opened at the Booth Theatre and went down to defeat with the playwright, Philip Barry, fighting bravely in its defense. Were he and his play ahead of their time?
The New York Titans contended yesterday that victory had been illegally kicked, not snatcherd, out of their hands last Saturday night by the Boston Patriots.

Premier Khrushchev lost no time yesterday in beginning his campaign to woo American and world public opinion. His speech on landing here went to great lengths to give the impression that he is a sober statesman come to advance the cause of peace and negotiation and to further the cause of Soviet-American friendship. This was quite a different performance from the one he put on in Paris last May when he torpedoed the summit meeting.

Although the Canadian economy is marking time much the same as is business in this country, the news for investors is good. Dividend payments scheduled for September by Canadian companies aggregate $79,185,000, compared with $76,292,000 paid in the 1959 month, and $74,126,000 in the 1958 period, according to J.R. Timmins Co.
An electronic bookkeeping system for retail stores that is said to eliminate the use of sales books and pencils as well as many other manual sales operations was demonstrated yesterday.

A comparison was made yesterday between the 769,000,000 people who have attained full independence from the old-style colonial powers since 1939 and the 973,000,000 who now live under the domination of the Soviet Union and Communist China.

MINNEAPOLIS, Sept. 19 -- The brothers Clinton W. Murchison Jr. and John D. Murchison, Dallas financeers and oil men, were ousted today from the board of directors of Investors Diversified Services, Inc., the nation's largest mutual fund management company.
MOSCOW, Sept. 19 (UPI) -- The Soviet people were told today that Premier Khrushchev, after a voyage in which he "inspired" those around him, had made a triumphal entry into New York.
ROME, Sept. 19 -- Floods caused by heavy rainstorms, after spreading havoc and death through northern and central Italy, have cut all roads and railroad lines between Rome and the north.

A telling commentary on the travails of the variety comedian in television was inherent in last night's premiere of "Jackpot Bowling" over Channel 4. Milton Berle, the "Mr. Television" of a decade ago.
Production will begin today at a now refinery of American Sugar Refining Company on the Mystic River near Bunker Hill in the Charlestown area of Boston.
RABAT, Morocco, Sept. 19 -- King Mohamed V instructed his son today to support efforts of the Algerian nationalist Provisional Government to obtain United Nations intervention in Algeria.
Claudius Charles Philippe, former head of the banquet department at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, yesterday was fined $10,000 -- the maximum that could be imposed -- for evading $25,472 in income taxes.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- Secretary of State Christian A. Herter said today that he saw no prospect of any private meeting between President Eisenhower and Premier Khrushchev at the United Nations.
ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 19 -- The leader of 1,200,000 unionized steel workers called on the major steel producers today to join in a program intended to keep the industry permanently free of strikes.
Daniel Gutoff's piano recital last night at Town Hall did not show much realization of the potential indicated in his previous appearances here.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- The Secretary of the Department of Health, Education and Welfare made public today the text of the letter he had written to all Governors calling attention to the broad scope of the new law to give medical care to the needy aged.
Representative Adam Clayton Powell Jr., who had made hitter attacks on Senator John F. Kennedy's civil rights record earlier this year, hopped aboard the Kennedy-Johnson bandwagon yesterday.
The Right Rev. James A. Pike, Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of California, said yesterday that a Roman Catholic President would not be committed to follow the dictates of the Vatican.

The first volume of Coward-McCann's new American Vista Series will be an anthology edited by Walter Havighurst and called "Land of the Long Horizons: The Midwest." It will be published next Monday. The 448-two-column-paged history is told in the language of those who lived it, a selection of eigthy-two pieces.
The trial of William Smith, lawyer accused of arranging for the substitution of clean arrest records for gambling defendants with prior convictions, began yesterday in Special Sessions Court.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 (AP) -- In an address at a National Press Club luncheon, Lord Home said the prosperity of Britain would be more certain "if we can bring to an end the political and economic division of Europe."
LONDON, Sept. 19 (Reuters) -- West European newspapers saw the United States in the lead today in the opening round of New York's diplomatic meetings but warned that the victory might be short-lived.
A state commission started an inquiry yesterday to determine if the tenant-selection policies of the City Housing Authority violated the law against racial discrimination.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- The real reason Premier Khrushchev has come to the United Nations is to extend his influence among the African countries, Senator John F. Kennedy said tonight.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- The State Department said today that no new restrictions were being placed on the movements of Soviet reporters covering the United Nations Genral Assembly in New York.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 19 -- Following are excerpts from addresses today before the special session of the General Assembly on the situation in the Congo:
ST. LOUIS, Sept. 19 (AP) -- Bobby Miller, making his first start since June 7, held the Los Angeles Dodgers to five hits tonight as the St. Louis Cardinals scored a 1-0 victory.

CHICAGO, Sept. 19 (AP) -- Grain futures prices continued their slow general decline today with losses running to major fractions of a cent in rye and soybeans and to a cent in wheat. Corn and oats were slightly easier.
DETROIT Sept. 19 (AP) -- The automotive industry is almost halfway to its announced goal of having 520,000 new 1961 models in stock by Oct. 1.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 (AP) -- A House subcommittee suspended its investigation of the defection to the Soviet Union of two American code specialists today. The subcommittee chairman criticized hiring of the men and said the National Security Agency's security procedures needed study.
A number of medical myths were put to rest here yesterday at the opening of the Second International Meeting on Forensic Pathology and Medicine at New York University Medical Center.
KARACHI, Pakistan, Sept. 19 -- Prime Minister Jawaharal Nehru of India arrived today for a five-day visit aimed at improving relations between his country and Pakistan.
Now the happy season is upon us to whet appetites and to sharpen thirst.

Despite centralized control over the Soviet educational system, school reforms put into effect in February, 1959, are proceeding at a slow rate, according to a United States educator who has just returned from the Soviet Union.

Arthur T. Roth, chairman of the Franklin National Bank of Long Island, testified yesterday that his institution would have to immobilize $637,000 in additional cash with the Federal Reserve System if it were to establish a branch in New York City.
CHARLESTON, W. Va., Sept. 19 (AP) -- Senator John F. Kennedy returned today to West Virginia and promised he would rescue its jobless workers from "Republican indifference and neglect".

CHICAGO, Sept. 19 (UPI) -- Bob Schmidt's grand-slam homer, the second of his career, powered San Francisco to a 4-1 conquest of the Chicago Cubs today after the Giants had won the opener of a double-header, 11 -- 4.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 (AP) -- Physicians treating severe burn cases were urged today to watch carefully for facial burns as an indication of possibly fatal lung damage.

Although high schools in New York State have led the nation instructing gifted students, too many school officials consider the movement an expedient rather than a new educaional way of life, an authority on the gifted said last night.
Ivy League teams swing into the football procession this week and, from the reports of two of the coaches yesterday, there is scarcely a club not capable of beating any other one in the group.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- President Eisenhower and Vice President Nixon talked to American nationality groups today about the goal of freedom and justice for captive peoples everywhere. The two leaders agreed the goal could be achieved without war.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Tuesday, Sept. 20 -- The General Assembly in effect endorsed Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold's Congo policy early today despite a bitter attack by the Soviet Union.

DELAWARE, Ohio, Sept. 19 (UPI) -- Countess Adios paced to an eight-length triumph in the featured Breeder's Filly Stake, which opened a week of Grand Circuit racing at the fairground today, and bettered six world records.
Jorge Fernandez, the Argentine welterweight who had lost close decisions to Emile Griffith in his last two outings, got back on the right track last night.
RIVERHEAD, L.I., Sept. 19 -- Long Island's potato harvest season was celebrated here today. The value of the crop to growers and shipper-packers is estimated by the state at $18,000,000 this season.
LONDON, Sept. 19 -- Traffic wardens appeared on the scene today and received a decidedly mixed reception from unwary motorists when they began handing out Britain's first parking tickets.
A concerted effort to combat the threat of waterways tolls Is being undertaken by the inland waterways industry in cooperation with its customers.

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 19 -- Senator John F. Kennedy moved today to counter Vice President Nixon's attempts to depict him as the political captive of organized labor.
Three bids to supply the city's rock salt needs for the coming winter -- two of them identical to the fourth decimal place -- were opened yesterday by Purchase Commissioner Roger J. Browne.

CLEVELAND, Sept 19 (UPI) -- Barry MacKay and Bernard (Tut) Bartzen came through with their second singles victories today as the United States completed a 5-0 sweep of the American zone Davis Cup final over Venezuela.

JACQUES TIFFEAU, a Seventh Avenue designer, said today that he had been offered, and declined, an appointment to replace Yves St. Laurent as designer of the House of Dior in Paris.
The stock market gave up some $7,500,000,000 in paper values yesterday in its biggest decline of the year.
Presidential and Vice-Presidential candidates of the two major parties may be hard pressed to utilize all the free television time being made available to them in still-growing quantity.

LONDON, Sept. 19 -- Persistent small sales lowered share prices in the stock market here today. Shares offering low yields generally had losses of around a shilling (14 cents), while other falls were smaller.
THE following dinner menu is given as a guide to the use of foods that are reasonable in cost. A recipe is offered for an easy-to-prepare main dish.

Acquisition by Davidson Bros., Inc., of Kobacker Stores, Inc., was proposed yesterday by the presidents of the two department store chains, Joseph Davidson and Marvin Kobacker. Subject to stockholder approval, contracts were signed last Saturday for the acquisition.
A 16-year-old boy was accused yesterday of trying to steal thirty birds from a pigeon fancier, but the boy's lawyer said he had just wanted to play with the birds.

ALBANY, Sept. 19 -- Vice President Nixon's chance of carrying New York State was rated as good today by Governor Rockefeller. He gave the same estimate to the Republican's chance of retaining their present majorities in the Legislature.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Sept. 19 -- Howdy Myers may get booted out of the National Society of Moaning College Football Coaches for this, but he will sweat on a stack of rule books that Hofatra will lose a lot fewer games than it wins this season.

CARACAS, Venezuela, Sept. 17 -- Venezuela offers a striking example today of the difficulties of working out Latin America's greatest problem -- development with democracy.

Fidel Castro moved to Harlem last night after having stalked angrily from the Shelburne Hotel to complain in person at the United Nations against the treatment he said he was getting in New York.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 19 -- Leading diplomats will gather here tomorrow for the opening of the General Assembly's fifteenth session -- a session that is expected to be the most eventful in United Nations history.
TOKYO, Sept. 19 -- Crown Princess Michiko, wife of Japan's future Emperor, revealed today a new technique in child-rearing that could be a boon to all traveling parents.

A women's Zionist group, Mayor Wagner and Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt all expressed the hope here yesterday that Americans would not be influenced by any "religious issue" in their vote for the Presidency.
A lot of coffee was poured and a lot of cookies passed around in the Bronx yesterday as neighborhood women turned out to hear Mrs. Joseph P. Kennedy talk about "my son Jack."
Clients of Walter Scott Co., real estate concern, have completed the assembling of a 60-by-100-foot site on Seventy-ninth Street between First and Second Avenues for a two-story commercial building.

Stanley Holloway's use of two popular songs from "My Fair Lady" -- "With a Little Bit of Luck" and "Get Me to the Church on Time" -- in "Laughs and Other Events" has provoked a controversy.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I am sure that Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy's order canceling all police vacations and days off for the duration of this United Nations General Assembly session will create quite a furor, particularly since 1,300 New York City policemen of the Jewish faith will be affected by it because of the incidence of the Jewish New Year.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I have read with mounting interest the comments of Americans on our recent defeats and victories at the Olympic Games, particularly one statement, often repeated, having to do with the country's youth becoming soft and our international prestige suffering because of Soviet and other victories over our athletes.

ELMSFORD, N.Y., Sept. 20 -- The Ardsley Country Club foursome of Dott Watson, Paul Wise, Robert, McDonald and James Kridel won the Westchester Professional Golfers Association's pro-amateur benefit tournament today at the Elmwood Country Club with a net best ball of 28-32 -- 60.

At least five fights broke out yesterday outside the United Nations and other disturbances occurred near some of the foreign delegation buildings in the city. Three persons were slightly injured and four were arrested.
The new president of the American Bankers Association is a son of a blacksmith, who is sworn to ''help destroy any possible image of stuffiness."

An 11.8 per cent jump in the short interest on the New York Stock Exchange to 3,634,971 shares in the month ended last Thursday was reported by the exchange yesterday.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y. Sept. 20 -- The new African states admitted to the United Nations today have quickly shown that they will seek a political middle ground between East and West.

Students who have requested transfers from their neighborhood junior high schools under the Board of Education's new open-enrollment policy will begin entering their chosen schools today.
The Transit Authority decided yesterday to use for another year an ultrasonic rail tester that picks up defects invisible to the naked eye.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Sept. 20 -- Queen Juliana said today the Netherlands was against any weakening of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization. The Queen recommended an increase in defense expenditures.

WHO wants to look like a movie star? Apparently a great many women, and luckily for them, there is Helen Rose. Mrs. Rose, a petite brunette with a pretty, sweet smile, has been designer to the movie queens at Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer for eighteen years. For the last two and a half years, she also has been designing a collection that is sold in one store exclusively in any particular city across the country.
Secretary of Commerce Fredrick H. Mueller will launch here on Sept. 30 the export promotion program of Isbrandtsen Company, Inc., a major steamship operator.

Powerful Melaneslan sculptures of a kind never seen in this country before and New Guinean paintings made for a persuasive anthropologist will go on exhibition today at the Museum of Primitive Art, 18 West Fifty-fourth Street.

KINGS POINT, L.I., Sept. 20 -- When last seen in 1959, the Merchant Marine Academy eleven was thinly manned by ordinary mortals who succumbed to fatigue -- and an opponent with more depth -- in the second half.

Screen rights to "Gypsy," the long-running Broadway musical based on the autobiography of Gypsy Rose Lee, have been acquired by Warner Brothers.

No official action concerning the selection of a new president of Trans World Airlines, Inc., was taken at yesterday's special board meeting of ten minutes, which was postponed until today. However, the designation of Fred M. Glass to the post, which has been vacant since last July 28, is expected to be announced today, according to a source believed reliable.
JERSEY CITY, Sept. 20 -- A sharply divided City Commission appointed nine persons today to serve on a twelve-member board of managers for the Jersey City Medical Center.
RIVERSIDE., Calif., Sept. 20 (AP) -- Lee Duncan, who trained four generations of Rin Tin Tin dogs for the films and television, died here today of a heart attack at his ranch. He was 67 years old.

VIENNA, Sept. 20 -- The "cold war" was banished from today's opening session of the fourth annual General Conference of the International Atomic Energy Agency.

PARIS, Sept. 20 -- Jamin, the famous French trotter, will leave for the United States next Monday to compete in the international trotting championship series at Yonkers Raceway on Oct. 11 and 20. BUYING a new lipstick or a bottle of perfume in New York is just about as much fun as shopping for frozen vegetables. As Pittsburgh awaits with feverish impatience its first world series in thirty-three years, there is just one dark cloud on the horizon. It doesn't exactly concern the youngsters who now scamper around Forbes Field, just off the campus of Carnegie Tech and the University of Pittsburgh. They're too young to know what happened in that series of 1927.

BONN, Germany, Sept. 20 -- West Germany's two major political parties were reported today to have agreed to postpone a session in West Berlin of the Bundestag -- Parliament's lower house -- until after the inauguration of the new United States President.
ROME, Sept. 20 -- After five days of heavy rain that spread death and destruction from the Alps to Naples, the sun shone over the greater part of Italy today.

The United Nations General Assembly convened yesterday for its regular annual session. It is a measure of the growing importance of the organization that it has brought to the same world forum an impressive array of world leaders, including heads of state, premiers and foreign ministers.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 (AP) -- Senator John F. Kennedy announced the formation of a Natural Resources Advisory Council today and said the nation's natural resources had been disastrously neglected by the Eisenhower Administration.

PELHAM, N.Y., Sept. 20 -- Flower arrangements in tune with the season and the decor of each home to be visited are being prepared by members of the Women's Guild of Christ Protestant Episcopal Church for its sixteenth annual tour of old houses in this area.
Stocks came back yesterday after Monday's sharp decline to score a moderate gain on average. However, before the recovery set in, key averages again sank to lows for the year.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 20 -- The historic events of the fifteenth General Assembly will be carired by radio to the most extensive audience ever reached by the United Nations.
Buff Donelli definitely does not belong to the school of oaches who spend their hours way from the football field with Schopenhauer. Pessimism is entirely foreign to his nature.
BAMAKO, Sudan, Sept. 20 -- Premier Modibo Keita said today that Sudan wished to avoid becoming a satellite of either the East or the West in the world power struggle.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 -- President Eisenhower is expected to renew his "open skies" proposal in his speech to the United Nations General Assembly on Thursday.
Nearly 1,000 delegates to the general assembly of the Telephone Pioneers of America attended the opening luncheon of the group's thirty-fifth annual meeting yesterday at the Statler-Hilton Hotel.

CHICAGO, Sept. 20 (AP) -- Activity on the Board of Trade was centered mainly in soybean futures again today where a moderately brisk demand raised prices by major fractions to a cent a bushel on almost all contracts.

The victory of Richard Smith and Roger Bohl of Quakertown, Pa., in last week-end's Johnny Appleseed rally in Ohio puts this pair at the top of the list for the national championship. Driving a Fiat 2100 and representing the Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. team, Smith and Bohl, have posted a low score of 5 points.

Premier Khrushchev played the part of a helpful Ukrainian village elder on the sidewalk outside his country's United Nations mission on Park Avenue yesterday. He promised a tearful woman from the Ukraine that he would let her long-lost daughter rejoin her in the United States and sealed the matter with a kiss.

Michigan borrowed $25,000,000 in the bond market yesterday to finance the construction of trunk line highways. The money was raised on serial bonds due from 1961 to 1985 at an interest cost of 3.78316 per cent.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The ultimate interest cost of government capital improvement programs is important, is likely not to be clearly recognized, and deserves the prominence you have been giving it in your columns, most recently in your editorial of Sept. 8 on the city's debt service under the caption, "Pay Later and Pay Triple."
WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 -- The Public Health Service named the national organizations today to be called in to help advise on the use of live-virus vaccine for poliomyelitis.
LONDON, Sept. 20 -- Industrial share prices rallied strongly in the stock market here today after a bad start but closed lower on balance.

The victory of the Social Democrats in the Swedish general elections on Sunday was so impressive that it deserves special notice even in these remarkable days. Not the least impressive feature was the example of enlightened democracy in action that the Swedes have given. This is not a cause for surprise, but the results were.
William Smith, a lawyer accused of faking arrest records for gambling-case defendants to get them lesser sentences, was convicted yesterday in Special Sessions Court.
A TV show with a formidable built-in "equal time" headache went on camera on the East Side yesterday.
Governor Rockefeller, a top-drawing card among Republican campaigners nationally, strolled the sidewalks of New York yesterday extolling the qualifications of a local candidate.

Achievement medals were presented yesterday by the Deafness Research Foundation to David Sarnoff, board chairman of the Radio Corporation of America, and Herbert Hoover Jr., former Under Secretary of State, at a luncheon attended by 300 persons at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

Edwin Way Teale, writer-photographer-naturalist, has a new book on Dodd, Mead's list scheduled for Oct. 17 publication. Called "Journey Into Summer," it is the third volume in Mr. Teale's survey of the natural history of the American seasons.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 (AP) -- The United States must move promptly with moral and material help for new African nations or see them pulled closer to the Communist orbit, W. Averell Harriman said today.

Basaeball is a game in which the main idea is to score, regardless of the finesse -- or lack of it -- involved. So the league-leading Yankees were not the least bit embarrassed when, in the eleventh inning, the Washington Senators presented to them the run that brought a 2-1 victory last night at the Stadium.
CLEVELAND, Sept. 20 (AP) -- Dick Gernert, Lou Berberet and Al Kaline hit home runs for Detroit tonight as the Tigers beat the Cleveland Indians, 9 -- 1.

ANN ARBOR, Mich, Sept. 20 (AP) -- Consumer attitudes toward the nation's economy have not changed significantly in the last three months, the latest survey conducted by the University of Michigan disclosed today.

This year's Imperial Ball, an annual event that always boasts an appropriately filled royal box, will have as honor guests Prince and Princess Tomislav of Yugoslavia. The fete, scheduled for Dec. 15 at the Waldorf-Astoria, will benefit the Hospitalized Veterans Service.
The Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service intervened yesterday in contract negotiations between the General Electric Company and unions representing more than 100,000 of its employes.
Cotton futures moved 3 points up to 9 off on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday. A point is 5 cents a bale. The volume continued small.
ST. LOUIS, Sept. 20 (AP) -- Charlie James hit a base-filled two-out pinch single in the ninth inning, giving the St. Louis Cardinals a 3-2 victory over the Los Angeles Dodgers tonight.
BAY CITY, Mich., Sept. 20 -- Vice President Nixon appealed today for a campaign truce on partisan oratory that might lead Premier Khrushchev to believe the United States was weak and divided.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 20 -- The focus of attention at the United Nations today was on Nikita Khrushchev and Fidel Castro (why are the wicked so interesting and the good so dull?), but the real hero of the day was the Secretary General of the United Nations, Mr. Dag Hammarskjold.
LARCHMONT, N.Y., Sept. 20 -- The opening competition for the Amorita Cup put the Long Island Sound team of International One-Design Class sailors firmly ahead of Bermuda today.

DALLAS, Tex,, Sept. 20 -- The Democratic national platform was brusquely disclaimed at the Texas Democratic Convention today. However, Gov. Price Daniel pleaded for support for the Kennedy-Johnson ticket.

NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y., Sept. 20 -- Henry Cabot Lodge hedge-hopped across upstate New York today, taking the Democrats to task for their failure to push civil rights legislation at the post-convention Congressional session.
A courteous reception in Harlem and a flattering surprise visit from Premier Khrushchev made Fidel Castro a jaunty and satisfied man yesterday.

Premier Khrushchev visited Harlem yesterday to pay an informal call on Fidel Castro, whom he praised as a "heroic man." The Soviet Premier, abruptly ending the comparative isolation of his first hours in New York at noon, swept out of his headquarters at the Soviet United Nations mission, 680 Park Avenue, at Sixty-eighth Street, and headed north in a motorcade for Harlem.

The First Boston Corporation and associates will offer to the public today an issue of $50,000,000 first and refunding mortgage bonds, 4 3/4 per cent series due in 1990, of the Public Service Electric and Gas Company, New Jersey.
FARMINGDALE, L.I., Sept. 20 -- The Polytechnic Institute of Brooklyn broke ground in the rain today for its $1,600,000 Groduate Center.

ALTHOUGH Signora Gigliola Curiel from Milan and Bernard Newman come from opposite sides of the Atlantic they are in one-world agreement about how women should look. They proved this yesterday in their exclusive winter collections for Bergdorf Goodman.
The Chase Manhattan Bank will move its branch office at 75 Maiden Lane to 85 John Street, northwest corner of Gold Street, in the insurance district downtown.
"THE HOSTAGE" is a grab bag of wonderful and dreadful prizes. Brendan Behan's theatrical concoction, which opened last night at the Cort, mixes irreverent hilarity with tasteless rubbish.
KARACHI, Sept. 20 -- Pakistan appears to be leaning toward the Soviet Union in a determined effort to cut her oil imports and save scarce foreign exchange.

The heads of most of the major Jewish organizations of the United States met last week and decided to make no demonstrations or to take any other offensive actions against President Gamal Abdel Nasser of the United Arab Republic during his impending visit to this country.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 20 -- Frederick Henry Boland, the Irish diplomat who was elected today to the Presidency of the fifteenth General Assembly of the United Nations, has a particular fondness for a Latin quotation from Horace: "Aequam memento rebus in arduis servare montem" -- "remember to keep a cool head in difficult circumstances."

WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 20 -- Major Fingo, a 3-year-old owned by C.T. Black of Berryville, Va., scored his seventh victory in twenty starts this season by taking the Hillcrest Pace tonight at Roosevelt Raceway.

A group of investors has contracted to buy the forty-six-story building at 295 Madison Avenue, the southeast corner of the avenue and Forty-first Street. Alvin M. Greenstein, Shep Lieberman, Solomon Klausner and Harry L. Rubin are members of the group.

"THAT was not done when I was born, so why should it be done now? " The question was only rhetorical. The African who asked it believed that it was unanswerable, a complete refutation of the arguments of British soil experts in Kenya who were pleading for modern methods of erosion control and reclamation.

Chase R. McCoy's T.V. Lark, currently regarded as one of the top 3-year-olds in the country, was vanned into Aqueduct yesterday with his victory in last Saturday's United Nations Handicap behind him and the $100,000 Woodward at Aqueduct this Saturday just ahead of him.
Mayor Wagner voiced complete support of the police yesterday against Soviet, Polish and Cuban charges of mistreatment by security details protecting delegates to the United Nations General Assembly.

Diffident Republican women, who may be too shy to ring their neighbors' doorbells to invite them, please, to vote for Mr. Nixon and Mr. Lodge, were instructed yesterday in the not-so-gentle art of "getting out the vote."
HUTCHINSON, Kan., Sept. 18 -- The clamorous world that lies beyond the wheat fields presses closer upon the people of this pleasant town.
SVETLANA BERIOSOVA gave her first performance of the season in "The Sleeping Beauty" with the Royal Ballet at the Metropolitan Opera House last night, and a lovely performance it was.
"Mr. Spatz, please, if you don't stop answering, how am I going to ask you a question? "

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 20 (UPI) -- Pittsburgh added momentum to its National League pennant drive tonight with a double victory over the Philadelphia Phillies, taking a 3-2 decision after Bob Friend had won the opener of a twilight-night doubleheader, 7-1.

Federal funds have been assured for a $4,000,000 project to rebuild two railroad bridges across busy Queens Boulevard, Borough President John. T. Clancy of Queens announced yesterday, but the completion date was a matter of doubt.
MILWAUKEE, Sept. 20 (AP) -- Jay Hook pitched a two-hitter in blanking Milwaukee, 9 -- 0, tonight as the Cincinnati Reds dampened the Braves' hopes of moving up in the National League race.

With his control of the Alleghany Corporation now being contested by the Murchison oil family of Dallas, Allan P. Kirby, chairman and president of Alleghany, has asked for the resignation from the company's board of a key Murchison representative, Joseph M. Fitzsimmons.

The Communist leader of Hungary, Janos Kadar, was not molested yesterday afternoon when he emerged after nearly twenty-eight hours in the headquarters of Hungary's United Nations mission at 10 East Seventy-fifth Street.

A special survey conducted by the Better Packaging Advisory Council has found serious consumer dissatisfaction with the labeling of food products. As a result, the survey found, impulse buying was being cut and sales had declined.
More than the usual number of traffic jams developed in Manhattan yesterday because of the opening of the United Nations General Assembly.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 20 -- The General Assembly opened its 1960 session at 3:22 P.M. today in the presence of Premier Khrushchev of the Soviet Union, President Tito of Yugoslavia, Premier Fidel Castro of Cuba, and other heads of government.
WUPPERTAL, Germany, Sept. 20 (AP) -- Otis Davis of Los Angeles, the Olympic 400-meter winner, was defeated tonight by the Rome silver medalist, Carl Kaufmann of Germany.
The transfer of $50,000 worth of negotiable securities from a Canadian bank to Lowell M. Birrell, fugitive financier in Brazil, has been blocked by the trustees of the Swan Finch Oil Corp.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 (AP) -- Attorney General William P. Rogers announced today that as a result of court action the American Radiator and Standard Sanitary Corporation had agreed to divest itself of its Youngstown Kitchens division at Warren, Ohio, acquired through a merger transaction in January, 1956.

Trading in United States Government securities came to a near standstill yesterday as dealers and investors waited for the expiration of the Treasury's offer to exchange longer-term bonds for up to $6,100,000,000 of war-issued 2 1/2 s due in 1967, 1968 and 1969.

The widening interest of Americans in European stocks has caught the eye of brokerage concerns, investment counselors, banks and others -- and brought forth some advice. David L. Babson Co., Boston investment counseling company, has formulated some ground rules in its latest weekly letter.

A European technique for determining whether a victim had died of drowning was discussed here yesterday at the Second International Conference on Forensic Pathology and Medicine at the New York University Medical Center, 550 First Avenue.

The opening of the fourth annual General Conference of the International Atomic Energy Agency (I.A.E.A.) at its headquarters in Vienna calls attention to the shifts in emphasis in the agency's program that have been found necessary during the first three years of its existence.
LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Sept. 20 -- A caretaker government of students and young university graduates was named today to take over the administration of the Congo.
Vacationing non-Jewish members of the police force were asked yesterday to volunteer to return to work so that Jewish policemen could be off for the Rosh ha-Shanah and Yom Kippur holy days.

Alex Webster, one of the New York Giants' front-line halfbacks, was placed on the inactive list yesterday as the team's roster was cut to thirty-eight players. This is the maximum number of men permitted on a National Football League squad when the season opens.

Thomas E. Stakem, vice chairman of the Federal Maritime Board, declared yesterday that the United States merchant fleet's participation in the movement of American foreign trade "has been diminishing to the danger point."

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Sept. 20 -- James S. Hamlin, vice president of the Henry Kelly Importing and Distributing Company, Inc., 413 West Four-teenth Street, New York, importers of and wholesale dealers in wines and liquors, died today at his home at 50 Flint Avenue here after a long illness.
PEGGY ROTZELL, of Philadelphia won the special prize for having the best record throughout the tournament in the New York-New Jersey championships played at Asbury Park, N.J., over the last week-end.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: It ought to be said at this point in the Presidential campaign that the opposition to Senator Kennedy among most independent Democrats, and independents generally, has nothing to do with religion. It will be bad for the country, and unfair to Mr. Nixon, if events like Dr. Norman Vincent Peale's unfortunate statement obscure this fact.
PARIS, Sept. 20 -- The French Government installed today the first of four commissions of European and Moslem Algerians to study problems of Algeria and advise the Government on future development.
THE following dinner menu is given as a guide to the use of foods that are reasonable in coat. A recipe is offered for an easy-to-prepare dish.
HAVANA, Sept. 20 (AP) -- Premier Fidel Castro's hotel troubles in New York are being used in one of the most bitter anti-United States campaigns in Cuban history.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 -- Senator John F. Kennedy pledged tonight that if elected President he would move three ways in his "first ninety days" to strengthen the world position of the United States.

CAIRO, Sept. 20 -- President Gamal Abdel Nasser made several changes in his Cabinet today. He added no new names to the United Arab Republic's official family, but shifted some ministers and gave added responsibilities to others.
A genuine, non-fiction space suit -- a head-to-toe one that will enable the crewman of a satellite to step out into space -- is being developed by the Air Force.

SAMNEUA, Laos, Sept. 20 -- The military commandant of this beleaguered provincial capital in northeastern Laos has turned down an offer of aid by Premier Souvanna Phouma to help combat the Communist forces that nearly ring the town.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 21 (AP) -- Ike Delock practically pitched the Baltimore Orioles out of the American League pennant picture tonight by limiting them to three hits as the Boston Red Sox posted a 4-1 victory.
PRINCETON, N.J., Sept. 21 -- Princeton's Borough Engineer has refused to grant occupancy permits for five rooms in a new $520,000 dormitory at Princeton University.
BROOKVILLE, L.I., Sept. 21 -- It's the scrimmages, not the games, that worry C.W. Post's football coach.
ST. LOUIS, Sept. 21 (AP) -- Duke Snider's pinch-hit single opened a two-run rally in the twelfth inning tonight and led the Los Angeles Dodgers to a 5-3 victory over the St. Louis Cardinals.

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 21 -- Insurgent forces in the United Steelworkers of America made a formal plea today for Federal intervention after one of their chiefs had been mauled in a new outbreak of violence at the union's convention.

W. Randolph Burgess, United States Ambassador to the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, urged the nation's bankers yesterday to give continued backing to foreign aid as the most effective and least expensive way of maintaining the peace.

NOW that the shark scares are about over and the surge of shark fishing inspired by the scares has subsided, let us permit science to take over and give us the dots on the matter. Fishermen ought to know about these things; they make good party talk.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Sept. 21 -- Twenty-three Negroes, including thirteen children, began a sitdown strike today in front of the William B. Ward Elementary School, an all-white facility in the fashionable Quaker Ridge neighborhood of North New Rochelle.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 21 -- Vincent Price, whose roles have made him expert in horror movies, is convinced that the worst horror in Hollywood is the indifference of the movie industry to the cultural life around it.
In a demonstration of his neutral line, President Tito will see and speak to both President Eisenhower and Premier Khrushchev today.
Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange were unchanged to 14 points (70 cents a bale) up yesterday. The near July contract posted the extreme gain.

The mountain of surplus wheat on the hands of the world's big four Wheat producers has grown this year -- and increased the disposal problems. Stocks on hand on Aug. 1 aggregated 2,721,500,000 bushels, up 9 per cent from the year-before level, according to the Canadian Government's Bureau of Statistics.
VIENTIANE, Laos, Sept. 21 -- Premier Souvanna Phouma said today Government forces had stopped the advance on this Laotian capital by troops of the Revolutionary Committee of Savannakhet.
DELAWARE, Ohio, Sept. 21 (AP) -- Eleven of harness racing's fastest 3-year-old pacers line up tomorrow afternoon at the Delaware County Fairgrounds for the fifteenth Little Brown Jug classic.
SAVANNAKHET, Laos, Sept. 21 -- Reinforcements are being sent to the beleaguered city of Samneua by the anti-Communist revolutionary headquarters here as fast as available air transport permits.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 21 -- Amid all the distress today over a rumor that someone might conceal a deadly weapon in a camera aimed at Premier Khrushchev, a photographer for a news magazine strode gaily up to a pedestrian entrance of the United Nations carrying four cameras.

PARAMUS, N.J., Sept. 13 -- Mrs. John J. Houlch, the young wife of a mechanical engineer from Indian Point, N.Y., stood in the Bergen Mall shopping center here the other day with her small son and spoke her mind on politics.
FLINT, Mich., Sept. 21 -- The Buick Special, a luxury smaller car, was shown at a preview today. The new entrant gives Buick the widest price spread of all General Motors divisions.

An anxious young couple who refuse to give up hope won a minor diplomatic victory yesterday. It was a promise from Janos Kadar, Hungary's Communist leader, to consider letting their 7-year-old daughter out of Hungary.
