The production of electric power in the nation fell to 13,903,000,000 kilowatt-hours in the week ended last Saturday from 14,216,000,000 in the preceding week, Edison Electric Institute reported yesterday. In the comparable 1959 period production was 12,779,000,000 kilowatt-hours.
The Bowater Paper Corporation, Ltd., of London, announced yesterday that it would offer its common stockholders of record of Sept. 15 rights to 6,000,000 additional common shares.

Premier Khrushchev turned a Park Avenue balcony into an impromptu Soviet forum yesterday. He appeared twice within a few hours on the stone balustrade of the Soviet Union's United Nations mission headquarters at 680 Park Avenue, at Sixty-eighth Street.

LONDON, Sept. 21 -- The finance ministers of the British Commonwealth nations agreed today that the "essential interests" of their countries should be safeguarded in any negotiations to end the economic division of Europe.

"THE VULGARIANS," by Robert Osborn, enters the crowded what-we-must-do-to-be-saved scene with splendid clamor. This, a subtitle Informs us, is "a satire in pictures and words on the decline of greatness and rise of mediocrity in America." Or anywhere, at any time, for that matter.

The police broke up a milling crowd of supporters of Premier Fidel Castro of Cuba, anti-segregationists and friends of Patrice Lumumba, deposed Premier of the Congo, late last night near the Theresa Hotel in Harlem.
PARIS, Sept. 21 -- France received today an expert's report on the health of her economy.

If the Murchison oil family of Dallas has its way, the Alleghany Corporation, which has long been but the corporate shadow, first, of the late Robert R. Young, and now, of Allan P. Kirby, will become "a diversified investment company boldly taking large speculative positions."
WHEN President Tito of Yugoslavia stepped off the liner Queen Elizabeth Tuesday morning he took many persons on the pier by by surprise.
HAVANA, Sept. 21 (AP) -- Two small bombs exploded in Havana during the night -- the third straight night of nuisance bombing in the Cuban capital.

Tang of Autumnal Equinox There are numerous traditions about the weather at the time of the equinoxes, but none of them makes it clear whether the equinox is supposed to cause certain weather conditions or vice versa.
The country's two leading trans-Atlantic passenger steamship lines announced yesterday they would jointly promote off season ship travel to Europe.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 21 -- The Austrian Foreign Minister, Dr. Bruno Kreisky, called on the United Nations General Assembly today to take up the question of the Austrian minority in Italy.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -- The Federal Reserve Board reported today that the condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in leading cities showed the following principal changes for the week ended Wednesday, Sept. 14:

The directors of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad announced yesterday that they were ready to go ahead immediately with the New York Central Railroad in making a study of savings that a merger of the two carriers could effect.
The State of Connecticut borrowed $35,440,000 in the bond market yesterday to finance highway construction.

ALBERT A. OSTROW is the new authority on games for the Association of American Playing Card Manufacturers, to which some thousands of card players write each year for advice on the rules of games ranging from contract bridge, pinochle and canasta down to primero, tresette, and nearly twenty different forms of solo.
Rosh ha-Shanah, opening the Jewish New Year 5721, began at sundown yesterday with services in temples and synagogues.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -- The Council of Christian Churches demanded today -- and was refused -- an apology from the Democratic National Committee for a committee memorandum citing two of its ministers as leading "anti-Catholic extremists."
LONDON, Sept. 21 -- The rebuffs suffered by the Soviet Union in the Congo and at the United Nations are regarded here as major setbacks in Moscow's attempts to bring Africa within its influence.

The Yankees collected nine unearned runs on their way to a 10 -- 3 victory over the Washington Senators yesterday at the Stadium. But Casey Stengel's pennant-bound Bombers didn't mind backing into their sixth straight triumph any more than the 6,868 fans seemed to mind the haphazard antics of the athletes.
President Kwame Nkrumah of Ghana declared last night that Patrice Lumumba was still head of "the legitimate government" of the Congo.

Landlords of decaying walk-up tenement houses are to get competent help in property management heretofore available only to wealthy management corporations, the city's Housing and Redevelopment Board announced yesterday.

David Ross, producer-director, displayed his dexterity as a juggler yesterday. He postponed "When We Dead Awaken" from Oct. 3 to an unspecified date at the Fourth Street Theatre. It will be supplanted by "Hedda Gabler," starring Mai Zetterling in her New York stage debut.
The police took extra precautions yesterday to protect Premier Khrushchev after two plots to assassinate him were reported.
A company in which David Rockefeller has interests has sold 20,000 shares in B.F. Goodrich Company, according to the latest insiders report of the New York Stock Exchange.
The transfer of junior high school students under the Board of Education's new open enrollment policy to aid integration got under way smoothly yesterday.

PRINCETON, N.J., Sept. 21 -- For a team that has been picked to finish in the second division of the Ivy League, Princeton has the potential to give fits to some of the more fancied members of its set.
A 9-year-old girl and a Cuban opponent of Premier Fidel Castro were wounded by gunfire yesterday during a brawl in a restaurant between foes and supporters of the Castro regime.
MOSCOW, Sept. 21 -- The Soviet Union sought today to convince world opinion that only the United States was blocking a disarmament accord at the United Nations General Assembly.

Two plots of land off the south side of Bruckner Boulevard running through to Story Avenue and fronting on Theriot, Leland and Underhill Avenues have been sold by Louis Ebling to Allstate Outlet Stores. Inc. It will be used for the construction of a motel.

JONES BEACH, L.I., Sept. 21 -- Stockton, Calif., reached the final of the winner's bracket in the world tournament of the Amateur Softball Association tonight by scoring a 2-1 victory in eleven innings over Oklahoma City.
Music, or a reasonable facsimile, for teen-agers will blast out Saturdays on the National Broadcasting Company television network starting Oct. 15.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I am one of many residents of this country who have just returned from a summer in Europe. Along with many others I have tried my best while over there to redress the misconceptions which distort or belittle the policies and the ideals of America.

The photograph of Premier Khrushchev embracing Premier Castro at the United Nations on Tuesday will doubtless become famous. One can read into it all kinds of symbolisms, not the least being that a bear hug can be lethal.
The comings and goings of delegates to the United Nations General Assembly disrupted midtown traffic less yesterday than they had Tuesday.

Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy, defying an implied ultimatum from Mayor Wagner, refused last night to apologize for a remark that had been interpreted as a slur on the religious sincerity of Jewish policemen.
MIDDLETOWN, Conn., Sept. 21 -- Fair weather or foul, Norm Daniels, the head football coach at Wesleyan, plans to be prepared.

Purchase Commissioner Roger J. Browne announced yesterday that he was rejecting all three bids received Monday to supply the city's need for rock salt. The salt would be used to help remove snow from the city streets next winter.
LARCHMONT, N.Y., Sept. 21 -- Long Island Sound International One-Design Class skippers completed a sweep over Bermuda for the Amorita Cup today despite miserable sailing weather.

LONDON, Sept. 21 (Reuters) -- The West German newspaper Deutsche Zeitung said today the United Nations vote supporting Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold "not only struck the Soviet Union a telling blow but also very largely destroyed Khrushchev's propaganda ideas before the Assembly proper started."
MANKATO, Minn., Sept. 21 -- Senator Lyndon B. Johnson found the weather sticky but the crowds responsive today as he attacked Ezra Taft Benson and Republican farm policy.

ELISABETHVILLE, the Congo, Sept. 21 -- The United Nations threatened today to use force to protect the civilian population of the Secessionist Province of Katanga against "repressive operations" by the state police and soldiers.
Market fluctuations in highgrade bonds were irregular yesterday.
Three leading heads of state in Africa who are coming to the United Nations General Assembly, including President Gamal Abdel Nasser of the United Arab Republic have been invited to speak in Harlem.

VALHALLA, N.Y., Sept. 21 -- The House Staff Loan Fund of the Grasslands Hospital, the Westchester County Medical Center here, will benefit from a fashion show and bridge tea to be held in the Grasslands auditorium on Monday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -- President Eisenhower will confer privately in New York tomorrow afternoon with President Tito of Yugoslavia and three other foreign leaders. A dramatic shift of plans today expanded his visit to the United Nations into a major venture in personal diplomacy.
CHICAGO, Sept. 21 (AP) -- Two-run homers by Minnie Minoso and Jim Landis tonight hoisted the Chicago White Sox to a 7-2 victory over the Kansas City Athletics and into second place.

There is a steady increase in the sponsorship of obedience training classes by community recreation centers in Westchester County, Mrs. Anne Hunt of Purchase, N.Y., who instructs at some of them, said last week.

HONG KONG, Sept. 14 -- The Communist regime in mainland China is making a special effort to rouse the patriotic fervor of the people by publicizing anew exploits of the period when the Communists gained power.

NEW YORK is becoming increasingly a city with eyeravishing restaurant interiors. Three dining establishments with decors as elegant as aspic and gay as cotton candy are opening within a three-week period.
GENEVA. Sept. 7 -- On the outskirts of this city, hard on the French border, is one of the most ambitious and most successful international scientific enterprises ever undertaken.

An unpublicized meeting the State Department is scheduled to hold today with the maritime attaches of eight West European nations was strongly attacked yesterday by Ralph E. Casey, president of the American Merchant Marine Institute.
LONDON, Sept. 21 -- Work at the port of London was brought almost to a standstill today by an unofficial strike of tally clerks. They are the men who check cargoes on and off ships.
BALBOA, C.Z., Sept. 21 -- The ceremony of raising the Panamanian flag officially in the United States Canal Zone for the first time was marred here today by the stabbing of a United States official.
Fidel Castro withdrew from the limelight yesterday as the Cuban delegation to the United Nations split into two teams.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 21 -- A number of Latin-American delegates said tonight they agreed with President Eisenhower's decision to exclude Cuba and the Dominican Republic from the luncheon he is giving tomorrow after his address before the General Assembly.

James Reston, the Washington correspondent of The New York Times, told 500 public-relations men and women yesterday that he believed the next President would win by a wide margin of votes in the electoral college.
Richard Rodgers is about to try what he calls "the big experiment."

Realty Equities Corporation has purchased the four-story elevator garden apartment building at 12 Hempstead Avenue, on the corner of North Village Avenue, Rockville Centre, for cash over a first mortgage of $460,000.
The State Education Department has told the Board of Education here that it is free to reorganize its administration.
Here arc three recipes that are favorites of the newly remodeled New York restaurants. Two of them are chicken dishes that require Bechamel sauce; one is for Guacamole.

WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 21 -- Maria Key is the 3-1 favorite in the field of twelve in the $23,064 Proximity Stake for 2-year-old trotters at Roosevelt Raceway tomorrow night. The Proximity, named for the great trotter of the 1940-50 period, is the filly division of Friday's $71,881 Westbury Futurity.
The president of City College said yesterday that "Communist-oriented students" controlled one of the six student newspapers at the college.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -- The Census Bureau has determined finally, subject to no further adjustment, that the population of Vermont was 389,881 last April 1 and the population of North Dakota was 632,446.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Sept. 21 -- Floyd Patterson has just completed a greatly acclaimed exhibition tour of the land of Ingemar Johansson. His enthusiastic reception by the Swedish public and press, however, also had its bittersweet side.
LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Sept, 21 -- Reports from the interior tonight indicated that the withdrawal of Soviet technicians from the Congo might be nearing completion.

Purchase of the world-wide interests of Northam Warren Corporation and its affiliates by Chesebrough - Pond's, Inc., has been agreed to in principle by their directors, it was announced jointly yesterday by J.A. Straka, president of Chesebrough-Pond's, and Northam Warren, president of the company bearing his name.

NASHVILLE,Tenn. Sept -- 21 (UPI) -- The press secretaries of both major Presidential candidate potested to the four big networks today against the exclusion of newspaper reportMil from the initial television debate between Vice President Nixon and Senator John. F. Kennedy.
TRENTON, Sept. 21 -- Secretary of Labor James P. Mitchell made it clear today that if Vice President Nixon is elected President, he would be willing -- even anxious -- to continue in his post.
MANILA, Sept. 21 -- Foreign Minister Felixberto M. Serrano expressed optimism today that the Philippines and the United States would reach agreement soon on a new treaty concerning military bases.
CHICAGO, Sept. 21 (AP) -- Ernest Burford of Memphis and Ace Armstrong of Elizabeth, N.J., fought to a ten-round draw in a middleweight bout in Chicago Stadium tonight.

JEFFERSON CITY, Mo., Sept. 21 (UPI) -- It took Missouri Democrats only sixty-five minutes today to nominate Lieut. Gov. Edward V. Long for the United States Senate and Hilary A. Bush for Lieutenant Governor.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 (AP) -- For the first time in recent years, the Securities and Exchange Commission today softened a disciplinary action against a broker by the National Association of Securities Dealers, Inc.
The wholesale commodity price index rose to 83.6 on Tuesday from a seven-month low of 83.4 on Monday. The daily index, compiled by the Bureau of Labor Statistics, stood at 86.4 on Sept. 17, 1959.
NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 21 (UPI) -- The police arrested a Tulane University graduate student today on charges of criminal anarchy growing out of a lunch-counter sit-in.

WASHINGTON, Sept 21 -- Senator J.W. Fulbright said today that Vice President Nixon "is asking tha Democrats to join him in a conspiracy of silence or of misrepresentation in order to mislead the American people."

Bob Austin, supervisor of officials of the American Football League, yesterday declared that a double foul (one by each team) had been committed in the final seconds of the New York Titans-Boston Patriots game at the Polo Grounds last Saturday night.

LONDON, Sept. 21 -- Buyers returned to the stock market here today and, with stocks still in short supply, prices of top industrials bounded ahead. Many second-line shaves scored appreciable though smaller gains.
The image of the United States abroad "is not very good" because this country indulges in "white-supremacy nonsense that we cannot afford," the Right Rev. James A. Pike said here yesterday.

WILMINGTON, Del., Sept. 21 (AP) -- Sol A. Dann today asked a Delaware court to dismiss a $30,000,000 libel and slander suit filed against him by Chrysler Corporation on the ground it was brought solely "to embarrass, humiliate and harass."

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 21 -- Leaders of nearly a dozen African republics acknowledged their admission to United Nations membership today with praise for France and warnings against attempts to involve Africa in the "cold war."

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Sept. 21 (AP) -- Circuit Judge Walter B. Jones denied a motion by The New York Times Company today to have the trial of $1,500,000 in libel suits filed by Montgomery's three city commissioners delayed until January.
CHICAGO, Sept. 21 -- The United Arab Republic will send 250 ancient national art treasures to the United States for exhibition in major cities, including New York and Chicago.

PARAMUS, N.J., Sept. 21 -- Al Mengert, who already has won both the New Jersey open and the New Jersey Professional Golfers Association championship this year, today made an auspicious start in the Metropolitan Golf Association open.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 21 -- Premier Sylvanus Olympic of Togo said in an interview today that the dissolution of the Mali Federation could result in the leftward drift of one of its components -- the Sudan Republic.
Pacific Power and Light Company borrowed $20,000,000 in the bond market yesterday at an interest cost of 5.1434 pet cent.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -- A former Army counter-intelligence agent cited before Senate investigators today scores of cases in which Communist East Germany employed mass abductions, torture and sex to spy on West Berlin.

Smith-Corona Marchant, Inc., reported yesterday that it had record sales of $93,358,883 in the fiscal year ended on June 30, compared with a volume of 592,181,565 for the year before, However, the company incurred a loss in contrast to a profit in fiscal 1959.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 (AP) -- India formally asked the United States today for $150,000,000 of American surplus cotton over the next four years to help stabilize Indian clothing costs.
BONN, Germany, Sept. 21 -- With seemingly deliberate vagueness, Communist East Germany left the Allies wondering today whether it had begun a sharp new squeeze on Berlin.

Following two days of organizational work the star-studded session of the United Nations General Assembly gets down today to the main business at hand -- the great debate between the West and the Soviet bloc that already dominates the world scene and is likely to determine the international climate for some time to come.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -- Senator John F. Kennedy urged the State Department today to meet with African leaders at the current United Nations session to shape a "full attack" on the continent's education needs.

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 21 -- The president of the New Jersey School Superintendents Association said today the rapid changes expected in the decade ahead posed problems for school boards, for education in general, and for school superintendents.

SYRACUSE, Sept. 21 (AP) -- Virus-inspired sniffles and aches beat a retreat from the Syracuse football camp today, lifting the powerful Orange eleven's morale for Saturday's opener against Boston University.

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 21 -- Banks are mastering the lesson hat no more than a few of them can "beat the market" in anticipating swings in interest rates, a dealer in United States Government securities said here today.

Many boxes have been taken for the Oct. 7 performance by the Royal Ballet of "The Sleeping Beauty" at the Metropolitan Opera House. The evening has been arranged as a benefit for the Town School Scholarship Fund.

An American edition of "The Memoirs of General Lord Ismay," with a prefatory note by Sir Winston Churchill, will be issued by Viking on Oct. 10. The author was Sir Winston's chief of staff during World War II from the fall of France until V-J Day and afterward, working daily with the principal British and American leaders.

The International Union of Electrical Workers filed unfair labor practices charges with the National Labor Relations Board against the General Electric Company yesterday. It accused the company of interfering in union affairs and intimidating employes.

World sugar futures were weak yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange. Rumors that France would offer refined and raw sugar in the world market depressed quotations.

ACCRA, Ghana, Sept. 21 -- The Government of Ghana invited tenders today for construction of the Volta River dam, which is intended to lead to the industrialization of Ghana. The power made available would be used initially by a consortium of aluminum companies to smelt alumina to aluminum.

Mrs. Phillip du Pont's 5-year-old Tempted, the top handicap mare of 1959, won the seventh running of the $30,000 Maskette Handicap at Aqueduct yesterday.

I KNOW a village (it's really a small city) in Westchester County. A lovely lady lives there who writes poetry. She is one of the few poets now alive who is admired by scholars, intellectuals and other poets and at the same time is beloved by thousands of readers. LOS ANGELES, Sept. 22 (UPI) -- Pone Kingpetch of Thailand retained his world fly-weight championship tonight by knocking out Pascual Perez of Argentina after 2 minutes 32 seconds of the eighth round.
BILLINGS, Mont., Sept. 22 -- Senator John F. Kennedy went after the outdoor type in five big Western states today.

BERLIN, Sept. 22 -- Leonard Bernstein and the New York Philharmonic Orchestra found their reward tonight in a West Berlin concert hall for having flown across the Atlantic to give two concerts in this harassed, divided city.
DARIEN, Conn., Sept. 22 -- The Darien Board of Education has announced it has liberalized its transportation regulations to permit school buses to operate on private roads.

An account of how food and drug advertising exploits public health is given by Ralph Lee Smith in "The Health Hucksters." The author contends that false and misleading advertising persuades Americans to spend more than a billion a year for foods, drugs and cosmetics that have no real benefit.
SIR JAMES FRASER commented on the curious fact that men take more pride in being lucky than in being skillful or talented. Today's hand might be said to bear him out.

AS part of a project to recover in music the sounds that were characteristic of significant periods in American history, Richard Bales, conductor of the National Gallery Orchestra in Washington, has now made an album entitled "The Revolution."
SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 22 -- The top-ranking officer of the Air Force declared today that the pre-eminence of the United States in space was essential to any guarantee of world security.

IN his five years as New York's Police Commissioner, Stephen Patrick Kennedy has been called many things: autocratic, dictatorial, inflexible, chilly, austere, holier-than-thou, aloof, tough, uncooperative, incorruptible and tyrannical.

ABOARD THE U.S.S. NORTHAMPTON, in the Norwegian Sea, Sept. 22 -- An Allied striking fleet raked the coast of Western Europe with simulated atomic raids today as the first phase of Exercise Sword Thrust ended.

LINCOLN, R.I., Sept. 22 (AP) -- Officials of Lincoln Downs race track feel certain that holders of sixteen daily-double tickets worth $1,138,40 each will comply with a new Federal regulation rather than forego their winnings.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -- Governor Rockefeller will represent President Eisenhower at next week's independence celebrations in Nigeria, the White House said today.

LONDON, Sept. 22 -- Prime Minister Macmillan will fly to New York Sunday to address the United Nations General Assambly during the latter part of next week. The date for his address has not been decided.

LONDON, Sept. 22 -- Industrial shares failed to fully maintain an early improvement in the stock market here today but scored more rises than falls. The Financial Times industrial shares index rose 0.9 point to 328.7.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -- Secretary Arthur S. Flemming said today that Governor Rockefeller could make a start on helping "medically needy" persons not now on relief without raising taxes.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -- The Federal Maritime Board and the Farrell Lines signed a $62,722,226 contract today for the construction of six cargo ships for the United States-African trade routes.
Junior high schools here have begun a three-year enriched curriculum for gifted pupils.
TOKYO, Sept. 22 -- Crown Prince Akihito and Crown Princess Michiko left here this afternoon for a sixteen-day goodwill visit to the United States.
LAHORE, Pakistan, Sept. 22 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru made a fervent appeal today for Indian-Pakistani unity in the face of what he called grave dangers to world peace.

ROCKFORD, Ill., Sept. 22 -- Vice President Nixon lunched on barbecued buffalo and met a champion baby beef steer that had been named for him as he campaigned today across the tall corn country of Missouri and Illinois.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I wish to comment particularly upon that part of Senator Kennedy's statement before the Greater Houston Ministerial Association on Sept. 12 in which he discussed the importance of religious liberty for all: Protestant, Catholic and Jew.

The Rev. Dr. Julius Mark, senior rabbi of Temple Emanu-El, said yesterday that the United States had lost its sense if national purpose "not because of our prosperity, but because of our tendency to equate material well-being with national purpose."
LONDON, Sept. 22 -- Strong opposition from other Commonwealth countries is jeopardizing Britain's efforts to reach an accommodation with the sixnation European Economic Community, or Common Market.
President Eisenhower redefined his new goal for the Americas yesterday as a better life for the underprivileged people of all countries in the Organization of American States.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 (AP) -- President Eisenhower may be asked to help resolve the controversy between New York and Virginia over construction of a super aircraft carrier.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Newspaper accounts of the death of Stephen Carlton Clark on Sept. 17 failed to mention his major contributions in the field of medical education.
ELMIRA, N.Y., Sept. 22 (AP) -- Remington Rand announced today that it would transfer the manufacture of all its standard and portable typewriters from Elmira to European plants by 1961.

Retail sales have been going up. So has the population. But the number of retail stores has been declining.
If Dick Sakala serves as an adequate quarterback for Columbia Saturday, the chances are that the Lions will get their season off to a good start against Brown at Baker Field.

A leading producer of fire engines said yesterday that it was planning to enter the automobile manufacturing field.
IF fall is here, can cranberries be far behind? Somehow these deep red berries are as inextricably linked with narrowing, mistily mysterious days as they are with Thanksgiving and turkey.

CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Sept. 22 (UPI) -- Two Polaris missiles fired from a submerged nuclear submarine failed today.
SOUTH BEND, Ind., Sept. 22 -- Henry Cabot Lodge said today that there would be "a completely new line-up" of top United States diplomats abroad if Vice-President Nixon were elected in November.
President Eisenhower made his third appearance yesterday before the United Nations with a record of having only half his proposals to that organization carried out.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 22 (UPI) -- The Pittsburgh Pirates moved closer to their first National League pennant in thirty-three years today by sweeping their third double-header in five days. They beat the Chicago Cubs, 3 -- 2 in eleven innings and 6 -- 1.

CHICAGO, Sept. 22 -- Plans for next Monday night's television debate between the major Presidential candidates approached completion today. Four panelists were designated to cross-examine the candidates.
NAHA, Okinawa, Sept. 22 -- A United States Marine Corps transport, trying to ditch at sea with an engine in flames, crashed with "tremendous impact" today, killing all twentynine marines aboard.
United Airlines, Inc., is considering making a public offering of additional common stock "in the near future," the company told the Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday.

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 22 -- Ray M. Gidney, United States Controller of the Currency, said today that he was not encouraging New York City banks to "break any speed limits" in establishing branches in Nassau and Westchester Counties.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 22 -- The Soviet Union accused the United States today of trying to "sidestep" a disarmament debate during the General Assembly session.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 22 -- The Pennsylvania Railroad announced late today that all salaried employes in its general offices who make less than $18,000 a year were being furloughed for two days each in the last two weeks of this month.
PORTLAND, Ore., Sept. 22 (UPI) -- Mason Rudolph of Clarksville, Tenn., posted an early lead of 65 today and saw it stand up throughout the first round of the $27,000 Portland open golf tournament.

PARIS, Sept. 22 -- Gen. Raoul Salan, a leading figure in the 1958 army-settler revolt in Algeria that brought General de Gaulle to power was forbidden today by the French Government to return to his home in Algiers.

Premier Khrushchev said last night that he considered President Eisenhower's United Nations address conciliatory, and hinted that he would be receptive to an invitation to meet the President. DELAWARE, Ohio, Sept. 22 (AP) -- Highly-favored Bullet Hanover came back after a disappointing start today and won the fifteenth annual Little Brown Jug pace for 3 years-olds.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 11 points (55 cents a bale) up on near October and 8 off to 5 up on other months yesterday.

The New York Philharmonic will begin its 119th season with a non-subscription pension fund benefit concert in the redecorated Carnegie Hall on Tuesday. This will be the first concert in the Hall since it was bought for preservation by the city.

Although the yachting season's predicted-log power cruiser champion skipper may not be confirmed until West Coast results are tabulated, Elias A. Kalil of Manhasset, L.I., is likely to be the titleholder by more than 1,000 points.

Wagner College stands high atop Grymes Hill on Staten Island. On a clear, sunny day the co-educational student body gets a magnificent view of New York's busy harbor. It is a view that promotes an optimistic regard for all aspects of campus life.

Neiman - Marcus Company, Dallas, Tex., in its report for the six months ended on July 31, showed a net loss of $15,995 on sales of $16,672,520. In the corresponding period last year the specialty store with two branches in Texas cleared $144,121 or 17 cents a share on sales of $16,917,156.

THE fall season of antiques shows, getting an early start, opens today in Connecticut in the New Haven Arena. The New England penchant for early American will be reflected in the majority of the seventy-nine dealer displays.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 -- The wholesale average primary market prices for the week ended Sept. 20 held steady at 119.4 per cent of the 1947-49 base, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today. In "First Ladies -- in Fashton, Too!" (Sept. 11), Martha Weinman wrote that Mrs. John F. Kennedy recently injected the delicate issue of women's fashions into the Presidential campaign by wearing a gay yachting outfit and bouffant hairdo, thus raising the question: is it politic to be chic! No mutter how they dress, however, Miss Weinman concluded, the Indies will never manage to please everybody.

Some 500 financial specialists from all over the world are expected to converge at Washington; D.C., this week for the annual meeting of the international financial institutions that were set up at Bretton Woods, N.H., in 1945.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Permit me to congratulate The New York Times on its editorial comment of Sept. 16 "The U.N. in Danger." The comparison between Hitler and Khrushchev is certainly appropriate. Of very great importance is the warning to the new states in Africa on the nature of Soviet colonialism.
DALLAS, Sept. 24 (AP) -- Bobby Layne set a career record for passing and led the Pittsburgh Steelers to a 35-28 victory over the Dallas Cowboys in a National Football League game tonight.

OGDENSBURG, N.Y. -- Visitors to the St. Lawrence Valley this fall will find something new to look at and make use of. It is the $20,000,000 suspension bridge linking this Northern New York city with the hamlet of Johnstown, Ont.

CHICAGO, Sept. 24 (AP) -- Senator John F. Kennedy took a one-day rest today from his airborne Presidential campaign, which seemed to have picked up momentum as it rolled over the Great Plains and Rocky Mountains.

BALTIMORE -- A sprightly new red brick inn will open here next Wednesday opposite the dingy red brick Victorian hulk of Johns Hopkins Hospital. It is the 150-room Sheraton-Baltimore Inn and it is situated not in a fine residential area, not in the downtown business section or among the retail specialty shops, not in the trimlawned suburbs, but, rather, in the heart of a dilapidated neighborhood in East Baltimore.

THE enigma of television persists. In the closeups of the mounting drama at the United Nations General Assembly and the joint appearances of Vice President Nixon and Senator John F. Kennedy, the medium's importance in the conduct of public affairs is Being demonstrated as never before.

SHANGHAI, Sept. 24 (Reuters) -- A bearded old lantern-maker, a clay-modeler who used to be a rickshaw boy, young girls making delicate artificial flowers or cawing intricate designs on ivory or stone -- these are examples of a new development in Communist China's varied folk arts.

Spokesmen for Human Events, a weekly Washington news-letter, have denounced a suggestion made on the Senate floor that the publication was contributing to the anti-Catholic campaign against Senator John F. Kennedy, the Democratic Presidential candidate.

SALISBURY, Southern Rhodesia, Sept. 20. -- African brides-to-be in Southern Rhodesia are rebelling against Lobola -- the traditional marriage price that has been paid in cattle to parents for centuries.

THE author of this shrewd and tart but well-poised volume is a Canadian novelist with an established reputation here as well as in his native country. Like so many other contemporary writers, Hugh MacLennan is also a university teacher, either from desire or necessity, and what he offers in "Scotchman's Return" is a collection of "familiar essays" -- which is, unfortunately, at the present moment, probably the least respected of all literary genres.

BETHLEHEM, Pa., Sept. 24 (UPI) -- Lehigh University turned two pass interceptions into touchdowns today and went on to a 27-14 victory over Delaware, the 1959 Lambert Cup and Middle Atlantic Conference champion.

The Oct. 20 performance of "Becket" at the St. James Theatre will be a benefit for the Federation of Protestant Welfare Agencies, which Serves 500,000 persons in Greater New York annually. The play will open at the St. James Theatre ion Oct. 5.

Department stove sales in this area rebounded strongly last week from the effects of Hurricane Donna. In the preceding week the storm had cut sales by about 10 per cent. Leading retailers put this week's gain more than 5 per cent above the 1959 level.
CHICAGO, Sept. 24 (UPI) -- The Atlantic and Pacific Coasts will be running four hours apart tomorrow when the Far West and scattered Midwest areas revert to Standard Time.

Two students in Colombia had the urge to adventure last spring and headed their car northward from Bogota on the Pan American Highway. Their journey ended only recently in New York, and proved to them that it takes more than ambition to cover the 12,500 miles.

TO THE EDITOR: SPEAKING at a writer's conference recently, I was asked if I felt that publication of such books as "Lady Chatterley's Lover" and "Peyton Place" indicated a trend toward smut in contemporary fiction.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 -- One of the world's most prominent economists, Per Jacobsson of the International Monetary Fund, presented encouraging views today on this country's problems with its balance of international payments.

ALTHOUGH the calendar says it is fall, many of summer's annuals and perennials continue to flower vigorously, if less prolifically. September is an ideal time for making small-scale flower arrangements, which require little floral material.

THE week's most piquant combination of exhibltions is at World House Galleries, where the moody Belgian recluse, James Ensor -- no wife, no friends, no pupils -- is installed on the tippet floor, while the lower is given over to a lively party of seven vigorous American women, ranging from Georgia O'Keeffe, a proud and historic 72, to Joan Brown, a bouncing and experimental 22.

SAN ANTONIO, Sept. 25 (AP) -- Louise Suggs of Atlanta became golf's leading money winner among women for 1960 today as she fired a par 71 to win the San Antonio civitan open with a fifty-four-hole total of 215.

E.W. (Skip) Etchells of the Rocky Point Yacht Club, scoring 3 points, won the Past Commodore Nutmeg Trophy yesterday at the City Island Yacht Club. Etchells completed a sweep of the two-day, three-race event by taking the final race yesterday.

LONDON, Sept. 25 -- Hugh Gaitskell, leader of the Labor party, said today that if the party rejected the official policy on nuclear weapons it would be going "unilateralist and pacifist" for the first time in history.

THOSE who want to give their decor a fresh look for fall might be interested in the contemporary fabrics and furniture at Dillhoff-Tecta International, Inc., a new concern at 26 East Fifty-fifth Street. Its merchandise is available through decorators.
Not everyone who would vote against a Presidential candidate only because he is a Roman Catholic can be accused of bigotry, a Protestant Episcopal priest said yesterday.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 25 -- U.N.'s cold war is a struggle between Moscow and Washington for allegiance of the vital center. If, by a mixture of badgering and blandishment, Khrushchev can swing a majority of uncommitted nations to his side, he may succeed in crippling the organization and bending it to his will.
Ten major new parks should be developed, for the New York metropolitan region, according to a two-year study made public yesterday.

It becomes clearer every day that Premier Khrushchev did not come to U.N. headquarters with the intent to make a reasonable settlement of any question whatsoever. He came here to intrigue, cajole and bully.
The nine major motion picture producing and distributing companies will set up machinery to help their employes contribute money to their political parties.
CINCINNATI, Sept. 25 (AP) -- Home runs by Joe Koppe and Tony Gonzalez highlighted a nine-hit attack by Philadelphia's last-place Phils today in a 7-1 victory over the Cincinnati Reds.

Premier Khrushchev's proposal that the United Nations be headed by a directorate of three secretaries, each having a veto power, would seem likely to complicate substantially the functioning of the world organization, if not to paralyze it altogether.

HOUSTON, Sept. 25 (UPI) -- Tom Flores, a quarterback, passed to Gene Prebola for a 14-yard touchdown with 4 minutes 58 seconds remaining and Larry Barnes kicked the extra point to give the Oakland Raiders a 14-13 upset victory over the Houston Oilers in an American Football League game today.
PARIS, Sept. 25 -- The North Atlantic nations -- the United States and Western Europe -- are moving with increasing speed in the direction of a single vast economy.
The visit of Premier Khrushchev to this country has helped to make foreign policy the leading concern of American voters, according to a nation-wide survey by The New York Times.
CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Sept. 25 -- The United States failed for the fifth time today to send a space probe into an orbit about the moon.

Leaders of the International Union of Electrical Workers said last night that a vote by members had overwhelmingly rejected a contract offer by the General Electric Company and had authorized a strike next Sunday.

THE television networks are faced with problems. They gave equal time to President Eisenhower and Soviet Premier Khrushchev but their exercise of discretion ran into second-guessing. They thought of the idea of a series of hospitality nights for Vice President Nixon and Senator John F. Kennedy but Time magazine is upset over the invitation list.

A novel and thought-stimulating plan to transfer the responsibility for financing and constructing new schools to the state was proposed at the recent meeting of the State Council of City and Village School Superintendents. It came from Dr. Charles A. Brind, counsel to the State Education Department and to the State Dormitory, which has been performing such a function for colleges.

Edmund R. Schroeder, Bronx governor for the State Association of Young Republican Clubs, said yesterday he had urged Governor Rockefeller to reject George Salvatore for an interim appointment to the City Court bench in the Bronx.

CHICAGO, Sept. 25 (UPI) -- The St. Louis Cardinals were eliminated from the National League pennant race today when Glen Hobble of the Chicago Cubs beat them, 5-0. Hobbie allowed six hits, all singles, in gaining his fifteenth victory.

FRONT-PAGE news was made recently in suburban newspapers when the city of Norwalk, Conn., experienced daily, major traffic jams created by high school students' cars. The reverberations that followed a dispute between school authorities and the police department was felt, not only by the students, but by teachers, parents and townspeople.
A New York City official sought last week to stop maritime industry criticism of Congress for its investigation of the Port of New York Authority, it was disclosed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 (UPI) -- Vice President Nixon left tonight on a 4,700-mile, six-day campaign tour that will take him into the South as well as the home territory of his Presidential rival, Senator John F. Kennedy.
Scientists from ten European nations and Australia are due to meet in London a week from today to put the finishing touches on plans for an international agency to explore space.

Over-the-counter stocks broke sharply early last week along with the bulk of listed securities traded on the New York and American Stock Exchanges. There was a big difference, however, in the over-the-counter and listed markets later in the week.
Direct obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public that will mature within twelve months amount to 578,945,603,971. They consist of Treasury securities as follows:

GENEVA, Sept. 25 -- The Swiss stock market bounced back strongly last Wednesday after continuing for two days the broad retreat that had marked the preceding week. The upturn continued on Thursday, but a weaker note set in on the week's final day of trading.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 25 -- Senator John F. Kennedy received one of the most tumultuous ovations of his campaign today as he motored through twelve miles of Cleveland streets to a Democratic rally on the Lake Erie waterfront.

Japanese at Hiroshima who were exposed to radiation during the explosion of the atomic bomb in 1945 are more prone to cancer of the lung, stomach, breast, ovary or uterine cervix than those not exposed.

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Sept. 25 -- Patrice Lumumba left his residence for the first time in more than a week today and then proclaimed his "imminent victory over President Joseph Kasavubu" in his fight to remain Premier.

Premier Fidel Castro of Cuba was invited yesterday to align himself with President Gamal Abdel Nasser of the United Arab Republic and others who want to construct a diplomatic alliance to stand between East and West.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 25 (AP) -- Bobby Locke of the Cleveland Indians blanked the Chicago White Sox, 4-0, with a a four-hitter today, officially eliminating the 1959 American League champions from this year's pennant-battle.
Cargo movements to and from Matadi, the major port of the Congo, are greater now than at any time in the last few years, according to officials of Farrell Lines.
Secretary of State Christian A. Herter warned the new African states and Cyprus yesterday to beware of Premier Khrushchev's plan for altering the United Nations structure.
The police were unable to accept an invitation to serve a summons at a Greenwich Village coffee house yesterday. They were too busy guarding foreign dignitaries here.
A Canadian metallurgist has been elected president for 1961 of the American Institute of Mining, Metallurgical and Petroleum Engineers, it was announced yesterday.
Another effort is being made in Germany to read the last rites over the Reichsbank, an institution that has been defunct since 1948 but continues to linger on, thanks largely to official oxygen.

Per Jacobsson, Managing Director of the International Monetary Fund, is listened to with respect in the international financial world. His report that the United States is making good progress toward ending recent heavy adverse payments balances -- and thus halting the drain of gold from our reserves -- will undoubtedly influence opinion.

SANDS POINT, L.I., Sept. 25 -- Arab security guards protecting President Gamal Abdel Nasser of the United Arab Republic include two bomb experts who virtually take apart his black limousine for inspection each time the car is used.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- The United States, to encourage international cooperation in space research, has invited foreign scientists to participate in research with the next Tiros meteorological satellite.
HOT SPRINGS, Ark., Sept. 25 -- A commission of Southern leaders was established today to define the goals of higher education in the region for the next ten to fifteen years.
THE following dinner menu is given as a guide to the use of foods that are reasonable in cost. A recipe is offered for an easy-to-prepare main dish.
"I ALWAYS enjoy taking on impossible things," commented a dynamic Englishman. His vivid blue eyes sparkled at the very thought of the "impossible" things he already has achieved.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 25 (UPI) -- The Baltimore Colts, held scoreless until two minutes before half-time, opened their bid for a third consecutive National Football League title today by beating the Washington Redskins, 20-0.
Jose Ferrer could not resist the lure.

Experiments With the Language Everybody beyond the period of infancy is in the word business, but some are more in it than others. Those who are perhaps farthest in are the ones who find themselves from time to time trying to experiment with the language.

BRIARCLIFF MANOR, N.Y., Sept. 25 -- The three younger Turnesa brothers, Willie, Jim and Doug, defeated the three elder members of the famous golfing family, Phil, Joe and Mike, 2 up, in their annual best-ball benefit match at Briar Hall Country Club today.

Three cardinals, seven archbishops, sixty bishops, thirty-six monsignori and forty-one priests participated in a solemn pontifical mass yesterday at St. Patrick's Cathedral honoring the golden jubilee of the National Conference of Catholic Charities.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 25 -- Forecasts of a swelling neutralist coalition in the United Nations have prompted a closer examination here of the meaning of the neutralist attacks upon the existing blocs of East and West.
BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 25 -- Scores of items dating from Biblical times, including a fragment of the Dead Sea Scrolls, went on exhibition in Buenos Aires yesterday.
GLEN COVE, L.I., Sept. 25 -- Premier Khrushchev indicated today that his plan for a three-man United Nations directorate would give each of the three the power to veto decisions.

Following are excerpts, compiled by The New York Times, The Associated Press and United Press International, from editorials published over the week-end on Premier Khrushchev's speech Friday to the General Assembly of the United Nations:

There has never been a time in our history when the United States was so preoccupied, so worried, even so alarmed about Latin America. We have reason for anxiety, and much thought is being given in Washington about what can be done to improve our relations.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- The International Monetary Fund reported today that it was "well on the way" to completion of its second full cycle of assistance to member nations.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Sept. 25 -- President Sukarno confiscated six printing plants this week-end, halting publication of the majority of Indonesia's most important Opposition and anti-Communist newspapers.
CHICAGO, Sept. 24 (AP) -- Grain futures were under fairly steady selling pressure this week although they mustered a few short-lived rallies from time to time.

THE week-end of the Royal Ballet at the Metropolitan Opera House was taken up with repetitions of the two new Frederick Ashton ballets, "Ondine," at both performances yesterday with the original cast, and "La Fille Mal Gardee" at both performances Saturday.
"THE Campaign and the Candidates," a new series of interviews with Presidential and Vice-Presidential aspirants and their wives began Saturday night at 9:30 over Channel 4.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 (AP) -- American companies added $2,500,000,000 last year to their investments in foreign subsidiaries and branches but the flow of investment capital has slackened somewhat this year.

Seldom have Queens voters been wooed with the political ardor they are encountering this year. The reason is simple. In a national election in which New York's forty-five electoral votes could be controlling, Queens County, notoriously independent at the polls, could determine the outcome in the state.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 (UPI) -- Former Gov. W. Averell Harriman of New York charged today that the Eisenhower Administration was treating the new African republics with "shocking neglect."

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 25 -- Ralph Nelson, perhaps the only man here who writes, acts, directs and produces, has become the key figure in what may be one of the most exciting experiments in show business.
The cabaret theatre, a popular form of entertainment abroad that permits spectators to eat and drink while the show goes on, has found a champion in H.B. Lutz.

WHOEVER would have thought that a tree could replace a piece of furniture? But it has, according to artificial tree designer Helene Levy, who says that nature lovers and non-nature lovers alike are beginning to simulate the woods in all corners of the house -- and not just in the dreary corners.
Ruth Rowland Nichols, a society girl who became a world-famous flier, was found dead yesterday in her apartment at 400 East Forty-ninth Street.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 25 -- President Kwame Nkrumah of Ghana called on the African states today to draft a "Monroe Doctrine" for their continent.
New York University announced plans yesterday to construct a building with about 175 middle - income cooperative apartments on land it is about to buy from the Washington Square Village Corporation.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- Vice President Nixon released today a 4,000-word report on his proposals for meeting "the current challenge to American education" with Federal aid.
The Pittsburgh success story of 1960 must be interpreted as a solid team victory. No one man can take the bows.

MILWAUKEE, Sept. 25 (UPI) -- The Pittsburgh Pirates lost to the Milwaukee Braves, 4-2, today, but captured their first National League pennant in thirty-three years when the Chicago Cubs eliminated the St. Louis Cardinals in Chicago.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 (AP) -- A three-run homer by Brooks Robinson in the eighth inning gave a 3-1 victory today to the Baltimore Orioles over the Washington Senators.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: It is regrettable that the 1960 New York State Legislature passed a bill prohibiting state and local health authorities from requiring milk dating. The efforts of the City Council and Mayor Wagner to restore the dating on milk and cream sold here should be commended.
Senator John F. Kennedy was pictured yesterday as being in "strong and powerful agreement" with Adlai E. Stevenson and Chester Bowles oh United States foreign policy in critical years ahead.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 26 -- Prime Minister Macmillan and President Gamal Abdel Nasser of the United Arab Republic met today for the first time since the Suezcrisis four years ago. They shook hands warmly and exchanged courtesies.
Lillian Gish, who gained a notable niche in the American theatre for her romantic and serious parts, will make one of her rare appearances in comedy this season.

LONDON, Sept. 26 (UPI) -- The Electrical and Musical Industries group is set to take over another family business hard on the heels of its recent acquisition of Morphy Richards, domestic appliance concern.
Theresa Greene, soprano, sang at Town Hall last night a program made to order for art-song connoisseurs.
THERE is probably not a child in town who won't be enchanted by "Christopher's Wonders."

LONDON, Sept. 26 -- The Liberal party revealed today that it was planning a "massive takeover bid" for a substantial block of Labor party voters to build up a "non-Socialist, radical" opposition to the Conservative Government.

The New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad was upheld in court yesterday in its long-standing contention that it, as well as the New York Central Railroad, has rights in the operation and income of the Biltmore Hotel.

The McCrory Corporation plans to diversify its variety store operations by merging with National Shirt Shops of Delaware, Inc. Directors of both concerns approved the move in principle yesterday. National would be operated under its present name as a division of McCrory, with added resources of McCrory.
THE following dinner menu is given as a guide to the use of foods that are reasonable in cost. A recipe is offered for an easy-to-prepare main dish.

GARFIELD, N.J., Sept. 26 -- A $4,000,000 plant for the conversion of used newspapers into newsprint is expected to be in full operation by January, 1962, Mayor Joseph Kobylarz announced today. The plant in now under construction.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Sept. 26 (AP) -- Newspaper accounts of the religious issue in the Presidential campaign have fanned "the flames of bigotry," the State Senate majority leader, Walter J. Mahoney, said tonight.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 26 -- The mystery of what makes a "children's" picture successful was explored today by two men whose film, "Dog of Flanders," finished first in the children's category of the Venice Festival over fifty films from fourteen nations.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 26 (AP) -- The San Francisco Giants, revived by three straight pinch hits and a basesfilled triple by Don Blasingame, scored six runs in the eighth inning tonight and defeated the Los Angeles Dodgers, 6 -- 2.

Jose Gonzalez, a promising welterweight from Puerto Rico, violated one of the cardinal rules of boxing last night by leading with his right hand. The transgression paid off in the form of a spectacular third-round knockout victory for the 20-year-old youngster over Candy McFarland of Philadelphia in the scheduled ten-round feature bout at St. Nicholas Arena.

Mayor Wagner renewed his charge yesterday that Vice President Nixon was "part and parcel" or a "reactionary and unholy alliance" between "a group of men elected as Democrats from some of our Southern states" and Republican legislators.

WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 26 -- The Rainbow Stable's Adie Rainbow, driven by Stanley Dancer, scored a three-quarter-length victory in the Nassau Pace before 18,011 fans at Roosevelt Raceway tonight. B'Haven was second and Glenville third.

JACKSON, Miss., Sept. 26 -- The Mississippi Supreme Court ruled today that a chancery judge exceeded his authority in ordering a Roman Catholic to send his children to public school and to allow them to attend a Protestant church.

The International Development Association -- fated inevitably perhaps to be better known as IDA -- was formally established yesterday in Washington. It becomes the fourth member of a set of useful international financial institutions comprising also the World Bank, the International Monetary Fund and the International Finance Corporation.

THOSE with more than casual concern about the nutritive value of the foods they eat will be interested in a newly published bulletin from the United States Department of Agriculture. "Nutritive Values of Foods" is a thirty-page booklet packed with much information not readily available elsewhere.

YONKERS, Sept. 26 -- A Lutheran theologian warned today that Christianity might suffer irreparable harm if the present political struggle "degenerates into a squabble about school buses and ambassadors to the Vatican."
More than 2,000 policemen waiting to be promoted to sergeant and higher ranks pressed their fight yesterday to have Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy cited for contempt of court.

Senator John F. Kennedy and Vice President Nixon appear to be operating on the theory that New York State's highly prized forty-five electoral votes can be won or lost during the registration of voters.
Propaganda replaced violence, but not the threat of it, yesterday on the sidewalks near the Harlem headquarters of Premier Fidel Castro of Cuba.

Federal Street Fund, Inc., a new mutual fund, announced yesterday filing of a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission covering a proposed offering of a minimum of $20,000,000 market value in shares of its stock.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Most of those who have for years considered the United Nations a valuable instrument for peace and freedom will, I believe, agree that this is no time to push panic buttons.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y. Sept. 26 -- Prime Minister John Diefenbaker of Canada accused the Soviet Union today of rebuffing conciliatory overtures from the United States by launching a major "cold war" offensive.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (AP) -- Federal Judge F. Dickinson Letts swore in Terence F. McShane as chairman of the board of monitors over the Teamsters Union today.

"I DON'T know why there's always so much confusion everywhere I go," the hero of Evan S. Connell Jr's new novel, "The Patriot,"* says toward the end of the book. "I'm really getting sick and tired of everything. I'm just about to do a flip, and I don't mean maybe!"

The first chancellor of the city's college system, Dr. John Rutherford Everett, said yesterday one of his major concerns would be to preserve the personality of each of the institutions in the system.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 26 -- Premier Fidel Castro brought a vigorous indictment of United States "aggression" against Cuba to the United Nations today and warned other underdeveloped nations against a similar fate.
The world will be watching the Soviet Union today for the possible disclosure of a spectacular space flight or a comparable achievement in another field.

LONDON, Sept. 26 -- Three first-class cabins aboard the Queen Elizabeth were badly damaged by fire and some of the liner's main cables were affected, officials revealed when the vessel docked at Southampton today.
UNITED NATIONS, Sept. 26 -- President Kwame Nkrumah of Ghana, in a series of meeting's with world leaders, pressed today for the formation of a neutral bloc of African states.

President Eisenhower said last night that America's military, moral, economic and politcal strength was being steadfastly maintained to meet dangers resulting from "a powerful, secretive dictatorship."

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Sept. 26 -- Negroes were thwarted again today in an attempted sitdown at a predominantly white school from which they had been excluded because they did not live in the district.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Events are taking place on Taiwan that should be profoundly disturbing to the American people. Recently the editor of an Independent fortnightly, Free China, was arrested by Chiang Kai-shek's military, and is now being court-martialed.

ENGLEWOOD CLIFFS, N.J., Sept, 26 -- The league bowlers at the Prentice-Hall Company here apparently are among the luckier ones in this area. According to the league president, they have shopped around for the most reasonable rates for bowling and have come up with a bargain that is sometimes available to others.
Some 30,000 longshoremen here will get a raise of 5 cents an hour starting Saturday under their contract with the New York Shipping Association.
Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange were steady yesterday and advanced 1 to 11 points. A point equals 5 cents a bale.

LAST night's discussion between Vice President Nixon and Senator John F. Kennedy was a dignified and constructive innovation in television campaigning. Undoubtedly it helped to quicken public interest in the Presidential contest.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (UPI) -- A national retail clothing association charged the Federal Trade Commission today with "fighting the battle of the discounters against the interests of small, independent retailers."
The autumn appeal of the Greater New York Fund was opened yesterday with a luncheon at the Commodore Hotel attended by more than 1,300 volunteer workers.

United States Government securities were firm to a shade down yesterday as a good demand for ninety-one-day bills helped the entire list. The rest of the market for fixed interest obligations was quiet as buyers awaited the pricing of municipal and corporate issues to be brought to market in the next two days.
SCARBOROUGH-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., Sept. 26 -- The tenth annual scholarship benefit house tour of the Mount Holyoke Club of Westchester will be held Oct. 11 from 1 to 5 P.M.

Nine Democratic legislators yesterday urged the State Insurance Department to postpone an increase in premium charges for auto liability insurance secured through the Assigned Risk Plan. The new premiums are to go into effect Oct. 1.
Governor Rackefeller told President Eisenhower yesterday that his speech to the United Nations last week had evoked a tremendously enthusiastic response throughout the country.
The trial of two Brooklyn lawyers charged with the secret ownership of five dilapidated Manhattan tenements proceeded in Special Sessions yesterday, despite renewed attempts to delay it.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 -- New pressure was applied to West Germany and other foreign industrial powers today to extend more aid to under-developed countries.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 26 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold served notice on Premier Khrushchev today that he would continue to maintain the "independence, impartiality, objectivity" of his Congo policy until the General Assembly instructed him to do otherwise.

Justice Irving H. Saypol in Supreme Court, New York County dismissed yesterday one of several suits brought by the Franklin National Bank of Long Island in its challenge to the legality of the state's new Omnibus Banking Law.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 26 -- Clarence K. Crossan, a Philadelphia Councilman from 1923 to 1951, died yesterday at the age of 84.

VIENNA, Sept. 26 -- Vyacneslav M. Molotov returned to his old debating form today in a forty-five-minute speech criticizing a United States-supported project being considered at the fourth annual conference of the International Atomic Energy Agency.

HEWLETT HARBOR, L.I., Sept. 26 -- Frank Logan and Steve Legakis of Great River carded a 33, 31 -- 64 and won the Long Island Professional Golf Association's amateur-pro tournament at the Seawane Harbor Club today.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 26 -- Premier Fidel Castro's address to the United Nations General Assembly seemed tonight not to have impressed the new African members of the world body.

The New York Board of Rabbis accepted yesterday Mayor Wagner's "apology in the name of the city administration" for remarks Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy had made about Jewish policemen's religious sincerity.
The speediest woman in the world ambled through New York yesterday, using up the seconds she had saved in the Olympics.

The United States yesterday named three youngsters -- Earl Buchholz, Chuck McKinley and Dennis Ralston -- to team with Bernard Bartzen and Barry MacKay in the campaign to recover the Davis Cup from Australia.

LONDON, Sept. 26 (UPI) -- Western Europe's cotton textile industries, reported that the second quarter of 1960 was a busy one and that at mills in some countries full employment was assured well into 1961.

SHOPPERS who think that they need a fat checkbook to become Rosette Pennington customers should think again. Recently this shop, at 20 East Fifty-sixth Street, added a new department devoted to the young and not so young who wear sizes 5 to 13 and 6 to 14 with prices for the most part as small as the sizes.
TRENTON, Sept. 26 -- The Pennsylvania Railroad has become the sixth major carrier in New Jersey to accept a state subsidy for the maintenance of its commuter services.

ABOARD THE U.S.S. NORTHAMPTON, off the coast of France, Sept. 26 (UPI) -- Vice Admiral Harold T. Deutermann of the United States led a forty-vessel task force through the foggy Atlantic Ocean today as part of the world's first simulated attack by carrierborne nuclear bombers.
Manhattan suffered through one of its most exasperating days of traffic jams yesterday.
Stocks declined sharply yesterday and reached new lows since September, 1958, in active trading on the New York Stock Exchange. Despite a late recovery, prices closed near the lows of the day.

World sugar futures were strong yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange. Higher prices followed the announcement over the week-end that Dominican Republic sugar would be permitted to enter the United States under the sugar quota system.

Robert Herridge will produce two shows for "The C.B.S.-TV Workshop" this season. Although Albert McCleery will continue as regular producer of the Columbia Broadcasting System series, guest producers will be engaged from time to time.

WITH a regularity that would do credit to a Capistrano swallow, autumn brings new cooking classes. Ann Roe Robbing who started her program in cuisine last year, has moved to larger quarters, and classes begin Oct. 3.
A 56-year-old Queens contractor was described in court yesterday as the heir-apparent to the title of city scofflaw king.

HICKSVILLE, L.I., Sept. 26 -- The Cantiague Rock, a one-and-a-half-ton boundary marker between the towns of Oyster Bay and North Hempstead, was lowered by a crane today into a new base at its site at Cantiague Rock Road and Prospect Avenue.
Life began anew for Carnegie Hall yesterday afternoon.
SAMNEUA, Laos, Sept. 26 -- The Communist-led Pathet Lao rebels reopened their attack today on the outnumbered Laotian garrison defending this northern bastion.

Premier Khrushchev has been referring to U.N. Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold as a representative of the "parties to the military blocs of the Western powers," But, as Mr. Hammarskjold's brief opening address to the morning session of the General Assembly yesterday indicated, the offense, from the Kremlin point of view, is worse than that.

The Ballets Africans of the Republic of Guinea, which played a successful engagement here last year, returned last night for a second season, this time at the Alvin Theatre, again under the auspices of Luben Vichey.
LONDON, Sept. 26 -- A little extra selling in a hesitant market caused widespread losses in industrial share prices on the stock exchange here today.
LIVERPOOL, England, Sept. 26 (Reuters) -- British seamen began signing on for duty today after a nine-week wildcat strike that seriously disrupted British shipping.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 26 -- President Eisenhower warned today against "glittering political promises of pie in the sky" at the expense of the national economy and United States leadership of the free world.

OTTAWA, Sept. 26 (Canadian Press) -- Canada's national production slumped 1 1/2 per cent in the second quarter of this year from the January-March level, the Bureau of Statistics reported today. It was the first drop in three years.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 -- The chairman of the Senate's special committee investigating unemployment problems accused Labor Secretary James P. Mitchell today of having distorted the picture for political reasons.

Clear similarities between high and low pressure areas on ordinary weather maps and areas in which the earth's surface radiates much or little heat have been revealed by experiments with the Explorer VII satellite.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Sept. 26 -- President Sukarno's forth-coming appearance at the United Nations was seen here today as a move to dramatize Indonesia's mode of peaceful co-existence and to offer the President's formula for achieving it.
Premier Khrushchev said yesterday that if the world powers agreed to disarm and disband their armies, he would be ready to accept "any measure of control anyone proposes."
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 23 -- Prime Minister Macmillan began to rally British Commonwealth support for Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold today.

ORIGINALITY does not come easily to American designers, who often must bow to the strong commercial winds on Seventh Avenue. Struggling young designers might find a ray of hope emanating from an old brownstone on East Fifty-fifth Street, where a young woman who calls herself FonTayne has kept a custom dress business in good health for several years.
CHICAGO, Sept. 26 -- Vice President Nixon and Senator John F. Kennedy avoided victory claims tonight in their debate. They pointed to the electorate as the final referee.
The International Union of Electrical Workers proposed arbitration or fact-finding yesterday to avoid a nation-wide strike against the General Electric Company next Sunday.
CHICAGO, Sept. 26 -- Vice President Nixon and Senator John F. Kennedy argued genteelly tonight in history's first nationally televised debate between Presidential candidates.

NICE, Sept. 26 -- When the nine-day, 4,600-mile Auto Tour de France sped out of this city Sept. 15, it was clear that victory and the major share of $50,000 in prize money would go to Olivier Gendebien or Willy Mairesse.
MELBOURNE, Sept. 26 -- National Biscuit Company of America has bought the Australian Purina Cereal group for more than u2,500,000 (Australian) in cash ($5,600,000).

LONDON, Sept. 26 -- With Britain's colonial empire dwindling and the Commonwealth expending a Parliamentary committee recommended today that the Colonial and Commonwealth Relations, offices be merged.

Rolling directors may not gather moss but apparently they can gather some basic knowledge about a company. Ralph F. Peo, chairman of Houdaille Industries, Inc., a large producer of construction materials, auto parts and industrial tools, believes in periodic tours of company facilities by his directors.

THE National Association for Mental Health has assembled a group of pamphlets or various aspects of child development and behavior. Pamphlets are available, prepaid, from the association, 10 Columbus Circle. Prices include mailing costs.

The thirteen-story office building at 140 West Fortysecond Street has been sold by 140 West 42nd Street Realties to the E.K. Realty Company for cash over mortgages of $376,500. Tha sale was negotiated by Judah Wattenberg and Leonard, Levites, Schiller, brokers.
JOHN V. LINDSAY, United States Congressman for Broadway and other less flamboyant baillwicks, does not believe that Federal support for the arts would be gross or corrupting.

A mixed hard-and-soft-sell campaign has been decided upon by The Rockmore Company to meet the unusual requirements of its client, Johnston Murphy Shoes.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 26 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru of India, President Tito of Yugoslavia and President Gamal Abdel Nasser of the United Arab Republic met today for a round of consultations at the United Nations and at the United Arab Republic's Headquarters at 900 Park Avenue.

CHICAGO, Sept. 26 (UPI) -- Frank Baumann, a southpaw, pitched the Chicago White Sox into a second-place tie with Baltimore in the American League standing tonight by defeating the Detroit Tigers, 6 -- 3.
Lieut. Jose Paz Novas, who described himself as chief of Cuba's military espionage apparatus in the United States, announced yesterday that he had defected.

American Investors Life The American Investors Life Insurance Company, Houston, Tex., has purchased all of the outstanding insurance business of Colorado Credit Life, Inc., Boulder, Colo. The transaction gives American Investors a total of $270,000,000 of life insurance in force.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 26 -- For the time being the lines are holding well here against the Communist attack on the United Nations.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 -- Casey Stengel made it clear tonight that there would be no relaxing moments for his New York Yankees.

BONN, Germany, Sept. 26 -- An eleven-month judicial investigation has produced "no evidence' that Dr. Theodor Oberlaender, the most publicized former Nazi to hold high office in West Germany, took part in a 1941 massacre of Polish Jews.

GENEVA, Sept. 26 -- The negotiations between the United States, Britain and the Soviet Union for a treaty to ban nuclear weapons tests will reopen here tomorrow under the cloud of the East-West clash at the United Nations.
Steel production is scheduled to taper off this week, the American Iron and Steel Institute said yesterday.

BERLIN, Sept. 26 -- Walter Ulbricht, East Germany's Communist leader, warned today that the "most harmful results" would follow if the Western Big Three maintained their restrictions on the travel of East Germans to the West.

SALISBURY, Southern Rhodesia, Sept. 26 -- Officials of the governing United Federal party, leaders in the Federation of Rhodesia and Nyasaland, considered plans today to resist recommendations of the Monckton Commission.

PASADENA, Calif., Sept. 26 -- Dr. Linus Pauling released today the text of a letter to the Senate subcommittee on internal security objecting to the official record of his recent testimony before the body.

Over the River and Into Ontario Not long ago there was jubilation along the St. Lawrence when a dream of several centuries came true and seagoing vessels from around the world could, proceed halfway into continental North America.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 26 -- The chief of the United Nations' Congo operation has urged a reconciliation of the clashing political forces in the new African state "before it is too late."

YESTERDAY Sept. 26, 1960 GENERAL ASSEMBLY Continued general debate: In morning session heard President Antonin Novotny of Czechoslovakia, Diogenes Taboada, Minister for External Affairs of Argentina; Prime Minister John Diefenbaker of Canada; in afternoon session heard Mehmet Shehu, Chairman of the Council of Ministers of Albania, and Premier Fidel Castro of Cuba.
OYSTER BAY, L.I., Sept. 26 -- Sabre, owned and captained by Ernest B. Fay of Houston, won the United States 5.5-meter yacht sailing championship today by one point.

A nation-wide audience listened last night to the debate between Vice President Nixon and Senator John F. Kennedy on political philosophies. Most of the audience apparently made one of two basic decisions: their vote preferences remained unchanged, or they were still very much undecided.
"THE PLAY OF THE WEEK" is off to a rousing start. Its first treat of the season on Channel 13 is the Phoenix Theatre's production of "Henry IV, Part 1." It's not to be missed.

The first court action to test the constitutionality of the state's controversial Condon-Wadlin Law, which prohibits public employes from striking, has been started by the Secondary School Teachers Association of New York.

Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru of India, who is being courted by both Soviet and Western leaders as potentially the deciding influence in the United Nations crisis, spent yesterday obtaining first-hand impressions from world leaders representing the full range of diplomatic positions in the dispute.
El Espectador, an Argentinebred racer owned by William C. (Cal) Partee, was the surprise star of the show on the opening day of Belmont Park's fall meeting yesterday.
BLUEFISH still seem to be most active along the Jersey coast, but Montauk Point boats are doing fine with them now, as well as with striped bass.

Studebaker-Packard will enter the luxury-compact field this year with an eight-cylinder Lark Cruiser. It also has come up with a more powerful six-cylinder engine for its regular Lark series.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 -- The Government's shortestterm borrowing costs tumbled again today, following last week's further easing in the short-term money market.

The Federal Bureau of Investigation will distribute 140,000 man-wanted filers across the nation today in the search for Francisco Molina, alias Pancho the Hook. He is a suspect in the fatal shooting of a 9-year-old girl during a brawl between supporters and foes of Premier Fidel Castro here last Wednesday.

K'tut Tantri, who says she is the great-granddaughter of a witch from the Isle of Man, became the adopted daughter of a Balinese rajah. She operated one of the "most glamorous" hotels in the Far East, entertaining celebrities from all over the world, and incurred the wrath of the Dutch settlers who objected to her liberal attitude toward the natives.
WHEN Dag Hammarskjold succeeded Trygve Lie as Secretary General of the United Nations in 1953, no one expected he would ever become as controversial a figure as his predecessor.

DURING spring training the New York Yankees set all sorts of records for maladroitness in losing twenty-one of thirty-two exhibition games. Far more alarming than the defeats was the team's shoddy play.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 -- The problem of how to manage our agricultural surplus long ago became so complicated and political that necessarily the latest remedies proposed by the Presidential candidates are complicated and political also.
