Free-standing twin headlights, set in space "scooped out" from the front fenders, is the major styling change in the 1961 Imperial. The placement of the chromed lamps apart from the fender and coachwork metal has not been seen on American production cars since the late Thirties.

Ethel Kennedy stumped the Bronx yesterday in support of Senator John P. Kennedy for President. From Alexander's Department Store to Hunter College voters shook hands willingly and accepted Kennedy buttons.
A computer system used by the Internal Revenue Service was described at the opening of a new school for advanced electronic data process programing.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 -- The Port of New York Authority ran into a possible snag here today in its efforts to transform a New Jersey swamp into an airport for jetliners.

Following is the text of the speech by President Eisenhower laset night at the Golden Jubilee dinner of the National Conference of Catholic Charities at the Statler-Hilton Hotel, as recorded by The New York Times:

The International Minerals and Chemical Corporation realized a 21 per cent increase in earnings on a sales gain of 10 per cent for the fiscal year ended on June 30, the annual report disclosed yesterday.
Harness racing will borrow a page from baseball's book when Yonkers Raceway holds an experimental Ladies Night on Oct. 5 in a twofold bid to attract distaff trade.
The battle for control of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad has been extended for the second time this month.
KANSAS CITY, Mo., Sept. 26 (UPI) -- Bud Daley pitched the Kansas City Athletics to a 6-1 victory over the Cleveland Indians tonight. The triumph was Daley's sixteenth of the season.

Two luxury apartment houses in Manhattan -- one nearing completion and the other in the planning stage -- will be offered for sale to investors through a syndicate being organized by the Glickman Corporation of Nevada.
LAGOS, Nigeria, Sept. 26 -- Princess Alexandra of Kent arrived smilingly in a tropical downpour today for Nigeria's independence celebrations. The British colony becomes Independent Saturday.
Mrs. Emily Post, for many years a leading authority on all matters of social good form, died Sunday in her apartment at 39 East Seventy-ninth Street after a brief illness. Her age was 86.

RYE, N.Y. Sept. 26 -- The Harrison Country Club team of Jerry Desio and Edward Kurland won the Westchester Professional Golfers Association pro-amateur tournament today with a best-ball card of 32, 33 -- 65.

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Sept. 26 -- Two members of the Congo's caretaker Government were severely beaten and then kidnapped this morning. The attackers were civilians reported to be followers of Patrice Lumumba.
CHICAGO, Sept. 26 (AP) -- Grain futures prices moved over a rather broad range today in both directions from preceding closes.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 26 -- Following are excerpts from a report to Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold by Rajeshwar Dayal of India, his special representative in the Congo:
Francis Gary Powers has written to The New York Times that he is sure it was not an explosion of his U-2 reconnaissance plane that brought it down over the Soviet Union May 2.

"We were pleased but not necessarily satisfied." That was Coach Buff Donelli's reaction yesterday to Columbia's 37-0 victory over Brown last Saturday in the most decisive football triumph scored by the Light Blue in more than a decade.
The Texas Gulf Sulphur Company said yesterday that it planned to invest $20,000000 to $30,000,000 in the construction of facilities in Utah to develop rich potash reserves.
The Pittsburgh Pirates will try to live down one of the oldest myths in world series history -- that they quit to the mighty Yankees in 1927.

VIENTIANE, Laos, Sept. 26 -- Premier Souvanna Phouma said today he was "disturbed" by reports that forces of the pro-Communist Pathet Lao movement had been on the move in the northernmost province of Phongsaly.

President Eisenhower scored a major personal and diplomatic triumph yesterday as he returned to New York to continue his campaign for full support of the United Nations and to address a Catholic Charities dinner.
An Oklahoma oil company is exploring the floor of the Atlantic Ocean more than three miles off New Jersey to determine if oil deposits exist.
A Brooklyn savings banker contrasted yesterday the approaches of Long Island's two largest commercial banks to the opening of Nassau County to competition from New York City institutions.

NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 27 (UPI) -- Negro witnesses told the Federal Civil Rights Commission today that law enforcement officers in north Louisiana had threatened them when they tried to get Negroes registered to vote.

RABAT, Morocco, Sept. 27 -- The United States Government has offered the new Republic of Mali in West Africa "assistance in all fields," it was announced here today after the return of Charles Woodruff Yost, the United States Ambassador to Morocco from a mission to Mali.
MORRISTOWN, N.J., Sept. 27 -- Conservationists are intensifying their efforts to make the Great Swamp area in Morris County a wildlife refuge.
PITTSBURGH, Sept. 27 (UPI) -- Dick Schofield singled in the sixteenth inning tonight to drive in Gino Cimoli with the run that gave the Pittsburgh Pirates a 4-3 victory over the Cincinnati Reds.

A million shouting, waving New Yorkers gave President Eisenhower a rousing sendoff yesterday as he left the city after an overnight visit and talks with nearly a dozen world statesmen. The President, pink-cheeked and beaming in his open car, acknowledged the cheers and applause by alternately waving his arms and jabbing the air with two fingers in the familiar victory sign.
Lower, shorter and narrower bulk, but the same wide track, indentifies the standard-sized 1961 Pontiacs.

With the casting of a 14-year-old Los Angeles schoolgirl in the title role of "Lolita," producer-director Stanley Kubrick has set a Nov. 28 starting date for his "faithful" film adaptation of Vladimir Nabokov's startling romance.
Senator Jacob K. Javits, a leading Republican proponent of medical care for the aged, sought to amplify yesterday on that part of the Nixon-Kennedy television debate dealing with the issue.

THE aura of sheer goodwill emanating from Carnegie Hall last night was a tangible force that must have made its presence felt from Fifty-seventh Street to the Hudson River and (one hopes) the United Nations Building.
Representative Chester Bowles said yesterday that a Democratic National Administration, taking office Jan. 20, would take nine steps to improve the foreign policy position of the United States.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 -- A prominent Jesuit theologian said in a speech here tonight that the Roman Catholic Church would not attempt to interfere in the political activities of a Catholic President nor would a Catholic President be bound by Catholic morality in deciding public issues.
IT has been rumored that Maxmilian furs are caviar fed, they always are so outstanding in quality.

Jack Brabham, the world champion race driver, has a busy schedule during the next seven or eight weeks. On Sunday he will race in the Australian Grand Prix. Then he will fly to Indianapolis for a two-day experimental whirl on the two-and-a-half-mile scene of the annual Memorial Day 500-mile race.
CHICAGO, Sept. 27 (AP) -- For the first time the payments of state taxes averaged more than $100 for every man, woman and child in the nation in the year ended June 30, a survey showed today.

A pertinent and hard-hitting reminder that racial prejudice exists in many ways and many places outside the South was provided last night by the American Broadcasting Company in the first of its news series of occasional documentaries entitled "Closeup."
UNITED NATIONS, Sept. 27 -- President Kwame Nkrumah of Ghana proposed to a meeting of forty-four Asians and Africans at the General Assembly today the formation of a neutralist group.

The development of electron tubes that print high-quality photographs from electronic signals sent over ordinary telephone or telegraph lines or radio channels was announced yesterday by the Raytheon Company.
The General Motors Corporation disclosed yesterday that it was conducting a survey of officers and employes to see whether they had any Interests in supplier companies.
Passengers who have been wondering what happened to the M-1 crosstown bus that used to traverse Chambers Street were told yesterday that it has moved -- five blocks to the south.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 27 -- The glum civilization envisioned by George Orwell in his novel, "1984," employed an official language known as Newspeak. This was "designed not to extend but to diminish the range of thought."

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: As to the article in The Times on Sept. 10 by Wayne Phillips, regarding Hoffman and Swinburne Islands, it is true that there is no apparent physical development of these islands at the present time.

In almost every segment of American life from fashion to journalism to scholarship, the award has multiplied with fantastic growth during the last decade. Like any Inflate currency, its value has become debased.

United Nations diplomats last night joined music lovers, both prominent and unknown, for the opening of the 119th season of the New York Philharmonic. The concert was a benefit for the orchestra's Pension Fund and the first non-subscription opening in its history.

ARDMORE, Pa., Sept. 27 -- The world amateur team championship begins tomorrow at the Merion Golf Club, and today golfers from the thirty-two competing nations took time out from their final practice rounds for a salute to the man who once made a sweep of the world's top individual crowns.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: If, as has been reported, our Government is accepting the candidacy of the United Arab Republic for a seat on the United Nations Security Council, it is, in my judgment, taking an intolerable position. It is hard to believe that this candidacy would be seriously advanced; it would be deeply distressing if our Government should go along with this move.
The market for corporate and municipal fixed-interest securities was stronger yesterday as new offerings priced a little lower than recent issues found a receptive market.
THE following dinner menu is given as a guide to the use of foods that are reasonable in cost. A recipe is offered for an easy-to-prepare main dish.

Detroit sold $21,200,000 in bonds at competitive bidding yesterday and Cleveland sold $7,000,000 worth. At the same time, Massachusetts announced the projected offering of $69,500,000 of new obligations and Los Angeles County, $10,000,000.
Broadcasters yesterday took curtain calls after Monday night's radio-television debate between Vice President Nixon and Senator John F. Kennedy.
WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 27 -- Lieut. Byrd, driven by Bob Walker, scored a half-length victory over Royal Affair tonight in the Long Island Pace before 18,154 fans at Roosevelt Raceway.
At 7 o'clock last night the New York Yankees announced they would accept mail orders for tickets to the world series games at the Stadium.
GENEVA, Sept. 27 -- The United States proposed today a twenty-seven-month moratorium on smaller underground nuclear test explosions.
VIENTIANE, Laos, Sept. 27 -- The tangle of military and political troubles that has beset Laos in the last seven weeks appeared today to be moving toward a settlement.

About three months have passed since the State Commission on Governmental Operations of the City of New York made any news on City Charter revision. From a newspaper point of view no news is hardly ever to be considered good news. But in this case quiet work behind the scenes, avoiding premature public controversy over revisions bound to be controversial, may be the best route to progress.

The rock-salt industry faced spreading Federal and local investigations yesterday. At the same time, bids by six companies to supply such salt to the Transit Authority were rejected as too high and, in many cases, identical.

RED SKELTON used the magic of his pantomime to open his new season with a superb show last night on Channel 2. He was playing in New York before a studio audience that included United Nations delegates from many countries.
CHARLESTON, W. Va., Sept. 27 -- Vice President Nixon packed the Civic Center beyond capacity tonight after a day of campaigning in the vain in Memphis, Tenn., and West Memphis, Ark.
BOSTON, Sept. 27 (UPI) -- The Baltimore Orioles walloped the Boston Red Sox, 17 -- 3, today behind four home runs and Jim Gentile's five runs batted in.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 -- Crown Prince Akihito of Japan and his commoner wife, Princess Michiko, arrived in Washington today for a three-day state visit.

A plot of 10,500 square feet of land on the southeast corner of York Avenue and Eighty-seventh Street has been assembled by Jack Resnick, builder. He will erect a twenty-one-story apartment house on the site.
Two West Coast ports were under fire from the Federal Maritime Board yesterday for granting "excessive" free storage to certain shippers.

Trading in the New York commodity futures markets was dull and featureless yesterday. Prices moved irregularly. Cottonseed oil, cocoa, coffee, eggs and lead rose; potatoes, sugar and zinc declined, and price movements for wool, rubber, hides and copper were mixed.
CANTON, Ohio, Sept. 27 -- The Kennedy campaign rolled across industrial Ohio today, accompanied by shrieks from thousands upon, thousands of supporters.

THE annual fall pageant of the trooping of the colors may be seen in full splendor just beyond the city limits. The countryside is a crazy quilt of bronze, golden and scarlet leaves. Parents and children can top off a drive through the country with several football games this Saturday afternoon.
Hunter College will open a new School of General Studies at its Bronx campus next spring, with an expected initial enrollment of 800, Dr. John J. Meng, president of the college, said yesterday.
The recommendations for parklands on Long Island were depicted yesterday by Robert Moses as "wild schemes."
CHICAGO, Sept. 27 (UPI) -- The Detroit Tigers defeated the Chicago White Sox , tonight, 2 -- 0, on a wild pitch and a sacrifice fly.

The State Commission Against Discrimination has accused the City Housing Authority of resorting "to dubious methods of pressure in order to inhibit" an investigation of possible racial discrimination in the authority's tenant-selection practices.

Justin Bomboko, youthful Congolese Foreign Minister and political backer of President Joseph Kasavubu, sharply criticized yesterday what he termed the "struggle" among the African nations themselves for "influence" in the Congo.

ISAAC STERN was a logical choice for soloist with the New York Philharmonic at the first concert last night in the newly saved and refurbished Carnegie Hall, and not just because he sparked the successful fight to save the 70-year-old hall.

After two brief rallies that fizzled out, stocks on the New York Stock Exchange closed lower yesterday in moderate trading. On average, prices once again -- for the fourth time in the last seven sessions -- reached new lows not only for the year but since September, 1958.

Dr. Castro has presented his version of the history of Cuban-American relations to the United Nations General Assembly. Unintentionally he may well have performed this country a service. In an audience as sophisticated as that which sat before him, few can have missed the point that a man who promises to be brief and then speaks for four and a half hours must be a difficult person to deal with on other matters as well.

THE blinding speed had long since departed from Lefty Gomez' fast ball and the Singular Senor was reaching the end of the trail. Having become a better entertainer than pitcher, the once great Yankee southpaw was invited to go on an overseas U.S.O. tour. When Lefty reported to a doctor for the usual injections, the medical man poised with his needle over the Gomez left arm.

ABOARD THE U.S.S. NORTHAMPTON, in the Bay of Biscay, Sept. 27 -- The second phase of Exercise Sword Thrust opened today with the sea power of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization maneuvering off the coast of Europe from the Arctic Circle to the Bay of Biscay.

Pan American Airways has negotiated what is believed to be the largest lease ever written for office space in Manhattan. The space will be in the skyscraper rising over Grand Central Terminal.

Nancy Walker has agreed to appear in "Do Re Mi," the forthcoming musical adapted by Garson Kanin from his novel dealing with the jukebox business. The diminutive comedienne, who is rated as one of Broadway's incomparable clowns, will play opposite Phil Silvers.

Offerings of $30,000,000 of twenty-five-year, 4 5/8 per cent debentures of Continental Can Company and $25,000,000 of twenty-year, 5 1/4 per cent bonds of the Commonwealth of Australia will reach the American investing public today.
The Soviet Union has accepted an invitation to participate in the 1961 New York World's Fair.

PARIS, Sept. 27 -- The imminent United Nations debate on France's six-year-old struggle with the Moslem rebellion in Algeria appeared certain today to intensify the deep divisions in French opinion on the subject.

THE Royal Ballet at the Metropolitan Opera House last night turned away momentarily from its repertory of full-legnth ballets by established choreographers to give a showing to short ballets by two of the younger choreographers on its roster.

Traditionally, the advertising and marketing of champagne has proceeded along fixed and rather narrow lines. The name of the vintner is endowed in the advertising with as much prestige as possible. After that the wine almost has to sell itself.

Premier Fidel Castro will fly home to Havana today. He was said to be satisfied with the impact of his indictment of the United States before the United Nations.

Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy ruled yesterday that Jewish policemen would have to work on Yom Kippur, just as they did on Rosh ha-Shanah, despite a new protest by the Rabbinical Council of America.

An expert diamond cutter, formerly with Tiffany Co., opened a grocery store -- and failed this year with liabilities of about $10,000. A machinist started a bookstore in a rural Midwest area -- and failed owing $9,000.

WOODMERE, L.I., Sept. 27 -- Joe Moore of the Century Country Club and Doug Turnesa of Briar Hall today captured the annual Metropolitan Professional Golfers Association's pro-pro Pinehurst championship at the Woodmere Club.
Neither a peaceful life nor a diet extremely low in meat and animal fats preserve Trappist monks from the ills often linked to high-pressure civilization, a new finding indicates.
HARDY AMIES is not in a position to volunteer the information that he designs many of the clothes that the Queen of England wears. However, if asked, the answer is yes.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 27 -- Secretary of State Christian A. Herter has icon-ferred informally with representatives of Argentina, Brazil and Chile, who, with the United States, are the guarantor powers of the 1942 border settlement between Peru and Ecuador.

Herman Levin, producer of "My Fair Lady," has won the first round against Martin Tahse, sponsor of "Laughs and Other Events." He had warned Mr. Tahse not to use two songs from "My Fair Lady" in the one-man show, starring Stanley Holloway.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 -- West Germany's Vice Chancellor, Dr. Ludwig Erhard, responded today to criticism of his country's limited foreignaid efforts. He was immediately presented with intensified United States pressure for Bonn to do more.

MOSCOW, Sept. 27 -- An Austrian airliner crashed and burned on its approach to a landing at Moscow's Shermetyevo Airport last night. Thirty of the thirty-seven passengers and crew members died -- three of them after they had been taken to a hospital.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 27 -- Following are excerpts from addresses in the General Assembly debate today:
Business faces a real crisis in the form of a squeeze on profits, the president of the American Management Association said yesterday.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 27 -- President Gamal Abdel Nasser scored a triumph in his first speech today before the General Assembly.
A merger of the Jack Heintz Corporation, Cleveland into the Siegler Corporation, Los Angeles electronics producer, was agreed to "in principle" yesterday by their boards.

The great debate at Belmont Park yesterday centered on the domestic issue of whether Mrs. Richard C. du Font's 3-year-old gelding, Kelso, would be able to carry his speed over the mile and five-eighths route of today's feature, the $56,500 Lawrence Realization.

CHICAGO, Sept. 27 -- A Chicago and Eastern Illinois Railroad executive told an Interstate Commerce Commission examiner today that his company made more money transporting coal with a barge-rail shipping operation than it did on coal traffic interchanged with other railroads.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 27 -- The United States is planning to publish within a few days a document dealing "fully" with the issues in its dispute with Cuba, James J. Wadsworth, permanent United States delegate, told the General Assembly tonight.

The Alleghany Corporation elected yesterday James J. (Gene) Tunney to its board. Mr. Tunney, the former heavyweight boxing champion of the world, is chairman of the McCandless. Corporation, which sells tread rubber for tire recapping.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 27 -- President Gamal Abdel Nasser of the United Arab Republic urged the General Assembly today to recommend "without delay" a meeting on disarmament between President Eisenhower and Premier Khrushchev.
NEW HAVEN, Sept. 27 -- A modern home for Yale University's literary treasures will rise on a site that workers started clearing today.
ALGIERS, Sept. 27 -- Discouraged, restless, but apparently calm, European Algiers is waiting for "something" to happen.
BOSTON, Sept. 27 (UPI) -- The Boston Red Sox dropped Stanley R. (Bucky) Harris as general manager today and replaced him with Business Manager Richard H. (Dick) O'Connell.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 27 -- Following, in unofficial translation from the Spanish, are excerpts from addresses to the General Assembly today by speakers for Guatemala and Paraguay:

President Eisenhower and Secretary of State Christian A. Herter have given Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy and his men a solid pat on the back for their handling of security during the current United Nations General Assembly session.

A new, less expensive Newport series will be added to the 1961 Chrysler model line-up. The medium-priced division of the Chrysler Corporation will continue its Windsor and New Yorker series but has dropped the Saratoga models.
Prices for cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange rose 1 to 24 points (5 cents to $1.20 a bale) yesterday.
Premier Khrushchev said last night that he was prepared to sit in a locked room as long as necessary with President Eisenhower to achieve agreement on disarmament.

Bank records showing that Jacob Brownstein and George S. Meissner were officers of corporations that owned Manhattan tenements involved in numerous housing violations were introduced yesterday in the trial of the two men.

ANDOVER, Mass., Sept. 27 -- The resumption of a rivalry that started in an era when leather nose guards were accepted football gear and a lemorphosphate was a popular beverage in soft-drink emporiums is being eagerly anticipated on the Phillips Academy campus here.
A high Defense Department official said yesterday that national security relied on a strong merchant marine.
A leading Protestant clergyman warned here yesterday that distributors must share the blame for obscene publications on the nation's newsstands.
VIENNA, Sept. 27 -- The Unit, ed States and Soviet delegations were at loggerheads today over the International Atomic Energy Agency's projected safeguards and control plan.
Security analysts around the country must have been happy yesterday with some cheery corporation news to ponder.

FOR several months now the front pages of the world's press have continued to demonstrate the truth of the ancient proverb about something new always coming out of Africa. A somewhat less disturbing novelty from Africa is a book published this week, "Stanley's Way: A Sentimental Journey Through Central Africa"* by Thomas Sterling.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 (AP) -- A Wall Street brokerage house has been charged with using illegal tactics to sell shares in Pearson Corporation of Bristol, R.I., builder of fiber glass boats.

DALLAS, Tex., Sept. 27 -- "Russia is in dire need of capital on the hoof," a top Administration economic adviser said here today. "Mr. Khrushchev won't in decades get agriculture to the level of present-day America under his full government support system," said Dr. Karl Brandt, a member of the Council of Economic Advisers to President Eisenhower.

Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru of India gave a large dinner party last night that brought together representatives of such antogonistic groups as the North Atlantic Treaty Organization and the Warsaw Pact, Israel and the Arabs.

A virus has been linked with eight human cancers in findings to be reported today by scientists at the Sloan-Kettering Institute for Cancer Research. The virus was isolated from transplanted tumors of the mouth, muscle, ovary and other tissues, and from the non-cancerous livers and spleens of cancer patients, the report says.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: With the visit of a violently anti-American Castro to these shores, the Sept. 18 Times article on Colombia's Accion Cultural Popular (Cultural Popular Action) well illustrates a prime example of a Latin-American self-help movement on a mass scale which seeks to remove the causes that help make possible a Castro or a Trujillo.

A big increase in the city's program for cooperative and limited-dividend, middle-income rental housing was announced yesterday by J. Clarence Davies Jr., chairman of the city's Housing and Redevelopment Board.

VIENNA, Sept. 28 -- The fifteen-power resolution on safeguards and controls of atomic energy materials and equipment was adopted by a committee of the International Atomic Energy Agency today over the opposition of the Soviet bloc and six uncommitted countries.

Our Changing City Like any man-made institution, the city -- and particularly Our Town -- is a changing thing, for it has a life of its own even though it be but a reflection of the lives of the men who create it.

YESTERDAY was Howard Schenken's birthday and his wife gave him a "surprise" party, which like all surprise parties turned out to be no surprise but did assemble a large number of bridge notables to honor him.

A merged account, headed jointly by Bank of America, National Trust and Savings Association, San Francisco, and Bankers Trust Company, New York, submitted the only bid yesterday for $75,000,000 of California veterans and school building bonds. The group bid 100 for $50,000,000 of veterans bonds, and 100.2917 for $25,000,000 of school building obligations, both due from 1962 to 1986.
A metal box may become the salvation of the depressed steamship industry.

GEORGE JEAN NATHAN'S exuberant capacity for enjoying the colors of life brightens the pages of "The Magic Mirror,"* a collection of his theatrical writings made by Thomas Quinn Curtiss. He diligently cultivated the notion that he was a terribly worldly cynic. But, of course, he was really one of the most extravagant romanticists of his time.
The New York Stock Exchange expelled a member yesterday on charges of fraud. And it announced that its responsibility did not end with that action.
PRINCETON, N.J., Sept. 28 -- "We're happy to hear that Columbia has its best football team in years. It's a healthy state of affairs for all the Ivy League teams to be strong."

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Sept. 28. -- The 16,000 Negroes in this suburban city were of divided opinion today when one of their leaders went on trial in City Court on a charge of disorderly conduct in the sitdown at the William B. Ward School one week ago.
MONTREAL, Sept. 28 (UPI) -- Federal Government intervention was being sought today to head off a threatened strike by about 600 Great Lakes seamen.
Four men were convicted by a Federal jury yesterday of a total of 141 counts of extortion and conspiracy for having exacted tribute for unloading interstate shipments of meat.

The story of baseball's "Black Sox Scandal" of 1919, which recently was canceled by "Du Pont Show of the Month," will be presented in a different dramatic form by "The Witness." Both television shows are produced by Talent Associates, Ltd.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 -- Exports last month continued to run substantially ahead of 1959 levels, the Department of Commerce estimated today.
Following is a statement on housing issued here yesterday by Vice President Nixon:

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Sept. 28 -- There is a special and startling taste to life in Leopoldville. It cuts through the maze of Congo politics and can be felt like a live thing in the city's streets. It is the awareness of fear.
National Airlines, Inc., had a net loss of $2,958,179 in the year ended on June 30 and will also end up in the red in the first quarter of its new fiscal year.
PARIS. ALEXANDRE is coming to New York. The genial hairdresser, whose adventurous scissors have shingled some of the most famous heads in Europe, hopes to duplicate his success in the New World.

Garvice H. Ridings, manager for facsimile equipment and systems of the Western Union Telegraph Company, received the F.E. d'Humy Award Medal yesterday. This is given by Western Union each year to the Western Union man "who has made a most significant contribution to the telegraph art."
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Thursday, Sept. 29 -- The longest agenda list in United Nations history was approved by he powerful Steering Committee last night and forwarded to the General Assembly.

YESTERDAY (Sept. 28, 1960) GENERAL ASSEMBLY Continued general debate hearing Eduardo V. Haedo, President-elect of the National Council of Government of Uruguay; Jens O. Krag, Foreign Minister of Denmark; Todor Zhivkov, member of Presidium of the National Assembly of Bulgaria; Jorge B. Illueca, Panama's delegate; Antonio Segni, Foreign Minister of Italy and Sardar Mohammed Naim, second deputy Premier of Afghanistan.

CHICAGO, Sept. 28 -- The Chicago and Eastern Illinois Railroad made a profit of 8 cents a ton on coal it hauled from Mount Vernon, Ind., to Chicago with a joint barge-rail rate of $3.33 a ton, Guy H. van Searingen, vice president for planning, testified today at an Interstate Commerce Commission hearing.

The Port of New York Authority's conditional indicated willingness to buy and operate the Hudson and Manhattan Railroad represents a significant departure from past policy. The offer, expressed at the opening of the New Jersey Senate's investigation of the authority, was made simultaneously with a renewed declaration of the principle that "self-support is the bedrock upon which the entire Port Authority financial structure is founded."

The nation's machine tool industry had a surge in new business last month. Net new orders were the third highest this year and 34 per cent above those of July. The gain was the best for any month so far in 1960.
BOSTON, Sept. 28 (AP) -- Jackie Jensen agreed today to return to the Boston Red Sox in 1961.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 -- How much Federal aid should go to the cities and states for housing?
WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 -- Secretary of the Treasury Robert B. Anderson painted a bullish picture of the national economy today.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Although a registered and voting Democrat, President Eisenhower's belated rise to positive, dynamic leadership in his speech before the U.N. made me proud to be an American. His speech was studded with specific suggestions for resolving the present state of embittered relations with the Soviet Union.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 28 -- The United Nations, General Assembly voted unanimously today to admit two new West African republics-Senegal and Mali (formerly the French Sudan) to membership in the world forum.

Gen. Nathan F. Twining, who winds up a forty-four-year military career tomorrow, said last night that the only reliable peace guarantee was a military machine strong and alert enough to win a war even if subjected to surprise attack.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 28 -- Prime Minister Macmillan and Premier Khrushchev will meet tomorrow for a talk that will have considerable effect in determining the direction of events at the United Nations General Assembly.

To Dan Topping, co-owner of the New York Yankees, the report that George Martin Weiss shortly will step down as the general manager of the club, is the "damndest story I ever read." Topping, who could not be reached Tuesday, yesterday interrupted a brief vacation, rushed back from Southampton, L.I., and made himself available for an interview.

Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy last night restored days off to a limited extent for all patrolmen and sergeants. This would indirectly make it easier for Jewish policemen to get time off for Yom Kippur services.
ESKDALE, W. Va., Sept. 28 -- Frank Palma massaged a watermelon absent-mindedly with his right hand and stared through his dusty store window at a mountainside rich in coal but poor in jobs.

The media war in Grand Central Station among the women's magazines, which already has embraced attacks and counter-attacks in both sight and sound, will see a new front opened this morning -- the taste front.

Gov. Foster Furcolo of Massachusetts withdrew yesterday his offer to have a committee of governors intervene in negotiations between the General Electric Company and the International Union of Electrical Workers.

The nation's stocks of gasoline declined by 2,542,000 barrels in the week ended last Friday, according to the American Petroleum Institute. Part of the decline reflected a lower level of production, which amounted to 28,575,000 barrels for the period, compared with 29,365,000 a week earlier.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 28 (AP) -- The Chicago Cubs beat the San Francisco Giants, 6 -- 3, today on Bob Andersen's nine-hit pitching. Only 5,513 fans turned out, the smallest crowd of Candlestick Park's first season.
LBOPOLDVILLE, the Congo Sept. 28 -- The President of the Government of Leopoldville Province warned today that political confusion might touch of "civil war" in the Congo's capital.

Mrs. Richard C. du Font's 3-year-old gelding, Kelso, moved into the top rank of stakes-winners at Belmont Park yesterday when he equalled Man o' War's 40-year-old track record in winning the Lawrence Realization by four and one-half lengths.

A resolution calling for merger negotiations with the United Papermakers and Paperworkers Union was adopted here yesterday by delegates attending the five-day convention of the International Printing Pressmen and Assistants Union.

The American merchant marine is contributing between $800,000,000 and $1,000,000,000 annually toward maintaining a favorable United States balance of payments, the Committee of American Steamship Lines reported yesterday.
The leaders of two nations that were at war with each other four years ago met yesterday afternoon in what was described by both sides as a "very cordial atmosphere."
ARDMORE, Pa., Sept. 28 -- With JacK Nicklaus of Columbus, Ohio, contributing a record 66, the United States today took the lead in the opening round of the world amateur team golf championship.
A long-time member of the Board of Education's Board of Examiners said yesterday that the school system failed to weed out undesirable probationary teachers.

LAGOS, Nigeria, Sept. 28 -- Police forces were reported today to have arrested about 3,500 marauders in an attempt to put down intertribal warfare. The fighting has taken a number of lives in the bush of northern Nigeria almost on the eve of independence.
PROVIDENCE, R.I., Sept. 28 (AP) -- Claiborne Pell, a political novice won the Democratic nomination tonight to succeed Senator Theodore Francis Green, defeating two seasoned campaigners.
COMMACK, L.I., Sept. 28 -- Vice President Nixon, touring Long Island today, unveiled a broad new Republican program for improving housing conditions in the nation, particularly in urban areas.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept, 28 -- Denmark proposed today that the Eastern and Western powers take a new step toward disarmament by opening approximately corresponding sections of their territories to international inspection.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 -- Britain joined today the chorus if voices that have been raised here this week to press West Germany to greater efforts to aid under-developed nations.
BUFFALO, Sept. 28 -- Senator John F. Kennedy was cheered and applauded by huge, enthusiastic crowds today as he brought his campaign for President into western New York.

"UN: The First Fifteen Years," by Clark M. Eichelberger, will be published by Harper on Oct. 19. It discusses the work of the international organization with emphasis on the important developments in the last five years since the publication of the author's "UN: The First Ten Years."

THE revue that opened last night at the One Sheridan Square is called "Greenwich Village. U.S.A." What opportunities for a revue with a title like that! A simple theatregoer would think that he could expect an evening full of bright barbs and sharp shafts, of satire and comedy -- in short, a revue with some sort of thematic point of view that would hold the program taut.

Thirteen tenants at the Stuyvesant Town housing development are asking the Board of Estimate to nullify rent increases that the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, the project owner, intends to impose.

RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, Sept. 23 (Reuters) -- Pakistan, charged today that Afghanistan's troops were massing on the northwestern frontier and that loyal tribesmen had repulsed a thrust by an armed Afghan band into Pakistani territory.

A NEW, scaled-down sewing machine, called "Sewhandy," has been designed especially for young seamstresses. The nonelectric, miniature machine actually sews fabric with thread like mother's full-size model. It operates by turning a hand wheel on its side.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Many words have been published on the Congo situation, but none have caused us more surprise than the editorial of Sept. 17, which states that "Ghana has shown a leaning to one side of the struggle, and that is the side of Lumumba," and suggesting that this "leaning" is principally because "he represents centralism against Kasavubu's federalism."
WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (AP) -- Internal Revenue Service agents across the nation staged a series of raids today aimed at suspected bookmakers, lottery operators and other gamblers.

A strong appeal to "men of goodwill everywhere" to exercise their influence with Soviet authorities to help alleviate the plight of Soviet Jews was made here yesterday by seventeen major United States Jewish organizations.
The New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad went deeply into the red again last month. It registered a net loss of $1,699,040 for August and reported an eight-month deficit of $9,590,039.
LONDON, Thursday, Sept. 29 (Reuters) -- A leading British surgeon said today that linking animal fat intake to heart disease was "nothing but a racket."
Premier Khrushchev said yesterday that he and President Tito of Yugoslavia had "fully come to terms" on a number of world problems.

LONDON, Sept. 28 -- Share prices advanced modestly in the stock market here today. The better tone among the industrials was believed to have reflected in part American buying of the leaders. Continued American demand also helped British Government securities extend their rally with rises of around 2s 6d (35 cents).

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 28 -- United Nations officials just back from the Congo said today that the United Nations civilian team in the Congo was trying to "tie in emergency activities with a crash training program for the Congolese."

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 28 -- The United States moved today to begin implementing through the United Nations President Eisenhower's five-point program of assistance to the new countries of Africa.
Fire Commissioner Edward F. Gavanagh Jr. yesterday suspended without pay two lieutenants and seven firemen accused of holding outside jobs in violation of Fire Department regulations.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept 28 -- Mr. and Mrs. Ray Start tried to recall today, in the backwash of the outstanding Hollywood party of the season how it had all happened.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 -- To the National, the Columbia, and the American Broadcasting Networks, Sirs:...
A strapping 23-year-old Norwegian royal visitor and Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt yesterday renewed a friendship that began in World War II.

The annual theatre party of the Women's Division of the American Friends of the Hebrew University has been arranged for next Tuesday at the Metropolitan Opera House, where the Royal Ballet will perform "Giselle."
A portrait of the Vice President of the United States as a family man who is still a "gay young blade" was drawn yesterday by his wife for an audience of admiring women.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 -- The Federal Reserve Board reported today that the condition statement of weekly reporting member banks, in leading cities showed the following principal changes for the week ended Sept. 21:
JAMES DOUGAN NORRIS has bade a bitter farewell to boxing, renouncing all connections with the sport and expressing regret that he ever became involved in it. That makes it unanimous.
The bond market was chiefly coupled with the distribution of $75,000,000 of California veterans' and school bonds yesterday.

Atlas Plywood Corp. Six new directors were elected to the eleven-member board of the Atlas Plywood Corporation at the annual meeting in Boston yesterday. The stockholders also voted to change the company's name to Atlas General Industries, Inc.

New York's oldest jewelry establishment -- Black, Starr Gorham -- is celebrating its 150th birthday with an exhibition that owes much of its splendor to work collected and sponsored by the Worshipful Company of Goldsmiths in London.

WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 28 -- A crowd of 18,518 wagered $1,590,157 tonight as Roosevelt Raceway closed a 104-night meeting. The total handle for the season was $183,282,527. This was an average of $1,762,332 per night, the highest ever at the raceway.
BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 28 (AP) -- Interior Minister Alfredo Vitolo announced tonight that a man suspected of being Martin Bormann, Hitler's long-missing deputy, had been arrested in Argentina.

"VISIONARY ARCHITECTURE," an exhibition that opens today at the Museum of Modern Art, is a collection of models and huge photographic enlargements of architects' dreams. They range from cities beneath the sea to buildings a mile high on land, and all are proposed less as fantasies than as possible solutions to problems that architects should face but haven't, or are going to have to face someday and had better be thinking about.

Share earnings of American Israeli Paper Mills, Ltd., for the fiscal year ending next March 31 are expected to be about double those of fiscal 1960, Joseph M. Mazer, chairman, reported at the annual meeting here yesterday.

Scheduled performances of "The Andersonville Trial" have been canceled in Atlanta and Birmingham, Ala. The play deals with a Confederate prison camp in which thousands of Northern soldiers died during the Civil War.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 -- Officials here are hoping that talks now going on in Luang Prabang, Laos, will end the feuding between non-Communist factions in the country.
BOSTON, Sept. 28 (UPI) -- Ted Williams ended his playing career today by hitting a home run against the Baltimore Orioles in his last time at bat.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 28 -- The man responsible for guarding delegates to the United Nations General Assembly against guns, bombs or simple accidents said today that the New York police had told him that "at no time have so many people of such high rank been collected at one meeting."
St. Louis seems to be strong on musical husband-and-wife teams.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 28 (UPI) -- Lew Burdette, gunning for his third straight twenty-victory season, gained his nineteenth triumph with a six-hitter tonight as the Milwaukee Braves defeated the Philadelphia Phillies, 9 -- 3.
SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 28 -- Another vessel in the expanding replacement program of the shipping industry and the Government went down the Bethlehem Steel Company ways here tonight.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 -- With Mickey Mantle hitting two home runs and Cletis Boyer one, the Yankees tonight completed a sweep of their three-game series with the Senators by downing the Nats, 6 to 3.
Yom Kippur -- the Day of Atonement, the most solemn event on the Jewish religious calendar -- will begin tomorrow at sundown.
Two more heads of state, President Sukarno of Indonesia and King Hussein of Jordan, arrived yesterday afternoon to attend the United Nations General Assembly.

The Loft Candy Corporation observed its one hundredth anniversary with record sales of $18,380,263 for the fifty-three weeks ended on July 2, it was reported yesterday. The volume represented an increase of $689,854 from the $17,690,409 for the fifty-two weeks to June 27, 1959.

The Pennsylvania Railroad Company, the nation's largest railroad, operated at a net loss of $3,089,500 during August. In the 1959 month, when its traffic was sharply curtailed by the nation-wide steel strike, the system had a net loss of $3,491,788.

Stocks rode a roller coaster yesterday as prices went up and down in a series of abrupt movements. At the end of the ride, stocks on the New York Stock Exchange were at their lowest levels since Sept. 5, 1958.

ABOARD U.S.S. NORTH AMPTON, in the Bay of Biscay, Sept. 28 -- Exercise "Sword Thrust," now in its final phase in the choppy waters of the Bay of Biscay and along the coast of Western Europe, was described tonight as "the most impressive maneuver North Atlantic Treaty Organization forces have ever held."

The purchase - money mortgage for one of five neglected tenements allegedly owned in secret by two Brooklyn lawyers was signed on the sidewalk entrance to a City College branch at Lexington Avenue and Twenty-third Street, Special Sessions Court was told yesterday.
The way was paved by the City Planning Commission yesterday for the broad rehabilitation of a shabby twenty-two-block section of lower Manhattan.
The New York Telephone Company borrowed $60,000,000 in the public bond market yesterday at an interest cost of about 4.585 pen cent.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Thursday, Sept. 29 -- The Soviet Union suffered a setback early today when it attempted to provide Premier Khrushchev with a General Assembly forum for his disarmament proposals.
Prof. Jim Lee Howell whistled his class in Advanced Football to order promptly at 11:30 A.M. at Fordham University yesterday.

With all due understanding of the religious problems involved, we support Police Commissioner Kennedy's requirement that his entire force remain on duty during the present emergency, regardless of holy days. The extraordinary situation created by the presence of controversial world figures at the United Nations General Assembly calls for extraordinary police protection.

The publishing concerns of Harcourt, Brace Co. and the World Book Company announced their forthcoming merger yesterday. Another announcement disclosed that Random House, Inc., had taken another step to expand its publishing operation, by acquiring the L.W. Singer Company of Syracuse, a textbook publisher.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange advanced 4 to 22 points yesterday. (A point equals 5 cents a bale.)

When an investor owned utility company and a rural electric cooperative join forces amicably it is like a dog not barking at a cat. Yesterday, the Pennsylvania Electric Company and the Warren (Pa.) Electrical Cooperative, Inc., announced a joint venture.
LONDON, Sept. 28 -- Britain has shelved her plans to build another massive fusion power research machine for at least three years.
HOT SPRINGS, Ark., Sept. 28 -- Southern Governors abandoned today the region's traditional support for free trade and urged adoption of an essentially protectionist policy.
Premier Fidel Castro of Cuba flew home yesterday in a Soviet luxury airliner, proclaiming friendship for Premier Khrushchev and the American people.
PITTSBURGH, Sept. 28 -- Webb Knapp, Inc., has contracted to acquire ten acres in the heart of Pittsburgh for an $18,000,000 group of apartment towers.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 28 -- Adlai E. Stevenson opened tonight three days of campaigning for Senator John P. Kennedy in Los Angeles after suggesting in Berkeley that the Communists might be "genuinely frightened" by the global arms race.

TRENTON, N.J., Sept. 28 (AP) -- Dwight R.G. Palmer, State Highway Commissioner, today announced the statu had signed a $1,425,000 contract with the Pennsylvania Railroad calling for continued commuter service until Aug. 29, 1961.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 -- The Federal Power Commission adopted today a new policy for the regulation of prices by independent natural gas producers.

State Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz reported yesterday that his office was investigating rock-salt companies for possible violation of the state's antimonopoly layvs. The study is also looking into identical bids submitted last week on New York City contracts.

HACKENSACK, N.J., Sept. 28 -- Political activity in Bergen County picked up speed today with visits by Senator Clifford P. Case, Republican running for re-election, Thorn Lord, his Democratic opponent, and State Senator Walter H. Jones, Republican leader of the courty.

UNITED NATIONS, Sept. 28 -- Ecuador's Foreign Minister, Dr. Jose Chiriboga Villagomez, announced today that he would inform the United Nations that Ecuador considered its 1942 border settlement with Peru null and void.
THE American Broadcasting Company, encouraged by the popularity of its "Hawaiian Eye" programs, has come up with another adventure series set in exotic surroundings.
Publication of the new International Edition of The New York Times, to be printed daily except Sunday in Paris and air-delivered the same morning throughout Europe, will begin on Thursday, Oct. 20.

The Vice President is moving on to treacherous ground when he suggests that Senator Kennedy refrain from criticizing American foreign or domestic policy because of the encouragement such criticism might give to Mr. Khrushchev.
YONKERS, Sept. 28 -- The $25,000 American Test, a mileand-a-quarter event for free-for-all trotters, will be the feature tomorrow as Yonkers Raceway opens its fifty-four-night fall meeting.
The Canadian Pacific Railway Company yesterday reported declines in earnings and revenues for August and the first eight months of 1960.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 (UPI) -- Scientists have used the speed of light as a measuring stick to set a record for accuracy in a space age surveying project at Cape Canaveral, Fla., the Government reported today.

RYE, N.Y., Sept. 28 -- Mrs. Edwin H. Vare Jr. of Bryn Mawr, Pa., won her first United States senior golf title today and became the first to win all the major women's championships in the United States.
Wishnow Horowitz were the brokers in the sale of three five-story apartment houses in the Bronx.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (AP) -- The Navy reported a possible break through today in developing a torpedo capable of tracking and destroying nuclear-powered submarines.

DALLAS, Tex., Sept. 28 (UPI) -- Americans must stick strictly to the free enterprise system in order to win the economic cold war with Communism, Leslie B. Worthington, president of the United States Steel Corporation said today.

While Premier Khrushchev poses before the United Nations General Assembly as the great champion of total disarmament, willing to accept any proposed controls, the real Soviet attitude on the crucial issue of control has been revealed again at the General Assembly of the International Atomic Energy Agency meeting in Vienna.
A strike of railroad workers in the Port of New York set for 12:01 A.M. Saturday was postponed for sixty days yesterday through Presidential action under the Railroad Labor Act.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I have read your editorial of Sept. 20 supporting the building of more midtown parking garages on the partial ground that the public perversely insists on driving into the heart of the city and that therefore additional parking facilities are unavoidable.

FRED ASTAIRE, whose nimbleness afoot seems impervious to the years, presented his annual hour of infectious song and dance last night over Channel 4. There have been rumors from Hollywood that he may not attempt another for some time, a report seemingly borne out by the wording of his acknowledgment of thanks to his sponsor.

ENDICOTT, N.Y., Sept. 28 -- A new approach to the study of proteins, the basic ingredients of all living things, was described here today at a symposium on the medical, and biological uses of electronic computers.
MOSCOW, Sept. 28 (AP) -- Leading Soviet medical specialists are giving exhaustive tests to a candidate for space flight, Pravda reported today.

BONN, Germany, Sept. 28 -- Moscow's stand that the air corridors to Berlin can be used only to supply the Allied garrisons in that divided city has aroused concern among the three Western powers responsible for West Berlin's security.
THE fashion house of Christian Dior in Paris has bestowed the ultimate glory on a 34-year-old Parisian designer named Marc Bohan.

Dr. Buell G. Gallagher, president of City College, announced yesterday that the student newspaper he had called "Communist oriented" was seeking to have him publicly censured. He said the paper was accusing him of slander.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 -- Following are excerpts from a speech given today by Secretary of the Treasury Robert B. Anderson at the joint meeting of the World Bank, the International Monetary Fund and the International Finance Corporation:

JAPANESE Crown Princess Michiko's device of tape recording lullabies to lull her 7-month-old son, Prince Hiro, to sleep during her tour of this country with her husband, Prince Akihito, has drawn the praise of a local pediatrician.

EAU CLAIRE, Wis., Sept. 25 -- Vote switching seems to be quite common this year in the Ninth Congressional District of Wisconsin, where the maple leaves are beginning to turn the hills into a colorful spectacle.
McALESTER, Okla., Sept. 28 (AP) -- A convict's role as a guinea pig for medical science shortly before he died in the Oklahoma Penitentiary's electric chair was disclosed today.

NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 28 (AP) -- The United States Civil Rights Commission ended hearings into charges of discrimination against Negroes in voting today in a stormy exchange with Jack Gremillion, attorney general of Louisiana.

TRENTON, Sept. 28 -- The head of a citizens' group opposed to a jetport in Morris County expressed fears today that that Port of New York Authority might induce the Legislature to reverse its stand and approve the facility.

Mrs. James M. Mertz, of Rye, who divides her sports interests between dogs and yachts, has just had a memorable week-end in both. First she became the winner with her husband of the Nail Trophy for the best season record in Long Island Sound racing.

Experts agree that the revue format is the most difficult type of entertainment to produce successfully. For that reason, few have been done in recent years. Mindful of the hazards, John Fearnley is preparing to introduce "Anyone We Know," to be directed by him for a local premiere in May.

IT may look easy but it is painfully difficult to domesticate Oscar Wilde to the musical comedy stage. "A Delightful Season," a musical version of "Lady Windermere's Fan," which opened at the Gramercy Arts Theatre last night, is an object lesson in the traps the brilliant stylist sets for his admirers.

VIENTIANE, Laos, Sept. 28 -- Military leaders of the neutralist Government of Laos and of the Right-Wing opposition met today with King Savang Vathana at the royal capital of Luang Prabang. The talks were aimed at ending the nation's eighteen-day-old civil war.

FORT WAYNE, Ind., Sept. 28 -- Those who know Senator Lyndon B. Johnson in Washington as a subtle parliamentary strategist and an apostle of political compromise would hardly recognize him as a campaginer for Vice President.
Commodity futures wore traded in narrowly mixed ranges on New York exchanges yesterday. Trading was dull and generally listless.

IN the days when the Brooklyn Dodgers were at Ebbets Field, the name Abe Stark was constantly before the public. A sign at the concrete base of the right field scoreboard proclaimed that any batter who hit the sign on the fly would receive a free suit at Mr. Stark's clothing store on Pitkin Avenue in the Brownsville section.

SAN JUAN, P.R., Sept. 28 -- The box score at the end of the first day's fishing in the Seventh International Game Fish Tournament here was impressive, yet the fishing was even better than the box score showed.
Senator Eugene J. McCarthy expressed the belief yesterday that Vice President Nixon might be persuaded to keep the religious issue alive in the Presidential campaign.

Letters Abroad, Inc., 45 East Sixty-fifth Street, will benefit from a preview of the fifth International Hallmark Art Award Exhibition at the Wildenstein Gallery, 19 East Sixty-fourth Street, Tuesday evening. The exhibition will run from Wednesday, through Oct. 26.

PARIS, Sept. 28 -- The French Government tonight forbade more than 140 of the country's top intellectuals, including actors, writers and teachers, to appear on the state-run radio and television or in state-run theatres.
CHICAGO, Sept. 28 (AP) -- A moderate general demand nudged grain futures prices a bit higher today in a mostly dull trade.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 -- Amid the flurry of reports buzzing around the Yankees these days came one more today.
PEPPER of the sort that is sprinkled on eggs is the most sought-after spice in the world.

SAG HARBOR, L.I., Sept. 26 -- Art, religion and the Space Age have been blended by a 65-year-old Sag Harbor artist into a huge stained glass window that will be dedicated next week in the New Synagogue in Chicago.
Since most football player these days are either good big men or better big men, it is in triguing to watch a team whose players are mostly small, medium and calorie conscious.

STORRS, Conn., Sept. 29 -- Bob Ingalls was a somber-faced football coach today as he pondered his Connecticut Huskies' chances against a powerful Rutgers squad here Saturday in Memorial Stadium.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 29 -- Starting literally with peanuts, Davre J. Davidso'n has built a nationwide, $40,000,000-a-year vending machine operation dispensing everything from soup through several courses to nuts.

The Southern Pacific Company reported yesterday a jump of 20 per cent in profits last month. Net income rose to $5,543,379 from $4,637,564 in August of last year. Net operating income was $4,555,932, up from $3,711,709 in 1959.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Congratulations on your clear and forthright editorial "Mr. Khruschev's Big Lie" (Sept. 24) in which you depict the U.S.S.R. for what it is: "The greatest colonial empire of the present day." As one who has studied the topic for some time, may I draw your readers' attention to a few more salient facts Mr. Khrushchev has conveniently omitted from his speech in the United Nations.
MONTREAL, Sept 29 (AP) -- Six hundred seamen struck the N.M. Paterson Sons, Ltd., fleet of thirty-six ships today as last-minute contract negotiations failed.

The United Arab Republic is, and has been for a year, a candidate for one of the non-permanent memberships in the U.N. Security Council. Behind President Nasser's drive for this position is the endorsement of the Asian-African bloc, plus the Charter stipulation that in the selection of these non-permanent members "due regard" shall be paid to "equitable geographical distribution."

Leaders of five key neutral countries in the United Nations were reliably reported last night to have prepared an appeal for President Eisenhower and Premier Khrushchev to meet again to ease the tensions of the "cold war."

GENEVA, Sept. 29 -- Britain said today that the projected control system must be ready in two years to make on-the-spot investigations of possible violations of a treaty banning nuclear weapons tests.
Businesses borrowed slightly more from New York City banks to meet quarterly tax and dividend payments this September than they did last year.
Robert G. Fairburn announced yesterday that he was resigning as chairman of the Diamond National Corporation, effective Dec. 31.
TRENTON, Sept. 29 -- Preliminary talks between the Hudson and Manhattan Railroad and the Port of New York Authority concerning the possible purchase of the road may be imminent.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- Ghana raised its voice for socialism today, responding to earlier remarks by the chairman of this week's meeting of finance ministers and bankers from sixty-eight countries.
The market for fixed-interest securities continued its leisurely pace yesterday.
LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Sept. 29 -- President Joseph Kasavubu moved today to reduce the number of rival governments in the Congo from three to two.
YONKERS, Sept. 29 -- Fog and dampness marred, the reopening of Yonkers Raceway tonight.

A CHANGE in personnel on the highest-ranked American bridge team, announced yesterday, may affect the line-ups of American teams in national and international tournaments in the coming year, although ostensibly only two players are involved.
A United Nations clerk has been arrested in the investigation of a swindle that may involve $250,000, according to a source in the office of District Attorney Frank S. Hogan.
Prime Minister Macmillan and Premier Khrushchev reviewed East-West differences for more than two hours last night. They agreed they probably would meet again next week.

SYRACUSE, Sept. 29 -- Senator John F. Kennedy challenged the value of Vice President Nixon's foreign policy experience tonight. He did so in a major attack on the Eisenhower Administration's handling of that policy.
Mrs. Marion duPont Scott's 6-year-old bay gelding Benguala, carrying 148 pounds, fenced to a six-length victory at Belmont yesterday in the $19,625 Brook Steeplechase Handicap.
CHICAGO, Sept. 29 (AP) -- Profit takers worked persistently on grain futures today and at the close of trading on the Board of Trade had most prices on the minus side of yesterday's final levels.

BONN, Germany, Sept. 29 -- The West German Government is expected to announce tomorrow economic sanctions against East Germany in reprisal for the Communists' mounting pressure against West Berlin.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 29 -- Gov. Luis Munoz Marin of Puerto Rico has protested to the United Nations against charges that Puerto Rico was treated as a colony by the United States.

TRUST the French to make vice as innocent as a fable. In "Irma La Douce," a musical comedy that came to the Plymouth Theatre last night from Paris via London, the Gallic gift for genial satire turns an evil-ridden district around the Place Pigalle into a kind of cynical fairyland and its depraved inhabitants into charming acquaintances.

YESTERDAY (Sept. 29, 1960) GENERAL ASSEMBLY Continued general debate hearing Prince Norodom Sihanouk, Chief of State of Combadia; Harold Macmillan, Prime Minister of Britain; Dr. Bruno Kreisky, Foreign Minister of Austria; Zulfikar Ali Bhutto, Minister for Fuel, Power and Natural Resources of Pakistan; Jose R. Once again "The Sleeping Beauty" constituted the program of the Royal Ballet at the Metropolitan Opera House last night. Its Princess Aurora this time, however, was Nadia Nerina, who had not danced it previously this season.

RYE, N.Y., Sept. 29 -- Mrs. Harrison Flippin of Ardmore, Pa., and Mrs. T.W. Hawes of Summit, N.J., won the annual Scotch foursomes tournament of the United States Senior Women's Golf Association today.

The first boat of a new class of steel motor sailers arrived from the Netherlands this week aboard the Black Diamond Line's Black Tern. Four more, all identical, will be shipped at intervals from the builder, the Westhaven Shipyard of Rotterdam.

Humorous experiences of an American in Lebanon are told by William Peter Blatty in "Which Way to Mecca, Jack?", which Bernard Geis will publish on Oct. 28. Mr. Blatty, who was born in Brooklyn of Arab parentage, was sent by the United States Information Agency to Lebanon as an information officer.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Sept. 29 -- With less than four hours' sleep after his smashing primary victory last night, Claiborne deB. Pell of Newport laid plans today for a brief vacation before plunging into a new campaign as the Democratic nominee for Senator from Rhode Island.
Any firemen found to be working at outside employment henceforth will be dismissed from the force, Fire Commissioner Edward F. Cavanagh Jr. ruled last night.

At the Institute in Paris where Louis Pasteur helped found the science of microbiology, a group of researchers is delving into the sexual behavior of bacteria.

EXETER, N.H., Sept. 29 -- Phillips Exeter Academy's football squad is short on depth this season and Ted Seabrooke, the Big Red's good-natured head coach, has been joshing the team's manager, Jim Horwitz, about it.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 29 -- Cambodia proposed today that the United Nations establish and guarantee a neutral zone in Southeast Asia to serve as a buffer area between the powerful Eastern and Western blocs.
LEONARD BERNSTEIN led the New York Philharmonic in its first subscription concert of the season last night at Carnegie Hall and he performed as piano soloist with the orchestra.

LONDON, Sept. 29 -- The Liberal party opened its annual conference at Eastbourne today in a buoyant mood.

THE old and the new jostled shoulders as the fall season of the New York City Opera Company opened last night at the City Center. The old was really old: Claudio Monteverdi's "Orfeo," dating from 1607, only about ten years after the very birth of opera in Florence.

One of these countries is the United States, and an excellent illustration is the present status of Puerto Rico.

Net income of ACF-Wrigley Stores, Inc., for the fiscal year ended on June 25 amounted to $3,695,175, equal to 90 cents a share, on 4,117,083 shares of common stock outstanding. The food chain, which had 177 super-markets in operation at the end of June, cleared $3,533,011, or 86 cents a share, in the preceding fiscal year.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Sept. 29 -- Senator Lyndon B. Johnson wound up a Midwest tour today with a series of attacks on "those who would divide this country" along religious, racial or regional lines.

No feathers are to be used to grease pans, and toothpicks are to be dispensed in a sanitary manner at New York's 1964 World's Fair. Furthermore, straws must be individually wrapped, and all custard-filled products used at the fair must be manufactured in New York City.
Vice President Nixon will invade a Democratic-Liberal stronghold next Wednesday when he campaigns for two hours in the garment district of Manhattan.

Wall Street brokers, notice ably garrulous on appraisals of stocks, business conditions, the economic outlook, taxes and such, were silent yesterday on a subject close to home. At least a dozen declined to comment on the industry's latest and greatest embarrassment in years -- the failure of a brokerage concern and its expulsion from membership in the New York Stock Exchange.
DETROIT, Sept. 29 -- Thomas E. Dewey accused Senator John F. Kennedy tonight of naively echoing Soviet propaganda in his campaign for the Presidency.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- The United States has advised its citizens in Cuba to send home their wives and children. Also, it informed the Cuban Government today that the Nicaro nickel-processing plant in Oriente Province would be closed down.

Dr. Grayson Kirk, president of Columbia University, announced plans yesterday for a new International Center to house the Columbia School of Interntional Affairs, the new International Affairs, the new and the Foreign Area Studies.
LONDON, Sept. 29 -- The threat of a national railroad strike here and Wall Street's continued weakness unsettled the stock market here today.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 (AP) -- Sales by manufacturers dropped during August for the fifth straight month, but there was a rise in new orders, the Department of Commerce reported today.

MINEOLA, L.I., Sept. 29 -- Motorists voiced concern today over the "arbitrary and unreasonable" cancellation of automobile insurance policies at a hearing before the Joint Legislative Committee on Insurance Rates and Regulations.
A family of robots to explore the bottoms of the oceans and the surface of the moon and the planets was proposed here yesterday at the Instrument Society of America's scientific meeting.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed 6 to 35 points (30 cents to $1.75 a bale) off yesterday. The far months showed the most weakness and also old October.

The specter of identical bids for supplying the city with 80,000 tons of rock salt continued to haunt the Department of Purchase yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- The next three weeks will help answer one of the most important question of the Presidential election: How effective will President Eisenhower be in his active campaign to elect Vice President Nixon?

THINGS are seldom what they seem -- for which the Florida Citrus Commission is grateful. Now that the damage inflicted by bad-tempered Donna has been assessed, it is felt that the extra-large crop could have fared worse.
No bids were received yesterday by the California Toll Bridge Authority for $7,000,000 of revenue bonds, due on July 1, 2000.

THE Mafia dramatists guild and the American Bar Association must have been equally dismayed by last night's premiere of "The Witness" over Channel 2.
WHILE world leaders gathered yesterday at the United Nations, the Metropolitan Museum of Art played host last evening to another assembly with an international flavor.

COOPERSTOWN, N.Y., Sept. 29 -- Stephen C. Clark, business man, philanthropist and a founder of the National Baseball Hall of Fame, bequeathed $11,675,000 to a hospital, schools, charities and individuals, it was, disclosed today.
ARDMORE, Pa., Sept. 29 -- Through the mist and rain today, two young American golfers scored 67's to help the United States increase its lead to twenty strokes in the world amateur team championship.

Development Services, Inc., realty sales and management concern, has relocated its headquarters to 135-14 Northern Boulevard, Flushing, Queens. According to its president, Anthony J. Pelletier, the company will continue to maintain branch offices in all five boroughs.
The free Shakespeare Festival Theatre in Central Park, once opposed by city officials as a nuisance, has fostered plans for an expanded program of education, entertainment and civic safety.

The Yankees yesterday suffered their first setback in their quest of another world series title. They learned that Elston Howard, who has been sharing the first-string matching duties with the incomparable Yogi Berra,may be lost to the Bombers for the first two games in Pittsburgh.
Cottonseed oil futures fell sharply yesterday on the New York Produce Exchange in the most active trading in more than a year.
HAVANA, Sept. 29 (AP) -- Premier Fidel Castro indicated at a welcome-home celebration last night that a legal showdown was nearing on the United States naval base at Guantanamo.

Doing homework by the television set is a practice generally frowned on by parents and educators. But pupils at Junior High School 64 in Brooklyn may earn special credit by watching TV at home -- provided they tune in on programs suggested by the school.

BOSTON, Sept. 29 -- Vice President Nixon carried his campaign to the home ground of his Democratic opponent tonight with one of his sharpest political attacks to date on Senator John F. Kennedy.
NEWARK, Sept. 29 -- Plans for the functioning of the new Meadowlands Regional Development Agency were advanced today with the swearing in of twelve commissioners to the state body.

SAN JUAN, P.R., Sept. 29 -- Nothing immoderate happened today in the seventh international game fish tournament, but then it wasn't a day of skunkage either and everybody professes to be as happy as people fishing to beat each other can be.
Three new public schools will be built in Brooklyn at a total cost of $7,377,956 under contracts approved yesterday by the Board of Education.

The New York Giants' defensive platoon worked overtime in the rain on the Fordham University football field yesterday seeking ways to thwart double-wing plays. The St. Louis Cardinals will use that formation against them Sunday in a National Football League game at St. Louis.
PROVIDENCE, R.I., Sept. 29 -- Claiborne deBorda Pell paid a visit this noon to the grand old man of Rhode Island politics, Theodore Francis Green, whom he hopes to succeed as United States Senator.

PORTSMOUTH, N.H., Sept. 29 (AP) -- Secretary of Commerce Frederick H. Mueller, addressing a textile manufacturers' meeting worrying over the threat of imports, suggested today that tariff relief might come through lumping together evidence of injury to one group of products.

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Sept. 29 -- Just forty-eight hours after the United Nations decided on its Congo rescue operation, a dozen men carrying small black bags landed in Leopoldville to begin a battle that could last twenty years.

Stockholders of the Lionel Corporation, model railroad and electronics concern, at a special meeting here yesterday approved the acquisition of the assets of Anton-Imco Electronics Corporation, Maj. Gen. John B. Medaris, Lionel president, announced.

The gulf that separates the free world from the Soviet bloc in aims, methods and manners was revealed before a startled United Nations General Assembly yesterday in a spectacle that is not unknown to some parliaments but is without precedent in this world forum where the sensibilities of nations are involved.
TAIPEI, Taiwan, Sept. 29 -- President Chiang Kai-shek and leaders of his Kuomintang (Nationalist party) conferred today about Nationalist China's future.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- Department store sales in the nation in the week ended Sept. 24 were 2 per cent above the level of a year ago.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 29 -- Alan Stoneman is a sponsor who has no conflict with the men and women who stage the television shows his company pays for. For Mr. Stoneman believes a sponsor should limit his television interference to the commercials.

Secretary of the Treasury Anderson gave a vigorous and optimistic evaluation of this nation's economic outlook in his speech to the current international financial meeting in Washington. His theme was that the present relative stagnation, at a high level, in the American economy -- a situation some observers are calling a recession and others are predicting will shortly be followed by a recession -- is simply a transition to a new situation.

Daily average borrowings by member banks of the Federal Reserve System rose $146,000,000 to $225,000,000 in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. Daily average reserves in excess of requirements rose $95,000,000 to $608,000,000.
Yom Kippur, the Jewish Day of Atonement, will start at sundown today here and over the world.

The thirteenth annual Blue Grass Ball was held last night at the Plaza. As in previous years, the dinner dance, which was attended by many prominent New Yorkers, benefited the New York Travelers Aid Society and was sponsored by Elizabeth Arden.

Banton L. Wyckoff took the stand yesterday at the trial of his two alleged partners as the owners of five Manhattan tenements in which 199 violations accumulated while the city sought the true owners.
TOKYO, Friday, Sept. 30 -- A message by Premier Khrushchev attacking the United States shattered the deliberate calm of the forty-ninth meeting of the Interparliamentary Union yesterday.
CLEVELAND, Ohio, Sept. 29 (UPI) -- Design of an open hearth steel furnace nearly double the size of the largest presently in use in the United States was reported today by two Soviet steel experts.
MONTCLAIR, N. J., Sept. 29 -- Mayor Gustav Scherbaum of Graz, Austria, arrived here today from Vienna to help mark ten years of friendship between his city and this suburb.

Tod Williams, who hit his 521st home run on Wednesday and said he would play no more baseball, may have driven himself into a television job.
CHICAGO, Sept. 29 -- The Air Line Stewards and Stewardesses Association sued the Air Line Pilots Association yesterday for $1,000,000.

BLOOMFIELD, N.J., Sept. 29 -- The defending champions, Frank Vileno and William Mangin of Alpine, were eliminated in the quarter-final round of the New Jersey pro-amateur match play golf championship today by Monte Norcross and John Jarema of Metuchen, 2 and 1.

TRENTON, Sept. 29 -- Almost 40 per cent, or 68,000, of the 177,320 persons now employed in Union County live outside the county while more than 69,000 persons who live there commute to jobs elsewhere in New Jersey or in New York.
NICE, France, Sept. 29 -- Brigitte Bardot, the movie star, was reported tonight to be recovering from an overdose of sleeping pills.

Two ladies from San Antonio, Tex., have formed Spice Wood Enterprises to back Broadway shows. Both Mrs. Carolyn B. Negley and Mrs. Jean G. Kuntz prefer to operate under the firm's name, but inasmuch as the identity of each is a widespread Broadway secret, they were told they could not conduct their business anonymously.

Fifteen years have elapsed since Columbia defeated Princeton in football. With such able hands as Gene Rossides, Lou Kusserow and Bill Swiacki in the line-up, the Light Blue eleven of 1945 gave a 32-7 trimming to a Tiger whose claws had been blunted by the World War II suspension of formal gridiron activity at Old Nassau.

The Hertz Corporation has expanded its operations by forming a company to rent party supplies, hospital and sick room equipment, television sets, glassware, silverware and other merchandise.
