The New York Chapter of the Association for the Help of Retarded Children will benefit from a luncheon and fashion show to be held in the ballroom of the Sheraton-East on Oct. 10. Mrs. Norbert A. McKenna and Mrs. Robert E. McCormick, co-chairmen, head the benefit committee.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- Secretary of the Treasury Anderson has presented some statistics of the American economy, and founded certain conclusions thereon, that bear directly on one of the major issues between the Presidential candidates of 1960.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- Railroad freight loadings last week were above levels of the corresponding week of last year, when the nation-wide steel strike was in progress. Truck freight loadings for this same period were slightly down.

Mayor Wagner's office said yesterday that all Jewish policemen who wanted to observe Yom Kippur apparently would have "a very, very good chance" of getting off duty under a new work schedule and through exchanges with non-Jewish officers.

PARIS, Sept. 29 -- The French Government made public today a 1961 budget indicating a conviction that the French economy had ended a two-year convalescence and was ready for a little light exercise to produce expansion.

The Republic Corporation (formerly Republic Pictures Corporation) cleared $1,340,294 in the thirty-nine weeks ended July 30. This was equal to 52 cents a share. In the corresponding period of 1958 $675,678 or 19 cents a share was cleared.

PORTUGAL has so far escaped the mass invasion of the eager American shopper. But not for long. The many beautiful antiques discovered by decorator Evelyn Jablow this summer are enough to awaken any homemaker's wanderlust.

Federal Tool Corporation Directors and stockholders of the Federal Tool Corporation, Lincolnwood, Ill., and of Proven Products, Inc., and the Federal Premium Service, Inc., Stokie, Ill., have approved a merger plan, it was announced yesterday.
SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Sept. 30 -- Vice President Nixon campaigned in the Republican heartland of upstate New York for the first time today.
Cottonseed oil futures rallied yesterday on the New York Produce Exchange to regain the ground lost in a sharp decline on Thursday.
Long coffee breaks, a boon to many workers and a bane to some of their employers, are the order of the day at a unit of the West Virginia Pulp and Paper Company. In fact, they last all day long.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- The United States is being maneuvered into a defensive position by the mounting neutralist pressure for an Eisenhower-Khrushchev meeting, diplomatic sources said today.
Jonathan Guy Flatow, going on 11 days old, might be a good man for scientists who are studying the effects of early experience and environments to remember.

HONG KONG, Sept. 30 -- The publication in Peiping this week of a new volume of works by Mao Tse-tung, chairman of the Chinese Communist party, was a carefully planned and executed move, analysts of Chinese affairs here believe.

IF there is a '"twixt-teener" around who does not know what she is, the term means a young girl with a still boyish figure, who is between the ages of 11 and 14. Furthermore, it is Abraham Straus' idiom for this special kind of person who now has her own department of clothes on the second floor, called the "Twixteen Shop."

WHAT with the Tuesday night Pension Fund concert and Thursday night's preview, yesterday afternoon's Philharmonic concert in the "new" Carnegie Hall was something of an anticlimax even though it was the first regular subscription concert of the season.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- Average wholesale prices in primary markets rose 0.1 per cent during the week ended last Tuesday to 119.5 per cent of their 1947-49 average, the Buerau of Labor Statistics announced today.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 30 (UPI) -- Lee Walls hit a bases-filled single with one out in the fourteenth tonight, capping a three-run rally that gave a 7 -- 6 victory to the Philadelphia Phillies over the Cincinnati Reds.
The stock market took a hammering last month and ended sharply down, but on a rallying note. Prices firmed yesterday to enable the market to recover a portion of the month's earlier losses.

The McCrory Corporation is expanding its variety chain business into the home and auto supply store field by acquiring a controlling stock interest in the Oklahoma Tire and Supply Company, Tulsa, Okla.

THE strange, comic life of the Town of Titipu took over the stage of the City Center last night when the New York City Opera Company presented Gilbert and Sullivan's "The Mikado" in the same admirable production it had created last season.

The fifteen-story and penthouse apartment building at 67 Hanson Place in Brooklyn has been sold by Jacob Fine to the Recoa Realty Corporation for cash above $475,000 in mortgages. The broker was Don Clarke.
CHICAGO, Sept. 30 -- Following is the text of President Eisenhower's informal talk here today to the Polish-American Congress, of which Charles Rozmarek is president:

ANYONE at loose ends today might stroll over to the Curzart card shop at 198 East Fifty-eighth Street and get an early start on Christmas. Here, a large collection of new cards, ranging in price from 5 cents to $1.25, has just arrived.

The development of computer technology and automatic control on the Chinese mainland has been so rapid as to "astound" the Russians, according to a report presented this week to the Office of Naval Research.

A history of the anti-slavery movement in this country will be published Oct. 12 by Harper and will be titled "The Crusade Against Slavery: 1830-1860." The book, written by Louis Filler, will be a volume in the New American Nation Series.
A decision by the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Judicial Circuit has left the nation's two leading maritime unions facing the threat of a major damage suit.

A report to the recent meeting of the American Chemical Society by Prof. Otto Westphal of the University of Freiburg, West Germany, described some remarkable developments in the study of bacterial toxins, named endotoxins, which promise to open a new era in medicine, with fruitful new approaches to the treatment of both infectious as well as noninfectious diseases.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 30 -- The Yugoslav press is presenting the United Nations General Assembly session in the terms of a struggle by the uncommitted nations to get the big powers to settle down and talk sense.
HYANNIS PORT, Mass., Sept. 330 -- Senator John F. Kennedy was described today as very heartened by the results of two days of campaigning in upstate New York.
The Giants and the Titans, New York's rival professional football companies, completed rehearsals yesterday for their out-of-town engagements tomorrow.
MIAMI, Sept. 30 (AP) -- Eddle Johns, a sophomore quarter-back, made a spectacular debut tonight as Miami routed North Carolina, 29 -- 12.

HESPERIA, Calif., Sept. 30 (UPI) -- Bill Blanton of San Diego, who has never won a major pro tournament, shot a 6-under-par 66 today to take a three-stroke lead in the first round of the $20,000 Hesperia open.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 30 -- The West has shown distressing lack of teamwork in gaining or holding favor among U.N. neutrals. Cooperation among the NATO allies has so far seemed disorganized and lackadaisical. Although President Eisenhower gave a sensible lead in his outline of African policy, insufficient advantage has been taken of this.

IT has been more than twenty-six years since "Men in White," Sidney Kingsley's stage play about conflicts and pressures in a big hospital, won a Pulitzer Prize. Last night it was revived on television as the season's first offering of "Show of the Month" over Channel 2.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- The Western Big Three were reliably reported today to be in full Support of West Germany's threat to cut off trade with Communist East Germany unless the Communists stop harassing West Berlin.

President Gamal Abdel Nasser of the United Arab Republic continued last night his work of seeking converts to neutralist policies abong the new African states, whose leaders are attending the United Nations General Assembly.
The old, tuneful gospel hymns still top the list among Protestant churchgoers.
CAIRO, Sept. 30 -- The visit to the United Nations General Assembly by President Gamal Abdel Nasser has been viewed here as a resounding success.
Borough President Hulan E. Jack of Manhattan, whose second trial will begin next Wednesday, has been under a selfimposed suspension from office for nearly nine months.
Yom Kippur, the Jewish Day of Atonement, started at sundown yesterday with the intoning of the traditional Kol Nidre (All Vows) in temples and synagogues.

The California Toll Bridge Authority, which received no bids on its offering of $7,000,000 of revenue bonds on Thursday, announced yesterday that it would seek bids again on Oct. 18. The term obligations come due in 2000.

Television's magic lantern will beam to a national audience today one of college football's most fascinating early-season matches. It presents stalwart Syracuse, the top-ranked varsity team of 1959, against Kansas, whose smashing triumphs over Texas Christian and Kansas State hint grandeur that nay not be an illusion.
New York State's experiment in classroom education by television starts its third year Monday morning.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 30 (UPI) -- The United States Department of Justice today won a major antitrust victory in obtaining a court-approved agreement requiring the Firstamerica Corporation, the nation's largest bank holding company, to divest itself of sixty-five offices and $500,000,000 of deposits.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 30 -- Colombia's Foreign Minister told the General Assembly today that twenty American republics had stood together against Soviet intervention in this hemisphere even if Cuba asked for it.

Abraham Lincoln High School marched for five touchdowns and walloped Lafayette, 34 -- 0, at Lincoln Field yesterday. Marty Rosen scored two touchdowns on runs of 30 yards and 5 yards. Harold Wolland, the quarterback, passed for one touchdown and ran 10 yards for another.
ARDMORE, Pa., Sept. 30 -- Only one question remains in the minds of the golfers competing here in the world amateur team championship: By what margin will the United States win tomorrow?
The bond market plodded through another dull session yesterday with a quickened pulse noticeable only in over-the-counter corporate issues.
KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Sept. 30 -- Senator Lyndon B. Johnson urged Southern audiences today to remain loyal to the Democratic party in their own economic interest.
KANSAS CITY, Oct. 1 (UPI) -- Frank Lary gained his fifteenth victory of the season tonight by hurling the Detroit Tigers to a 5-3 decision over the Kansas City Athletics.
Stocks rallied sharply yesterday and swept ahead to equal the best gain of the year.
The decline in interest rates has about run its course, and any further decline, particularly in short-term rates, is bound to be limited, a leading economist said here yesterday.
New automobile insurance rules, under which "bad risks" in the Assigned Risk Plan can be given penalty charges of up to 100 per cent, go into effect today.

VIENTIANE, Laos, Sept. 30 (AP) -- A quarrel that could split the Laotian Government wide open erupted today between Premier Souvanna Phouma and Captain Kong Le, the leader of the August coup, Captain Kong Le put Prince Souvanna Phouma in power.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 30 (AP) -- Norm Larker drove in three runs tonight but lost ground in his National League batting duel with Dick Groat of Pittsburgs, as the Los Angeles Dodgers defeated the Chicago Cubs, 7 -- 5.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- The State Department tonight advised all United States travelers to stay away from Cuba "unless there are compelling reasons" for going there.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 30 -- President Kwame Nkrumah of Ghana proposed today a reorganization of the United Nations Secretariat by the appointment of three deputy Secretaries General "acceptable to the Western and Eastern blocs and to the neutralist countries."

YONKERS, Sept. 30 -- Dave Legum drove the 4-year-old Brown Star, a 10-to-1 shot, to an upset victory tonight in the Yorktown Pacing Handicap at Yonkers Raceway. Turning the mile in 2:02 2/5, Brown Star beat the favored Quick Lady by a neck.

In cautious contrast to American brokers, Lord Ritchie of Dundee, chairman of the London Stock Exchange, said the other day that the exchange did not believe in promoting investment among small investors.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed 7 points off to 14 points up yesterday. A point equals 5 cents a bale.
SAN JUAN, P.R., Sept. 30 -- Something like a record was in sight tonight in the Seventh International Game Fish Tournament but the trouble is that the matter is a little complicated.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 30 (UPI) -- Bob Buhl pitched a five-hitter to beat the Pittsburgh Pirates for the fourth straight time this season as the Milwaukee Braves scored a 13 -- 2 victory over the National League champions tonight.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- A Federal Aviation Agency official suggested today that "pre-occupation" with the safety of jet planes in recent years was partly to blame for a poorer safety showing on non-jet planes.

LONDON, Sept. 30 -- Share prices continued to lose ground in the stock market here today. The industrial lists were almost unrelievedly dull. Declines ranged to 1s 3d (17 1/2 cents) among steel and engineering shares and to a shilling (14 cents) in motor, electrical equipment, chemical, store, textile, building and brewery stocks.
HAMMOND, Ind., Sept. 30 (AP) -- Plans to reorganize the Standard Oil Company of Indiana and two of its subsidiaries have been approved by stockholders.
WHITTIER, Calif., Sept. 30 -- Vice President Nixon need have no worries about where his home town stands. If the Presidential election were held today, he'd probably get three-fourths of the vote.

The market for new fixed-interest securities promises to show a heavy volume next week, with corporate and utility issues holding the center of the stage. More than $170,000,000 of private bond issues is scheduled.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 30 -- A random canvass of United Nations delegates today indicated little support for the suggestion by Premier Khrushchev and President Sukarno of Indonesia to move the organization's headquarters.
A national organization to mute the nerve-jangling noises of trucks, pneumatic drills, canslamming garbage collectors, sirens and boisterous parties was proposed to Mayor Wagner yesterday.

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo Sept. 30 (Reuters) -- Col. Joseph D. Mobutu, the Congolese army strong man, declared tonight that Communist China had offered Patrice Lumumba $2,800,000 in aid funds but rejected a request to send volunteers to the Congo.
MOSCOW, Sept. 30 (AP) -- Communist China's Ambassador to the Soviet Union was quoted today as having said that his country would work for peaceful coexistence.
The Police Department announced last night that every Jewish policeman who had requested time off to observe Yom Kippur was off duty by sundown.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- Both major parties asserted today that they were skirting bankruptcy.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 30 -- Only about 25 per cent of American college students are estimated to be old enough to vote. But Henry Cabot Lodge continued to campaign among them today as if they were going to swing the election in November.

Gheorghe Gheorghiu-Dej, First Secretary of the Rumanian Communist party, said yesterday that a Balkan entente could be set up without disrupting the ties of member states to either the North Atlantic Treaty Organization or the Warsaw Pact, which is the Soviet-bloc equivalent of NATO.
PARIS, Sept. 30 -- France continued today to maintain an attitude of official detachment from the events at the United Nations General Assembly.
RYE, N.Y., Sept. 30 -- A jet engine was used today to dry off a stretch of highway for paving after it had been soaked by three days of rain.

Mayor Wagner signed a local law yesterday requiring that all multiple dwellings in the city containing nine to thirteen apartments have a resident janitor, or one living within 200 feet of the premises.
The Yankees gave themselves a lively world series tune-up at the Stadium last night.

Sol Hurok, the Russian-born impressario who specializes in bringing artists from various parts of the world to the United States, is going to sponsor Michael MacLiammoir's one-man presentation, "The Importance of Being Oscar," on Broadway.

Crown Prince Harald of Norway told 500 business men of Norwegian descent here yesterday that he was optimistic that the gap between the European Common Market and the European Free Trade Area would be bridged.

An American steamship line has invested about $500,000 of venture capital in the cause of more foreign trade for ships that fly the United States flag. The initiative has taken the form of a mobile trade fair promoted by the Isbrandtsen Company, Inc., whose fleet of cargo vessels will visit many world ports with displays of American-made products.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- A Massachusetts Institute of Technology team received patents this week for SINS, the mechanism that enables American submarine skippers to navigate without shooting the stars or using the magnetic compass.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- The Defense Department announced today that $107,000,000 would be added to the Polaris submarine missile program.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I should like respectfully to urge that the American people reserve Judgment as to the case of Lei Chen; the publisher and political figure, until the evidence is all in.
Crown Prince Akihito and Princess Michiko of Japan arrived here yesterday morning for a four-day unofficial visit that will include sight-seeing and an afternoon at Yankee Stadium tomorrow.

HAWORTH, N.J., Sept. 30 -- Westchester defeated New Jersey and Long Island today and retained its title in the Metropolitan women's intersectional golf matches for the Myra Paterson Trophy. The competition was held at the White Beeches Country Club.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In your editorial, of Sept. 24, "Liberal Party Independence," you say. "Without passing at this time upon the comparative qualifications of the Democratic nominee, Supreme Court Justice Henry L. Ughetta of Brooklyn, we welcome and applaud evidence -- rare enough in the record of the party -- that the Liberals are on occasion willing to detach themselves from the Democratic cause."

A series of chance medical discoveries in the last eighteen months has surrounded a widely used anti-diabetes drug in mystery. The mystery continues to deepen, with new reports of unexpected effects being produced by the drug.
HAVANA, Sept. 30 (UPI) -- Premier Fidel Castro Threatened today to execute any "American spies or saboteurs" caught in Cuba.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- Secretary of Defense Thomas S. Gates Jr. said today that if his two-month-old reorganization of the lagging missile base program does not work, "we may have to appoint an overall 'czar.'"

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 (AP) -- Railroad labor chiefs today formally rejected a new appeal by the New Haven Railroad for its employes to accept a 10 per cent wage deferral for six months to help the railroad out of financial difficulties.

The New York Racing Association was notified yesterday that it would have to file Federal income tax form 1099 on all daily double pay-offs exceeding $600 on a $2 ticket and exceeding $3,000 on a $10 ticket.
PRINCETON, N.J., Sept. 30 -- Columbia will bring its strongest football team in years to Palmer Stadium at 2 P.M. tomorrow in an attempt to post its first victory over Princeton since 1945.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- Controller General Joseph Campbell has found that at least $151,500,000 of the Administration's claim of a budget surplus for 1960 resulted from a deliberate delay of expense payments by a single-day.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- The managing director of the International Monetary Fund said today that he had heard more deflation talk than usual at this week's meeting of world financial officials and that the talk was not warranted.

Wigny, foreign minister of Belgium.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 (AP) -- Farm product prices rose by 1 per pent from mid-August to mid-September, the Department of Agriculture reported today.

LAGOS, Nigeria, Saturday, Oct. 1 -- Nigeria became an independent nation within the British Commonwealth today.

Increased activity by film distributors this fall, after a summer shortage of major releases, is indicated by nine new bookings announced yesterday by local theatre managers.

OAKLAND, Calif., Sept. 30 -- An Army plane carrying six persons crashed in the Orinda Hills today, killing all aboard including Maj. Gen. Carl F. Fritzsche, commandant of Fort Ord Training Center.

The various forces which have so sensationally increased the costs of hospital insurance have been strikingly measured and analyzed in a study of the claims experience of nine of the larger life insurance companies between 1950 and 1957. "WINE, WOMEN, AND WOAD,"* by Ed Fisher -- or, as the jacketeer calls him, Edipus Piscatorius -- is a cheerfully scribbled lampoon of man's eternal waywardness. Once more the decline of the Roman Empire serves to point the usual morals, if that's the word I want, for our own rather feverishly restless age.
Nine fillies and mares, all stakes winners, are slated to run in the $91,100 Beldame Handicap at Belmont today over the mile and one-eighth route.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 (AP) -- The Justice Department asked the Supreme Court today to review a lower court decision setting aside the construction permit for a nuclear power reactor in Michigan.

ONE of the innovations announced for the current season was a half-hour situation comedy to be done in the format of the animated cartoon. With so many sponsors making witty use of drawings -- indeed some of the commercials have been more amusing than many of the shows -- the prospect of such an entertainment series was both enticing and overdue.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Sept. 30 -- The hard-fought campaign for Brazil's Presidency wound up tonight with one leading candidate suffering "almost total exhaustion" and the other in bed recovering from an electoral accident.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 30 -- Premier Khrushchev, in his private conversation, has shown no willingness to make concessions in his positions on disarmament, Berlin and the structure of the United Nations.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 30 -- Brown and Yale, each looking for its first Ivy League football victory meet tomorrow afternoon in the Yale Bowl. Starting time is 2 o'clock. A crowd of 25,000 is expected.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y. Sept. 30 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold described today the fifteen newly admitted African nations to the United Nations as signifying an "African political renaissance" that should also extend to the world organization.
BRIDGE has a very complex code of ethics, which only the best players understand fully, and the code is concerned chiefly with hesitations.
ANN ARBOR, Mich., Sept. 30 (AP) -- The state police said today that an unsuccessful attempt to bribe an Oregon football player had been made the day before the Michigan game here last Saturday.

BONN, Germany, Sept. 30 -- West Germany served Communist East Germany today with three months' notice that it would break off trade relations. The move could precipitate a showdown crisis over Berlin.

ROANOKE, Va -- With the official opening yesterday of another section of the Blue Ridge Parkway, fall visitors to this area will find nine new overlooks from which to view the foliage spectacle of the Virginia highlands.

Roving Minstrel and Garvvol, a Louis E. Wolfson entry, are expected to give Globemaster the most competition in today's thirty-eighth running of the $50,000 added Cowdin Stakes at Belmont Park. The entry's probable odds are 4 -- 1.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 -- The Supreme Court convenes tomorrow to begin what may be one of its most significant terms.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 2 (UPI) -- Willie Mays cracked an inside-the-park home run with two on base today to help the San Francisco Giants score an 8-2 victory over the St. Louis Cardinals in the final game of the season for both clubs.

MAX BEERBOHM once wrote that he was a quiet and unexciting writer. He was right. And for some sixty years numerous discriminating readers, not persuaded that noise and excitement are the greatest of literary virtues, have cherished Max Beerbohm with deep affection. They prize the wit of one of the most spontaneously witty men who ever lived.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Oct. 2 -- Donald Mackenzie, the skipper of Black Arrow, captured his second race of the International Class fall series for the De Coppet Trophy today. A fleet of fifty sailed in a solid southerly breeze on a rough sea off Larchmont Yacht Club.

Trading in the over-the-counter market last week expanded as dealers moved to reduce their own inventories. The pressure of offerings was greatest early in the week when the market for listed securities fell to lows since the fall of 1958.

WASHINGTON, Oct 2 -- Premier Fidel Castro's expropriation of American holdings in Cuba has apparently had no great deterrent effect so far on United States investments in the rest of Latin America.

WHEN Doris Yarick made an unexpected debut at Town Halt last March, as a substitute soloist with the Clarion Concerts, it was predicted that she would be heard from again. Within a week the Charlotte, N.C., soprano had won the third annual Town Hall Award in the "Joy in Singing" series, which entitled her to the debut recital she gave in Town Hall yesterday afternoon.

THOSE who fancy themselves able to read the future in tea leaves or maybe in old scorecards have let themselves be deluded by the fact that the Yankees grievously mistreated the Pirates in the 1927 world series and stomped off with victory in four straight. They find this omen irresistible. The same thing will happen again.
Still riding the crest of the winning streak that clinched the American League pennant a week ago, the Yankees closed the season yesterday by winning their fifteenth game in a row.

Seventy-six policemen were promoted yesterday in a field ceremony at the United Nations Plaza at Forty-third Street.

CHICAGO, Oct. 3 (AP) --- Cleveland's right-handed pitching star, Jim Perry, shut out the Chicago White Sox, 4 -- 0, on five hits today and recorded his eighteenth triumph of the season. This tied him with Chuck Estrada of the Baltimore Orioles for the most victories by an American League pitcher this season.
CLEVELAND, Oct. 2 (UPI) -- Milt Plum outpassed Bobby Layne as the Cleveland Browns chalked up a 28-20 victory today over the Pittsburgh Steelers.

GREENWICH, Conn., Oct. 2 -- Emil (Rus) Mosbacher Jr. sailed the blue-hulled sloop Fun to victory today in the fourth and final race of the Indian Harbor Yacht Club's series for the Whitmore Trophy. But Alfred E. (Bill) Luders Jr. won the cup with Storm for the third time.

For the first thirty-nine weeks of 1960, daily net demand and time deposits of the thirteen New York Clearing House Association member banks averaged $26,310,000,000, down $692,000,000 or 2.56 per cent from the $27,002,000,000 for the 1959 period, M.A. Schapiro Co., Inc., reported yesterday.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 2 (AP) -- The Chicago Cubs scored two unearned runs in the fourteenth inning last night and beat the Los Angeles Dodgers, 10 -- 8. The game lasted 4 hours 54 minutes.

LONDON, Oct. 2 -- Business was rather slack in the stock market last week, but there was enough selling to depress prices somewhat.

lona Prep of New Rochelle upset St. Francis Prep, 13 -- 6, yesterday in a Catholic High Schools Football League game at Boys High Field, Brooklyn. St. Francis is the defending league champion.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 2 -- Debonair, charming, gentlemanly classy, cool and tough. All of these adjectives were applied last week to Henry Cabol Lodge during his first campaign visit to southern California.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 (AP) -- Jackie Brandt's eighth-inning homer enabled Baltimore to score a 2-1 victory over the Washington Senators today. It clinched second place for the Orioles, their highest finish since their return to the American League in 1954 after a fifty-year absence.
There was no progress yesterday toward ending the strike that started at 12:01 A.M. against the General Electric Company.

PARIS, Oct. 2 -- The French Actors Union called a strike tonight against the state-operated television network to protest Government measures against artists who had advocated military insubordination in Algeria.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Oct. 2 -- The trustees of the Southern Education Reporting Service voted today to continue it to June 30, 1963, if the Ford Foundation would authorize a new financing grant. The present grant expires in June.

The 1961 Lincoln Continental has been cut sharply in size and variety and is expected to be reduced in price. It also has been restyled substantially to give it the appearance of the classic Mark series of four years ago.

His argument is deceptive because it oversimplifies the problem and dangerous because his remedy will fail to cure it.

Two youths were shot last night in what the police called a clash between two feuding Brooklyn street gangs. One of the youths, shot in the right eye, was in critical condition.

CHICAGO, Oct. 3 -- The American city was defended today against a charge of criminal negligence in permitting urban blight to grow unchecked. But its citizens, particularly business leaders, were urged to exert greater influence to preserve and promote municipal well-being.

The Department of Public Works said yesterday it would readvertise tomorrow for bids on the construction of a seventy-foot fireboat. The department said it would drop the requirement that bidders' shipyards be within 200 miles of New York.

Va., Sept. 30 -- The uncommitted voter is giving the politicians sleepless nights in the complex of steel centers and drowsy farm towns that makes up West Virginia's First Congressional District. New York City banks reported gains ranging from 5 to 27 per cent yesterday in net operating earnings for the first nine months of 1960. Higher interest income from loans and higher fee and commission income than in the 1959 period offset generally lower interest income from securities.

The Chicago, III., Board of Education is planning the sale of $15,000,000 of bonds on Oct. 18. The obligations will come due serially from 1962 to 1980.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 (UPI) -- A qualified 18-year-old has about one chance in ten of eventual exclusion from the draft unless he marries and has children, the Defense Department estimates.

That's a slightly depressing thought for survivors of the Great Depression, isn't it? Yet there it is. In book after book we see the mushroom clouds of today blotting out yesterday's inhumanities and old terrors being given new coatings of the picturesque.

NEW YORK, it seems, is becoming a city of kitchens with diminishing dimensions. To judge from inquiries directed to this department, there are many who are obliged to cook on double hot plates or, as the saying goes, on two burners.
CHICAGO, Oct. 3 (AP) -- Wheat, soybeans and rye steadied on the Board of Trade here today, but the feed grains weakened.

A new book by Edward Higbee, called "The Squeeze," will be published Oct. 28 by Morrow. It is a view of living conditions in the metropolitan areas of the United States, the urban centers, the suburbs and the bordering countryside.

Edward Chodorov, who wrote and directed "Oh, Men! Oh, Women!" for Broadway production in 1953, has been signed to stage "The Captains and the Kings," an initial play by Leo Lieberman. John Gerstad was originally named as director.

NICE, France, Oct. 3 -- Floyd Patterson left Britain last week having profoundly impressed most of the country with his intelligence, articulafeness and sensitivity. Britain seemed agreed that he was not at all what one expected of a prizefighter.

SCARBOROUGH, England, Oct. 3 -- The British Labor party opened its fifty-ninth annual conference here today apparently well on the way to a policy of neutralism and nuclear disarmament and to a shakeup of its leadership.

HAVANA, Oct. 3 (AP) -- The real purpose behind Maj. Ernesto Guevara's coming visit to Moscow is to negotiate the sale of Cuba's entire 1961 sugar crop to the Communist bloc through a barter deal. Government sources said today.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 3 -- On the eve of most world series, each fearless baseball expert has a strong opinion as to which team will hold the victory party after the final game. TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: With reference to Prof. Robert A. Scalapino's letter published Sept. 27, I wish to add certain facts to those already touched upon by Prof. David N. Rowe in his letter which appeared Oct. 1.

Most New York commodities drifted lower in dull and featureless trading yesterday. Cocoa, cottonseed oil, coffee, wool, hides, copper and lead declined; the world sugar contract and zinc rose, and price movements for potatoes and rubber were mixed.

Carroll Baker, now completing the Manhattan filming of "Something Wild," will report to Washington Oct. 17 for her next starring assignment, as the American wife of a Japanese diplomat during World War II in "Bridge to the Sun."
Mayor Wagner said last light that Premier Khrushchev wanted the United Nations out of New York because the city belied Communist doctrine on the "decadence of democracy."
Broadway's 7:30 Wednesday night curtain is in danger of collapse.

SHELAGH DELANEY, the Lancashire lass who wrote "A Taste of Honey" when she was 19, regards the world without illusions. Her play, which opened at the Lyceum last night, is an evocation of disenchantment done with touching honesty.

HAVANA, Oct. 4 (AP) -- Roman Catholic opposition to the Leftward lunge of Premier Fidel Castro's Government mounted today. The reading of another pastoral letter accusing the nation's Communists of trying to destroy Catholic inluence "by leaps and bounds" was disclosed today.

CHICAGO, Oct. 4 -- A new tax structure, expanded efforts to curb inflation, and a fresh policy of labor reform were among the steps offered here today to insure the nation's economic growth in the Nineteen Sixties.

President Tito of Yugoslavia and President Gamal Abdel Nasser of the United Arab Republic -- two of the leading neutralists at the United Nations General Assembly session -- left for home yesterday in some-what pessimistic moods.
In his spirited rejection of Premier Khrushchev's demand for his resignation, Secretary General Hammarskjold has emphasized two points of utmost importance to United Nations members.

YESTERDAY Oct. 4, 1960 GENERAL ASSEMBLY Continued general debate, hearing N.V. Podgorny of the Ukraine; Saeb S. Salaam, Premier of Lebanon; Evangelos Averoff-Tossizza, Foreign Minister of Greece; Jose Felix de Lequerica of Spain; Walter Nash, Prime Minister of New Zealand; Crown Prince Moulay Hassan of Morocco.; J.M.A.H. Luns, Minister for Foreign Affairs of the Netherlands.

MOST writers are specialists. They write only fiction, or only poetry, or only letters to the editor. Although some of the world's truly great writers are magnificently versatile and excel in several varieties of literature, the all-around man of letters has always been exceptional and never so exceptional as today.

John W. Hanes, the board chairman, said yesterday the New York Racing Association was seriously disposed toward moving for an end to daily double wagering at Belmont Part, Aqueduct and Saratoga next year.

Too frequently in the past Congressional committees seeking to preserve the security of the United States have failed to understand the meaning of the First Amendment, confusing dissent with disloyalty, criticism with subversion. That was McCarthyism, which has declined but has not yet died. Too frequently in the present do we still see evidence of the same mentality, in both the Senate Internal Security subcommittee and its counterpart, the House Un-American Activities Committee.

The seizure of 110 pounds of pure heroin here Monday may eventually create a shortage of the drug among addicts in New York and northern New Jersey, George H. Gaffney, district supervisor of the Narcotics Bureau, said yesterday.
Viveca Lindfors has been engaged to star in "The Queen and the Rebel," the Italian drama Ugo Betti wrote in 1949, four years before his death. The adaptation has been made by Eugene Lion.

Ivy League football coaches are not going to subscribe to an "open skies" formula in the intraleague gridiron warfare. That was apparent yesterday as all of them concentrated upon vigilance along the air lanes for next Saturday's action.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Oct. 4 (UPI) -- Adios Butler smashed a world record for harness racing that had stood for twenty-two years today when he paced through a one-mile time trial on Lexington's famed "Red Mile" track in 1:54 3/5.
Robert Kennedy charged last night that the Republican party has started a "Red smear" campaign against Senator John F. Kennedy.
CHICAGO, Oct. 4 (AP) -- The Chicago Cubs' managerial merry-go-round today shook off another luckless pilot, Lou Boudreau. He resigned after being refused a three-year contract.

Prime Minister Macmillan told Premier Khrushchev yesterday that he hoped that the Big Four could resume negotiations on Berlin in January or February at the level of either the heads of government or the foreign ministers.
Three liens totaling more than $140,000 were filed yesterday against Webb Knapp, Inc., for work done in connection with Freedomland, the amusement pork in the Bronx.

Combined net operating earnings of the First National City Bank of New York and its trust affiliate for the nine months ended on Sept. 30 were $56,015,000, or $4.58 a share. This compared with the $48,923,000, or $4 a share if calculated on the 12,240,000 shares now outstanding, cleared in the 1959 period.
DETROIT, Oct. 4 (AP) -- Cities working on renewal projects with Government aid were told today that "there is no magic in Federal dollars."
The Isbrandtsen Company has no immediate schedule or timetable for exercising its control of American Export Lines, Matthew S. Crinkley, executive vice president, said here yesterday.
BERLIN, Oct. 4 -- Walter Ulbricht offered today new assurances on access to Berlin in seeking Allied recognition of Communist East Germany. The conditions he laid down appeared to be unacceptabe.

An American Negro journalist gives a first-hand report on the storm of racism and revolution that is raging through Africa in "The Reluctant African." The author is Louis E. Lomax a former staff member of The Afro-American and The Chicago American.

Two members of Premier Fidel Castro's 26th of July revolutionary movement and a Cuban who deserted from the United States Air Force were arrested in Miami yesterday by Federal Bureau of Investigation agents as they attempted to flee the country.
Joseph Curran, president of the 40,000-member National Maritime Union, assailed Secretary of Labor James P. Mitchell yesterday, calling him "a phony, a crackpot, a union buster."
CORONADO, Calif., Oct. 4 -- This was a day of firsts in the Henry Cabot Lodge campaign.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Oct. 4 -- Janio Quadros, a political moderate with an outstanding record as a public administrator, took a commanding lead today in the first returns of Brazil's Presidential election.

THE Royal Ballet last night gave the second performance of its newly restudied "Giselle" at the Metropolitan Opera House with Margot Fonteyn in the title role, Michael Somes as Albrecht, Christine Beckley as Myrtha and Leslie Edwards as Hilarion.
A new training workshop for tersons afflicted with cerebral talsy was opened here yesterlay.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 4 -- Belgium assured the United Nations today that she would be glad to get her naval vessels out of Congolese waters, but the ships will have to be towed or carried away.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 4 -- Foreign Minister Evangelos Averoff-Tossizza of Greece urged all powers today to avoid interference in the Congo and "put our trust" In the United Nations operation there.
PITTSBURGH, Oct. 4 -- Pie Traynor said it didn't happen. Ford Frick said it did. Danny Murtaugh said, either way, he couldn't care less and Casey Stengel echoed Murtaugh's expression.
VIENTIANE, Laos, Oct. 4 -- Premier Souvanna Phouma told a mass meeting arranged by Left-Wing groups today that he would begin negotiations with the Communist-led Pathet Lao movement with a week.

A public offering of $60,000,000 of thirty-year 4 1/2 per cent mortgage bonds of the Youngstown Sheet and Tube Company is being made today by an investment banking group headed jointly by Kuhn, Loeb Co. and Smith, Barney Co.

Merely keeping up with the "Joneses" of the National Football League in offensive technique is to guarantee a middle-class finish. But the New York Giants have a loftier goal in mind, so they began tinkering with their T yesterday.

Banks appear to be discovering embezzlements earlier and apprehending a larger percentage of hold-up men. As a result, losses from hold-ups and embezzlements declined in the first six months of this year.
WARSAW, Oct. 4 -- A court specially constituted for the case sentenced three ringleadears in a large-scale industrial black-market ring today to life in prison.

WATERTOWN, Conn., Oct. 4 -- Football enthusiasm is running high at the Taft School because of an unexpected 20-to-12 victory over Kingswood last Saturday and two electrifying runs by the Red and Blue's Haskins Ridens, a 144-pound right halfback.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 4 -- The Asian-African group, which now has forty-four of the ninety-eight votes the General Assembly, decided today to oppose Portugal's candidacy for a seat on the Security Council.
The Concert Artists Guild will benefit from a dinner concert, to be given in honor of Isaac Stern, the violinist, at the Pierre on Oct. 23.

CECIL BEATON, a man who has been appraising human faces for more than forty years, never grows bored or discouraged by new ones. An eminent theatrical designer, painter, writer and England's first photographer of the Royal Court, Mr. Beaton has lost not a degree of his vivid curiosity about beauty.

BERLIN, Oct 4 -- A West Berlin audience got tonight an American writer's view of politics and the struggle for power that it can generate among men seeking the Presidency. With a tiny minority dissenting, the audience loved it.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 -- Officials of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization powers are studying methods for achieving a unified atomic weapons policy within the Alliance.

Chesapeake and Ohio Railway's fight to gain control the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad took a convivial turn yesterday -- and may put it at least one drink ahead of its rival, the New York Central Railroad, which also is trying to persuade stockholders of B. O. to accept an offer.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 4 -- The use of fear in diplomacy, or what we now call political warfare, is familiar throughout history, but rarely has the technique been employed with greater skill than by Mr. Khrushchev.
Demonstrators against President Tito charged here yesterday that his Government had taken reprisals against their relatives in Yugoslavia. They asked the State Department to investigate.
Dr. Howard A. Rusk last night became the first doctor to be honored with the Hundred Year Association's annual Gold Medal award.

The Cast OEDIPUS REX. opera-oratorio in two acts by Igor Stravinsky. Libretto (after Sophocles) by Jean Coctcau. Conductor, Julius Rudel; sets, costumes and staging by Paul Sylbert; chorusmaster, William Jonson.

The suit brought by Secretary of Labor Mitchell to invalidate the election of the president and seventy-four other officers of the National Maritime Union will be a major test of the guarantees of democratic procedures in the Landrum-Griffin Act.
LAGOS, Nigeria, Oct. 4 -- Prime Minister Sir Abubakar Tafawa Balewa left today for New York at the head of a sixteen-man delegation to the United Nations.
"Is that your father?" a little girl on roller skates asked a man who was standing next to the statue of Alfred E. Smith near Catherine Street.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 4 points up to 5 points off yesterday. A point equals 5 cents a bale.

Directors of the Acme Steel Company yesterday reduced the quarterly dividend to 10 cents a share on the common from 30 cents paid in previous quarters. It is payable on Nov. 5 to holders of record of Oct. 17.
The rival Presidential nominees yesterday pledged efforts to promote civil liberties. They made statements to be published in the monthly bulletin of the American Civil Liberties Union.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Oct. 4 -- White South Africans will vote tomorrow on whether their country shall become a republic. Their decision is bound to have an important bearing on future events in Africa south of the Sahara.

OTTAWA, Oct. 4 (Canadian Press) -- The Supreme Court of Canada today reversed a lower court judgment that would have opened the way for Canadian oil companies to collect tax refunds amounting to about $60,000,000.

SCARBOROUGH, England, Oct. 4 -- An unruly Labor party conference approved today a resolution establishing the annual conference rather than the Parliamentary party as "the final authority" for formulating party policy.
CHICAGO, Oct. 4 (AP) -- Heavy purchases for export created demand of wheat futures on the Board of Trade today and most wheat contracts advanced to new highs for the season.
BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 4 -- The state oilfields combine today postponed inviting private foreign companies to develop such of Argentina's oil resources as are not already being exploited.

MOULAY HASSAN, Crown Prince of Morocco, has never accepted his title in a purely decorative sense but rather with the challenging view that a prince's role is to accomplish romantic feats. Since his teens, Prince Hassan has been tilting with dragons of one sort or another, and thus far he has won the upper hand.

A change in plans for the first major benefit for the Children's Rehabilitation Center of Rome on Oct. 14 has been announced. Instead of a theatre party, followed by a supper, the committee is arranging a Festival of Rome, a champagne supper dance, to take place that night at Leone's restaurant.

WEST ORANGE, N.J., Oct. 4 -- Vice President Nixon charged tonight that the Kennedy farm program would raise family food costs 25 per cent, reduce beef and pork supplies to wartime rationed levels and put 2,000,000 Americans out of work.

NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 4 -- The nation's transportation industries are rapidly becoming an undesirable investment risk as a result of the lack of a clear-cut rate-making policy, the National Defense Transportation Association was told today.

Five distinguished musical figures have been named to judge the eleventh annual Musical Talent in Our Schools series, which is sponsored by The New York Times and its radio station, WQXR. They are Artur Rubinstein, Rudolf Serkin, Isaac Stern, Leonard Rose and Abram Chasins.

TORONTO, Oct. 4 (Canadian Press) -- A realty man does not us1/2 his knowledge fairly if he does not tell his customer the conditions under which his home can be sold, J.G. Downs, chairman of the Real Estate Research Corporation of Chicago, said here today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 -- The United States celebrated the third anniversary of the space age by sending a message from President Eisenhower to the United Nations by way of a new communications satellite launched today.

HIGH on the list of pork favorites but low on the budget scale is delicately flavored, sugar cured, smoked pork shoulder butt. It is a boneless portion of the shoulder that weighs from one and one half to four pounds.
TULSA, Okla., Oct. 4 -- Better service to air shippers would give the air freight industry as much new business as would a reduction in rates of 25 per cent, an aviation consultant estimated today.
Further downward price adjustments in new corporate bonds of top investment grade held the attention of the bond market yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 (UPI) -- A Republican spokesman today accused the Democrats of starting a smear campaign against Vice President Nixon as the result of an accusation by Henry M. Jackson, Democratic national chairman.

The threat of division looms before the British Labor party today when its annual conference debates rival views on disarmament and British policy in the nuclear era. The strong leftist forces at the Scarborough meeting are pushing for a policy of unilateral nuclear disarmament, and a complete triumph for their views could mean the departure from the party of leader Hugh Gaitskell and his faction.

HONG KONG, Oct 4 -- Deputy Premier Abdyl Kellezi of Albania, the only European Communist notable who attended Communist China's National Day celebration Oct. 1, said today that Peiping was advancing the "correct principles of Marxism-Leninism."

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 4 -- When Branch Rickey, the empire builder, assumed control of the Pirates almost a decade ago, he grandiosely embarked on a Five-Year Plan, one that was to have the flexibilities and extensions of all such schemes.
LIKE the nation's scientists, crystal designers this year are looking to the sky.
Unless private and public agencies act now, the number and quality of American physicians will decline to a point where the national health is endangered, a medical report warned yesterday.
KINGSPORT, Tenn., Oct. 4 (AP) -- An explosion at the sprawling Tennessee Eastman corporation chemical plant late today killed at least eleven persons and injured more than sixty.
RABAT, Morocco, Oct. 4 -- Eleven deserters from the French Foreign Legion in Algeria were presented here today as conscientious objectors to colonial wars.
The Rambler American has had its first major styling change since its debut ten years ago.

The nation's mail-order industry is undergoing a major change in sales technique. Volume, which has swelled largely on the concept of customers' ordering by mail, is being built up heavily through the use of the telephone.
Of the many excessively difficult problems that this session of the General Assembly is facing, none surpasses in difficulty the problem of Algeria.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Oct. 5 -- An independent candidate, Janio da Silva Quadros, apparently smashed the Government's political machine across the nation to emerge tonight as an almost certain winner of Brazil's Presidential elections.
LONDON, Oct. 5 - Prices of a wide range of industrials advanced on the stock market here today.

TAIPEI, Taiwan, Oct. 5 -- The Kuomintang (Nationalist) party will take disciplinary action against a number of its prominent members who have openly criticized the arrest and courtmartial of Lei Chen, dissident political leader.

CHICAGO, Oct. 5 -- The American Council on Education reported today that the price of higher education was high and was going higher. It said, however, that the increasing cost was far less expensive to the American people than settling for mediocrity would be.

The nation's gasoline stocks rose by 511,000 barrels in the week ended last Friday, according to the American Petroleum Institute. The increase resulted largely from a rise in production which totaled 29,018,000 barrels, compared with 28,575,000 in the preceding week.
NORWALK, Conn., Oct. 5 -- A $4,500,000 expansion program was announced today by Andre Blumenthal, president of Norwalk Hospital.
Plans to borrow $67,500,000 on promissory notes were announced yesterday by the New York World's Fair 1964-1965 Corporation.

Electric power production fell to a two and one-half month low of 13,779,000,000 kilowatt-hours in the week ended last Saturday, the Edison Electric Institute reported yesterday. In the preceding week output was 14,156,000,000 kilowatt-hours, and a year ago, 13,234,000,000 kilowatt-hours.
Nostalgia blossomed on the steps of the Public Library last night, as New York marked its annual "Salute to Fall."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 -- By analyzing Senator Kennedy's proposed farm program in terms of dollar-and-cent costs and unemployment consequences that anyone can comprehend, Vice President Nixon has switched his campaign tactics from the polite abstract to the rough particular.
Sales of United Merchants and Manufacturers, Inc., rose to a record of $468,154,485 and profits climbed by 15 per cent in the fiscal year ended on June 30, J.W. Schwab, chairman, reported yesterday.
A new dimension, suspense, is being introduced into television commercials. It is hope that the viewer will wonder how the commercial will end.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 (AP) -- The United States Court of Appeals ruled today that Terence F. McShane might not serve as chairman of the Board of Monitors or the teamsters union pending further study of the case by the court.

The Amerada Petroleum Corporation increased the quarterly dividend yesterday with the declaration of 65 cents a share or the common stock. It is payable on Oct. 31 to holders of record of Oct. 17. In previous quarters shareholders received 50 cents a share.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Thursday, Oct. 6 -- Opponents of a South African republic held a sizable but uncertain lead early today as the count of votes in yesterday's referendum continued.

MOSCOW, Oct. 5 -- The Soviet press bitterly accused Dag Hammarskjold, United Nations Secretary General, today of showing cowardice and subservience to United States "imperialists" in having refused to resign.

CINCINNATI, Oct. 5 -- The United Mine Workers made it plain today that it would fight any effort by the Federal Government to force changes in its internal structure to conform with the union-democracy provisions of the Landrum-Griffin Act.

Business and governmental leaders of Asian nations demonstrated yesterday that despite the Soviet bloc's trade-aid drive they continued to look primarily to the United States for development assistance.

At least nine representatives of shoe businesses in the Philadelphia area died in Tuesday's Eastern Air Lines crash in Boston Harbor. They were returning home from the annual Advance Spring Shoe Market Exposition of the New England Shoe and Leather Association which had ended in Boston.

WEST HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Oct. 5 -- A plan to improve state support to local school districts was presented today to Speaker Joseph F. Carlino of the State Assembly and legislators from Nassau and Suffolk Counties.
SACRAMENTO, Oct. 5 -- Henry Cabot Lodge said in a speech today that Earl Warren, Chief Justice of the United States, had "pushed the decision" to eliminate public school segregation.
Girl Scout Celebration Day was marked yesterday with a reception in the Plaza Hotel.
Plans and patrons for a dinner in behalf of the World Federation for Mental Health's United States Committee have been announced by Mrs. Henry Ittleson.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 -- A ten-nation conference on technical aid to under-developed nations indicated today that two United Nations aid funds would be enlarged soon.
Jimmy Brown is the leading ground-gainer in the National Football League.

President Kwame Nkrumah of Ghana declared at a rally in Harlem yesterday afternoon that the 20,000,000 Americans of African ancestry constituted the "strongest link between the people of North America and the people of Africa."
PITTSBURGH, Oct. 5 -- The Pirates whooped happily as they raced up the subterranean ramp to their dressing room after defeating the Yankees in today's world series opener.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Oct. 5 -- A lone wolf politician with a reputation as a reformer, a talent for administration and the sure instinct of a crowd pleaser apparently has won the election for the Presidency of Brazil.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 5 -- The Philippines strongly defended the United States today with a recital of the political freedom and economic benefits that the Philippines enjoyed during forty years as an American colony.

"THE TRIAL BEGINS,"* by Abram Tertz, is the surprise novel of the year. You would not think that such a small book could pack so much explosive force. It does so in the most disarming way -- by expressing in a line, a scene, a fragment of conversation, the essential confrontations of public and private lives.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 5 -- There is widespread agreement among diplomats here that if the neutralist states become influential as a bloc in world diplomacy, it will have been largely because of the efforts of President Tito of Yugoslavia.

TULSA, Oct. 5 -- An aircraft manufacturer's representative asserted today that the major restraints on air cargo's development came from the nation's failure to understand and define the "supplementary" roles of commercial and military air logistics.

Showing drive and spirit that are bound to please, the New York Rangers began their National Hockey League season last night by beating the Boston Bruins, 2 -- 1, at Madison Square Garden.

The Citizens Union made public yesterday its ratings of candidates in the six State Senate and sixteen Assembly contests in Manhattan.

ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 5 (AP) -- Alerted Girl, the 4-5 choice, won the Home Bred Handicap today with an assist from the stewards. P. and W. Stable's Anna Dee was first by a nose but was disqualified and placed second for interference.
NEW CITY, N.Y., Oct. 5 -- The favorites advanced as the first round of the Jack Moone memorial Scotch mixed open golf tournament was completed at the Dellwood Country Club today.

WEATHER has a formidable Influence on the cooking, shopping and dining habits of the nation. Women cook more during periods of inclement weather. The greater percentage of them bake desserts and make more casseroles from leftover foods.
Four hundred Liberal party leaders and workers cheered Senator Lyndon B. Johnson yesterday as he gave them an old-fashioned stem-winder of a political speech.

NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 5 -- The policies of organized labor present a serious challenge to the United States merchant marine, Solon B. Turman, president of Lykes Brothers Steamship Company, Inc., said today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 -- Something like an attack of first-night jitters is setting in among the Republicans here as the time approaches for the second nationally televised debate between Vice President Nixon and Senator John F. Kennedy.

Net operating earnings of the Chase Manhattan Bank for the nine months ended on Sept. 30 were $55,205,307, or $4.11 a share. This represented an increase of 20 per cent from the $45,968,516, or $3,42 a share, in the 1959 period.

The Studebaker-Packard Corporation, in a further diversification move, announced yesterday the acquisition of D.W. Onan Sons, Inc., Minneapolis builder of electric generating plants. The price was not disclosed but terms included cash, common stock and a share in future earnings, it was stated.
NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Oct. 5 -- The attempt by some of the 16,000 Negroes here to increase the integration of Negro and white children in the public schools continued today on several fronts.

Premier Khrushchev will appear in a live, unrehearsed interview on David Susskind's "Open End" telecast here Sunday at 9 P.M.
LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Oct. 4 -- The crisis in the Congo has turned into a magnet for a strange collection of foreigners that has come to dominate the tone of the city.

The trustee of the bankrupt Hudson and Manhattan Railroad Company yesterday challenged the fairness of the Port of New York Authority's offer of $20,500,000 for the Hudson Tubes and other company property.

One of the major commodities that the New York City Transit Authority has to sell in its subway system is convenience. Ever since the change in fare above 10 cents made it impractical to use coins in the turnstile slot the public has suffered considerable inconvenience in buying tokens. Sometimes there are long lines of prospective passengers waiting to buy them at subway change booths.

Lee Hyun Yung, a 10-year-old Korean girl who lives in Seoul, has 1,100 adopted brothers and sisters on Manhattan's upper East Side. The members of her American family are students at Public School 80, at 415 East 120th Street.
Business demands for credit strengthened markedly in September, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported in its monthly review published today.
Mrs. Nelson A. Rockefeller made an electioneering tour for the Republican ticket yesterday, shaking hands with people of Czech, Polish and Italian origin and with others on the lower East Side.

THE eating marathon -- more formally known as the Food Editors Conference -- continues its informative but fattening ways all this week. During the course of the hectic four days already past, a number of new products or new ways of using old products have been introduced to food editors from the four corners of the United States.

HAGERSTOWN, Md., Oct. 5 (AP) -- James H. Carmichael, president of the Fairchild Engine and Airplane Corporation for the last two years, has resigned and the company's chairman and founder, Sherman M. Fairchild, has taken over as chief executive officer.

CHICAGO, Oct. 5 -- The resourcefulness of the home-build ing industry in putting available funds to work and cutting their costs to make better housing easier to buy will be the only limiting factor in the housing market of the next decade, the nation's mortgage bankers were told here today.

THE number of new buildings in New York has nothing on the small boutiques. However, these specialty shops are small only in size. Even the larger stores have acknowledged their popularity by making some of their departments into "jewel-like" boutiques.
LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Oct. 5 -- Col. Joseph D. Mobutu has moved to wrest control of Stanleyville, the capital of Oriental Province, from Patrice Lumumba.
Firmness appeared in the market for prime corporate bonds yesterday after two days of declining prices, but United States Government securities drifted lower in light trading.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Oct. 5 (AP) -- The president of the Great Lakes -- St. Lawrence Association urged construction of an all-American canal between Lake Erie and Lake Ontario today as an alternative to improvements in the Welland Canal in Canada.

Bowman Gray, chairman of the R.J. Reynolds Tobacco Company, sold 11,667 shares of the company's common stock last month and made a gift of 323 shares. With the sale and gift, Mr. Gray's holdings total 75,000 shares, according to the latest insiders' report of the Securities and Exchange Commission, issued yesterday by the New York Stock Exchange.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 -- A group of 166 Roman Catholic laymen affirmed its belief today in the separation of church and state and in full religious freedom for all.

Two thousand fireman picketed City Hall for two and a half hours yesterday in a move to win improved working conditions.
BING CROSBY'S first special of the season, an attraction on Channel 7 last night, was a highly tuneful outing of very considerable style and imagination.

LONDON, Oct. 5 -- The North Atlantic Treaty Organization command structure -- tested Exercise Sword Thrust and other recent European-wide exercises -- has been strengthend in the last year but it is still complex and cumbersome.
ALGIERS, Oct. 5 -- A Member of the French Army General Staff in Algeria charged today that Morocco "is apparently trying to create frontier incidents" with the French Army.

A NEW wall light switch plate was announced yesterday by Sylyania Electric Products. This plate produces a soft emerald light when the switch is turned off so that it may be easily found in a darkened room.

A fire in a manhole containing high-tension power cables at Seventy-fourth Street and Second Avenue caused New Yorkers, considerable trouble yesterday.

The State Board of Regents made it clear yesterday that Regents examinations in high schools would be continued.

CHICAGO, Oct. 5 (UPI) -- Parker MacDonald scored with less than eight minutes remaining tonight to give the Detroit Red Wings a 1-1 tie with the Chicago Black Hawks in their opening game of the National Hockey League season.

When the Skye terrier Ch. Evening Star de Luchar won best-in-show at the recent Northwestern Connecticut Dog Club event in Goshen, Conn., her owner was sought for a discussion of European dogs, shows and methods.

Hulan E. Jack, Borough, President of Manhattan for the last seven years, has not served in his office for the last nine months.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 5 -- The United States has agreed to expand and accelerate its program of military aid to Indonesia, authoritative sources said today.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 5 -- The Pittsburgh Pirates brought down the proud Yankees, 6 to 4, in the first game of the world series before 36,676 spectators at Forbes Field today.

Terry Bartolet, a sophomore, will be the first-string quarterback for Harvard this Saturday against Cornell. Bartolet will replace Charlie Ravenel, who was injured last week. Now the question is: Who will replace Bartolet as the No. 2 quarterback?

LAGOS, Nigeria, Oct. 5 -- A sweeping twenty-year plan to train thousands of doctors, engineers and other specialists is under consideration by the Government of newly independent-Nigeria. Six days of voter registration begin here on Monday. From a record of 3,566,377 in the 1944 Presidential election year, the rolls now stand at just 2,558,775.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: So many angry voices have been raised at the present session of the United Nations -- we have even seen the practices of heckling and table-thumping introduced for the first time -- that some wise and constructive speeches made by delegates of the smaller nations have passed almost unnoticed.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 5 -- A carnival atmosphere one never would experience in sophisticated New York prevailed at Forbes Field, and in all of Pittsburgh, today for the opening game of this city's first world series in thirty-three years.

Three inspectors from the Building Department testified in Special Sessions yesterday that they had found numerous violations of the Multiple Dwelling Law in Manhattan tenements allegedly owned by two Brooklyn lawyers.

TADEUSZ KANTOR, the 45-year-old leader of Polish avant-garde art, makes his American debut at the Saidenberg Gallery, 10 East Seventy-seven Street, in an exhibition that opened Tuesday and will continue until Oct. 29. Far from a local celebrity In a first bid for international attention, Mr. Kanton received, a world-wide press last year when a Paris exhibition reinforced the position he had established in Cracow.
LOUISVILLE, Oct. 5 -- A screaming crowd liberally sprinkled with teen-agers welcomed Senator. John F. Kennedy to Kentucky tonight.

The time has come for a 35-year old director, known in London, Paris and New York, to take an extended sabbatical. That decision was reached by Peter Brook.
The nation-wide strike against the General Electric Company passed its fourth day yesterday with no settlement in sight.

Trading in commodity futures was unusually dull yesterday on the New York exchanges. Prices moved in narrow ranges. Potatoes, cottonseed oil, eggs and rubber rose; hides, cocoa and sugar declined, and price movements for copper, wool, soybean oil and coffee were mixed.

Martin Schulman, a slum landlord who operates principally in Greenwich Village, was sentenced yesterday to fifteen days in the Workhouse for longstanding violations of the building and health codes in a tenement at 40 and 42 Macdougal Street.

School officials here expressed keen disappointment yesterday over the City Planning Commission's slashing of the Board of Education's capital budget request for 1961.

Japan was urged yesterday by a Department of Commerce official to move more speedily toward a general lifting of restrictions on United States products. Citing the extensive growth of Japanese exports to this country, Eugene M. Braderman, director of the agency's Far Eastern division, asked that the liberal trade policy that had encouraged this growth be reciprocated.

Daily average borrowings by member banks of the Federal Reserve System declined $25,000,000 to $200,000,000 in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. Daily average reserves in excess of requirements rose $77,000,000 to $597,000,000.

Stocks moved forward briskly yesterday morning in a continuation of Wednesday's late rally but sagged in afternoon trading on the New York Stock Exchange. The earlier gains were pared but not erased and prices closed up on the average.
E.J. Brach Sons Directors of E.J. Brach Sons yesterday proposed a six-for-one split of the common stock, subject to shareholder approval on Nov. 10.

Scientists at the General Electric Research Laboratory in Schenectady said yesterday that they had achieved what were described as "revolutionary breakthroughs" in devices for producing superpower radio-frequency signals.

ONE of the greatest gastronomic delights in Manhattan is the collection of culinary volumes at the Corner Book Shop, 102 Fourth Avenue. It is a sort of Fibber McGee's closet of the food world. The Columbia Gas System, Inc., borrowed $30,000,000 in the bond market yesterday at an interest cost of about 5.14 per cent.

PARIS, Oct. 6 -- The Bank of France lowered its discount rate today to 3.5 per cent from 4 per cent and liberalized consumer credit repayment terms.

The first day of the Festival of Succoth, or the Jewish Feast of Tabernacles, was observed yesterday in synagogues and temples over the city.

Two steamship companies, one American and one Brazilian, have agreed to pool freight revenues on cargoes moving from United States Atlantic ports to Brazilian ports.

Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 2 points off to 9 up yesterday. A point is 5 cents a bale.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Mayor Wagner's television report of progress in the city's effort to control juvenile delinquency is encouraging proof that the troubled youth of our communities will respond when help is offered in solving their problems.
CINCINNATI, Oct. 6 -- Senator John P. Kennedy has added a crowd analyst to his traveling staff to help assess the significance and portent of the throngs he is attracting.

PORTLAND, Ore., Oct. 6 -- Henry Cabot Lodge charged today that Senator John F. Kennedy was "unable" and Senator Lyndon B. Johnson was "unwilling" to lead the Democratic party to action on civil rights in the August session of the eighty-sixth Congress.
A syndicate of builders has purchased the northwest corner of Third Avenue and Thirty-fourth Street for improvement with a luxury apartment house. Henry Baker was the broker in the sale.

Ten men, posing as police detectives and equipped with counterfeit police credentials, extorted amounts ranging from $10 to $10,000 from business men visiting the city, District Attorney Frank S. Hogan said yesterday.

MONTREAL, Oct. 6 (UPI) -- Jacques Plante, wearing the goalie's fiberglass face mask he designed himself, handled nineteen shots flawlessly tonight as the Montreal Canadiens trounced the Toronto Maple Leafs, 5 -- 0.

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Oct. 6 (UPI) -- Col. Joseph D. Mobutu started today whipping his disorganized Congo Army into a well-disciplined fighting force capable of stamping out the tribal wars that have nearly ruined this new nation.

Advance mortgage commitments of commercial banks declined in the year ended last Aug. 15, the American Bankers Association reported yesterday. Delinquencies and foreclosures were slightly above those of a year ago.

SPEAKING before a fabric-minded audience at a Fashion Group luncheon yesterday at the Astor Hotel, Carolyn Schnurer noted that color is influencing our lives move every day. Mrs. Schnurer, fashion and promotion director of Fuller Fabrics, illustrated her point with everything from colored telephones and kitchen utensils to the great vogue for cosmetics and hair tints in off-beat colors.
TRENTON, Oct. 6 -- The State Director of Purchase and Property has authorized the purchase of 21,985 tons of rock salt for $389,000. It will be used on icy highways this winter.

POCANTICO HILLS, N.Y., Oct. 6 -- The formation of the Greenrock Corporation to manage the vast Rockefeller properties here was announced today. It will handle them much the same as John D. Rockefeller Jr. did personally until his death last May 11.

Output of paper and paperboard in the United States is continuing at a steady level and should reach record highs this year, Howard E. Whitaker, president of the American Paper and Pulp Association, said yesterday.

DETROIT, Oct. 6 (AP) -- Ron Murphy, Bobby Hull and Eric NesterenKo took advantage of a ragged Detroit defense with early goals as the Chicago Black Hawks scored a 4 -- 2 victory over the Red Wings. It was the National Hockey League home opener for the Wings before 8,613 persons at Olympia Stadium.

WASHINGTON, Conn., Oct. 6 -- All reports to the contrary, those battle cries ringing through this quiet Litchfield County village on these cool, autumn afternoons are not emanating from Indians back on the warpath.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 6 -- "It never shoulda stopped raining," lamented a Pirate fan as the mourners filed dolorously out of Forbes Field at the end of an afternoon of torment and unassuaged grief. He was eminently correct. Only rain could have saved the beloved Bucs today and even that is open to question.
THE Nassau Championships, an annual tournament of the Nassau-Suffolk Bridge Association, will be played this week-end at the Malibu Beach Club in Long Beach, L.I.

Two youths, one 17 years old and one 18, were sentenced to death yesterday for killing two teen-agers in a West Side playground on Aug. 30, 1959.
Prices of high-grade bonds fluctuated irregularly and within narrow limits yesterday in a trading session little different from Wednesday's.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 -- The International Nickel Company received patents this week for improvements to its successful equipment for prospecting by air. The improvements bring about more positive and accurate signals as to the presence of ore.

Current debates over modern education almost invariably involve the pros and cons of that latest addition to the arsenal of learning: the teaching machine.
