Detroit will play host beginning this week to the national automobile show. It is the first time since the initial show in 1900 that the city has been chosen to be the site of the exhibition.

There are few phenomena in the modern world that are so often misunderstood and misrepresented as private capital investment in underdeveloped countries. The Communists, of course, picture such investment as a means by which the recipient nations are "robbed and enslaved." But even many non-Communists in under-developed countries tend often to look with suspicion or worse upon the private investment from another country.
A British customs officer must cope with smuggling, pilferage and complaints from the general public just like his American counterpart, Britain's top customs official said here yesterday.

BOSTON, Oct. 11 (UPI) -- Alex Delvecchio scored on a power play late in the third period to lift the Detroit Red Wings into a 3-3 tie with the Boston Bruins tonight, leaving both National Hockey League teams without a victory after four games.
MOSCOW, Oct. 10 -- Foreigners with cameras have to worry about more than focus and exposure when taking snapshots in the Soviet Union.

JEAN RENOIR is too old, too skillful and too sophisticated to be wasting his time on rather foolish, inconsequential traveling-salesman type of jokes. And that, it appears, is what he's doing in his new French comedy, "Picnic on the Grass" ("Le Dejeuner sur l'Herbe"), which opened at the Paris yesterday.

Shutters Unlimited, Inc., designer and manufacturer of wooden accessories for homes and business buildings, has leased a floor at 520 West Forty-eighth Street. Gallant-Roth Co., Inc., were the brokers.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 11 -- Though the Yankees trail the Pirates in the world series, Casey Stengel still leads all leagues in double talk. He dangled participles all over Forbes Field today but dropped very little information.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., Oct. 11 -- Among the wealthy residents and prosperous commuters who predominate in the green-blanketed hills and valleys of Somerset and Morris Counties and among the less affluent residents of Middlesex County, a soft-spoken intellectual is seeking re-election to the House of Representatives.
ELIZABETH, N.J., Oct. 11 -- No Congressional race in New Jersey is being waged with more vigor than the contest here in the Sixth District, Union County.

MONTREAL, Oct. 11 (UPI) -- Dickie Moore of the Montreal Canadiens holds a 2-point lead over four players, including last year's scoring champion, Bobby Hull of the Chicago Black Hawks, in the National Hockey League scoring race.
YONKERS, Oct. 11 -- Su Mac Lad led almost all the way in tonight's $64,300 Gotham Trot at Yonkers Raceway and won by three lengths.

Senator John P. Kennedy expressed hope yesterday that Vice President Nixon would join him in a fifth joint television appearance, but the Republics candidate countered with the suggestion that they expand their fourth appearance to two hours.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 11 -- President Tito of Yugoslavia has canceled plans for a visit of several days in Italy. The Yugoslav Government gave no official explanation for the cancellation.

BEHIND the scenes of bridge there are many who do not share the spotlight with the players who win the big tournaments, but who have contributed no less to the success of the game. Prominent among such men is Thomas F. McCarthy, who was declarer in today's hand.
A new comprehensive zoning law for the city, the first since New York's original Zoning Resolution of 1916 was adopted, is slated for approval by the City Planning Commission next Tuesday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture said today that the weather in September was favorable for the maturing of crops and that record farm production appeared to be assured this year on the basis of October conditions.
ELISABETHVILLE, the Congo, Oct. 11 (AP) -- Rebellious Baluba tribesmen pillaged a mission of Franciscan Sisters in Kabalo, northern Katanga, a Katanga Government spokesman said.

GREENWICH, Conn., Oct. 11 -- Seven years ago, the Greenwich Riding Association undertook to develop more active personal interest in equestrian competition among its older members and others in the area to whom horsemanship had become principally a spectator sport.

The deadline for nominations for the 1961 Pulitzer Prize in Letters will be Dec. 1, rather than the February date of past years. The change announced recently was made by Prof. John Hohenberg, secretary of the advisory board.
PARIS, Oct. 11 -- The Defense Committee of the French National Assembly approved today a project for a French atomic striking force modified to maintain close parliamentary control of the program.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 11 -- An urgent recommendation was made here today to the country's surgeons to cut down drastically on the number of small blood transfusions to prevent "needless danger" and sometimes death to patients.

TOKYO, Wednesday, Oct. 12 -- Inejiro Asanuma, Opposition Socialist leader who led the campaign that resulted in the cancellation of President Eisenhower's visit to Japan, was stabbed to death today while speaking at a political rally in downtown Tokyo.

John Cooper of England, who built the cars in which Jack Brabham of Australia won the world road-racing championship in 1959 and 1960, was in New York briefly on Monday. He and Brabham had just returned from Watkins Glen, N.Y., where Jack finished second to Stirling Moss in a 203-mile Formula Libre race.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 11 -- Houston's formal application for a franchise in the National League was seen by baseball men tonight as the opening shot in a struggle between the National and American Leagues for the rights to the Houston territory.
PITTSBURGH, Oct. 11 (UPI) -- New York made a formal application tonight for a National League franchise, it was learned here.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 11 -- There was one time last season when the Pirates were at their miserable worst. They had lost three games in a row. In the third of these defeats they were at their shabbiest. They made only five hits off the San Francisco Giants and compounded their difficulties by contributing seven errors.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Oct. 11 -- The president of the National Association of Home Builders warned today that if the present trend of "making progress backwards" continued, "we will never solve the country's housing needs."
THE corner carved out of Bergdorf Goodman's fourth floor for antiques is sparkling today with English and European trophies won on a recent buying expedition.
BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 11 -- A Government crisis deepened today as differences between the two top army leaders became evident.
Six singers in addition to eleven previously announced will make their Metropolitan Opera debuts during the company's 1960-61 season, which opens Oct. 24.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 (UPI) -- The House Committee on Un-American Activities resumed today its investigation of the defection of two United States code clerks to the Soviet Union.

The price of domestic copper was cut by producers by 3 cents a pound to 30 cents yesterday. The reduction was attributed to an excess of work supply over demand. The industry's analysts have estimated the surplus at 10 per cent.

Although autumn leaves are just beginning to fall and snow is not euen in sight, it is apple blossom time on Seventh Avenue. Beginning Monday and continuing into November, designers of America's garment district are presenting their spring collections to the press and the store buyers. The clothes will be in stores starting in mid-December, Capsule reports follow of collections seen yesterday.

LONDON, Oct. 11 -- While prices of industrials continued without a trend today on the stock market, British Government securities went sharply ahead on strong investment demand. The funds closed with gains of up to 5 shillings (70 cents).
A Queens mother beamed proudly yesterday as her 11-year-old son won an award for his essay on fire prevention. The monther had won a similar award when she was 11.

The Columbia Pictures Corporation cleared $1,905,000 in the fiscal year ended on June 25, in contrast to a loss of $2,445,000 in the preceding fiscal year, the report of A. Schneider, president, disclosed yesterday.

The Monterey Oil Company has agreed to sell substantially all of its business and assets to the Humble Oil and Refining Company, according to a joint announcement yesterday by Morgan J. Davis, president of Humble and Howard C. Pyle, president of Monterey.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 -- Many people ask half-wonderingly why Khrushchev came to the U.N. meeting in the first place, why he stayed so long and just what he hoped to achieve. The answer was really clear before he ever arrived and that clarity has since been sharply etched.

STAUNTON, Va., Oct. 11 -- Prize bulls offered by the head of one of the nation's largest advertising agencies were standout attractions at the pure-bred Aberdeen-Angus cattle auction held here yesterday.

Sun Dog of the Sanford Stud Farms may safely be described as an improving jumping horse. A year ago at Aqueduct he won the Grand National Steeplechase by six lengths. At Belmont Park, yesterday, he won the same event by fifteen lengths.
UNIVERSITY PARK, Pa., Oct. 11 -- "Syracuse can be beaten. I hope we're the ones who do it."

On the eve of a theatre vote on the fate of the 7:30 o'clock curtain time for Wednesday night stage performances, David Merrick, one of Broadway's busiest entrepreneurs, remained firm in his decision to go back to the traditional 8:30 or 8:40 curtain for his current six attractions starting tonight.
ALBANY, Oct. 11 -- The State Board of Law Examiners announced today that 921 persons had passed the July examination for admission to the bar. A total of 1,767 applicants took the test.
Dave Garroway will star in one of his rare specials Friday night, Nov. 18, over the National Broadcasting Company television network.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 (UPI) -- An Agriculture Department official said today that no special treatment had ever been given a grain storage company that lists Edgar Eisenhower, the President's older brother, as one of its directors.
An 81-year-old woman has been "rotting" needlessly in the Civil Jail for more than three years because her lawyers "abandoned" her, Queens County Surrogate Anthony P. Savarese said yesterday.

THE history of the Polaris missile -- its beginning as a dream, its succession of failures and its triumphant emergence from the ocean over Capo Canaveral -- was recorded last night by Edward R. Murrow and Fred W. Friendly in an excellent documentary on "C.B.S. Reports" over Channel 2.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 11 -- James J. Wadsworth United States permanent representative to the United Nations, declared today that Premier Khrushchev had "lost ground since arriving here Sept. 19.
Thomas R. Dash, drama critic of Women's Wear Daily, was elected president of the New York Drama Critics Circle at the group's annual meeting yesterday in the Algonquin Hotel.
An eight-city pilot project bringing together Legal Aid and Family Service facilities was formulated yesterday at the opening of the Thirty-eighth Legal Aid and Defender Conference.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 11 -- Henry Cabot Lodge held one of his patented college question-and-answer shows this morning. Later, after winding up his West Coast tour, he boarded a commercial jet airliner for a swing into New York and the South.

Ten winter programs for the New Yorker Theatre's Monday night film society were announced yesterday by Daniel Talbot and Peter Bogdanovich, sponsors of the series.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 -- The United States has quietly urged West Germany and the Netherlands to keep secret a recently revived technique for producing atomic-weapon materials. This is to prevent more nations from joining the atomic club.

The directors of the International Paper Company proposed a three-for-one split of the common stock yesterday. The board also declared a 2 per cent stock dividend on the common and voted to increase the quarterly cash dividend to 78 3/4 cents a share from 75 cents.

Stocks churned around on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday in apparently aimless trading. At the close of trading, more issues were down than up. but there were enough gains scattered throughout the list to push key averages to a minor rise.

THERE has been a great deal of second thinking by experts about the 1959 vintage of European wines. Hailed at the harvest as "the greatest vintage of the century," the revised estimate seems to be that the wines will be exceptionally good, and that their life span win be about twenty years -- which is relatively short for vintage wines.
ATLANTA, Oct. 11 -- Senate Lyndon B. Johnson criticized Vice President Nixon today in scathing terms as he whistlestopped across the South to the cheers of thousands of Democratic partisans.

Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 5 points up to 7 points off yesterday, with near months steady.

The United States Goverment securities market improved in moderately active trading yesterday, largely in reaction to the favorable reception accorded the Treasury's special offering yesterday of $1,500,000,000 of one-year bills.

EUGENE ORMANDY walked onto the Carnegie Hall stage last night, swung into the ''Star-Spangled Banner" and launched the New York series of the Philadelphia Orchestra.

The Meredith Publishing Company of Des Moines, Iowa, is expected to acquire the Appleton-Century-Crofts, Inc., publishing house here.

THE exhibition, "100 Drawings from the Museum Collection," opening today at the Museum of Modern Art, makes two principal points: the first and greatest is the richness and variety of the museum's possessions in this field, and the second, the inability, because of limitations of space, ever normally to show more than a fraction of these.
LONDON, Oct. 11 (AP) -- Terry Downes, the British middleweight champion, upset Joey Giardello of Philadelphia in a ten-round bout at Wembly Indoor Stadium tonight.

POTTSTOWN, Pa., Oct. 11 -- Although The Hill School's football squad has an important date with Williamson Trade on Saturday and its soccer team meets Pennsylvania's freshmen tomorrow, the big noise in the locker rooms today centered on the national presidential election.

Short covering firmed domestic sugar futures yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange. Prices closed unchanged to up 4 points (hundredths of a cent a pound) on a relatively light turnover of 7,450 tons.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The editorial of Oct. 5 "Reform Law Test" correctly observes that Labor Secretary Mitchell's suit against the National Maritime Union "will be a major test of the guarantees of democratic procedures in the Landrum-Griffin Act."

The St. Regis Paper Company reported yesterday that its net earnings in the nine months ended on Sept. 30 fell to $16,1766,139 from $22,144,275 in the 1959 period. The decline occurred despite a rise in sales to a record $396,839,066 from $368,157,824 a year earlier.

NICE, France, Oct. 11 -- Riviera resorts threatened the French Government today with an administrative strike and street demonstrations if it persisted in a plan to dump 6,500 barrels of radioactive waste in the Mediterranean.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The second Kennedy and Nixon debate confirms the impression left by the first that neither was a debate in the meaning of that grand term. The authors contend that although the Soviet Union and other Iron Curtain countries have been exploiting the Arab world's nationalism there are other foreign elements equally active in Egypt.

The finals of the first Walter W. Naumburg International String Competition, will be in the form of a free public concert to take place Oct. 21 at the Grace Rainey Rogers Auditorium of the Metropolitan Museum of Art.
Ordinarily Radio Station WQXR is a rather staid place with dignified announcers tiptoeing down the corridors an classical music mixing gently with the conditioned air.
SILVASSA, Nagar Aveli, Oct. 12 -- A major step will be taken Saturday toward integration of two former Portuguese enclaves with India.

Directors of the Ford Motor Company yesterday authorized an extra dividend of 30 cents on the common stock in addition to the quarterly dividend of 75 cents a share. The declarations, both of which are payable on Dec. 1 to holders of record of Nov. 1, bring the total for the year to date to $3, or 20 cents more than the 1959 distribution of $2.80 a share.
LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Oct. 12 -- The Congo's military regime threatened sanctions against the United Nations today and repeated its demand that it be permitted to arrest Patrice Lumumba.

RICHARD STRAUSS great opera, "Der Rosenkavalier," missing from the repertory of the New York City Opera Company since 1954, returned there last night in a production newly staged by Ralph Herbert, Julius Rudel conducted.

American Steel Foundries which was direct beneficial owner of more than 10 per cent of the common stock of the General Steel Castings Corporation, has sold its holdings in the company in the public market.
More than $3,000,000 in assets of the estate of Saul H. Bourne, music publisher and former partner of Irving Berlin, will be sold here tomorrow at a public auction.
When a lumbering crane blocks traffic these days at the Manhattan approach to the George Washington Bridge, closed-circuit television is Watching.
MONTGOMERY, Ma., Oct. 12 (UPI) -- Attorney General MacDonald Gallion of Alabama blocked Federal agents today from inspecting voter registration records in Sumter County for the second time.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 12 -- The world economic situation was described here today as one of "uncertainty, if not concern," because the bright prospects of a year ago had not materialized.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 (AP) -- Tthe Southern Railway Company reported today that it was considering a $150,000,000 bond issue to purchase control of two other railroads.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 12 -- Edward Charles (VVhitey) Ford, the pitching hero of today's world series game, has been laughing his way through life ever since he can remember. The lefthander from Lake Success, L.I., subscribes to the axiom that all work and no play can make Whitey a bore.

The Democratic leadership declared yesterday that a majority of eight hundred thousand to one million for the Kennedy-Johnson ticket seemed in the offing in this city. The claim was based on the results of two privately conducted polls.

TOKYO, Thursday, Oct. 13 -- The fatal thrust of an assassin's sword has set the stage for a far-reaching change in Japan's national political campaign. Its results could also threaten the recently concluded Japanese-United States security pact.
BERN, Switzerland, Oct. 12 -- The European Free Trade Association decided today that it would not accelerate its tariff-cutting to keep an exact pace with the European Common Market.
Legal Aid Society offices are not increasing as fast as the national population, according to the annual report of William H. Avery, president of the National Legal Aid. and Defender Association.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 -- (AP) -- The Senate Internal Security subcommittee renewed today its contention that the Communist party has actively infiltrated the United States nuclear test-ban movement.
MIAMI, Oct. 12 -- Senator Lyndon B. Johnson found indications today of a revival of Democratic strength in Florida, the party's major problem state in the South.
A syndicate of investors headed by Sidney Kramer of the Kramer Realty Company has'purchased the twelve-story loft building at 692-94 Broadway, 384-85 Lafayette Street and 2 to 20 East Fourth Street.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., Oct. 12 (AP) -- American Mining Congress officials warned today that the national economy would succumb to labor socialism unless what it called the growth of labor monopoly power was checked by realistic Congressional action.

FAIR LAWN, N.J., Oct. 12 -- Magistrate Arthur Minuskin heard arguments tonight in the case of Mrs. Dorothy Nogard, who was arrested Sept. 7 for having a slot machine in her home at 12 Aberdeen Place here.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 12 -- Frederick H. Boland, President of the General Assembly, adjourned tonight's session to end the "spectacle" created by Soviet-bloc heckling of Western delegates.

Electric power production dipped, for the second consecutive week, in the period ended last Saturday to 13,725,000,000 kilowatt-hours, the Edison Electric Institute reported yesterday. In the preceding week the figure was 13,779,000,000 and a year ago, 13,086,000,000 kilowatt-hours.
While the election outlook is still cloudy, the business outlook has become clearer, at least to the First National Bank of Chicago.
The city celebrated Columbus Day yesterday in weather that the Admiral of the Seas would have relished aboard the salty little Santa Maria.
LONO BEACH, Calif., Oct. 12 -- Vice President Nixon kept his political gunsights trained today on the policies toward Quemoy and Matsu of his Democratic rival, Senator John F. Kennedy.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 -- The Treasury's off-and-on romance with a new cash technique for refinancing maturing debt has cooled again.

CHICAGO, Oct. 12 (UPI) -- Glenn Hall scored his first shut-out of the season tonight to help the Chicago Black Hawks climb to first place in the National Hockey League with a 3-0 victory over the Toronto Maple Leafs. The triumph ran the Hawks' unbeaten string to four games.
HONOLULU, Thursday, Oct. 13 (AP) -- A pilot crashed at sea in his single-engined plane near Wake Island last night in an attempt to fly 7,698 miles nonstop from Oakland, Calif., to Manila.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In his Oct. 7 television debate with Senator Kennedy, Vice President Nixon made this statement: "Whenever we do anything that's wrong we can express regrets. But when the President of the United States is doing something that's right, something that is for the purpose of defending the security of this country against surprise attack, he can never express regrets or apologize to anybody, including Mr. Khrushchev."
WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 (UPI) -- Postmaster General Arthur E. Summerfield put into regular service today a mail sorting machine he expects will hold down the number of Post Office employes.

Senator John F. Kennedy said yesterday that, if elected President, he would call a series of conferences in the White House and elsewhere to open the way for broad compliance with school desegregation and other civil rights laws.

Harold S. Geneen, president of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, challenged both Presidential candidates yesterday on the issue safeguarding foreign investments of American citizens.
The Columbus Day observance yesterday limited bond trading to a lazy session on the New York Stock Exchange, where corporate bond prices closed firm.
Ferdinand Oyono, Cameroon delegate to the United Nations, was taken to the West Thirtyfifth Street police station from the United Nations area yesterday.

AN Englishman had the original idea. Americans dote on them. But when it comes to creating sandwiches, there is nothing like a Dane.

With three shows on the boards "The Music Man," "Toys in the Attic" and "The Wall"), Kermit Bloomgarden is getting ready to do another. The go-ahead signal affects "The Gay Life," Mr. Bloomgarden says a large house, which was not disclosed, is required for the musical, due in late March or early April.

HACKENSACK, N.J., Oct. 12 -- New Jersey's Seventh Congressional District sprawis across all of Hunterdon, Warren and Sussex Counties in the nonthwest part of the state. It also includes thirty-three communities in Bergen County and two in Passaic.
Henry Cabot Lodge, campaigning in East Harlem yesterday, put the Republican ticket on record as favoring the appointment of a Negro to the President's Cabinet.
Syracuse's drooping football champions no longer lead the nation's major college teams in offense but the Orangemen still are tops in defense.

CHICAGO, Oct. 12 -- Inland Steel Company and Allied Structural Steel Company announced today cancellation of the agreement whereby Inland would have purchased Allied through an exchange of stock. Opposition by the Department of Justice was blamed.
PROVIDENCE, Oct. 12 (AP) -- John Alien, a 32-year-old United States Olympic walker from Buffalo, won the national twenty-five-kilometer championship today by almost half a mile.

Because of the importance of purchased frozen foods in modern living, the United States Department of Agriculture has just released an informative booklet on how to select them in the market and how to protect their quality in the home freezer.
NICE, France, Oct. 12 -- The French Riviera's campaign to prevent the Government from dumping atomic waste in the Mediterranean gained an initial victory today.
The possibility that Premier Khrushchev's departure for Moscow may be delayed until Friday emerged last night as a result of the uproarious debate in the United Nations General Assembly.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 (AP) -- Roman. Catholic educators, caught between rising costs and booming enrollments, are looking for ways to cut the traditional twelve-year elementary and secondary school program to ten years.
BOSTON, Oct. 12 -- A device that its makers say enables a physician to look at his patient's intestinal ulcers in his own office without need for surgery was demonstrated here today.
PARAMUS, N.J., Oct. 12 -- Senator Clifford P. Case called on the Administration today to step up its efforts to effect an agreement between Israel and her Arab neighbors.
VIENTIANE, Laos, Oct. 12 -- Secretary of State Christian A. Herter's top expert on Far Eastern affairs arrived today as anxiety grew over the future of American relations with divided Laos.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Senator Kennedy is revealing anything but the maturity needed in the current critical international situation to keep us out of trouble. A certain dismaying impetuosity is revealed by his habit of fast talking and his stated worship of the "fast" -- fast thinking, fast action.
THE vehicle that Peter Lind Hayes and Mary Healy have chosen for their situation comedy series is a sporty model that they, drive in breezy style.

Franklin National Bank of Long Island will not expand into New York City until its suit challenging the legality of the state's new Omnibus Banking Law is settled, Arthur T. Roth, chairman, said yesterday.
Plans for an eighteen-story motor hotel on West Fiftyseventh Street, between Ninth and Tenth Avenues, were announced yesterday.
Voter registration quickened for the second straight day yesterday as 137,352 names were added to the rolls. Registration in the city will end Saturday.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 12 (AP) -- The American League, in line with its plan to increase membership to ten teams, is expected to approve the application of Dallas-Fort Worth and possibly Minneapolis-St. Paul at an expansion meeting next week.

Stocks edged down yesterday on the Now York Stock Exchange on the slowest trading in exactly one year -- since Oct, 12, 1959, also Columbus Day.
The United States economy appears to have "touched bottom" after a mild decline and should begin to rise soon, an economist said here yesterday.

LIMA, Peru, Oct. 12 -- Premier Pedro G. Beltran won a vote of confidence in the Chamber of Deputies today on the politically charged issue of gradual nationalization of the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey's wholly owned affiliate in Peru.

Trustees of teamsters' welfare funds are considering a hospital for members and their families in the metropolitan area. A half million persons would be affected.

The Scott Paper Company realized an increase of 12 per cent in earnings for the first nine months of this year on a sales gain of 6.9 per cent, according to the report of Thomas B. McCabe, president, issuec yesterday.

THE history of a store often reflects the changes in the American scene. The oldest store on Fifth Avenue is Arnold Constable, now commemorating 135 years of business. WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- Laos has joined the list of the United States' most important diplomatic trouble spots.

WHITE PLAINS, Oct. 13 -- Recreation and planning officials in Westchester County today protested the fight by some builders against rules requiring them to contribute land or cash for playgrounds in new subdivisions.

This column's correspondent in Africa reports from Accra that Louis Armstrong and his trumpet arrived in Ghana yesterday to take' up a battle position in Africa's ice-cold war. He was greeded enthusiastically and quickly learned the Ghanaian word for welcome -- akwaaba.
A Board of Education official warned the City Planning Commission yesterday that unless adequate funds were provided for new schools, more families would move to the suburbs.
RALEIGH, N.C., Oct. 13 (AP) -- Former President Harry S. Truman declared today that "the most disgraceful surrender in our history has happened" under the Eisenhower Administration.

MONTREAL, Oct. 13 (UPI) -- Two last-period goals by Bernie (Boom-Boom) Geoffrion and Dickie Moore paced the Montreal Canadiens to a 4-3 victory tonight over the Detroit Red Wings and moved the Stanley Cup champions back into undisputed possession of first place in the National Hockey League.

Measures to control the population of herring gulls because of their hazard to aviation are being studied by the Federal Fish and Wildlife Service, the Massachusetts Audubon Society and the Boston airport authorities, the Audubon group has reported.

PARIS, Oct. 13 (Reuters) -- Theodore M. Bernstein, an assistant managing editor of The New York Times, said today that the newspaper's new international edition, which begins publication here Oct. 20, will be "not simply a Paris newspaper but a Western European newspaper."
PITTSBURGH, Oct. 13 (UPI) -- Sixty-five records were set and twenty-seven tied by the Pittsburgh Pirates and New York Yankees in the 1960 world series.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 (UPI) -- Leaders of America's three largest Jewish organizations demanded today that Vice President Nixon repudiate a statement by his press secretary that the Jewish leaders called "an insult to our faith."
SCARBOROUGH, England, Oct. 13 -- British foreign policy moved today toward a tougher attitude toward the Soviet Union and more emphatic support of economic unity with Europe.

A fifty-year leasehold on Palisade Terrace, a nine-story apartment house at 1450 Palisade Avenue, Fort Lee, N.J., has been sold by the Investors Funding Corporation of New York. The buyer, an investor, acquired the property subject to mortgages of $1,178,000 and will pay rentals aggregating $4,450,000.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- The idea of an embargo on United States exports to Cuba originated with President Eisenhower, Government officials said today.
OLEAN, N.Y., Oct. 13 (AP) -- Governor Rockefeller reorganized a Republican dinner-rally here tonight into a television party.
LOS ANGELES, Oct. 13 -- An obviously angry Vice President Nixon declared today he was "shocked" that Senator John F. Kennedy had brought "notes" to their third joint television appearance.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 (AP) -- Admiral Arthur W. Radford was quoted today as having said that Senator John F. Kennedy's views on Quemoy and Matsu "could certainly start a war if they are believed by the Red Chinese."
MADISON, Wis., Oct. 11 -- The Republican state headquarters here is plastered with posters depicting a jut-jawed Vice President Nixon jabbing a forefinger at Premier Khrushchev's chest.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 (AP) -- The wage and salary income of Americans dropped in September, the Department of Commerce said today, but total personal income rose to a record. The wage lag was offset by increased social security, unemployment and veterans' payments.
CHICAGO, Oct. 13 -- Northwestern University announced today details of a plan to add sixty-five acres to its suburban Evanston campus by filling in part of Lake Michigan.

WORDS that brood and laugh and sing cascaded from the stage of the Cherry. Lane Theatre last night. They were from the pen of that boisterous, rebellious boyo, Sean O'Casey, and you won't hear anything more eloquent in any theatre in town.

WARSAW, Oct. 13 -- Wladyslaw Gomulka, Poland's Communist leader, returned from New York today with assurances that the United States would restore most-favored-nation treatment to Polish commerce within a few weeks.

THE buyers and the press are not the only fashion types rushing from showing to showing and building to building on Seventh Avenue these days. A whole contingent of models, are rushing around with them.

WINSTON-SALEM, N.C., Oct. 13 -- Henry Cabot Lodge's pledge to a Harlem crowd that a new Republican Administration would name a Negro to the Cabinet was modified drastically by Mr. Lodge in the South today.
Negotiations are in progress for the acquisition by the Monsanto Chemical Company of American Viscose Corporation's entire interest in the Chemstrand Corporation.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 13 -- A record $86,300,000 was pledged here today to assist underdeveloped nations. That is nearly $10,000,000 higher than last year's figure.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- The Soviet Union failed in an effort to bring off a spectacular space shot during the three and one-half weeks of Premier Khrushchev's stay in this country, official sources here have concluded.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 13 -- President Eisenhower has expressed willingness to serve as a roving ambassador of goodwill after he leaves the White House a highly placed source said tonight. A top campaign aide for Vice President Nixon said that the President was "passionately devoted" to serving the cause of peace whether in or out of the White House.

GENEVA, Oct. 13 -- The three-power conference on a treaty to ban tests of nuclear weapons inched forward today on secondary matters. The delegates remained unable to agree on the crucial issue of research to improve the detection of underiground explosions.

THERE are not many women who ever feel pampered, but there are many, many thousands who would like to be -- if only for forty-eight hours. On their behalf, a new type of beauty retreat is opening on Oct. 25 in Goshen, N.Y.
One day after her impressive victory in Belmont Park's mile-and-one-half Ladies Handicap, William du Pont Jr.'s 3-year-old filly Berlo was retired from racing yesterday for the remainder of the year.

YONKERS, Oct. 13 -- The favored Adios Oregon, driven by Vernon Crank, scored a one-length victory over Ante Bellum in 2:03 3-5 in the Ridgefield pace before 17,063 fans at Yonkers Raceway tonight. The winner paid $6.70.
BERLIN, Oct. 13 -- Trade talks between East and West Germans opened today on questions resulting from the cancellation by Bonn of the trade pact between the two parts of Germany.

TORONTO, Oct. 13 -- The present lack of confidence in the basic strength of the United States economy is unjustified, Roger M. Blough, chairman of the United States Steel Corporation, said here today.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 13 -- Following is the roll-call vote by which the General Assembly rejected a Soviet motion to discuss what the Russians called aggressive acts by the United States:
Voter registration was high for the fourth consecutive day yesterday as 135,774 names were added to the rolls. This brought the potential vote in next month's election to 3,097,172.

The present situation in Africa is the subject of "Kwamina," a new musical by Richard Adler (score and lyrics) and Robert Alan Aurthur (book), due here in May. It will be directed by Tony Richardson and produced by Alfred de Liagre Jr.

OTTAWA, Oct. 13 (UPI) -- A threatened tie-up of shipping on the St. Lawrence River was averted today when the 300-member Federation of St. Lawrence River Pilots came to an agreement with the Federal Government.

CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Oct. 13 -- Three black mice named Sally, Amy and Moe rode a missile nose cone 700 miles into space today and survived radiation, weightlessness and a dive back through the earth's atmosphere.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 13 -- Ferdinand Oyono, permanent delegate of the Cameroon to the United Nations, maintained today that his detention yesterday by the city police for failing to show his United Nations pass had been caused solely because of his color.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: It is my view of Premier Khrushchev's appearance on the television program "Open End" that he displayed really remarkable forbearance. Mr. Susskind, the interrogator, was fresh and, what seemed worse, although he would doubtless esteem it a virtue, he was insubordinate.

A stockily built man in his thirties who was seen limping away from the Times Square shuttle station just before a bomb went off Wednesday was described last night by the Transit Authority police as a prime suspect.
District Attorney Frank S. Hogan yesterday urged the use of public funds to aid the work of the Legal Aid Society and Defender Association.
IN these difficult times it is reassuring to remember that even international demonstrations can be conducted under completely cordial conditions.
HAVANA, Oct. 13 -- Anthony Zarba, a 28-year-old American, and seven Cubans were executed today. Five other Cubans were executed last night.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 13 -- The Pirates are the champions of the world. They just couldn't lose today. Nothing could stop them, including the Yankees. But the Bombers sure gave it a riffle, tying the score with a rousing two-run rally in the ninth and then getting booby-trapped by Bill Mazeroski's homer just as the world series reached the sudden-death stage.

Granbery, Marache Co. and associates are offering today 200,000 common shares of Radio Shack Corporation at $12.625 each. Of the total, 150,000 shares are being sold by the company to repay $450,000 in short-term bank loans and to raise $200,000 for improvements and equipment.
BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 13 -- Ten of Argentina's top officers resigned today in protest against President Arturo Frondizi's decision to retain Gen. Rodolfo Larcher as Secretary of War.
Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange declined 4 to 10 points yesterday. A point is 5 cents a bale.
Following is the transcript of the Kennedy-Nixon broadcast debate last night, as records by The New York Times:

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 13 -- Premier Khrushchev bade an angry farewell to the General Assembly today after threatening to walk out on any future disarmament negotiations unless they were conducted on Soviet terms.
The Grand Ballroom of the Plaza, where the night music is usually the fast fox trot of the society orchestra, last night echoed with the skirl of bagpipes.
The New York Giants held their last heavy workout yesterday in preparation for their home opener against the Washington Redskins at Yankee Stadium on Sunday.
LONDON, Oct. 13 -- Stock market prices moved downward again here today but most net losses among the industrials were less than a shilling (14 cents).

The use of an electronic computer to control the operations of a 140,000-barrel-a-day crude oil distillation unit at the Whiting, Ind., refinery of the Standard Oil Company (Indiana) was announced yesterday.
HACKENSACK, N.J., Oct. 13 -- The big question in New Jersey's Ninth Congressional District is how will its 30,000 new registrants vote?
Premier Khrushchev took leave of the United States last night after a stormy twenty-five-day visit to attend the fifteenth session of the United Nations General Assembly.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- Freight loadings for the rail and truck industries last week were about 1959 levels.

Shakespeare wrote, "You blocks, you stones, you worse than senseless things" (Julius Caesar, Act I, Scene I), and linemen usually have been just so many spear carriers on the Ivy League football stage.

WEST ORANGE, N.J., Oct. 13 -- V'es Ellis of Mountain Ridge shot a five-under-par 33, 34 -- 67 at the Essex County Country Club today and headed the pros in a state Professional Golf Association pro-amateur tournament for the seventh time this year.

The motions of the earth's crust over a long period will be studied by Columbia University's Lamont Geological Observatory with new equipment being installed in a mine of the New Jersey Zinc Company at Ogdensburg, N.J.
BOSTON, Oct. 13 -- An air Force-sponsored effort is being made to develop a beam of light so intense that it can be used as a superior form of radar.
WESTBURY, L.I., Oct. 13 -- Crowds of spectators line up here every day to stare in awe and to dream awhile before a case holding $1,000,000 in cold, enticing cash.
Terry Bartolet, Harvard's sophomore quarterback, will be at the helm of the Crimson eleven when it faces Columbia's Lions in Baker Field tomorrow.
The nation-wide General Electric strike dragged through its twelfth day yesterday without hint of progress toward settlement.
"THE TASTE OF COURAGE: The War, 1939-1945,"* edited by Desmond Flower and James Reeves, is one of the finest anthologies ever compiled. It is also one of the largest -- 1,120 large pages.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 (UPI) -- Attorney General William P. Rogers announced today that the Government had successfully concluded its efforts to recover some $37,000,000 in "windfall profits" on post-war housing projects.
PITTSBURGH, Oct. 13 -- By pushing and straining, it was possible at first to catch a few jubilant phrases by Pirate players over the din that prevailed in the Pittsburgh dressing room today.

PIRATES' FIRST -- Turley's first pitch to Virdon was high and inside for a ball. Virdon flied to Berra in left center. Kubek backed into short left for Groat's high pop. Skinner walked on a full count. Nelson hit a home run into the lower right-field stand, a drive of about 360 feet, scoring Skinner ahead of him and sending the Pirates into a 2 -- 0 lead.
Senator John F. Kennedy and Vice President Nixon bitterly accused each other before a national television audience last night of advocating policies on Quemoy and Matsu that would lead to war.
MAMARONECK, N.Y., Oct. 13 -- As par remained elusive, three players tied for the lead in the opening round of the Metropolitan Professional Golfers Association championship today.

Traditionally designs for the coming boating season have been unveiled at New York's boat show in January. Now the National Association of Engine and Boat Manufacturers, which conducts the New York event, has a serious rival that has already surpassed New York by holding a bigger "national" show in Chicago each year.
LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Oct. 13 -- Col. Joseph D. Mobutu denied today that his military regime intended to make ''war on the United Nations."
Inventories of refined petroleum products rose last week despite cutbacks in crude oil production and refinery operations.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- A three-member division of the Interstate Commerce Commission voted today not to interfere with increased rates on transcontinental freight by motor carriers and freight forwarders.
LONDON, Oct. 13 -- The split in the Labor party widened today with the resignation of Anthony Greenwood from its parliamentary Shadow Cabinet.
SALISBURY, Southern Rhodesia, Oct. 13 -- Three battalions of troops were summoned to duty today as a precaution against more African rioting in Southern Rhodesia.
Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy plans a study on employing blind persons in nonenforcement jobs to put more members of the force on the street.

COSTA MESA, Cailf., Oct. 13 (AP) -- Marty Furgol of Coghill, Ill., Tom Nieporte of Bronxville, N.Y., and Jim Steinbaugh of Yorba Linda, Calif., shared the first-round lead today in the $20,000 Orange County open golf tournament.
Production of steel fell back in September after a slight rise in August from July's level, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

AUTUMN is a carnival of color in New England. Foliage turns to gold and flame. Vines of yellow and scarlet bittersweet sprawl over old stone walls. Orange pumpkins are piled high around roadside stands.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 13 -- Laos endorsed today a proposal that the United Nations set up and guarantee a buffer zone in Southeast Asia between the major powers of the "cold war."
MONTGOMERY, Ala., Oct. 13 -- Senator Lyndon B. Johnson bore down on the religious issue at stops today in north Florida and Alabama.

Sidney Weiderlight, realty investor, has bought the County Line Shopping Center at South Main Street and Carman's Road in South Farmingdale, L.I. The seller was the T.C.H. Realty Corporation. Mr. Weiderlight was represented by Jesse H. Barkin, New York lawyer, in the purchase, which was made through James Fox Associates and Karl A. Weber, brokers.
William M. Barrett, a lawyer and poet, had an unpoetical moment here yesterday.
Broadway will retain the 7:30 Wednesday night curtain despite criticism by local restaurateurs and a defection by David Merrick, who controls six current shows.

ON Wednesday night, Michel Block went through the ordeal of playing Brahms' Mammoth B-flat Piano Concerto in Carnegie Hall in the finals of the Leventritt International Piano Contest. Last night the Belgian-born pianist, still in his early twenties, played a long and taxing recital in Grace Rainey Rogers Auditorium, to open the fifth season of the distinguished Young Artists Series there.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- It now appears likely that the controversy involving Dr. Linus C. Pauling will not end in a contempt case against him.

Huckleberry Finn would never have believed it. A 13-year-old runaway boy arrived in town yesterday from Jefferson City, Mo., after having taken a taxi to his bank and withdrawn $200 of the $700 in his savings account for traveling and hotel expenses.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- Attorney General William P. Rogers asserted today that the United States "has made its greatest strides forward in the field of civil rights" during the last eight years.

Smith-Corona Marchant, Inc., office equipment producer, has a new president and chief executive officer. He is the 43-year-old Emerson E. Mead, who had been executive vice president. Mr. Mead, who was elected at a board meeting in Syracuse yesterday, succeeds Elwyn L. Smith, who has retired from active management to become chairman of the executive committee.
PITTSBURGH, Oct. 13 -- Did the better ball club win the world series?

EVERYTHING is in pumpkin pie order, now that the economy-sized fruit is making its annual appearance on the local scene. Pumpkins at reasonable prices (8 to 10 cents a pound) are now gracing the city's fruit counters, as well as bedecking roadside stands in the surrounding country.
United States Treasury bills were strong and active yesterday as the rest of the bond market meandered through a quiet trading session.
ON Tuesday evening the Equity Library Theatre opened its seventeenth season with its 376th production, Thornton Wilder's "The Skin of Our Teeth."

Pan American World Airways, which operates extensively over international routes but is limited to serving the peripheral "gateway" cities of the United States, has been making agreements with truck operators for freight service into the United States.

As coach of the College All-Stars, Lou Rossini has more talent on hand than many of his basketball brethren command in a lifetime. But, true to his calling, he is worried about tonight's Milk Fund game against the New York Knickerbockers at the Garden.

Within the next year or so aluminum probably will score an important breakthrough in the residential housing field. The light metal will adorn dozens of handsome new apartment buildings which soon will supplant slum dwellings in six cities across the country.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 13 -- It wasn't that they weren't talking, because Casey Stengel and Bob Turley are on the best of terms. Nor was it that Casey was afraid he would not be understood. But the manager did not tell the pitcher that he was to start today's world series finale for the Yankees.

Following is a tabulation by Assembly Districts of new registrations in New York City since Monday. The coasting registration under permanent personal registration is given for each district, and the total. A comparison with 1956, the last Presidential election year, is omitted, because permanent registration did not go into effect until 1957.
IN lieu of a crystal ball, manufacturers of sterling silver are giving the public a glimpse into the future by sponsoring design competitions and showing the results in museums.

A major revision of trans-Atlantic air cargo rates has been proposed by three United States airlines at the current air traffic conference at Cannes, France, of the International Air Transport Association.

NEWARK, Oct. 13 -- After many years as a political John Alden, Alphonse A. Miele is campaigning in his own behalf. He is the Republican candidate for the House seat in the Tenth Congressional District, now occupied by Peter W. Rodino Jr.

Mrs. Hattie Gibson Hallowell, who was jailed nearly three and one-half years ago at the age of 80 in a dispute over an inheritance, may win her freedom at a hearing Monday in Queens County Surrogate's Court.
ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 13 -- One of this country's top-ranking Protestant leaders called upon his constituents today to approve the formation of a new 3,000,000-member Lutheran Church body.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 13 -- The declaration on colonies placed before the General Assembly by Premier Khrushchev sets out three brief policy points. They are:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 (UPI) -- Representative George H. Mahon, chairman of the House Defense Appropriations subcommittee, said today it would take "a huge and unprecedented" military build-up to defend Quemoy and Matsu in the absence of a Chinese Communist attack on Formosa.
Eugene O'Neill's "The Iceman Cometh," which was taped for television last August, may be shown in motion-picture theatres before it goes on television, according to National Telefilm Associates.

AMERICAN art, both contemporary and from earlier years, has no more redoubtable champion than Mrs. Edith Gregor Halpert, head of the Downtown Gallery, 32 East Fifty-first Street, which this week celebrates its thirty-fifth birthday.

Sales of the Dow Chemical Company for the quarter ended on Aug. 31 rose to $202,099,704 from the $191,681,368 volume of the 1959 period. Earnings, however, declined from those of last year, the report disclosed yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- Department store sales in the nation in the week ended Oct. 8, were 2 per cent above the level of a year earlier.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 13 -- Daniel Edward Murtaugh has a jutting jaw, a hawk nose, deep-set hazel eyes that flash fiereely from under shaggy brows and just about the mildest manner of any manager who ever led a baseball team to the world championship.

HIGHSTOWN, N.J., Oct. 13 -- Target No. 1 for Peddie School's football squad is Lawrenceville. The Gold and Blue meets the Lawrentians, who are unbeaten in sixteen games, on Saturday. Even the world series has taken a back seat here.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 13 -- Although the Pirates have appeared in only five world series, they hold the distinction, along with the Boston Red Sox, of having played in the first inter-league competition between the established National circuit and the newly arrived American in 1903.

The finance ministers of the free world are showing greater interest in the political outlook in the United States and the future of the American economy than in this country's balance of payments, according to James S. Rockefeller, chairman of the First National City Bank of New York.

CAIRO, Oct. 13 (AP) -- Egyptian archaeologists reported today the discovery of what they said was the longest rock-hewn tomb ever found in Egypt. They said they believe it contains the royal treasures of Pharoah Seti I.
A fully automatic passenger train that will be put into service on the shuttle line between the Times Square and Grand Central subway stations was demonstrated yesterday by the Transit Authority.
PITTSBURGH, Oct. 13 -- The series-winning home run Bill Mazeroski hit against the Yankees today completed the erasure of the only blot on the record of this fine young player.
Items collected from the area between Jamaica, B.W.I., and Vermont will be among the wares at the Christmas sale and exhibition arranged for the benefit of the Turtle Bay Music School.

PARIS, Oct. 13 -- Premier Michel Debre sought to persuade the National Assembly today that the creation of an independent French nuclear force would in no way diminish France's fidelity to a strong Western alliance.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 13 -- The Pirates today brought Pittsburgh its first world series baseball championship in thirty-five years when Bill Mazeroski slammed a ninth-inning home run high over the left-field wall of historic Forbes Field.

WHILE the Pirates and Yankees were batting in home runs yesterday afternoon, General Motors also was making its play to the grandstand. The issue: Whether the annual model changes in Frigidaire appliances are deterring progress toward eliminating service problems for consumers.

VERY few exhibitions can claim to cover a period of 10,000 years. But such, in fact, is the historical range of "The Arts of Denmark -- Viking to Modern," which opens today at the Metropolitan Museum and will be on view there until Jan. 8.

TORONTO, Oct. 14 (AP) -- Moss Hart, the playwright, suffered a heart attack in his hotel room today in the midst of revisions of the Broadway-bound Lerner-Loewe musical, "Camelot." He was taken to Wellesley Hospital, where his condition was described as satisfactory.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 -- -- The average of wholesale primary market prices edged lower by 0.1 per cent during the week ended last Tuesday to 119.4 per cent of the 1947-49 base, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today.

Denny Moyer, ranked fourth among welterweight contenders by the National Boxing Association, is a 2-1 favorite to defeat unranked Jorge Fernandez in their ten-round televised main event tonight in Madison Square Garden.
SAGINAW, Mich., Oct. 14 -- The Kennedy campaign temporarily left the airlanes and the electronic trial chambers of television today for a brief excursion through nostalgia.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Oct. 14 -- Mrs. Charles Leichner of Pine Hollow and Mrs. Patricia Tiernan Johnstone of Wheatley Hills took the low gross award today on a draw with 38, 40 -- 78. They won the final tournament of the season, a Pinehurst foursome, of the Women's Cross County Golf Association at the Hempstead Golf Club.

Consumers may not have made up their minds yet about the new automobile models, but the finance companies have. The companies, which under-write a large part of the 64 per cent of cars purchased on credit, are convinced that a buying surge soon will be felt.
A $3,450,000 auction ended three years of discord in Tin Pan Alley yesterday.

The thirtieth annual Monmouth County, N.J., racing-meet will be held next Saturday at Woodland Farm, the Red Bank estate of Mr. and Mrs. Amory L. Haskell. The proceeds will go to the various county charities.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 -- A Long Island company is prepared to supply a blast and fallout shelter equipped to house and feed nine persons for two weeks.

Bard College at Annandaleon-Hudson, N.Y., which started a century ago as a preparatory institution for the ministry and gradually became one of the nation's most progressive schools, will seek to recapture some of its stress on religion.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 -- President Eisenhower observed his seventieth birthday today, becoming the first President to do so while in office. But in a day crowded with memories he acknowledged that his thoughts were still of the future.
The third annual American Film Festival, the largest national convention of non-theatrical motion picture makers and representatives, will open next April 19 at the Barbizon-Plaza Hotel.
BEVERLY HILLS, Calif., Oct. -- Following is the text of a speech prepared for delivery tonight by Vice President Nixon :

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 14 -- The $2,000,000 Loeb Drama Center of Harvard University was dedicated here this evening at a ceremony attended by prominent alumni and faculty members of Harvard and Radcliffe.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 -- Republican party officials asserteted today that Senator John F. Kennedy wag "caught cribbing" in his television debate last night with Vice President Nixon.

HAVANA, Oct. 14 -- The Government nationalized Cuban banks and all the big industrial, commercial and transportation companies of the island today, including twenty enterprises owned by United States interests.

SCARBOROUGH, England, Oct. 14 -- Maurice Macmillan, son of the Prime Minister, appealed today at the Conservative party's conference for effort, sacrifice and a realistic approach to Britain's continuing economic problems.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 14 -- Yale and Cornell, both undefeated in Ivy League football, clash in the Yale Bowl tomorrow at 2 P.M.

CHEROKEE, N.C., Oct. 14 -- The Cherokee Indians are on the warpath again and a full-scale uprising has broken out here in the picturesque foothills of the Great Smoky Mountains. The Cherokee Nation's attack is aimed at their traditional seasonal employment in arts and crafts.
Music, some from the past and some from the present, is in the air for two future television specials.
Some of the leading companies in the domestic bowling industry intend to roll up higher sales by expanding their operations overseas.
WHITE PLAINS, Oct. 14 -- A custom-designed clubhouse for senior citizens of all social and economic strata will be dedicated here Sunday. It will be put in full use by the end of the month.
The world shipbuilding industry appears to be headed for a severe depression, an authoritative British shipping study reports.

Life on Park Avenue near the Soviet Union's United Nations mission, while hardly stark, was a little crabbed during Premier Khrushchev's twenty-five-day visit, according to the people who went through it.
LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Oct. 14 -- member of the military regime's governing commission was attacked and injured tonight by a mob of Lumumba follower.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 -- Two American tourists, held incommunicado for seven weeks by Soviet authorities, have been released and expelled from the Soviet Union, the State Department said today.

Cotton futures moved 4 points (20 cents a bale) up to 25 points ($1.25) off yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange. The distant months showed the biggest losses, while the gains were limited to the three nearby positions.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 -- With the departure of Mr. Khrushchev U.N. can at last resume its normal functions. One of these function might well be to consider how a world parliament should protect itself against deliberate disruption.

WEST KILL, N,Y., Oct. 14 -- It turned out today that Art Flick was at least half right in what he said about the hunting around here: the grouse and woodcock are wild and scary. There are not enough clinical data at hand yet to prove whether he was right in saying that there are more grouse and more woodcock than last year.

The bizarre performance of Premier Khrushchev before the United Nations has alerted the free world to new moves of Soviet power politics. This reaction is evident even among the "neutralists," but is most pronounced in Europe, where we face a new crisis over Berlin and Germany.

BEVERLY HILLS, Calif., Oct. 14 -- Vice President Nixon proposed tonight a series of four regional meetings of leaders of "free nations" to map a global offensive against Communist threats, bluster and bullying tactics.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 14 -- The United States Britain and Italy submitted today a draft resolution calling for the early resumption of negotiations on general and complete disarmament.

UTICA, N.Y., Oct. 14 -- Esteem for the past and confidence in the present are symbolized in this small industrial city by the opening today of two buildings to house the Munson-Williams-Proctor Institute, one of the country's most vigorous cultural centers outside the metropolitan area.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- Industrial production has fallen ther sharply in the latest two months, a report by the Federal Reserve Board indicated today.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y, Oct. 14 -- Premier Khrushchev's departure last night has eased ths strain under which delegates to the General Assembly have been laboring for the last three weeks.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 -- The Explorer VII satellite is braying away in space longer than planned because of an alarm clock that did not go off.

The Tough Club will celebrate its ninety-fifth anniversary tonight, Five generations of business men, politicians and actors have found Sanctuary from their wives and other ennobling influences in its plain, hearty atmosphere.
The market for new capital will shift into high gear next week after a halting pace this week. Fixed-interest obligations amounting to about $250,000,000 are tentatively scheduled for market.

The richest race of the New York thoroughbred season, the Champagne Stakes, will be contested at Belmont Park today. For 2-year-olds at a distance of a mile, the race will be worth a gross of $183,900 with nine starters.

IT is a long way from a street corner in the Third Ward of Houston, Tex., to Carnegie Hall. But the distance was narrowed last night by Sam (Lightning) Hopkins, one of the great singers of country blues.
BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 14 -- The army forced President Arturo Frondizi to change his War Secretary today as part of its drive to exercise political control of the Administration.

Chet Huntley, a news commentator for the National Broadcasting Company, discussed yesterday his reasons for raising the issue of the Chinese offshore islands of Quemoy and Matsu. He did so in a television interview with Senator John F. Kennedy Oct. 1.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I am amazed at hearing the two Presidential candidates say that they stand for the continuation of the separation of church and state.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TlMES: The concept of neutrality and neutralism in your editorial of Oct. 8 seems to me confused.
RIVERSIDE, Calif., Oct. 14 (AP) -- Stirling Moss of England escaped with minor burns today when his car caught fire during a tune-up run for a 200-mile Grand Prix for sports cars.

Dr. Teresa Casuso, a close friend of Premier Fidel Castro and a highly placed member of Cuba's permanent mission to the United Nations, declared here yesterday that she was defecting to the United States.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES : We have just experienced a verbal deluge -- part of the Great Debate between freedom and dictatorship. Might I suggest we have helped the adversary -- the dictators -- by not realizing that words are important -- particularly since so many of the nations of our planet have less than 20 per cent literacy.

The merger plans of Capital Airlines and United Air Lines were approved overwhelmingly yesterday by shareholders of both companies at special meetings held in Washington for Capital and in Chicago for United.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 14 -- Like the host after a big party, the United Nations settled back to a normal routine today, totted up the bills and assessed the wear-and-tear of the last three weeks.

WHITESBURG, Ga., Oct. 14 (UPI) -- A Negro man and woman were taken from their home in this village a week ago, stripped and flogged by a group of six heavily armed white men, Carroll County authorities reported today.
Mayor Wagner asked National League baseball club owners yesterday for an "early indication" that they would include New York City in the league's proposed expansion to ten clubs.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 (UPI) -- Senator Olin D. Johnston, chairman of the Senate Civil Service Committee, charged Vice President Nixon today with a "shocking misuse" of Government employes for political gain.
Laymen will preach and pray in thousands of Protestant pulpits across the country tomorrow in the annual observance of Laymen's Sunday.

UTICA, N.Y., Oct. 14 (AP) -- Governor Rockefeller said tonight that he had "no position at all" on whether the United States should fight to defend the islands of Quemoy and Matsu or negotiate a withdrawal from them.
ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 14 -- The United Lutheran Church in America overwhelmingly approved a merger proposal today that would establish a new 3,000,000-member Protestant denomination.

The movement toward further cartelization of international trade appears to be gaining momentum these days. The formation of an oil cartel composed of five of the leading petroleum export nations -- four in the Middle East plus Venezuela -- seems to be near completion. Twenty-eight countries controlling some 90 per cent of the world's exportable coffee have signed the International Coffee Agreement this year.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 14 (AP) -- The American Football League filed a $10,080,000 antitrust suit in United States District Court today against the National Football League and its thirteen professional teams.
INDIANAPOLIS, Oct. 14 (AP) -- District Army Engineers approved a deepwater port at Burns Ditch today.

CHICAGO, Oct. 14 (AP) -- Armour Co. announced plans today for a $60,000,000 expansion program that would make its meat business investment secondary to its chemical interests for the first time in its history.
The city had another bomb scare yesterday while the police were still searching for the man who set off a bomb that injured thirty-three persons in the Times Square shuttle station on Wednesday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 -- The United States Chamber of Commerce called on employers today to furnish post-retirement health insurance care for all employes to ward off "a compulsory system financed by higher Social Security taxes."

The Concert Artists Guild presented a joint recital by Michael Rogers, pianist, and Carol Wilder, soprano, in Town Hall yesterday afternoon. It was the first of a series that the Guild will sponsor this season. The Guild will choose two performers from among those participating in the series and award them solo recitals during the 1960-61 season.

United States Treasury bills held the stage in the bond market again yesterday as spirited bidding for end-of-the-year maturities pushed yields down 4 to 12 basis points. The rest of the Government list declined in light trading.
Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt explained yesterday why she had done what many people thought a "dreadful thing": Invite Premier Khrushchev to tea.
A split appeared to be widening yesterday in the ranks of striking International Union of Electrical Workers.
Stock prices showed a gain on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday despite a steady erosion in late trading. Volume was moderate.
An art show, auction and buffet supper have been arranged for Oct. 31 at the Pierre for the support of the Opportunity Shop, a project of the Community Service Society of New York.
VIENTIANE, Laos, Oct. 14 -- Prince Souvanna Phouma indicated today that United States attempts to solve the crisis in Laos had failed.
SHORT of a real baby, the next best thing for a little boy or girl elamoring after a brother or sister is the surprisingly realistic doll that recently had Fifth Avenue strollers agog.

High-energy hydrogen atoms trapped in a paraffin-lined quartz bulb have been used by three Harvard University physicists to make a clock that they hope will be 100,000 times more accurate than the best atomic clock now running.

DEARBORN, Mich., Oct. 14 -- The Thunderbird has been radically redesigned for 1961. While it still is a four-passenger vehicle it has taken on a jaunty continental flair that sets it apart from others of the sports type family cars.
Francisco (The Hook) Molina, the object of a nation-wide search after the fatal shooting of a 9-year-old girl here last month, was found yesterday morning, hiding out in a Queens apartment.
Today is the last day for voters to register for the 1960 Presidential election. The city's neighborhood polling places will be open from 7 A.M. to 10:30 P.M.

New York City's policemen are about to return to their normal work chart after the extraordinary trial they have been through, lasting nearly a month, for the protection of important visitors to the United Nations General Assembly. Their performance under the strong leadership of Commissioner Kennedy has won universal acclaim, including two warm, letters of congratulation from President Eisenhower.

TOKYO, Saturday, Oct. 15 -- Thousands of unionists marched through the official area of Tokyo today to mourn the assassination of Inejiro Asanuma, the Socialist party leader, and to demand the resignation of the Government of Premier Hayato Ikeda.

Borough President John T. Clancy of Queens urged the City Planning Commission yesterday to increase its proposed' 961 capital budget allocations for school construction, despite the city's restricted borrowing power within its debt limit.

LONDON, Oct. 14 -- The stock market bookkeeping account ended on a dull note today with industrial share prices continuing to sag. Selling orders increased following the publication of disappointing September trade figures and the survey by the Federation of British Industries indicating that there was less optimism regarding the economic outlook.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 -- President Eisenhower told the representatives of fifteen new African nations and Cyprus today that the Soviet Union would fail in its effort to communize the world and control it from Moscow.
A labor union organizing office workers of steamship lines here plans to intensify its efforts following successful voting in two companies in recent days.
WHAT W.S. Gilbert called "the fascination frantic for a ruin that's romantic" seldom overwhelms Aubrey Menen. Yet he explores it enthusiastically in his new book, "Rome for Ourselves."
King Frederik IX and Queen Ingrid of Denmark were welcomed to New York yesterday with a red-and-white ticker-tape parade up Broadway from Bowling Green to City Hall.

Following is a tabulation by Assembly Districts of new registrations in New York City since Monday. The existing registration under permanent personal registration is given for each district, and the total.
