ELISABETHVILLE, Katanga, Oct. 16 -- Col. Joseph D. Mobutu, the Congolese Army strongman, and President Moise Tshombe of secessionist Katanga Province held a surprise meeting today. They reached what was called an agreement of mutual friendship and respect.

HARTFORD, Oct. 16 -- Vice President Nixon announced today that Henry Cabot Lodge would make a major foreign policy speech Thursday. He said that one of the items to be covered in detail would be strengthening of the United Nations.
MIAMI; Oct. 16 (UPI) -- William O. Fuller, the father of one of the Americans executed by a Cuban firing squad, wept today and made his own declaration of war on the regime of Premier Fidel Castro.

The Rev. Dr. Daniel A. Poling, the Protestant editor who touched off much of the criticism of Senator John F. Kennedy on religious grounds, says in an editorial to appear this week that the election should not be decided on the religious issue.
MOSCOW, Oct. 16 -- The Soviet Union's commercial airline Aeroflot, was severely criticized in the press today for serious shortcomings and indifference toward its passengers.
The Rev. Dr. Donald S. Harrington delivered a sermon yesterday on Tolstoy in observance of the fiftieth anniversary of the author's death.

CHICAGO, Oct. 16 -- The indications today were that New York and Houston would be granted National League baseball franchises tomorrow. The prospective clubs, which would be Nos, 9 and 10 in the league, would field their teams in 1962.

Most cotton prices in the domestic market lost ground last week. At the close of trading Friday, active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange were, up 2 to down 36 points from the close of week previous.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 -- Leading Democratic figures contended today that Vice President Nixon had retreated from the- stand he had taken ten days ago on Quemoy and Matsu.
HARRISBURG, Pa., Oct. 16 (AP) -- Capt. W.A. Ringrose took opening-night honors in international jumping competition at the Pennsylvania National Horse Show tonight.
A life "underground" for most Americans Is forecast In a special report issued yesterday if the arms race between the United States and the Soviet Union continues for many more years.
The day was warm, the ice was cold and 2,000 persons turned out yesterday to skim over the surface of the Wollman Memorial Skating Rink in Central Park.
Governor Rockefeller's Administration was appraised yesterday by a predecessor, Herbert H. Lehman, as "undistinguished."

Senator Kenneth B. Keating said yesterday ha was "reasonably confident" that the Federal Government would pay New York's policemen for the extra time they worked during the recent United Nations emergency.

"THE Germans imposed the Nazi tyranny upon themselves," says William. L. Shirer in his "The Rise and Fall of the Third Reich: A History of Nazi Germany."* They Imposed it upon themselves peacefully and legally, prostrating themselves before "the Austrian corporal" according to the political procedures of a dying republic most of them had despised and sabotaged.
THE Athenian tenants in "The House on Stournara Street" are a harmless, human and basically sentimental lot, and so is the Greek-made comedy that arrived Saturday at the Cameo.

A new move is under way to decentralize the city's vast school system. It seeks to bring the schools closer to the public and to improve operations within the system, which is composed of nearly 1,000,000 pupils, about 50,000 employes and 800 school buildings and costs more than $500,000,000 a year.

In Town Hall Saturday night, Julian Bream proved once more that a man with a lute or guitar under his arm can make the orchestra, the opera, and all other massed musical aggregates seem excessive. His instruments spoke softly, but they spoke purely and directly, and one was almost surprisingly satisfied by what they had to say.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 16 -- The best that can be said about the steel business is that although it is still in a trough it shows no signs of sinking deeper. In the last week there has been enough improvement in order volume to raise hopes a trifle.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 (UPI) -- President Eisenhower gave another strong endorsement to Vice President Nixon today. He also appealed to Republican organizations, from precinct captains to state chairmen to help elect Mr. Nixon to the White House.

The Eastman Kodak Company achieved record sales and earnings in its three-quarter period ended on Sept. 4, according to the results announced over the week-end by Thomas J. Hargrave, chairman and William S. Vaughn, president.

The inexhaustible riches of Bach's music explain both the infinitude of programs devoted exclusively to this composer and the large number of devotees such events attract. It was no surprise therefore, that a near-capacity, highly appreciative audience gathered in Grace Rainey Rogers Auditorium Saturday night to hear the first of this season's programs in the Bach series there.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 -- Africa is the new frontier for diplomats who are young, healthy and have a sense of humor.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 16 (AP) -- Bobby Layne and Tom Tracy, with the help of an alert defensive unit, guided the Pittsburgh Steelers to a 27-14 triumph over the St. Louis Cardinals today in a National Football League game.

Theodore Bikel rarely strays far from his role as an actor. Even when presenting a program of international folk songs, as he did yesterday afternoon and evening at Town Hall, it is acting that is foremost.

HARTFORD, Conn., Oct. 16 -- Mr. Lodge told reporters here today that his Senate vote on aid to parochial schools had been misinterpreted, and that he had not advocated Federal aid for parochial school construction on last Sunday's "Face the Nation" broadcast.

The key Government economic indicators for September, 1960, released last week, make sobering reading. Industrial production last month declined to the lowest point of the year, falling back to the lowest level since last year's steel strike. Retail sales fell appreciably. Wage and salary incomes declined, but personal incomes reached a new high, primarily because Government transfer payments such as unemployment insurance, veterans' benefits, and Social Security payments rose.
ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 16 -- A group of Lutheran pastors were the guests of Orthodox rabbis at a post-Succoth reception here today.
Direct obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public that will mature within twelve months amount to $80,450,674,546. They consist of Treasury securities as follows:
HAVANA, Oct. 16 -- Two Americans were executed by a Cuban firing squad today after a military court had found them guilty of having participated in an invasion of Cuba.

ALBANY, Oct. 16 (AP) -- King Frederik IX and Queen Ingrid of Denmark paid a whirlwind visit to the capital of New York State today and rode in the same 1932 touring car that they had ridden in twenty-one years ago as Crown Prince and Princess.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 -- The logic of Soviet dynamism would seem to indicate we can expect a new crisis In the near future and that It will develop In Iran. The reasons for this assumption may be summarized accordingly.
YESTERDAY (Oct. 16, 1960) There were no meetings scheduled at headquarters.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 16 -- The eastward trek of movie producers from Hollywood will be augmented this week when two producers, both in their early thirties, will set up shop near Times Square to make a couple of movies in New York.
LONDON, Oct. 16 -- A series of depressing factors forced the stock market down last week, with the loss of most of the gains of the preceding week.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 -- To the surprise and delight of their scientific creators, weather satellites are showing promise in an unexpected role -- as an ice patrol.
The Rev. Dr. Hampton Adams, discussed the elements of permanence and change in individuals and in the church yesterday as his church ended a week-long observance of its 150th anniversary.

Lights Are Burning Late Fall adult education programs are under way across the land and the lights burn bright and late in high schools and in not a few college classrooms where business men and housewives eager to supplement their knowledge, people in pursuit of hobbies or people who are just seeking something to do, gather one or more nights a week for a term or two of concentrated study.
The nation's mutual funds did a Jot of growing up last week.
Officers of the United Federation of Teachers predicted last night that the union members would vote to strike against the city's schools on Nov. 7.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: For the second consecutive year Nihita Khrushchev has made a major proposal to the United Nations General Assembly. Last year he proposed "general and complete" disarmament of all nations. This year, since he indicates that such a goal would only be achieved with creation of an "international army" under the U.N., the U.N. would need to be revised to discharge satisfactorily its new responsibilities.

DALLAS, Oct. 16 (AP) -- Bobby Mitchell ran a kick-off 90 yards for a touchdown and raced 30 and 46 yards for two more today as the Cleveland Browns posted the highest score of the season in the National Football League.

Archibald MacLeish, recipient of three Pulitzer Prizes -- two for poetry and one for drama ("J.B.") -- is writing a new play, based on an aspect of Hercules. Professor MacLeish declined to reveal yesteday which of the legendary hero's feats would be touched upon.

HOUSTON, Oct. 16 (UPI) -- The Houston Oilers, sparked by an alert secondary that intercepted five Dallas passes, rode George Blanda's passing and kicking to a 20-10 victory over the Texans in an American Football League game before 19,026 fans today.

BERLIN, Oct. 16 -- Communist East Germany warned today that it would interfere with Berlin's lifelines to the West unless the Bonn Government agreed to renew the trade pact between East and West Germany.
CAIRO, Oct. 6 -- If Egypt has a surplus of anything it is the by-products of the date palm tree.
Four Egyptian sculptures that were smashed during their 2,500-year history have been reassembled for the duration of an exhibition opening tomorrow at the Brooklyn Museum.

HARTFORD, Oct. 16 -- Vice President Nixon and his running mate, Henry Cabot Lodge failed in a forty-five-minute private conference today to eliminate entirely their policy difference over appointment of a Negro to the Cabinet.

ANY woman who has ever had a baby is familiar with the case of the vanishing waistline. To cope with this on a practical level, Marti Huber has designed a series of attractive "Calico Coverups" to replace waist-cinching aprons.

THE Yiddish theatre, which came to New York seventy-eight years ago, opened a new season with little fanfare on East Broadway Saturday night. The occasion was a spirited, humorous comedy, "In-Laws," written by Chune Gottesfeld, a Yiddish journalist who has looked at the conflicts that have characterized immigrant Jewish life and has summed them up move as sarcastic dialogue rather than as an integrated bit of stagecraft.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 -- Voters who are not wholly convinced by analyses of Senators' voting records by labor groups and others showing Democrats at the "good" end of the list and Republicans at the "bad" end, can taek heart.

TUNIS, Oct. 16 -- Senator John F. Kennedy said in a letter published here today that he fell the Algerian question was "properly a matter of international concern, particularly when negotiations are not proceeding in good faith."
Fog and thunderstorms converged on the metropolitan area yesterday, causing flash floods n the suburbs and the crash of a sight-seeing boat.

VIENTIANE, Laos, Oct. 16 -- Pro-Communist elements have stepped up their pressure on the neutralist Government of Premier Souvanna Phouma in an effort to exploit tensions between Laos and the United States.
The International Union of Electrical Workers said here yesterday that many of its locals had expressed determination to continue the strike against General Electric Company.

BUFFALO, Oct. 16 -- Al Dorow, an impressive performer all day, scored with two minutes left to give the New York Titans of the American Football League a 17-13 decision over the Buffalo Bills today. A disappointing crowd of 14,998 fans at War Memorial Stadium saw the Bills suffer their sixth home defeat including two exhibition-game losses.

Apparently still stunned by the defeat they suffered in Montreal Saturday night, the New York Rangers toppled again last night. They dropped a 7-2 decision to the Toronto Maple Leafs at Madison Square Garden.
THE HAGUE. EXCEPT for the teen-agers who seem to run in packs whatever their nationality, Dutch women demand individuality in fashion.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Oct. 16 -- Narragansett Bay defeated Western Long Island Sound, 130 1/2 to 125 1/4, today as the three-race team match between Herreshoff S Class skippers from the two areas ended off the Larchmont Yacht Club.
DACCA, Pakistan, Oct. 16 -- A cyclone followed by a tidal wave is believed to have killed 3,000 people in East Pakistan last Monday, officials said today.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 16 (AP) -- Norm Van Brocklin's passes accounted for two touchdowns and set up a third today as the Philadelphia Eagles toppled the Detroit Lions, 28 -- 10, in a National Football League game before 38,065 at Franklin Field.
Roman Catholic Church membership increased at a greater rate last year than Protestant Church membership, according to statistics released yesterday by the National Council of Churches.

The educational programs of the English-Speaking Union will benefit from a preview of a collection of paintings, water-colors and pastels by James Whistler at the Knoedler Art Galleries, 14 East Fifty-seventh Street, on the evening of Nov. 1.

Four young teachers who Volunteered to begin their careers in one of the most difficult schools in the city are part of a new project to provide teachers where they are most needed and hardest to get.
THE figure of a tall man with a lumbering gait, twinkling eyes and mumbling voice looms large behind the "Arts of Denmark" show, which opened Saturday at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The American voter has been asked to believe In effect that the Catholic keeps his political life and his moral and religious life rigidly separated, confining each, as it were, on an island, with an unnavigable body of water in between.

John J. Cassese, president of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association, declared yesterday that 60 to 70 per cent of the city's police force of 24,000 were holding outside jobs in violation of department regulations.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 16 -- India presented a fifteen-power resolution to the United Nations today calling for greater efforts to end world tensions.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 12 -- When King Hussein of Jordan voiced confidence at a recent New York press conference that "it would not be long" before his country became economically self-sufficient, his explanations focused on rising industrialization there Statistics of the last few years lend credence to his views.
